filedesc.extent: XML file derived from 1 SGML (ISO 8879) encoded file approx. 1500KB; 232 JPEG (ISO/IEC 10918) files ranging in size from 83KB to 2900KB
filedesc.publicationstmt: Chapel Hill: Eaves, Essick, Viscomi; UNC LibrariesSeptember 2014
filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of a fully searchable electronic edition of Blake’s 116 water color illustrations to Thomas Gray’s poems. The Archive first published these designs in April 2005 in our Preview mode. This republication substantially increases the number and range of Blake’s pictorial motifs available for searching on the Archive.
The designs for Gray’s poems are among Blake’s major achievements as an illustrator. They were commissioned in 1797 by Blake’s friend, the sculptor John Flaxman, as a gift for his wife Ann, to whom Blake addressed the poem that ends the series. The commission may have been inspired by the Flaxmans’ seeing Blake’s water color designs to Edward Young’s Night Thoughts, begun in 1795. The Gray illustrations follow the same basic format. Blake cut windows in large sheets of paper and mounted in these windows the texts of Gray’s poems from a 1790 letterpress edition. Blake then drew and colored his designs surrounding the printed texts. Although listed by William Michael Rossetti in his catalogue of Blake’s drawings and paintings, published in the 1863 and 1880 editions of Alexander Gilchrist’s Life of William Blake, the Gray illustrations were virtually unknown until their rediscovery by Herbert Grierson in 1919. They are now among the Blake treasures at the Yale Center for British Art in New Haven, Connecticut.
Blake’s illustrations respond to Gray’s poems in a variety of ways, but always with respect for the specifics in the text. Many motifs are visualizations of Gray’s metaphoric images. The Gray illustrations share iconographic and stylistic similarities with the Night Thoughts designs; both series are indebted to the pictorial imagery Blake developed in his illuminated books of the early- and mid-1790s. For the more comic passages in Gray’s poems, Blake deployed a broad, almost caricature-like style. Many of the designs emphasize the imagination at work in the world through inspired acts of reading, writing, and performing music.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

objdescid.origination: William Blakeinventor, delineator, colorist, author. Blake is the author of the poem, Object 116. He also wrote the pen and ink titles or captions for the designs at or near the beginning of each poem; see Objects 2, 8, 14, 22, 36, 42, 52, 66, 78, 86, 94, 102, and 106. Many of these titles or captions are quotations from Thomas Gray's letterpress text.

objinfo.medium: The designs are pen an ink and water color over pencil. The inscriptions are in pen and ink. The small crosses Blake used to indicate the line or passage illustrated are in pencil.
objinfo.note: Blake has cut windows in large sheets of Whatman paper and mounted in these windows the letterpress texts from *Poems by Mr. Gray*, an octavo edition published in London by John Murray, 1790. Blake has not included the following sections from this edition: "Advertisement," pages [i]-vii; "Contents," page [ix]; "A Short Account of the Life and Writings of Mr. Gray," pages [xi]-xxxii; "The Tears of Genius. An Ode. To the Memory of Mr. Gray. (By J. T-)," pages [xxxiii]-xxxix; a fly-title to the "Poems," page [xli]; a fly-title to the "Notes," page [159]; the "Notes," pages [161]-78; and the 7 engraved illustrations.
objinfo.support: wove paperThis is the same paper Blake used for his water-color illustrations to Edward Young's *Night Thoughts*, begun in 1795, and may be stock remaining from that project. The inserted letterpress texts are printed on laid paper.
objinfo.pennednumbers: Blake inscribed a number, top left or top right, on most of the designs, beginning a new sequence of numbers for each poem. See the Textual Transcription of each design for these numbers.
objinfo.framelines: Blake (or possibly John Flaxman) has drawn framing lines in red ink around the edges of the inset text panels. Object 1 has 6 framing lines; all other objects have 1 framing line.
objinfo.binding: looseformerly bound, perhaps by John Flaxman shortly after Blake executed the designs, in a single half-calf volume, with a pencil drawing of Blake by Flaxman inserted as a frontispiece.

provenance.name: Yale Center for British Art
provenance.note: commissioned by Blake's friend the sculptor John Flaxman, possibly for £10.10s., as a present for his wife, Ann (usually called Nancy, nee Denman); by inheritance to John Flaxman on the death of his wife in 1820; sold from John Flaxman's estate, Christie's, 1 July 1828, lot 85 (£8.8s. to "Clarke" [probably the dealer George Clarke of Mount Street, London] on behalf of William Beckford [1760-1844]); by gift or bequest to Beckford's younger daughter Susan, who in 1810 had married the Marquis of Douglas, afterwards the 10th Duke of Hamilton; by descent to Sir Douglas Douglas-Hamilton, 14th Duke of Hamilton; sold 1966 through Sotheby's by private treaty to Paul Mellon; given 1992 to the Yale Center for British Art.

desc.objtitle: Ode on the Spring; Page 1: General Title Page, Object 1 (Butlin 335.1)

objnote.p: Butlin 335.1 attributes the three lines in pencil ("Drawings / by / William Blake") to John Flaxman. Blake (or possibly John Flaxman) has drawn six framing lines in red ink around the margin of the inset letterpress text. There are red-ink lines drawn above and below each line of letterpress text and the two printed ruled lines.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A flying swan with a nude male riding its back fills up most of the design. The man is probably a personification of "The Pindaric Genius" (see Blake's text, Object 2). The swan flies to the upper right corner, with its neck extended and its mouth open. It extends its left wing diagonally up and to the left, and holds its right wing, slightly folded, down to the right. Reins extend from its open mouth. Genius sits on the back of the swan. Seen from behind, he faces away with both outstretched arms raised. He turns his head to the left and bends it back, so that the left side of his face is visible in profile. He raises his left arm at 135 degrees and holds the bottom of a lyre in this open left hand, with his fingers extended. He holds his right arm in a vertical position and grasps reins extending from the swan's mouth with his right hand. His bent right leg is drawn up to the right, while his left leg, slightly bent, extends along the swan's back. He has short, curly hair. Both soles of his feet are visible. The text box obscures Genius' left thigh and part of his left arm near the elbow; it also hides part of the swan's left wing. Blue wash surrounding the swan indicates sky.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude male rides a flying swan. The man is probably a personification of "The Pindaric Genius" (see Blake's text, Object 2). Seen from behind, he faces away with both outstretched arms raised. He turns his head to the left and bends it back, so that the left side of his face is visible in profile. He raises his left arm at 135 degrees and holds the bottom of a lyre in this open hand, with his fingers extended. He holds his right arm in a vertical position and grasps reins extending from the swan's mouth with his right hand. His bent right leg is drawn up to the right, while his left leg, slightly bent, extends to the left along the swan's back. He has short, curly hair. Both soles of his feet are visible. The text box obscures his left thigh and part of his left arm, near the elbow.

A flying swan fills up much of the design. It flies towards the upper right corner, with its neck extended and its mouth open. It extends its right wing diagonally up and to the left, and holds its right wing, slightly folded, down to the right. Reins extend from its open mouth. The text box obscures part of its left wing.
Blue wash surrounding the swan indicates sky.

desc.objtitle: Ode on the Spring; Page 2: Blank Page Bearing List of Titles, Object 2 (Butlin 335.2)

objnote.p: Several of the lines of Blake's text in ink have been written over, or just above, the same or similar lines in pencil. See the Textual Transcription.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The poet Thomas Gray sits in the lower left corner of the design, facing right. His bent right leg is crossed over his left, which is bent and drawn back so that his left foot rests on tiptoe beneath his seat. He hunches over with his bent right arm lying along his lap and paper resting on his knee. He holds a quill pen loosely in his right hand, two fingers lying along its shaft. Its nib is on the paper; he may be writing. His head is bent and he looks down at his paper. His hair is short but curly and wild, and he wears a robe or gown loosely swathed over his limbs. Both of his feet are bare with carefully delineated toenails. A curved shape behind his back represents the leg and backrest of his chair. An orb near the upper right corner of the design seems to represent the moon. It emits a wide beam of light, partly obscured by the text box, that falls over the poet. Dark wash on either side of the beam and behind the poet's chair suggests the night sky. A curved border, possibly the outline of a dome, separates the poet, the moon, and the sky from the upper left corner and top of the design.

component.illusobjdesc: The poet Gray sits in the lower left corner of the design, facing right. His bent right leg is crossed over his left, which is bent and drawn back so that his left foot rests on tiptoe beneath his seat. He hunches over with his bent right arm lying along his lap and paper resting on his knee. He holds a quill pen loosely in his right hand, two fingers lying along its shaft. Its nib is on the paper; he may be writing. His head is bent and he looks down at his paper. His hair is short but curly and wild, and he wears a robe or gown loosely swathed over his limbs. Both of his feet are bare with carefully delineated toenails.
A curved shape behind the poet's back represents the leg and backrest of his chair.

An orb near the upper right corner of the design seems to represent the moon. It emits a wide beam of light, partly obscured by the text box, that falls over the poet. Dark wash on either side of the beam and behind the poet's chair suggests the night sky. A curved border, possibly the outline of a dome, separates the poet, the moon, and the sky from the upper left corner and top of the design

lg.l: Ode on the Spring
Design.
1The Pindaric Genius recovering his Lyre
2Gray writing his Poems
3 The Purple Year awaking from the Roots of
Nature. & The Hours suckling their.
Flowery Infants
4 "With me the Muse shall sit & thinkLines 9-10 are quoted, with minor variations, from page 44 of the letterpress text (Object 4).
At ease reclin'd in rustic state"
5. "Brush'd by the hand of rough MischanceLines 11-14 are quoted from page 45 of the letterpress text (Object 5).

FBrushd by the hand ofThis line, written in pencil, is a first version of the ink line immediately above. The line in pencil seems to begin with the letter "F," followed by some indecipherable words, followed in turn by the words transcribed here. The initial "F" and the indecipherable words may be quoted from the previous line in the letterpress text on page 45 (Object 5), "Fortune's varying colours drest."
Or chilld by Age"
Rough mischanceor Chilld by AgeThis line, written in pencil, is a first version of the ink line immediately above.
6Summer Flies reproaching the Poet
Summer flies reproachg th PoetThis line, written in pencil, is a first version of the ink line immediately above.
Around the Springs of Gray my wild root weaves
Traveller repose & Dream among my leaves.
-Will. Blake

desc.objtitle: Ode on the Spring; Page 3: Beginning of Poem, Object 3 (Butlin 335.3)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 7 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Curly vines with sparse leaves and loops appear throughout the design. Zephyrs and figures representing the hours and "the long-expected blossoms" cavort throughout. The personified form of "the purple year" appears in the lower right corner of the design (see the letterpress text here and Blake's text, Object 2). His legs are bent and drawn under his body, feet balancing on tiptoe. His lower body faces up, while his torso twists away from the viewer. He turns his head up, bent back slightly, as if he is looking at the Zephyrs above. His bent right arm is drawn back and braced to the right, with the palm of his right hand resting flat on the roots below him. His left hand is visible beneath his torso, also resting flat on the roots. He is nude, with thick, short, curly hair. His mouth is open slightly. The roots supporting his hands and toes represent "the Roots of Nature" (see Blake's text, Object 2), while the bright circle around his head like a halo is the sun in the distance. Two Zephyrs appear on the right side of the design, above the head of "the purple year." They fly or hover upside down with bodies nearly vertical. Both extend their straight left arms vertically past their heads and hold their right arms extended straight down by their sides. Eight "rosy-bosom'd hours" fly or hover around the text panel, cavorting with babes representing the "long-expected flowers," which they have "disclose[d]" according to the letterpress text, or carrying items related to celebration. In the upper left corner, an Hour sits facing right within a loop of vegetation, nursing a babe at her visible right breast. Just below this Hour, another hovers or flies facing forward, her legs spread and extended to the left. She carries a lyre beneath her left arm. An Hour balancing a tray on her head hovers or flies facing forward at the left, below the Hour with a lyre. She holds both arms out horizontally, with forearms bent upward, and grasps the sides of the tray with both hands. A fourth Hour hovers facing forward below the Hour with the tray; she is holding a babe who nurses at her breast. This babe is emerging from a cluster of green sepals that would surround a flower, attached to a nearby vine. Below this nursing Hour is another who hovers or flies facing away, arms extended. This Hour's upper body bends sharply back and to the left, twisting slightly so that her left shoulder blade appears closer to the viewer than her right. A babe kneels on a large leaf just above this Hour's right arm, bending forward towards the Hour. This babe, who seems to be female, holds her arms out vertically to either side. Four long petals, suggesting both a flower and flying garments, extend up and to the right from beneath the babe's lower body. Another Hour hovers or flies just below the text panel. Her body is horizontal, but she bends backward and turns to the left, so that her upper body faces forward. She holds her arms out horizontally. The vine that loops behind her and up to the right displays two blossoms with multiple petals from which babes emerge: one above her feet, and the other above her left hand. Both babes are visible from the waist up. The babe on the left bends backward and to the right, extending her arms above her head to reach toward the Hour's right hand. The babe on the right, of indeterminate gender, descends from the blossom facing down but bending backwards toward the Hour on the left, and extends one arm. Just to the right of the text panel, an Hour stands on tiptoe and stretches up to hold a babe overhead. Facing right, this Hour bends backward slightly and extends both arms vertically overhead. She holds the babe at its waist, and its rather limp upper and lower body hang from her hands, which are mostly hidden. One tendril of vine spirals around the figure of the Hour, wraps once around her upraised left arm, and spirals into air behind her. Near the lower left corner of the design hovers an Hour seen from above, facing down towards the bottom of the design, so that the top of its head and nose are visible. It reaches both arms down towards a babe below, which it holds or touches with one hand on either of the babe's shoulders. The babe below is resting in or emerging from between two green sepals, as if it were a blossom. These sepals belong to a plant that is rooted in the ground near the lower left corner of the design. The swaddled babe lies reclined with its head furthest away from the viewer. Three Hours stand or kneel facing left, in a row on the ground near the bottom left corner of the design. The Hour furthest right kneels resting on knee and tiptoe. She hunches over, bending sharply forward so that a babe on her lap can nurse from her visible left breast. The Hour in the middle stands but bends forward sharply. Her left leg is bent and drawn forward, while the shape of her gown suggests that her right leg is extended behind her. She extends both arms together, reaching down toward a blossom near her left foot. The Hour furthest left kneels, bending forward. She holds her slightly bent left arm down, reaching forward towards a babe nearer the lower left corner of the design. This babe hovers between two leaves of a plant rooted below the nearest Hour's knee. Alternatively, this babe may be resting on the rightmost leaf. Curly vines appear throughout the design. One, rooted beneath the legs of "the purple year," grows to the right near the bottom of the design, forming five loops of descending size as it nears the right side of the design. Another seems to be rooted near the bottom left corner of the design, growing up and looping to the right. It has two blossoms from which babes emerge. A third vine appears at the right side of the design, above the head of "the purple year." It grows left and splits into two tendrils: one tendril grows up and spirals around the figure of the Hour at the right side of the text panel, while the other grows down and to the left before looping back to the right. This latter tendril also carries the two blossoms from which babes emerge on either side of the Hour below the text panel. A fourth vine appears at the top left corner of the text panel, forming a loop above and to the right in which an Hour sits, nursing a babe. From there this vine grows rightward across the top and then down the right side of the design, creating six loops. A six-pointed star is poised just below a vine near the top of the design, just above the text box. This is "Fair Venus" (see the letterpress text). A miniscule bird, described in the text as an "Attic warbler," perches on the vine just above the star. Its head is bent back and its beak is open as if it is singing. Its tail extends down to touch the star. Blue wash surrounding the objects on the design suggests the sky.

component.illusobjdesc: The personified form of "the purple year" (see the letterpress text here and Blake's text, Object 2) appears in the lower right corner of the design. His legs are bent and drawn under his body, feet balancing on tiptoe. His lower body faces up, while his torso twists away from the viewer. He turns his head up, bent back slightly, as if he is looking at the Zephyrs above. His bent right arm is drawn back and braced to the right, with the palm of his right hand resting flat on the roots beneath him. His left hand is visible beneath his torso, palm flat on the roots and index finger extending to the right. He is nude, with thick, short, curly hair. His mouth is open slightly. The roots supporting his hands and toes represent "the Roots of Nature," while the bright circle around his head like a halo is the sun in the distance.
A bright circle near the lower right corner, surrounding the head of the personified form of "the purple year," represents the sun.

The intertwined roots extending two-thirds of the way across the bottom of the design, into the lower right corner, represent "the Roots of Nature" (see Blake's text, Object 2). They support the personified form of "the purple year."

Two Zephyrs appear on the right side of the design, above the head of the personification of "the purple year." They fly or hover upside down with bodies nearly vertical. Both extend their straight left arms vertically past their heads and hold their right arms extended straight down by their sides. Each Zephyr holds the right index finger on both of her hands extended as if pointing. The Zephyr on the right bends backwards and bends her head back to look down towards the bottom of the design. Her legs are extended straight behind her. Her long hair flies loose behind her head. She is nude from the waist up, with visible breasts; a semi-transparent skirt with a belt or hem at the waist covers her lower body, billowing around her legs and revealing her right foot, pointed as if on tiptoe. The leftmost Zephyr's visible right leg is slightly bent behind her. She wears a semi-transparent gown that floats around this leg, parting to show her right calf and foot. Like the other Zephyr, her foot is also pointed as if it is on tiptoe. Her gown is belted or gathered at the waist. Her head is bent back slightly, and a cap or hood partially covers her hair

Eight "rosy-bosom'd hours" fly or hover around the text panel, cavorting with babes representing the "long-expected flowers," which they have "disclose[d]" according to the letterpress text, or carrying items related to celebration. In the upper left corner, an Hour sits facing right within a loop of vine, her legs extended along its tendril to the right. Her left leg is crossed over her right at the ankle. She nurses a babe at her visible right breast. Her bent right arm is down, resting along her lap, and she loosely supports the babe's body with her right hand. She hunches forward over it and bends her head to look downward. Her hair is short or swept up, and she wears a skirt or gown that begins at her waist, below her breast, and extends to below her knees, falling to rest in folds on the same vine where it curves rightward below. The babe (of indeterminate gender) hovers or lies horizontally facing left, its mouth at the Hour's breast and its left arm extended horizontally. The babe's lower body twists forward so that both legs are visible, extended right together. It is nude and has curly hair. A small section of the Hour's left forearm may be visible just below the babe's torso.

Just below the Hour nursing a babe in the upper left corner, another Hour hovers or flies facing forward, her body twisted slightly to the right. Her legs are spread, with the right leg slightly bent and extended to the left, and the left leg extended down toward the lower left corner. Her right arm is at her side, bent so that her forearm extends across her torso. A lyre is tucked beneath her left arm; the fingers of her left hand rest on the right side of the lyre. Her head is turned slightly to the left. She is wearing a semi-transparent skirt or gown that begins at her waist, below her visible breasts, and billows in folds around her legs. Her upper body is nude. Both feet are partially visible below her hem and may be pointed as if she were on tiptoe. She has curly hair that is pulled back. A few tendrils fly above her left shoulder.

An Hour balancing a tray on her head hovers or flies at the left of the text panel, near the middle of the left side of the design. Her lower body faces right, but she twists at the waist to face slightly forward, and turns her head to look forward and slightly left. She is bending backward slightly. She holds both arms out horizontally, with forearms bent upward, and grasps the sides of the tray with both hands. Nude from the waist up, with visible breasts, she wears a skirt or gown that begins at the waist and extends to float below the level of her feet. She may be wearing a belt. One foot appears, probably the right, clad in a slipper with the toes pointing down. Her curly hair is drawn back and tendrils of it are visible above her left shoulder. The large tray balanced on her head is circled by intertwined loops.

An Hour flies or hovers at the left side of the design, just below the Hour balancing a tray on her head. This Hour nurses one of the babes representing the "long-expected flowers." Her vertical upper body faces forward, with both breasts visible, and she bends her head and looks down and to the left toward the babe at her right breast. Her eyes are down. Her lower body extends down and to the left, her right leg forward slightly, and her left leg hidden below the lower thigh. Her right arm is at her side, bent so that her forearm crosses her torso. With this arm she cradles the babe. Her left arm, at her side, is likewise bent so that her forearm crosses her torso. Her left hand supports her right breast. Her long hair is loose, and tendrils of it fly on both sides of her upper body. This Hour is nude, though the vegetation from which her babe springs covers her genitals. The babe emerges from within a cluster of green outer sepals that would surround a flower, facing right. The babe bends up and sharply back, its head facing up and away to nurse. Both arms are extended upward nearly vertically, embracing either side of the Hour's breast. Its visible right leg is bent. It is nude, though of indeterminate gender, and has short curly hair.

In the lower left corner, just to the left of the knees belonging to the personification of "the purple year," an Hour hovers or flies facing away. This Hour's upper body bends sharply back and to the left, twisting slightly so that her left shoulder blade appears closer to the viewer than her right. Her left leg is extended down, toe pointed as if on tiptoe. Her slightly bent right leg is extended backward, out toward the viewer, toe pointed. She holds her right arm out at 135 degrees, with her hand extended, palm facing down. Her left arm extends horizontally from her body, which is tilted so that her arm forms a 135 degree angle with the bottom of the design. Her left hand holds a vine to the left. She wears a semi-transparent long-sleeved gown that billows to the right of her lower body. Her hair is drawn up into a bun. Two dots symmetrically arranged above her head might be the terminals of insect-like antennae. A babe kneels on a large leaf just above this Hour's right arm, facing forward and left, and slightly down towards the Hour. This babe appears to be female, with the suggestion of visible breasts. At least one leg is drawn up beneath her, and she bends forward so that her torso nearly touches her thigh(s). Her head is up as if she is looking torwards the Hour's face. She holds her arms out vertically to either side. Her eyes may be closed, or may be poorly delineated. Her short, curly hair blows away from her face. Four long petals, suggesting both a flower and flying garments, extend up and to the right from beneath the babe's lower body.

An Hour hovers or flies just below the text panel. Her body is horizontal, but she bends backward and turns to the left, so that her upper body faces forward. Her slightly bent left leg extends out to the left, while her right leg, visible from the knee down, is bent up diagonally. Both feet are pointed as if on tiptoe. She holds her slightly bent left arm out horizontally to the left; her extended fingers on her left hand touch the hand of a babe to the left. With the wrist, palm, and fingers of this hand she supports the babe emerging from a flower above. Her right arm is extended horizontally to the right, her forearm bent up slightly. She turns her head to look forward and left. Her long, curly hair is loose and hangs down her back, visible on either side of her body. One tendril may drape over her left shoulder. She is nude from the waist up, with visible breasts, and wears a skirt or gown that begins just below her breasts and covers her hips, but disappears behind her right leg above her knee. A split in the skirt at the top of her right thigh reveals more of her upper leg. A small button, bead, or other ornament adorns the top of this split. A bracelet made of beads or small links circles her right arm. The vine that loops behind her and up to the right displays two blossoms with multiple petals from which babes emerge: one above her feet, and the other above her left hand. The babe on the left, above the Hour's feet, is visible from the waist up; the suggestion of breasts may indicate this is a female. She bends backward and to the right, extending her arms above her head to reach toward the Hour's right hand. She emerges from the blossom facing forward, but turns her head to look up and to the right. The babe holds her right arm vertically and her left at 135 degrees. Her mouth seems to be open, and her eyes may be closed, or may be poorly delineated. She is nude and has short, curly hair. The babe on the right, of indeterminate gender, is also nude and visible from the waist up as it descends from the blossom, facing down but bending backwards towards the Hour on the left. It extends its one visible arm, the left, past its head, resting it on the Hour's forearm. Its head is up as if it is looking toward the Hour. Its curly hair may be short, or may be drawn up or over its right shoulder.

Just to the right of the text panel, an Hour stands on tiptoe and stretches up to hold a babe overhead. Her visible breasts suggest that she is female. Facing right, this Hour bends backward slightly and extends both arms vertically over her head. She turns her upper body slightly so that her torso faces slightly forward, and she bends her head back to look up, so that her facial features are seen from below. Her legs are together. She is nude, and no hair is visible. She holds the babe at its waist, and its rather limp upper and lower body hang from her hands, which are mostly hidden. The babe's lower body may be resting along the Hour's left hand and wrist. The babe's upside down upper body faces away and its head faces down, seen from above. It extends both arms straight down towards the Hour, with both hands open, palms down. It has short, possibly curly hair and is of indeterminate gender. It seems to be wearing a gown or to be wrapped in draping cloth. A vine spirals around the figure of the Hour, wraps once around her upraised left arm, and spirals into the air behind her.

Near the lower left corner of the design hovers an Hour seen from above. Of indeterminate gender but probably female, this Hour faces down towards the bottom of the design, so that the top of its head and its nose are visible. It reaches both slightly bent arms down towards a babe below, which it holds or touches with one hand on either of the babe's shoulders. The Hour's right hand rests partly on the right side of the babe's head. The Hour's legs are together, bent and drawn up so that the top of its thighs are shown. Its lower left leg also appears, extending away from the viewer, who can also see the top of this foot. This Hour is nude, and has short hair or a bun. The babe below, also of indeterminate gender, is resting in or emerging from between two green sepals, as if it were a blossom. These sepals belong to a plant that is rooted in the ground near the lower left corner of the design. The plant has one leaf. The babe, which seems to be wrapped in cloth, lies reclined with its head furthest away from the viewer. It lifts its chin to look up at the Hour above. Its mouth is open and its eyes are raised. It has curly, possibly short hair.

Three female Hours stand or kneel facing left, in a row on the ground near the bottom left corner of the design. The Hour furthest right kneels resting on knee and tiptoe. She hunches over, bending sharply forward so that a babe on the ground at her knee can nurse from her visible left breast. Her left arm is at her side, bent so that her forearm rests on her upper thigh. She is nude and has curly hair that may be short, or may be drawn into a bun. Her eyes seem to be down or closed. The babe lies along her knee and thigh, facing right, with its visible right arm stretched up toward her stomach and resting on her thigh. It bends its head back to bring its mouth to her breast. Its right leg, slightly bent, extends backward with the lower leg resting along the ground, while its left knee is visible on the ground in front of the right. It is nude, but of indeterminate gender, and has short curly hair. Two leaves rise from the ground immediately to the left, while a third lies along the ground just below the babe, and a fourth along the ground towards the bottom of the design. This babe may be emerging from these leaves. The Hour in the middle stands but bends forward sharply. Her left leg is bent and drawn forward, while the shape of her gown suggests that her right leg is extended behind her. She extends both arms together, reaching down toward a blossom near her left foot. Her head is bent back slightly, so that she can look down. Her eyes are down or closed. She wears a long-sleeved gown that may be belted at the waist, and has long hair falling in a braid down her back. Her left foot is visible beneath the hem of her gown. Just to the left of her left foot grows a blossom surrounded by long leaves. It is slightly open, and the Hour's hands are inside; her palms face each other and are just slightly apart. The Hour furthest left kneels, bending forward. She holds her slightly bent left arm down, reaching forward towards a babe nearer the lower left corner of the design. Her head is bent slightly back, and her eyes are down or closed. Her hair is drawn back into a bun, although one tendril has escaped and hangs in front of her forehead. She is wearing a long-sleeved gown, and possibly a belt. The babe to the left hovers between two leaves of a plant rooted below the nearest Hour's knee. Alternatively, this babe may be resting on the rightmost leaf. Nude but of indeterminate gender, the babe faces right and extends its right arm in front of him at 135 degrees, up towards the Hour's face. It bends its head back; its mouth may be open. Its visible right leg, slightly bent, extends behind it. It has short curly hair.

Curly vines with sparse leaves appear throughout the design. One, rooted beneath the legs of "the purple year," grows to the right near the bottom of the design, forming five loops of descending size as it nears the right side of the design. Another seems to be rooted near the bottom left corner of the design, growing up and looping to the right. It has two blossoms from which babes emerge. A third vine appears at the right side of the design, above the head of "the purple year." It grows left and splits into two tendrils: one tendril grows up and spirals around the figure of the Hour at the right side of the text panel, while the other grows down and to the left before looping back to the right. This latter tendril also carries two blossoms from which babes emerge. A fourth vine appears at the top left corner of the text panel, forming a loop above and to the right in which an Hour sits, nursing a babe. From there, this vine grows rightward across the top and then down the right side of the design, creating six loops. Grass covers the ground at the lower left corner of the design, extending about a third of the way across the bottom of the design.
A six-pointed star is poised just below the vine near the top of the design, just above the text box. This is "Fair Venus" (see the letterpress text).

A miniscule bird, described in the letterpress text as an "Attic warbler," perches on the vine just above the star. Its head is bent back and its beak is open as if it is singing. Its tail descends to touch the star below.
Blue wash surrounding the objects on the design suggests the sky.

desc.objtitle: Ode on the Spring: Page 4, Object 4 (Butlin 335.4)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 7 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The poet Gray reclines next to "some water's rushy brink" (see the letterpress text), facing right with his lower body extended out to the right. He leans backward and rests his weight on his right elbow, which is propped on a root to the left. His right arm is bent and down by his side, with his forearm towards the viewer and his hand dangling. He holds a pen loosely betwen his first and second fingers on this hand. His left arm is extended across his lap, and his visible right leg is stretched along the ground, with his knee and the top of his right foot facing the viewer. He bends his head down. He wears a long-sleeved gown that extends to his knees. His short hair is curly and wild. The "Muse" (see Blake's text, Object 2) reclines half-sitting, half-lying above and to the right of the Poet, facing forward with her head nearer the right side of the design and her lower body extended left. She is resting on a cloud. Her bent legs are drawn up together with her knees forward. She lifts her upper body, propping herself on her left elbow, and supporting a lyre with her left arm and hand. Her eyes are closed; her long, curly hair is loose and drapes over her shoulders, and she wears a wreath of laurels on her head. She is dressed in a long-sleeved gown that covers her lower body in folds of fabric. The trunk of an enormous tree rises from behind the poet, near the lower left corner of the design, growing rightward as it reaches toward the top of the design. Above the text box the trunk splits into two large branches, which extend into the top two corners of the design. One root of the tree extends to the left of the poet, supporting his braced right elbow, and then curves downward into the water below the poet. An ivy vine ascends the enormous tree trunk from the left side, bearing leaves in three bunches. Grass covers the ground across the bottom of the design, and thin reeds grow upward from the water below the poet. Additional vegetation is visible in the shadow to the left of the tree trunk; this may represent branches with leaves. This part of the tree has been over-painted with dark wash that indicates either deep shadows or a rocky cliff. Other dark areas near the upper right side of the design may also be rocks; if so, then the setting is cave-like. Additional dark areas in the water below the poet's leg may be shadow. The lighter area near the top of the design, between the branches of the large tree, may represent sky. Water, perhaps a stream or river, extends across the bottom of the design.

component.illusobjdesc: The poet Gray reclines next to "some water's rushy brink" (see the letterpress text), facing right with his lower body extended out to the right. He leans backward and turns his upper body slightly forward; he rests his weight on his right elbow, which is propped on a root to the left. His right arm is bent and down by his side, with his forearm towards the viewer and his hand dangling. He holds a pen loosely between his first and second fingers on this hand. The tip of this pen may touch or rest on the root on which the poet leans. His left arm is extended across his lap, his forearm resting on his right thigh and his hand dangling from the wrist. The fingers of his left hand, three of which are extended as though pointing, may touch or rest on the ground. The poet's right leg is extended along the ground, with his knee and the top of his right foot facing the viewer. His left leg is not depicted below the thigh, which lies parallel to the right. He bends his head down and turns it slightly left so that his face is seen in profile. He wears a long-sleeved gown that extends to his knees. His short hair is curly and wild.

The "Muse" (see Blake's text, Object 2) reclines half-sitting, half-lying above and to the right of the Poet, facing forward with her head nearer the right side of the design and her lower body extended left. She is resting on a cloud. Her bent legs are drawn up together with her knees forward. She lifts her upper body, propping herself on her left elbow. Her left arm, bent upward from the elbow, also supports a lyre partly in front of her torso. The fingers of her left hand are visible resting on the top of the lyre. Her right arm is down but drawn slightly rightward across the front of her body; her right forearm and outstretched right hand rest, in front of her torso, on the rock formation on which she sits. She turns her head slightly left and down. Her eyes are closed. Her long, curly hair is loose and drapes over her shoulders, and she wears a wreath of laurels on her head. She is dressed in a long-sleeved gown that covers her lower body in folds of fabric. Her feet are not visible, hidden behind the poet.

The trunk of an enormous tree rises from behind the poet, near the lower left corner of the design, growing rightward as it reaches toward the top of the design. Above the text panel the trunk splits into two large branches, which extend into the top two corners of the design. These large tree branches may be the "oak's thick branches" mentioned in the text. One root of the tree extends to the left of the poet, supporting his braced right elbow. It curves downward into the water below the poet, splitting into two tendrils that echo the branches above. An ivy vine ascends the enormous tree trunk from the left side, bearing leaves in three bunches. Grass covers the ground across the bottom of the design, and thin reeds grow upward from the water below the poet. Additional vegetation is visible in the dark to the left of the tree trunk; this may represent branches with leaves. These have been over-painted with dark wash representing either a cliff or deep shadows.

Dark areas right and left of the tree trunk may represent the shadows cast by the trees (see the letterpress text) or large stones, including a cliff on the left. If stones, then the setting is cave-like. Additional dark areas in the water below the poet's leg may also be shadow. The lighter area near the top of the design, between the branches of the large tree, may represent sky.
Water, perhaps a stream or river, extends across the bottom of the design.
The muse (the figure on the right) reclines on a cloud.

desc.objtitle: Ode on the Spring: Page 5, Object 5 (Butlin 335.5)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 13 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The nude, muscular figure of "Mischance" (see Blake's text, Object 2) kneels on one knee near the bottom of the design, facing right and leaning on or climbing onto a stony ledge. He has short curly hair, a curly beard, and prominent fur-like chest hair. His right leg is bent and drawn up. His left leg is down and extended backward, resting on knee and tiptoe. Leaning forward, he extends his left arm down with his hand resting flat on the ground over the compressed figure of a fly in human form. His right arm is bent and drawn back, braced with his right hand resting palm down on the knob of a tree over a struggling human fly. A third smashed fly lies draped limply over the trunk of this tree just above Mischance's right hand. Contemplation stands at the right side of the design, on the same stony ledge. He faces left and hunches over slightly, with his head bent down. He is wrapped in a cloak with the hood drawn up, so that his wrinkled face is visible only from forehead to nose. His eyes are closed and his long white beard emerges from inside the hood to hang past his arms. Four human flies fall from Contemplation's shoulders to the ground, while one or perhaps two more huddle on top of his shoulders. A large boulder or deep shadow behind Contemplation appears above and to either side of him. A leafless tree grows on the other side of the rocky ledge where Contemplation stands, in the lower left corner of the design. From wide visible roots its trunk grows upward, then branches off rather sharply to the left, leaving a knot or knob to the right. Mischance rests his right hand on this knob. The tree bears several leafless branches to the left of the text panel. Above the tree flies or hovers a human fly of indeterminate gender, facing away and holding a trumpet to its mouth. This fly has two large wings spread on either side of its upper body. The trumpet it holds to its mouth extends away or up, curling in a spiral loop before ending in a bell facing right. Ten human flies dance or fly in a circle near the top of the design. Each fly has arms outstretched horizontally to link hands with the flies on either side. Blue and yellow washes around the design suggest the sky, perhaps at sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: The nude, muscular figure of "Mischance" (see Blake's text, Object 2) kneels on one knee near the bottom of the design, facing right. His right leg is bent and drawn up, his foot hidden behind the ledge that crosses the bottom of the design. His left leg is down and extended backward, resting on knee and tiptoe. Leaning forward, he turns his torso slightly forward. His slightly bent left arm is extended down, with his hand resting flat on the ground, palm down, over the compressed figure of a human fly. His right arm is bent and drawn back, braced with his right hand resting palm down on the knob of a tree over a struggling human fly. He has short curly hair, a curly beard, and fur-like chest hair.

Contemplation stands at the right side of the design, facing left and hunched over slightly, with his head bent down. He is wrapped in a cloak with the hood drawn up, so that his wrinkled face is visible only from forehead to nose. His eyes are closed and his long white beard emerges from inside the hood to hang past his arms. His left arm seems to be bent and crossed across his torso beneath the cloak. The shape of the cloak below suggests that his left leg is bent forward slightly.

A leafless tree grows in the lower left corner of the design. From wide visible roots its trunk grows upward, then branches off rather sharply to the left, leaving a knot or knob to the right. Mischance rests his right hand on this knob. The tree bears several leafless branches to the left of the text panel.

Four human flies of uncertain gender fall from Contemplation's shoulders to the ground; one or perhaps two more crouch on top of his shoulders. The human fly closest to the ground falls upside down, facing away. Its wings are spread on either side of its body, and it holds its arms (perhaps bent) over its head at 135 degrees. Its legs are bent and drawn up. The fly just above it also falls head first, facing away, with its left leg extended and its right leg drawn up, so that only its right foot is visible above its buttock. Its transparent wings are folded behind its back. Both arms are bent upward, held over its head. It bends backward, as if to look out toward the viewer, but covers its face with both hands. It seems to be nude. A third fly falls head first just to the right. It is poorly delineated, but seems to extend one arm straight over its head, and to hold the other down by its side. Above these parallel flies falls a fourth, also upside down. Facing away, it holds both bent arms overhead. Its head is bent back as if to look down, so that the top of its head is towards the viewer, and it holds both hands near its head. Both of its legs are extended, with the right crossed over the left at the ankle. Its semi-transparent wings are extended to each side. Above Contemplation's shoulders, a fly sits huddled with legs drawn up and crossed at the ankles. It faces forward but leans left to rest on Contemplation. Its wings are just visible above its own shoulder. It may be supporting its head with its bent left arm, bent double at the elbow and propped on Contemplation's hood. This fly may be nude or may be wearing tights. Its eyes are closed. A second fly, difficult to distinguish, may appear just to the left of the first that sits on Contemplation's shoulders. All three flies in the air seem to have short hair, while the one clearly pictured sitting on Contemplation's shoulders may be bald.

Mischance has smashed two human flies, and a third struggles beneath his weight. One compressed fly of uncertain gender sprawls on its back and side under Mischance's left hand, and is presumably dead or dying. Its head is out toward the viewer, facing up and to the right, and its right arm is outstretched along the ground to the right. Its lower body, not well delineated, lies curved around to the right on the other side of Mischance's fingers. This fly's long hair is loose, and part lies spread on the ground. It seems to be nude. A second fly lies limply draped over the trunk of the tree just above Mischance's right hand. It is nude, but its gender is difficult to decipher as it faces down, into the trunk. Its upper body hangs upside down, with head down and both arms dangling down past its head, and its spread wings sagging slightly on either side of its body. Its long, loose hair hangs between its arms. Its left leg is visible extended along the top line of the trunk, but this foot and the entire right leg are hidden. It may be dying or dead. A third fly struggles under Mischance's right hand, which is braced palm-down on the trunk of the tree. This fly is visible only above mid-chest, facing forward. The fly seems to be nude, and the suggestion of breasts hints that she is female. She arches her back, bending backward and tilting her head back to look up. Both arms are down and bent inward slightly, as if she is crossing her arms or wrapping them around her upper body, right forearm above left. They may be trapped between her torso and the tree trunk. Her mouth is open, and her face bears an expression of fear and pain. She may have short hair. Both wings are visible above her head and left shoulder.

Above the tree at the left side of the design a human fly of indeterminate gender and holding a trumpet hovers or flies, facing away. This fly has two large wings spread on either side of its upper body. The trumpet it holds to its mouth extends away or up, curling in a spiral loop before ending in a bell facing right. The fly's left arm, slightly bent, is extended vertically past its head; it holds the trumpet just beneath the loop with this hand. Its right forearm is visible above its right wing. It holds or touches the trumpet near the mouthpiece with its right hand. The fly extends its right leg backward and to the right, and its left leg backward and out toward the viewer. It has short hair, and wears tights that may cover its feet as well.

Ten human flies dance or fly in a circle near the top of the design. Each fly has arms outstretched horizontally to link hands with the flies on either side. The four at the top of the ring face forward and left, but are otherwise indistinct. The rightmost fly, rather indistinct as well, faces left with lower body extended backward slightly. The leftmost fly is slightly more defined, facing right with legs spread wide, the left leg extended forward and right leg extended backward. A loop above this fly's right leg may be clothing billowing in the air. The four flies forming the lower part of the ring are the most defined. One, who seems to be female with the slight indication of breasts, faces forward with her lower body extended leftward, and at least her right leg slightly bent. She has long hair and wears a long semi-transparent gown, both of which billow behind her. The fly to the left of her, also perhaps a female with one breast visible beneath her right armpit, faces away with both legs extended backwards. Her right leg is straight and her left slightly bent. Lines on this fly's back and buttocks suggest she may be wearing a gown or some other form of clothing that flies in the air to the left of her legs. She may have her hair in a bun, or have short, possibly curly hair. To the right of the female facing forward is a male fly, who faces away but turns his lower body to face right, with right leg extended horizontally backwards and left leg extended down on tiptoe. To the right of this male is another fly that may be male, facing away with legs extended leftward. His right leg is extended and his left may be bent forward. Both of these males to the right of the female in the lower section of the circle are nude or wear tights, and are bald or have short hair.
Blue and yellow washes around the design suggest the sky, perhaps at sunrise or sunset.
A large rock or boulder, or perhaps a deep shadow, appears above and to either side of Contemplation. He is standing on a stony ledge onto which Mischance is climbing from a slightly lower level.

desc.objtitle: Ode on the Spring: Page 6, Object 6 (Butlin 335.6)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 2 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The poet Gray rests at the base of a tree growing up the left side of the design. His lower body faces right, with knees drawn up, but at the waist he twists his upper body to face away. He is leaning on his left elbow, which he has propped on the tree's roots, and bends his head back to look up and to the right. A curling paper, possibly a scroll, is visible draped over his left forearm. The twisting trunk of the great tree grows up toward the top left corner, where one branch splits off and arches rightward over the text panel, becoming several smaller branches that hang back down toward the lower right corner of the design. These branches bear sparse leaves, mostly near their ends. Another large branch, or perhaps the rest of the trunk, continues up from the original split into the upper left corner. A grouping of four figures clusters in the crook of the tree that this split forms. A human fly sits facing left on the branch right where it splits from the trunk. Her legs are bent with knees raised to support a child on her lap, who may be suckling. She hunches over slightly and bends her head down towards the child's. She has two large butterfly-like wings raised behind her back. To the right of the mother and child stands a piper, facing forward and slightly right with legs together. It is difficult to discern this figure's gender. Its arms are bent upward and it holds a pipe to its mouth. It has three large pairs of wings, appearing on either side of its body from head to mid-calf. Another fly of indeterminate gender hovers or flies above the mother and child, facing down with its head towards the viewer. It holds its arms out horizontally, and seems to extend its legs behind it. It has at least one large pair of wings spread wide, but perhaps more. A female human fly sits on the top of the text box, facing forward and turning her head to look slightly right. Her legs are bent and drawn up, and she wraps her arms around the outside of her legs, wrists near ankles. She has long curly hair spilling over her shoulders and arms, and at least one, possibly two pairs of wings spread wide. Two small, probably young faces appear facing forward in the enclosure made by her arms and legs. Another adult human fly somersaults backward off the upper left corner of the text panel. It may be female, with the suggestion of breasts. It is upside down facing up and to the right, with arms extended and hands touching the edge of the text box. It is bent at the waist, and its slightly bent legs extend forward and to the right. Three wings appear to the left of its body, and two to the right. The faint outline of a pair of wings and a body belonging to a tiny additional fly, flying or hovering to the left of the text panel, appear just below and to the left of the somersaulting fly. Two human flies hover or fly in parallel to the left of the text box. Both are female and have short, curly hair or wear buns. Both are upside down with their upper bodies facing right. Each holds her right arm out straight, down and to the left towards the poet below them, with index finger pointing. Each extends her left arm straight upward, also with finger(s) pointing. They turn their heads to look down toward the poet. The leftmost fly has two clearly visible pairs of wings at her back. Part of a fifth wing may appear just below her waist. The rightmost fly has at least three pairs of wings appearing on either side of her body from shoulders to thighs. A spider web appears to the right of the text box, attached to the tree branches above and to the right and to the box to the left. In the middle of the web a tiny spider in human form appears, brandishing a sword or dagger in its left hand, and holding on to the web with its right hand, raised overhead. It seems to be wearing armor and possibly a helmet. Alternatively, it may be bald. A cluster of sixteen flies appears hovering or flying to the left of the tree branches hanging on the right side of the design. Blue and yellow washes around the design suggest the sky, perhaps at sunrise or sunset, and perhaps with clouds, especially below the text panel. Mountains or hills appear in the distance in the lower right corner of the design. The poet is also sitting on a hill or mound, the edge of which appears below and to the left of the mountains. A lower area visible in between, below the mountains, may be a grassy plain or valley, or water. Grass covers the hill or mound upon which the poet sits and also the distant mountains or hills. It may also cover the area in between, visible beneath the mountains, if this is land and not water.

component.illusobjdesc: The poet Gray rests at the base of a tree growing up the left side of the design. His lower body faces right, but at the waist he twists his upper body to face away. He is leaning on his left elbow, which he has propped on the tree's roots, with his arm bent. He bends his head back to look up and to the right. His right leg is bent and drawn up, with this foot flat on the ground, and his left foot is visible crossed over the right at the ankles. His torso hides his right arm. A curling paper, possibly a scroll, is visible draped over his left forearm. He has short, curly hair, and is wearing shoes and long-sleeved tights that end just below his knees.

An enormous tree grows at the left side of the design. Its massive roots support the poet Gray in the lower left corner, and extend rightward past the midpoint of the design's bottom edge. The twisting trunk of the tree grows up toward the top left corner, where one branch splits off and arches rightward over the text panel, becoming several smaller branches that hang back down towards the lower right corner of the design. These branches bear sparse leaves, mostly near their ends. Another large branch, or perhaps the rest of the trunk, continues up from the original split into the upper left corner.

A grouping of four figures clusters in the crook of the tree near the upper left corner of the design. A human fly sits facing left on the branch right where it splits from the trunk. Her legs are bent with knees raised to support a child on her lap, who may be suckling. She hunches over slightly and bends her head down towards the child's, supporting it with her bent left arm, which also rests on her lap. She is wearing a long-sleeved gown that covers her feet. Her hair may be short and curly, or may be pulled up into a bun. She has two large butterfly-like wings raised behind her back. The child's head and hand, raised just left of its head, appear above the mother's lap. It is facing away, seen from behind, and seems to be bald. A fold just below the mother's left elbow may be draped fabric from the child's clothing, if it is not just a fold in the mother's dress. To the right of the mother and child stands a piper, facing forward and slightly right with legs together. It is difficult to discern this figure's gender. Its arms are bent upward in front of its torso and it holds a pipe to its mouth. It has three large pairs of wings, extending from head to mid-calf. It may be nude or wearing tights. It has short, curly hair, or its hair is drawn up. Another fly of indeterminate gender hovers or flies above the mother and child, facing down with head towards the viewer. It holds its arms out horizontally, and seems to extend its legs behind it. It has at least one large pair of wings spread wide, but possibly more. It may be wearing a gown. It may have its hair drawn into a bun, or have short, curly hair.

A spider web appears to the right of the text box, attached to the tree branches above and to the right and to the box to the left. In the middle of the web a tiny spider in human form appears, brandishing a sword or dagger. This figure faces forward but turns its head to look slightly left. Its extended right arm is raised almost vertically, and it may be holding on to the web with this hand. Its slightly bent left arm is down by its side, and it grasps the weapon with this hand. Its lower body may turn slightly to the right. Its bent left leg is down. It holds its bent right leg drawn up and out, and possibly slightly right. It seems to be wearing armor, and possibly a helmet. Alternatively, it may be bald.

Two human flies hover or fly or descend in parallel to the left of the text box. Both are female and have short, curly hair or wear buns. Both are upside down; their upper bodies face right. Each holds her right arm out straight, down and to the left towards the poet below them, with index finger pointing. Each extends her left arm straight upward, also with finger(s) pointing. They turn their heads down to look toward the poet. The rightmost fly twists at the waist so that her lower body faces up. Her left leg is straight, and her right leg is bent and drawn up slightly. She is nude with visible breasts. The lower body of the leftmost fly faces left but also extends upward. She is wearing a gown or skirt that may begin just below her breasts, or may partially cover them. Only one foot, on tiptoe, is visible beneath the hem of her garment. Lines extending up from her lower body past her foot may be clothing. The leftmost fly has two clearly visible pairs of wings at her back. Part of a fifth wing may appear just below her waist. The rightmost fly has at least three pairs of wings appearing on either side of her body from shoulders to thighs.

A female human fly sits on the top of the text box, facing forward and turning her head to look slightly right. Her legs are bent and drawn up, and she wraps her arms around the outside of her legs, wrists near ankles. Her hands and feet are not visible. She has long curly hair spilling over her shoulders and arms down to the top of the text box, and a pair of wings spread wide, one on each side of her body. Alternatively, the wing-shaped outline inside each wing may represent a second pair of wings. She may be nude. Two small, probably young faces appear facing forward in the enclosure made by her arms and legs: on the right a round face with eyes above a striped torso, resembling a bee, and in the middle a second face with arms, a mouth, and the suggestion of ears above a body that extends down between the adult fly's lower legs. The gender of these two is difficult to discern. Both are bald. Another adult human fly somersaults backward off the upper left corner of the text panel. It may be female, with the suggestion of breasts. It is upside down facing up and to the right, with arms extended and hands touching the edge of the text box. It is bent at the waist, and its slightly bent legs extend forward and to the right. Its buttocks face up. Three wings appear to the left of its body, and two to the right. It is nude, and may have short hair. The faint outline of a pair of wings and a body belonging to a tiny additional fly, flying or hovering to the left of the text box, appear just below and to the left of the somersaulting fly.

A cluster of sixteen flies appears hovering or flying to the left of the tree branches hanging on the right side of the design. Six fly in a line formation just beneath the shortest branches with leaves. While most of the flies appear to have insect-like wings, one just to the right of the lower right corner of the text panel has bird-like wings that may have feathers. This fly faces right where the others appear mostly to face left or up.
Blue and yellow washes around the design suggest the sky, perhaps at sunrise or sunset, and perhaps with clouds, especially below the text panel.

Mountains or hills appear in the distance in the lower right corner of the design. The poet is also sitting on a hill or mound, the edge of which appears below and to the left of the mountains. A lower area visible in between, below the mountains, may be a grassy plain or valley, or water.
Grass covers the hill upon which the poet sits and also the distant mountains or hills. It may also cover the area in between, visible beneath the mountains, if this is land and not water.

desc.objtitle: Ode on the Death of a Favourite Cat; Page 1: Title-Page, Object 7 (Butlin 335.7)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The human-like cat Selima crouches on top of the text box, facing right and looking down at two goldfish in the water below. She is colored like a cat, with a tail, fur, whiskers, and feline ears and eyes, but human-like nose, mouth, hands, leg and foot. She kneels on knee and elbow with body contracted, and reaches down and right with her left arm, which is visible from mid-forearm. She wears a corset and a cloth or shawl pulled up partially over her head, through which the thick fur on her head and neck is visible. Two goldfish appear below the text box. They have fishlike attributes, including fins and scales, but human-like nude bodies with arms, hands, legs, and feet. The horizontal body of the lowermost goldfish faces forward, but he reaches his arms down and to the right, and turns his head up to look at Selima above. His mouth is open. The body of the uppermost goldfish is nearly horizontal, facing forward. He raises both arms extended straight at 135 degrees, with hands open and palms forward. He bends his head back to look up at the cat above. Dark wash surrounding the goldfish, covering two-thirds of the design, represents the water in which the fish swim and into which the cat peers. Lighter wash in the upper two quadrants of the design, above the horizon line of the water, suggests sky with thin clouds. A large cloud appears in the upper left corner of the design.

component.illusobjdesc: The human-like cat Selima crouches on the top of the text box, facing right. She is colored like a cat, with a tail, fur, whiskers, and feline ears and eyes, but human-like nose, mouth, hands, leg and foot. She kneels on knees and elbows with body contracted. Her visible right leg is bent and drawn beneath her, her right foot resting on tiptoe. Her right arm is bent and she rests on her right elbow and forearm, her right hand dangling from the edge of the text box. She reaches down and right with her left arm, which is visible from mid-forearm. Her left hand is open, palm down. Claws are visible on her fingers and toes. Her tail emerges leftward from beneath her foot, hanging from the left top edge of the text box. Peeking over the right top edge of the text box, she lifts her head to look down at the goldfish below. She wears a corset and a cloth or shawl pulled up partially over her head, through which the thick fur on her head and neck is visible.

Two goldfish appear below the text box. They have fishlike attributes, including fins and scales, but human-like nude bodies with arms, hands, legs, and feet. The horizontal body of the lowermost goldfish faces forward, but he reaches his arms down and turns his head up to look at Selima above. His mouth is open. Both arms are extended straight from the shoulder. He has drawn his right arm across his body down toward the lower right corner of the design, and raised his left arm. The position of both arms is nearest 135 degrees, though the left is slightly higher than the right. His slightly bent right leg is extended and his left bent and drawn up, slightly in front of the right. His hands are open, fingers extended and palms down. Fins appear below his right arm, extending from his wrist to his armpit and then along his right side to his hip, with smaller fins visible to the right of his right knee. On the left side of his body, fins line his left arm from wrist to armpit and down his left side, and also appear beneath his legs. The back of his head is also extended as if into a kind of fin. He may be male.

The body of the uppermost goldfish in human-like form is nearly horizontal, facing forward. He may be male. He raises both arms extended straight at 135 degrees. His hands are open, with palms facing forward. His slightly bent right leg is extended and his left leg bent and drawn up. He bends his head back to look up at the cat above. Scales appear clearly on his abdomen; lines on his upper torso, legs, and at the joints of his arms also suggest scales. Fins line his body, appearing between his right wrist and right ankle, between his left wrist and left hip, and along the top side of both arms between wrist and head. His mouth may be slightly open.

Light wash in the upper two quadrants of the design, above the horizon line of the water in which the goldfish swim, suggests sky with thin clouds. A large cloud appears in the upper left corner of the design.
Dark wash surrounding the goldfish, covering two-thirds of the design, represents the water in which the fish swim and into which the cat peers.

desc.objtitle: Ode on the Death of a Favourite Cat; Page 2: Blank Page Bearing List of Titles, Object 8 (Butlin 335.8)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Selima the cat lies on the top of the text box, her body facing left and her head turned to look forward. She is entirely cat in this design, with no human attributes as in the previous design. A plump child (probably female) sits on Selima's back facing left but turning her head to look partly forward, much like the cat. The child hunches over, resting her chin on her upraised right hand. Her visible left leg is bent forward and drawn up, heel to buttock. Two goldfish swim almost in parallel below the text box, facing right. The rightmost fish is half hidden behind the fish on the left. A female "angel form" (see the letterpress text) rides each fish, facing right. They both wear long gowns and have long hair extending horizontally behind them. Light wash over the top half of the design suggests the sky, perhaps at sunrise or sunset. Darker, blue wash over the lower half of the design suggests the water in which the goldfish swim.

component.illusobjdesc: Selima the cat lies on the top of the text box, her body facing left and her head turned to look forward. Her front left leg extends along the top of the text box to the left, while her tail lies rightward, dangling off the opposite edge of the text box. She is entirely cat in this design, with no human attributes as in the previous design. A plump child (probably female) sits on Selima's back facing left but turning her head to look partly forward, much like the cat. The child hunches over, resting her chin on her upraised right hand. Her right elbow is propped on the cat's back, forearm upraised, and her left arm is down and drawn forward, possibly bent with her left forearm resting in the crook of her right elbow. Her visible left leg is bent forward and drawn up, heel to buttock. The child seems to be wearing tights, perhaps with a belt. Her hair is short and curly, and she may be wearing a bow or ribbon of some kind on top of her head.

Two goldfish swim almost in parallel below the text panel, facing right. The rightmost fish is half hidden behind the fish on the left. Both have fins and scales and hold their mouths open, with tiny teeth visible along their bottom jaws. A female "angel form" (see the letterpress text) rides each fish. The angel form on the leftmost fish sits facing right with her legs outstretched to the right along the fish's back. Her legs are slightly bent and her right foot is crossed over her left at the ankle. She leans back to rest against the fish's dorsal fin. Her visible right arm is down by her side, bent at the elbow with her lower arm resting along her thigh. She may be pointing with her right index finger. Her head is down slightly, and her long braid extends horizontally behind her. She is wearing a long, long-sleeved gown that covers her feet at least partially. The rightmost angel form sits on the rightmost fish with her body facing right, but turns her head to look forward and left towards the angel on the left. Her visible right arm, slightly bent, is down by her side. Her right hand is resting on the fish's back, and she may be propping herself up with this arm. Her legs seem to be bent up away from the viewer. Alternatively they may be stretched out to the right along the fish's back, and end in stumps at her ankles. She is wearing a long, sleeveless gown, and has long hair (possibly in two plaits) extending horizontally behind her.
Light wash over the top half of the design suggests the sky, perhaps at sunrise or sunset. Darker, blue wash over the lower half of the design suggests the water in which the goldfish swim.

lg.l: Ode on the Death of
a Favourite Cat
Design.
1. "Midst the tideLines 5-6 are quoted, with minor variations, from page 50 of the letterpress text (Object 10).
Two Angel forms were seen to glide"
2. "Demurest of the Tabby kind"The line is quoted, with minor variations, from page [49] of the letterpress text (Object 9).
3"The pensive SelimaLines 8-10 are quoted, with minor variations, from pages [49]-50 of the letterpress text (Objects 9 and 10).
Her ears of Jet & Emrald Eyes
She saw & purr'd applause"
4. "Still had she gazd but midst the tideLines 11-14 are quoted, with minor variations, from page 50 of the letterpress text (Object 10).
Two Angel forms were seen to glide
The hapless nymph with wonder saw
A Whisker first & then a Claw &c"

5. "Malignant Fate sat by & smildLines 15-17 are quoted, with minor variations, from page 51 of the letterpress text (Object 11). The final word in line 15 is "smil'd" in the letterpress text. Blake appears to have changed this to "smild" with the ascender of the final letter uninked.

The slippery verge her feet beguildThe final word in line 16 is "beguil'd" on page 51 of the letterpress text (Object 11). Blake appears to have changed this to "beguild" with the ascender of the final letter uninked.
She tumbled head long in"

6 ."Nine times emerging from the floodLines 18-19 are quoted, with variations, from page 51 of the letterpress text (Object 11). Blake changed the first word in line 18 from "Eight" in the letterpress text to "Nine."
"She mew'd to every watry God"

desc.objtitle: Ode on the Death of a Favourite Cat; Page 3: Beginning of Poem, Object 9 (Butlin 335.9)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 9 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Near the top of the design, Selima lies along the grass-covered edge of a lake, gazing down at her reflection in the water below. Semi-reclined and wearing a bonnet and gown, Selima is almost fully human in this design, but has a cat's tail, eyes, and ears. The faint suggestion of whiskers appears on her cheeks, and her hair suggests a cat's fur. She lies on her left side facing forward, her legs extending along the ground to the left. The text box partially hides them. She props her torso up on her left elbow and forearm, and bends her head down and to the right to look at her reflection in the water. This reflection appears directly beneath her as a sketchily outlined mirror image of her head, torso, and arms. Her tail curls upward in an "S" shape above the text box. Her right foot emerges from the folds of her gown to the left of the text box. Blue wash below the bank and surrounding water-plants growing in the lake indicates water, while an area left blank along the design's bottom edge indicates the lake's bottom. A pair of nude cupids or putti (although one is female) sits embracing on the bottom of the lake in the lower left corner. They sit side-by-side facing forward but leaning left, with legs bent and knees drawn up, and arms entwined. One batlike wing or fish-like fin appears to the left of the pair, and another to the right. Flowering plants fill the water in the spaces between Selima's reflection and the putti. These plants seem to be rooted in the floor of the lake to the right of the embracing lovers. Their intertwined vines and branches support six pansy-like flowers, and many more lily-like flowers, as well as three round berries. Additional indeterminate vegetation may appear to the left of the putti, just to the right of the left edge of the design.

component.illusobjdesc: Selima lies semi-reclined near the top of the design, on the edge of a lake. She is almost fully human in this design, but has a cat's tail, eyes, and ears. The faint suggestion of whiskers appears on her cheeks, and her hair suggests a cat's fur. She lies on her left side facing forward, her legs extending along the ground to the left. The text box partially hides them. She props her torso up on her left elbow, her left forearm resting on the ground; her left hand is up and open with palm facing left. Her bent right arm is down by her side and drawn back slightly, resting along her hip, but she holds her right hand up and open with palm facing forward. She turns her head slightly right and bends it down to look down at her reflection in the water below, visible directly beneath her as a sketchily outlined mirror image of her head, torso, and arms. Her mouth is curved in a slight smile. Her tail curls upward in an "S" shape above the text panel. She is wearing a long, long-sleeved gown with an empire waist or belt and a thick, furry v-neck collar that suggests a cat's "snowy beard" mentioned in the letterpress text. Her right foot emerges from the folds of her gown to the left of the text box. She has short hair, or longer hair swept up into the bonnet or scarf she is wearing on her head. Her hair may be curly, although lines at her temples also suggest fur.

A pair of cupids or putti (although one is female) embraces near the lower left corner of the design. They are sitting on the floor of the lake. The female of the pair sits on the left, facing forward with her legs bent and drawn up. She leans left but turns her head slightly right. Her right upper arm is visible reaching right. The male of the pair also faces forward with legs bent and drawn up in front of him, but he leans even more sharply left into the female. He twists his torso leftward towards his lover and reaches his slightly bent left arm horizontally to the left, his left wrist resting next to her neck. He turns his head to the left, holding his face close to hers. He has short curly hair, while his companion has long hair falling past her shoulders. One batlike wing or fish-like fin appears to the left of the female lover, and another to the right of the male. Both figures are nude.
