Flowering plants fill the water in the spaces between Selima's reflection and the embracing couple. These plants seem to be rooted in the floor of the lake to the right of the embracing couple. The leftmost plant grows left and up towards the top of the water, supporting leaves and at least three large purple lily-like flowers. One large leaf just above the lovers grows downward and touches the lake floor. A slender blue vine grows near this leftmost plant and twines around its trunk twice before extending upward. Three red berries appear on its branches. Additional branches of this slender blue vine appear entwined with the larger plant growing up the left side of the design. Blue bell-like or lily-like flowers grow from its branches and from branches attached to the larger plant. One large leaf or stalk grows from the lake floor to the right of the leftmost plant. To the right of this leaf or stalk grows another large plant entwined with a smaller vine; together these fill the water below and to the right of the text box, with the vine ending in five spiral loops to the right of the text box. These entwined plants support six pansy-like flowers and one bell-like flower. The rightmost plant grows along the lake floor to the right and then up the right side of the design, consisting of two large stalks or leaves and a slender stem supporting two large bell-like flowers. Additional indeterminate vegetation may appear near the lake floor just to the right of the left side of the design.
Selima lies semi-reclined near the top of the design, along the edge of a lake. The ground on which she lies is covered with grass.
Blue wash below the bank and surrounding the water-plants indicates the water of the lake. A rectangular area left blank along the design's bottom edge indicates the lake floor.

desc.objtitle: Ode on the Death of a Favourite Cat: Page 4, Object 10 (Butlin 335.10)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 5 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Near the top of the design, Selima the cat crouches on a grassy bank or shore beside a lake or body of water. Blue wash below the bank indicates the water of the lake, while wash near the top left corner of the design suggests the sky, perhaps streaked with clouds. Selima is now mostly cat (see previous designs) but has human feet below the cloak she wears. The text panel partly hides her horizontal body, which faces left. She turns her head forward and down to look at the "angel forms," possibly metaphors for fish, in the water below (see the letterpress text). These angel forms swim below and to the left of the text box. They may represent the couple from the previous design. The topmost angel form is female, with the suggestion of breasts, and swims facing left with her body positioned diagonally from top left to lower right. Her arms merge into batlike wings or fins spread roughly horizontally: her left arm disappears into her left fin at the wrist, while lines in her right fin merely suggest a right arm. She is nude and has long curly hair. The lower angel form, also nude, has short curly hair that suggests he may be male. He swims with body horizontal, facing left, and bends his head back to look leftward. His batlike wings or fins are spread wide horizontally from his torso. Fate Atropos, an old woman, sits in the upper right corner of the design. Her lower body extends to the left, but she twists her torso to face forward and to the right. She turns her head back to the left, towards Selima, and bends it down slightly. A rope representing Selima's life is tied in a knot with frayed ends in the upper right corner of the design above the Fate Atropos, an old woman. It extends down the right side of the design and lies across the Fate's lap. She holds this rope with her left hand, and with her right a pair of shears or scissors poised to cut it in two.

component.illusobjdesc: Near the top of the design, Selima the cat crouches on the bank of a lake. She is now mostly cat, (see previous designs) but has human feet below her cloak. The text panel partially hides her horizontal body, which faces left. She turns her head forward and down to look at the "angel forms" in the water below. Both slightly bent forelegs are down, with her right leg positioned slightly in front of the left, which is mostly hidden by the text box. Her cat's feet with visible claws are flat on the side of the bank. Her lower body stretches rightward, and her left leg is extended, slightly bent. A cloak wraps her lower body, below which her human feet on tiptoe appear.

The Fate Atropos, an old woman, sits in the upper right corner of the design. Her lower body extends to the left, but she twists her torso to face forward and to the right. She turns her head back to the left, towards Selima, and bends it down slightly. Her slightly bent left arm is down by her side, and with her thumb and the tip of her fingers on this hand she holds a rope that extends down from the corner of the design above. Her right arm is bent and drawn across her body; she may be resting her right elbow in her lap. She grasps a pair of shears in her right hand, holding them open around the same rope, above her left hand. This rope, representing Selima's life, is tied in a knot with frayed ends in the upper right corner of the design above the old woman. It extends down the right side of the design to Fate's left hand, and then lies leftward across her lap before disappearing into the folds of her skirt. Fate wears a long gown with a high waist and a v-shaped neck that exposes wrinkled, bony cleavage. A cloak or cloth covers her head and falls past her shoulders, puddling on the ground on the right and in her lap on the left. White hair is visible at her left temple. Her mouth is open and her eyebrows drawn together. Wrinkles crease her face, neck, and the back of her right hand.

Two "angel forms" (see the letterpress text) swim below and to the left of the text box. They may represent the couple from the previous design as well as metaphors for fish. The topmost angel form is female, with the suggestion of breasts. She swims facing left with her body positioned diagonally from top left to lower right, but twists her torso to face forward slightly. Her arms merge into batlike wings or fins: her left arm disappears into her left fin at the wrist, while lines in her right fin merely suggest a right arm. She holds her arms and fins out slightly higher than horizontal. Her visible left leg is stretched straight behind her. While her right fin descends at least as far as her pelvic area, the left clearly extends past her left buttock, thigh, and lower leg as far as the ankle. She is nude and has long curly hair falling to her left shoulder. The lower angel form, also nude, has short curly hair that suggests he may be male. He swims with body horizontal, facing left, and bends his head back to look leftward. His legs extend together to the right: his right leg is straight and his left is bent backwards slightly. His batlike wings or fins are spread wide horizontally out from his torso. Both fins extend over his left buttock and thigh; the left also clearly extends down his lower left leg to the ankle.
Green wash across the bank on which Selima the cat crouches suggests that it is covered in grass.

Selima the cat crouches on a grassy bank or shore beside a lake or body of water. Blue wash below the bank indicates the water of the lake. Blue wash near the top left corner of the design suggests the sky, perhaps streaked with clouds.

desc.objtitle: Ode on the Death of a Favourite Cat: Page 5, Object 11 (Butlin 335.11)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil crosses to the left of lines 5 and 8 of the letterpress text. The first cross indicates the line or passage illustrated on this page; the second cross indicates the line or passage illustrated on the next page, Object 12.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Selima the cat, now in human form, plunges upside down into the water at the right side of the design, her body entirely submerged except possibly for the toes on her right foot and the end of her gown. She faces forward with her head bent back so that her exposed throat and chin face the viewer. She holds both arms up vertically by her head, with her forearms bent away from the viewer and mostly hidden. Her left leg is bent at the knee so that her lower leg is not visible, while her bent but extended right leg is fully shown. She is wearing a semi-transparent gown that reveals both breasts and swirls upward between her legs. Undulant and spiral lines on either side of her body suggest the violent parting of the water. "Malignant Fate" (see Blake's text, Object 8) in the shape of an old woman sits at the top of the design, partially hidden by the text panel. Her lower body faces forward and slightly left; the shape of her gown suggests that she is sitting cross-legged. She leans sharply right and down, twisting her torso to face Selima, who is below her to the right. Both arms are outstretched down towards Selima; both hands are open as if she has just pushed Selima into the water. She is wearing a long gown that completely hides her lower body, and a scarf or cloth that covers her head and falls over both shoulders. Two fish in human form swim in parallel below and to the left of the text panel. The leftmost fish is slightly hidden behind the rightmost fish. The bodies of both face left, but both turn their heads to look forward and to the right; both are positioned diagonally from top left to lower right. Both hold their arms up vertically. The rightmost fish, who seems to be male, grasps a spear with a fishhook for a head in his left hand, and a shield with his right hand. The leftmost fish, who may be female, holds a spear with a fishhook head in her right hand. A second hook appears to the right of her right elbow. The top of a third spear with fishhook head is visible above the shield. Both fish wear scaly armor. The leftmost fish also wears a skirt with a thigh-high slit, terminating in a button, on the left side. Their mouths are open. Green wash to the left and right of Fate suggests grass covering the bank on which she sits. Blue wash across the top of the design above Fate suggests the sky. Darker wash below the bank on which Fate sits, and surrounding Selima and the fish, represents the water of the stream. There may be clouds upper left.

component.illusobjdesc: Selima the cat, now in human form, plunges upside down into the water, her body entirely submerged except possibly for the toes on her right foot and the end of her gown. She faces forward with her head bent back so that her exposed throat and chin face the viewer. She holds both arms up vertically by her head, with her forearms bent away from the viewer and mostly hidden; wrapped around her head, her arms entirely obscure her face. Her torso twists left slightly. Her left leg is bent at the knee so that her lower leg is not visible, while her bent but extended right leg is fully shown. She is wearing a semi-transparent gown that reveals both breasts and swirls upward between her legs. At least her right leg seems to emerge partly from the folds of this garment. Undulant and spiral lines on either side of her body suggest the violent parting of the water.

"Malignant Fate" (see Blake's text, Object 8) in the shape of an old woman sits at the top of the design, partially hidden by the text panel. Her lower body faces forward and slightly left; the shape of her gown suggests that she is sitting cross-legged. She leans sharply right and down, twisting her torso to face Selima, who is below her to the right. Her head is bent down slightly as well. Both arms are outstretched down towards Selima. Her left arm is slightly higher than the right. Both hands are open as if she has just pushed Selima into the water; her right palm is out and her left is down. She is wearing a long gown that completely hides her lower body, and a scarf or cloth that covers her head and falls over both shoulders. Her mouth is open with the suggestion of an evil smile.

Two fish in human form swim in parallel below and to the left of the text panel. The leftmost fish is slightly hidden behind the rightmost fish. The bodies of both face left, but both turn their heads to look forward and to the right; both are positioned diagonally from top left to lower right. The fish on the right, which seems to be male, extends his left leg straight down with his foot on tiptoe. His right leg is bent backwards. He holds his straight arms up vertically overhead. With his left arm he grasps a spear with a fishhook for a head, while with his right he holds the handle of a shield that faces away. A strap for the shield encircles his arm near the elbow. He wears full-body armor with plates that resemble scales, especially in the torso area. It covers his head but has an opening for his face. His mouth is open. His hands and feet are likewise encased. The leftmost fish seems to be female, with the suggestion of breasts. Her visible left leg is extended straight down, parallel to her companion's left leg. Her left foot is on tiptoe. She holds both arms vertically overhead, although her left arm is hidden behind the male's shield above the armpit. She grasps a spear with a fishhook head in her right hand; a second hook appears to the right of her elbow. The top of a third spear with fishhook head is visible above the shield. She wears a scaly armored breastplate and a helmet with an opening for her face. Her neck, arms, and hands are encased in armor or fabric (tights), while a skirt that extends past her feet dresses her lower body. This skirt has a thigh-high slit through which her left leg emerges; a button or other ornament adorns the top of the slit. Her mouth is open, and curly hair appears at the edges of the face opening in her helmet.
Green wash to the left and right of Fate suggest grass covering the bank or shore on which she sits.

Blue wash across the top of the design above Fate suggests the sky. Darker wash below the bank or shore on which Fate sits, and surrounding Selima and the fish, represents the water of the stream. There may be clouds upper left.

desc.objtitle: Ode on the Death of a Favourite Cat: Page 6, Object 12 (Butlin 335.12)

objnote.p: The cross, written by Blake in pencil, left of line 8 of the letterpress text on the previous page (Object 11) indicates the line or passage illustrated on this page.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Selima the cat in human form appears to the left of the text panel, partially submerged beneath the water of a lake with her head bent back and her hands held before her as if she is praying. She is dead or dying, having drowned in the water (see the letterpress text). Her body faces roughly forward, with her lower body twisted slightly to the right and her upper body slightly to the left. Her left leg is bent backwards and her right leg is extended, though it curves rightward. She holds her arms up in front of her torso, bent upward with her vertical palms together in the position of prayer. Her head is bent sharply back so that her face is visible from beneath. Her mouth is open and her eyes seem to be raised. Her head, neck, and hands seem to emerge from the water. Her long hair is loose and appears floating in the water beside her left shoulder. She is wearing a semi-transparent gown that floats around her lower body, past her feet, through which her legs and feet are visible. Two goldfish swim in the water facing left below the text box. The lowermost fish is very slightly rightward of the fish above. Green wash across the design just above the text panel suggests grass on the bank or shore beside the stream, perhaps with a hedge, trees, or other indeterminate vegetation near the right edge. Above the bank a small hill or mound stretches from the left edge two-thirds of the way across the design. Dark wash surrounding Selima and the fish below the bank indicates the water of the stream.

component.illusobjdesc: Selima the cat in human form appears to the left of the text panel, partially submerged beneath the water with her head bent back and her hands held before her as if she is praying. She is dead or dying, having drowned in the water (see the letterpress text). Her body faces roughly forward, with her lower body twisted slightly to the right and her upper body slightly to the left. Her left leg is bent backwards and her right leg is extended, though it curves rightward. She holds her arms in front of her torso, bent upward with her vertical palms together in the position of prayer. Her head is bent sharply back so that her face is visible from beneath. Her mouth is open and her eyes seem to be raised. Her head, neck, and hands seem to emerge from the water. Her long hair is loose and appears floating in the water beside her left shoulder. She is wearing a semi-transparent gown that floats around her lower body, past her feet, through which her legs and feet are visible.
Two goldfish swim facing left below the text box. The lowermost fish is very slightly rightward of the fish above.
Green wash across the design just above the text panel suggests grass on the bank or shore beside the stream, perhaps with a hedge, trees, or other indeterminate vegetation near the right edge.

Above the bank next to the water, a small hill or mound stretches from the left edge two-thirds of the way across the design. Dark wash surrounding Selima and the fish below the bank indicates the water of the stream.

desc.objtitle: Ode on a Distant Prospect of Eton College; Page 1: Title Page, Object 13 (Butlin 335.13)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A boy or young man stands facing right on a terrace, leaning backwards against a stone structure, probably part of a wall or building. He stands with his left leg crossed over his right at the knee, his left foot resting on tiptoe. His right arm is bent and drawn back and he rests his lower right arm on the structure. He holds a book that rests on his thigh with his left hand. He is wearing slim shoes and tights with a wide collar; he has long hair that hangs over his shoulders. The stone terrace runs the length of the bottom of the design. A stone wall edges this terrace from the right side of the design to the young man on the left. The setting is probably Windsor Castle. A shadow falls across the wall in the lower right corner of the design. The river Thames runs horizontally across the design. Grassy banks flank it on either side. The spires or towers of Eton College appear nestled in the vegetation on the far bank of the Thames, near the right side of the design. Low hills appear in the distance beyond the Thames, behind Eton College. Undefined vegetation, perhaps trees, surrounds Eton College. Three small crafts appear on the water of the Thames, near the right side of the design. The largest is a sailboat just below Eton College. A much smaller boat with one sail appears to the left, while a small craft without a sail is visible between the two sailboats. Wash above the hills beyond Eton suggests the sky, perhaps streaked with clouds.

component.illusobjdesc: A boy or young man stands facing right on a terrace, leaning backwards against a stone structure, probably part of a wall or building. He stands with his right leg extended and his left leg bent over his right at the knee, his left foot resting on tiptoe. Both feet cast small shadows, but the shadow from his flexed left foot is slightly longer. His right arm is bent and drawn back, his lower right arm lying on a stone of the balustrade and his right hand dangling, fingers loose. His left lower arm and wrist appear next to his left hip. He holds a book that rests on his thigh with this hand. He is wearing slim shoes and tights with a wide collar; he has long hair that hangs over his shoulders.

The youth leans against a stone structure, probably part of a wall or building. He may be standing on a terrace defined by the low stone wall extending right to left below the text panel. The setting is probably Windsor Castle.
A shadow falls across the wall in the lower right corner of the design.
The spires or towers of Eton College appear nestled in the vegetation on the far bank of the Thames, near the right side of the design.

The river Thames runs horizontally across the design. It is visible just above the top of the terrace balustrade. Grassy banks flank it on either side. Low hills appear in the distance beyond the Thames, behind Eton College.

Three small crafts appear on the water of the Thames, near the right side of the design. The largest is a sailboat just below Eton College. A much smaller boat with one sail appears to the left. A small craft without a sail is visible between the two sailboats.
Wash along the banks of the Thames suggests grass. Undefined vegetation, perhaps trees, surrounds Eton College.
Wash above the hills beyond Eton College suggests the sky, perhaps streaked with clouds.

desc.objtitle: Ode on a Distant Prospect of Eton College; Page 2: Blank Page Bearing List of Titles, Object 14 (Butlin 335.14)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A running boy holding the string of a kite appears in the lower left corner of the design. He runs to the left, leaning forward with his legs spread wide. He twists his torso away so that his upper body is seen from behind, but bends his head up and back to look up and to the right at his kite. His right arm is extended and raised at 135 degrees, and he holds the string of the kite with this hand; his left arm is not visible. He wears long-sleeved tights with stockings below the knee. A collar appears at the back of his neck. He wears a shoe on his left foot, while his right foot is mostly not pictured, though the bare heel appears. He has short, curly hair. The kite flies in the upper right corner of the design. Since the boy in the lower left corner holds its string, this string runs diagonally across the middle of the design from upper right to lower left. Below the boy's left shoulder the string extends rightward past the boy and puddles on the ground beneath the text box to the right. Blue wash across most of the top of the design and surrounding the kite in the upper right corner suggests the sky, perhaps with clouds.

component.illusobjdesc: A running boy holding the string of a kite appears in the lower left corner of the design. He runs to the left, leaning forward with his legs spread wide: his weight rests momentarily on his bent right leg, while his bent left leg is extended horizontally backwards. He twists his torso away so that his upper body is seen from behind, but bends his head up and back to look up and to the right at his kite. His right arm is extended and raised at 135 degrees, and he holds the string of the kite with this hand; his left arm is not visible. He wears long-sleeved tights that end at the knee, below which stockings cover his legs. A collar appears at the back of his neck. He wears a shoe on his left foot. His right foot is mostly not pictured, though the bare heel appears. He has short, curly hair.

The kite flies in the upper right corner of the design. The boy in the lower left corner holds its string, so that this string runs diagonally across the middle of the design from upper right to lower left. Below his left shoulder the string extends rightward past the boy and puddles on the ground beneath the text box to the right.
Blue wash across most of the top of the design and surrounding the kite in the upper right corner suggests the sky, perhaps with clouds.

lg.l: Ode on a distant prospect
of Eton College
Design
1 Windsor terrace, a Boy contemplating,
a distant view of the Eton College.
2. A Boy flying a Kite
3 Two Boys wandering in the woods
by Eton College. The Shade of
Henry the Sixth is seen among
the trees -
"Henrys holy shade." line 4The words are quoted from page [55] of the letterpress text (Object 15).
4. "Say Father Thames for thou hast seenLines 13-15 are quoted, with minor variations, from page 56 of the letterpress text (Object 16).
Full many a sprightly race
Who foremost &c"
5 ."The Captive linnet"Lines 16-18 are quoted, with minor variations, from page 57 of the letterpress text (Object 17).
The rolling circle".
murmuring labours" &c
6 . Yet see how all around them waitLines 19-20 are quoted, with minor variations, from page 58 of the letterpress text (Object 18).
The vultures of the MindBlake has written a capital "M" over a lower-case "m" in the final word ("Mind").
7. Ambition this shall tempt to riseLines 21-22 are quoted, with minor variations, from page 59 of the letterpress text (Object 19).
Then whirl the wretch from high &c
Design
8. Lo in the Vale of Years beneathLines 24-25 are quoted, with minor variations, from page 60 of the letterpress text (Object 20).
The painful family of Death
9. Where Ignorance is blissLines 26-27 are quoted, with minor variations, from page 61 of the letterpress text (Object 21).
Tis folly to be wise
10 Boys playing at Top.

desc.objtitle: Ode on a Distant Prospect of Eton College; Page 3: Beginning of Poem, Object 15 (Butlin 335.15)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 7 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The "Shade" of Henry the Sixth (see Blake's text, Object 14), who founded Eton College, appears at the right side of the design. He faces left, hovering just above the ground, and holding a large open book out in front of him. He bends backward slightly and bends his head down, eyes lowered, to look at the book. He wears a long gown and a crown, and has curly, rather long hair that extends backwards from his head. An aura of light surrounds his head. Two boys or young men, presumably students at Eton, stand below the text panel. The one on the right faces forward and slightly right, but turns his head to look towards the left. He holds an open book out in front of his torso. The student on the left stands or steps facing right, with his left leg forward of the right, which is extended backwards. He turns his head to look away. His right arm is down straight by his side, and with his right hand he holds the spine of a large book or folder tucked under his forearm. Both students wear long-sleeved shirts and breeches, stockings, and shoes, as well as the floor- length black robes of Eton with slits below the shoulders for their arms to emerge. The student on the right also wears a mortar board with a tassel. Wash across the bottom of the design suggests grass. Bushes or low trees, lush with leaves, form a backdrop across the design for the two students and Henry the Sixth. Several trunks are visible to the left of the students and to the left of Henry. The roof of Eton College Chapel, with its characteristic spires, appears above the vegetation behind Henry at the right side of the design. Wash across the top third of the design suggests the sky, perhaps streaked with clouds.

component.illusobjdesc: The "Shade" of Henry the Sixth (see Blake's text, Object 14), who founded Eton College, appears at the right side of the design (see the letterpress text). He faces left, hovering just above the ground. His left arm is down by his side, bent forward to support one side of a book he holds open horizontally in front of his torso. His right thumb and part of his right wrist are visible supporting the other side of the open book. Henry bends backward slightly, and bends his head to look down at the book. His eyes are down as well, and he may be reading. He wears a long gown that merges almost indistinguishably with his figure at neck and wrists, though his dangling left foot emerges clearly from the folds of gown's hem hanging below. He has curly, rather long hair that extends backward from his head. He wears a crown. An aura of light surrounds his head.

Two boys or young men, presumably students at Eton, stand below the text panel. The one on the right faces forward and slightly right, but turns his head to look towards the left. He stands with his weight on his left foot, with his right leg bent and his right foot on tiptoe, in a slightly contrapposto position. His left arm is down by his side, but his right arm is bent forward at the elbow. He holds a small open book in front of him with his right hand. The student on the left stands or steps facing right, with his left leg forward of the right, which is extended backwards. His right foot is on tiptoe. He turns his head to look away. His right arm is down straight by his side, and with his right hand he holds the spine of a large book or folder tucked under his forearm. Both students wear long-sleeved shirts and breeches that end below the knee, below which they wear stockings and shoes. Both wear the floor-length black robes of Eton, with slits below the shoulders for their arms to emerge. Both have short, curly hair. The student on the right wears a mortar board with a tassel. His position also allows the wide, v-shaped, collared neckline of his shirt to show.

Wash across the bottom of the design suggests grass. Bushes or low trees, lush with leaves, form a backdrop across the design for the two students and Henry the Sixth. Several trunks are visible to the left of the students and to the left of Henry.
The roof of Eton College Chapel, with its characteristic spires, appears above the vegetation behind Henry VI at the right side of the design. Two of its arched windows are also visible.
Wash across the top third of the design suggests the sky, perhaps streaked with clouds.

desc.objtitle: Ode on a Distant Prospect of Eton College: Page 4, Object 16 (Butlin 335.16)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 12 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Father Thames reclines on the river he personifies, near the bottom of the design. Facing forward and slightly left, he leans right and rests his left arm on an overturned urn. The waters of the Thames pour from the urn's open mouth. Father Thames' lower body seems to face left, although only his left thigh is visible, extending left with knee bent. His right arm is extended leftward, slightly bent, with his right wrist seeming to rest on his left leg below the knee. He is nude but has long white hair and a long white beard that merge to cover much of his torso and lower body before finally drifting into the river's currents. He wears a crown or wreath of oak leaves and two acorns on his head. The water of the river Thames flows from the urn at the right leftward across the bottom of the design. The near bank appears in the lower right corner and stretches leftward halfway across the bottom of the design. The far bank of the river shows between the left side of the design and Father Thames' knee. A small hill rises above the far bank. The crenelated battlements and walls of Windsor Castle are visible above this hill. This edifice is clearly delineated to the left of the text panel. It seems to continue to the right of the text panel, where it becomes a more generalized, organic shape reminiscent of a mound or hill. Six boys or young men swim in the Thames or relax on its near bank at the bottom of the design. One sits on the top of the urn, just in front of Father Thames' left arm. This boy faces forward but turns his head slightly left, sitting with his bent right leg drawn up and his left leg extending down along the curve of the urn to the right. This boy is wearing tights. Two nude boys sit side by side on the bank of the river, with the boy on the left slightly in front of the boy on the right. Both hunch over with heads bent down. The rightmost boy sits with left leg drawn up; the boy on the left crosses his left leg over his right. To the left of the boys seated on the bank stands or walks a fourth boy who is shedding his clothes overhead. He faces away and to the left, standing or walking with his straight right leg slightly forward and his bent left leg extended backward, his left foot on tiptoe. He has raised both arms overhead, and the clothing he is removing wraps his arms, hiding the left below the elbow and the right just past the shoulder. This material billows in the air to the left and hangs down past the boy's torso on the right. He is otherwise nude. Two nude boys play in the water below Father Thames' leg. The boy on the right is visible from the buttocks up; he faces away and to the left but may be turning his head to the right. He leans forward and stretches his arms out horizontally. Only the head and arms of the leftmost boy are visible above the water. He faces forward with arms outstretched horizontally just above the surface of the water, and turns his head to look up to the right. His hair may be long, while all the other boys have short, curly hair. A sailboat floats on the Thames, just to the left of Father Thames' knee. The near bank of the river is covered with grass; wash on the far bank suggests it may be grassy as well, as is the hill rising beyond. Leafy trees and bushy indeterminate vegetation lines the hill and the bank. Several tree trunks are visible just to the right of the sailboat. Wash in the top half of the design suggests the sky, perhaps with clouds.

component.illusobjdesc: Father Thames reclines on the river he personifies, near the bottom of the design. With his torso facing forward and slightly left, he leans right. His left arm is bent and extended forward slightly, with elbow and lower arm resting on an overturned urn. The waters of the Thames pour from the urn's open mouth. Father Thames' left hand dangles, with his extended left index finger visible to the left of the urn. His lower body seems to face left, although only his left thigh is visible, extending left with knee bent. His right arm is extended leftward, slightly bent. His right wrist seems to be resting on his left leg below the knee, and his right hand dangles. The loosely cupped fingers of his right hand may touch the water of the river. He turns his head down to the right. He is nude, but has long white hair and a long white beard that merge to cover much of his torso and lower body before finally drifting into the river's currents. He wears a crown or wreath of oak leaves and two acorns on his head.

Father Thames reclines propped against an urn that appears near the lower right corner of the design. It is tipped over towards the viewer, so that its inner contents are visible. The water of the Thames flows out of the urn.

Six boys or young men swim in the Thames or relax on its near bank at the bottom of the design. One sits on the top of the urn, just in front of Father Thames' left arm. This boy faces forward but turns his head slightly left. He sits with his bent right leg drawn up and resting on the urn in front of him, and his left leg extending down along the curve of the urn to the right. His right arm, more difficult to see, seems to be drawn in front of his body, resting on his lap and along his lower right leg. His left arm, slightly bent, lies along the top of his left thigh. He may be holding a book, which may be partly open, in his left hand. He is wearing tights with a wide collar, and has short curly hair. Two nude boys with short curly hair sit side by side on the bank of the river, facing left. The boy on the left is slightly in front of the other. He sits with his right leg bent and down, foot resting on tiptoe, and his left leg bent and crossed over his right knee. His left foot and most of his lower left leg are hidden. He hunches over with his head lowered and his left arm drawn forward; this limb is hidden behind his legs below the midpoint of his upper arm. He has prominent, well-defined muscles, especially in his back and abdominal area. The boy to the right also hunches over slightly with lowered head. Unlike the other seated boy, this boy's eyes are lowered. His left leg is bent and drawn up, foot flat on the ground near his left buttock. His left arm is entirely hidden behind this leg below the shoulder. To the left of the boys seated on the bank stands or walks a fourth boy who is shedding his clothing overhead. He faces away and to the left, standing or walking with his straight right leg slightly forward and his bent left leg extended backward, his left foot on tiptoe. He has raised both arms overhead, with his more visible left arm slightly bent. The clothing he is removing wraps his arms, hiding the left below the elbow and the right just past the shoulder; this material billows in the air to the left and hangs down past the boy's torso to the right. The shape of his clothing suggests he has drawn his hands together overhead, grasping the material from the inside. He is otherwise nude, and has short, curly hair. Two nude boys play in the water below Father Thames' leg. The boy on the right is visible from the buttocks up; he faces left and away, but may be turning his head to the right. He leans forward and stretches his arms out horizontally, with his hands extended with palms down. He is nude with well-defined musculature in his back, and he has short curly hair. Only the head and arms of the leftmost boy are visible above the water. He faces forward with arms outstretched horizontally just above the surface of the water, and hands extended with palms down. He turns his head to look up to the right. His hair, which may be long, hangs down over his shoulders as if wet.
A sailboat floats or sails on the Thames, just to the left of Father Thames' knee.

The waters of the river Thames flows from the urn at the right leftward across the bottom of the design. The near bank appears in the lower right corner and stretches leftward halfway across the bottom of the design. The far bank of the river shows between the left side of the design and Father Thames' knee. A small hill rises above this bank. The buildings of Windsor Castle appear on the left side of the text panel; where they seem to continue to the right of the text panel these more generalized shapes suggest a mound or hill as well as the castle.
Wash in the top half of the design suggests the sky, perhaps with clouds.

The crenelated battlements and walls of Windsor Castle are visible above the hill rising from the bank of the river. This edifice is clearly delineated to the left of the text box. It seems to continue to the right of the text panel, where it becomes a more generalized, organic shape reminiscent of a mound or hill.

The near bank of the river is covered with grass; wash on the far bank suggests it may be grassy as well, as is the hill rising beyond. Leafy trees and bushy indeterminate vegetation lines the hill and the bank. Several tree trunks are visible just to the right of the sailboat.

desc.objtitle: Ode on a Distant Prospect of Eton College: Page 5, Object 17 (Butlin 335.17)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 4 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the lower left corner of the design, a boy or young man is rolling a hoop along a path that stretches across most of the bottom of the design, except where it is hidden behind the tree on the right. The boy faces and runs left, though his torso is turned slightly away towards the hoop. Leaning forward with head up, he puts his weight on his bent right leg; his bent left leg is extended behind him. His right arm is drawn back and he holds the stick with which he rolls the hoop in this hand. Another boy or young man appears to read a book while walking rightward in the lower right corner of the design. Facing to the right and slightly forward, his straight left leg is slightly forward, while his slightly bent right leg is extended backward. With both hands he holds a book open before him. He bends his head slightly and lowers his eyes as if reading. A large tree grows up the right side of the design. Rooted in the lower right corner, the massive trunk of this large tree extends beyond the design's right edge as it grows upward to the top right corner. Near the top of the design, two branches split off from the trunk to grow left across the top of the design. The topmost branch bears leaves and several smaller leafy branches. The lower branch is bare of leaves, and also splits into several smaller branches near the left edge of the design. Vines climb the trunk of the tree near its base, some bearing ivy leaves. A boy lies along the lower, bare tree branch. He lies face down, with his head near the trunk at the right, and hugs the branch with his legs. His left leg is extended along the far side of the branch, with his left foot hooked over the branch, and his right leg is bent and drawn up slightly with his right foot hooked over the branch from the near side. He holds on to the tree trunk with his left arm and leans down, reaching with his extended right arm towards a girl at the base of the tree. He is holding a nest with three fledgling birds in this hand; each little bird stretches its neck upward and holds its beak open. The girl or young woman who stands at the base of the tree trunk faces away and reaches up to the boy above. She stands on her tiptoes, her left leg extended backward. She is raising both arms vertically overhead toward the birds' nest that the boy above holds. Both of her hands are open and outstretched, with palms up. She tilts her head back so that her head and face are seen from above. A hill appears in the background, rising from the edge of the path or road running across the bottom of the design. Two large trees grown on this hill, one appearing on either side of the text panel. Each has a large trunk and thick leaves. Bushes or other indeterminate vegetation grows to the left of the tree on the right, and between the leftmost tree and the left edge of the design. Grass covers the hill to the path or road, and appears on the near side of the path above the bottom of the design. Two small, apparently male figures appear in the background near the leftmost tree, just to the left of the lower left corner of the text panel. The figure on the left faces right and stands or walks to the right. The figure on the right stands leaning against the trunk of the tree to the right, facing left. Blue wash in the upper half of the design suggests the sky. The boy running with a hoop and his hoop both cast shadows on the path. Shadows also appear along the lower edge of the path and on the path where it is visible between the tree and the right leg of the boy walking with a book. This boy casts his own shadow, which falls towards the lower right corner of the design. A shadow may cover part of the hill below the tree on the right as well.

component.illusobjdesc: A boy or young man is rolling a hoop in the lower left corner of the design. He faces and runs left, though his torso is turned slightly away towards the hoop. Leaning forward with head up, he puts his weight on his bent right leg; his bent left leg is extended behind him. His right arm is drawn back and extended behind him at about 45 degrees, and he holds the end of the stick with which he propels the hoop in this hand. His left arm is down by his side, bent forward. His hair, in a long plait, flies behind his head. He wears tights, or a shirt and pants, and a pair of slim shoes. The back of a wide collar appears at his neck, seen from behind. The hoop he rolls appears behind him. The hoop and his right foot cast a united shadow.
The boy rolling a hoop in the lower left corner rolls it along a path or road that stretches across most of the bottom of the design, except where it is hidden behind the tree on the right.

A boy or young man appears to read an open book while walking rightward in the lower right corner of the design. Facing to the right and slightly forward, his straight left leg is slightly forward, while his slightly bent right leg is extended backward. His right foot is on tiptoe. Both of his arms are down by his side and bent forward at the elbow. With both hands he holds a book open before him. He bends his head slightly and lowers his eyes as if reading. He has short curly hair, and wears shoes, stockings, and tights that end below the knee. His tights have a wide v-necked collar. He is casting a large shadow on the ground; it falls towards the corner of the design.

A girl or young woman stands in front of a large tree trunk near the right side of the design, facing away and reaching up towards a boy on the tree branch above. She stands on her tiptoes, her left leg extended backward. She is raising both arms vertically overhead towards the birds' nest that the boy above holds. Both hands are open and outstretched, with palms up. Her torso bends right slightly; she may be resting her right arm and/or hand on the tree trunk. She tilts her head back so that her head and face are seen from above. She is barefoot and wears a long gown with a belt or a defined waistline. Her hair is drawn back into a bun. Her right torso is in shadow, and her left foot may also cast a shadow that merges with the shadow of the reading boy to the left.

A boy lies along a tree branch near the upper right corner of the design. He lies face down, with his head near the trunk at the right, and hugs the branch with his legs. His left leg is extended along the far side of the branch, with his foot hooked over the branch and casting a shadow on its bark. His right leg is bent and drawn up slightly, his foot hooked over the branch from the near side. He leans down, reaching with his extended right arm towards the girl at the base of the tree. He is holding a nest with fledgling birds in this hand, palm up. His left shoulder and upper arm is raised towards the trunk of the tree above his head; this arm is hidden below the elbow, but four fingers of his left hand appear grasping the tree branch above. He holds his head up to look at the girl beneath. He is wearing shoes, stockings, and tights with a wide collar visible at the back of his neck. He has short curly hair. There are three fledglings in the next, each stretching its neck upward and holding its beak open.

Two small, apparently male figures appear in the background, just to the left of the lower left corner of the text panel. The figure on the left faces right and stands or walks to the right. This figure walks or stands with his weight on his straight left leg and his bent right leg extended backward. His visible right arm is down by his side and bent across his chest. He may be wearing tights. His hair is difficult to discern. The figure on the right stands leaning against the trunk of the tree to the right, facing left. He stands with his legs together, angled away from the trunk, and his visible left arm lowered and bent behind his back. He rests his back and this arm against the trunk of the tree. He may be wearing tights or a shirt and pants, and seems to have long plaited hair falling down his back.

A large tree grows up the right side of the design. Rooted in the lower right corner, the massive trunk of this large tree extends beyond the design's right edge as it grows upward to the top right corner. Near the top of the design, two branches split off from the trunk to grow left across the top of the design. The topmost branch bears leaves and several smaller leafy branches. The lower branch is bare of leaves, and supports the boy who holds a nest of birds in one lowered hand. This branch splits into several smaller branches near the left edge of the design. Vines climb the tree trunk near the girl standing at its base. The vines on the left of the girl bear several ivy leaves, while the vines on the right of the girl are bare of leaves.
A hill appears in the background, rising from the edge of the path or road running across the bottom of the design.

Two large trees grow on the hill in the background, one on each side of the text panel. Each has a large trunk and thick leaves. Bushes or other indeterminate vegetation grows to the left of the tree on the right, and between the leftmost tree and the left edge of the design. Grass covers the hill to the path or road, and appears on the near side of the path above the bottom of the design.
Blue wash in the upper half of the design suggests the sky.

In addition to the shadows cast by both boys near the bottom of the design, a shadow may cover part of the hill below the tree on the right. Shadows also appear along the lower edge of the path and on the path where it is visible between the tree and the right leg of the boy walking right near the lower right corner of the design.

desc.objtitle: Ode on a Distant Prospect of Eton College: Page 6, Object 18 (Butlin 335.18)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 18 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Children play across the bottom of the design while the spectre-like representations of "ills to come" (see the letterpress text) skulk behind them. A girl holding a doll stands facing right near the right side of the design. The transparent figure of Despair, behind her, wraps both hands around the girl's lower body. Despair's face appears facing forward above her left hand, with tears cascading down both cheeks. A girl playing with a ball stands or walks facing away and slightly left just to the left of the girl holding the doll. This girl raises both arms up vertically, her open hands raised above her head, and the ball suspended in the air between her hands. To the left of the girl with the ball, a boy leaps or strides forward, facing forward with his straight right leg down and his straight left leg extended behind him. He raises both arms out and up at 135 degrees, and he holds the brim of a hat in his right hand. A large creature lies on the ground behind him, representing Anger. Facing forward and to the left, it lies with its head on the ground between two front feet or paws, both of which have visible claws. A wide ruff around its neck suggests a lion's mane. The transparent human-like torso of Avarice appears above Anger and behind the leaping boy, clasping the boy around the waist. Avarice's torso faces forward, but he turns his head to the left. He wraps his right arm around the boy. His body fades into Anger, below, who can be seen through Avarice's right arm. A boy carrying a cricket bat walks to the right in the lower left corner, facing right but turning his head to look forward and to the left. His left arm is down by his side and he grasps the end of the bat with this hand. The human-like figure kneeling on the ground and facing right at the left edge of the design represents Jealousy. He bends his torso rightward and leans on his extended right arm, with his right hand flat on the ground. A snake coils its body around his lifted left arm. Gluttony appears as a pig's head visible to the right of Jealousy's lower body, facing right. The head is lowered so that its snout touches the ground. Three vulture-like beasts fly or hover in a row above the children, facing left. Together the three form a nightmarish mass of wings and claws out of which three heads clearly emerge. The text panel partially hides the body of the foremost vulture (seemingly female), who leans or bends down with human-like arms outstretched toward the boy with a bat, below. One drooping breast hangs near the top of her right arm. A second vulture's head appears to the left of this female, also looking down. A third head looks left, positioned to the left of the middle head. Three wings appear above the line of vultures, and multiple feet with claws are visible between their heads and the rightmost vulture's arms. A snake emerges from the right side of the text box, curving rightward and down to hang above the heads of the children. Five birds or winged animals fly in the sky in the top half of the design. Two to the left of the vulture-like creatures, and one above near the top of the design, are simple schematic outlines suggesting the figure of a bat or bird. The final two, just above the leftmost wing of the vultures, are more clearly delineated as birds with open beaks and feathered wings. The wide mouth of what seems to be a cave yawns near the lower right corner of the design. It is dark with shadow. If this is a cave, then the hill in which it appears may extend leftward across the bottom half of the design. The coloring of the hill and the ground on which the children play suggests that both are covered with grass. Shadows fall on the ground to the right of the girl tossing a ball, the right foot of the boy leaping forward, and the right foot of the boy holding the bat. Wash in the top third of the design suggests the sky, perhaps at sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: A girl holding a doll stands facing right near the right side of the design. Her torso is turned slightly forward. Both arms are down and bent forward, and she holds the doll with her right hand and supports its back with her left. She bends her head down slightly towards it. The doll sits facing left, its straight legs extended along the girl's right forearm. Its visible left arm is down. It may be nude or may be wearing a gown, and it appears to have long hair. The girl also has long hair falling over her shoulders and forward past her face on the side furthest from the viewer. She is wearing a long gown that puddles on the ground, obscuring her feet.

A girl playing with a ball stands or walks facing away and slightly left near the right side of the design. Her bent left leg is extended backward, her left foot on tiptoe. She reaches both arms up vertically, her open hands raised above her head with the palms facing up and out. A small ball appears in the air above her hands. She bends her head back sharply to look up. She is wearing a long gown that falls to the ground, although her left foot emerges from beneath its folds. Her long curly hair falls down her back.

A boy leaps or strides forward just to the left of the girl playing with a ball, near the bottom of the design. He faces forward, with his straight right leg down and his straight left leg extended behind him. His right foot is on tiptoe. He turns his torso slightly to the left and holds both arms out and up at 135 degrees. His left hand is open with the palm up. He holds the brim of a hat in his right hand, which is also palm up. His head is tilted to the right, and his mouth is open. He has short, curly hair and wears shoes, stockings, and tights or a shirt and breeches. His clothing has a wide, v-necked collar.

A boy carrying a cricket bat walks to the right in the lower left corner. He faces right but turns his head to look forward and left. His bent left leg is forward, and his bent right leg extended backward. His right foot is on tiptoe. He has bent his right arm across his chest and may be holding his left upper arm with his right hand. His left arm is down by his side, bent slightly forward; he grasps the end of the bat with this hand. The bat may be dragging on the ground on the far side of the boy. He is wearing shoes, stockings, and tights with a belt or defined waistline. The wide lapels of his collar are visible. A drawstring is tied at his right knee. He has long hair left loose. His mouth is open and his eyebrows drawn together and up, as if in an expression of concern, fear, or surprise.

The transparent figure of Despair wraps both hands around the girl holding a doll in the lower right corner of the design. The fingers of Despair's right hand wrap the girl's gown from the left, near the ground. A wavy line to the left of these fingers suggests the cuff of a sleeve. The fingers of Despair's left hand clasp the girl's gown near her pelvis; this hand extends to the right where Despair's forearm is visible just to the left of the right side of the design. Despair's face appears facing forward above her left hand, with her forehead creased and her eyebrows drawn together in an expression of sorrow. Her eyes are closed and her mouth is open. Four large tears cascade down each cheek. She seems to be wearing a hood or other head covering on her head, pushed back slightly so that the part in her hair appears. Long hair falls down past her chin on the right. Lines and shadow below her left hand suggest her clothing.

The human-like figure kneeling on the ground and facing right at the left edge of the design represents Jealousy. He seems to be male. He bends his torso rightward and twists it slightly forward, so that his head is seen mostly from above. He extends his left arm away from the viewer, at about 135 degrees. A snake wraps its body twice around his left forearm and once around his left hand. Jealousy grasps the snake with at least his thumb and middle finger, pointing his index finger upward. The snake's head, with mouth open and (possibly forked) tongue extended, appears to the right of Jealousy's hand. Jealousy's right arm is down and his right hand rests flat on the ground. This arm is slightly bent, and twisted so that the base of his right hand is forward. His visible right leg is bent and he rests his weight on knee and lower leg. Scales cover his breast while larger armor-like plates appear on his lower torso. He seems to be nude. Although he has a human-like face, his ears extend on either side of his head like small horns. He is bald, and two tiny snakes with open mouths and extended tongues form his tiara-like head ornament.

Gluttony appears as a pig's head visible to the right of Jealousy's lower body, near the lower left corner of the design. The pig's head faces to the right, and is lowered so that its snout touches the ground. Its eyes are closed.

A large creature lies on the ground behind the boy who skips forward holding his hat aloft. This creature represents Anger. Facing forward and to the left, it lies with its head on the ground between two front feet or paws, both of which have visible claws. It scowls with heavy eyebrows drawn together, and looks upward out of the corner of its eyes, as if toward the boy or the girl to his right. A wide ruff around its neck suggests a lion's mane.

The transparent, human-like, male figure of Avarice clasps the leaping boy who holds his hat aloft. Avarice's torso is visible facing forward, but he turns his head to the left so that his face is seen in profile. His right arm is bent up across his chest, and he wraps this arm around the boy, with his hand holding the child's torso on the right side. Avarice's left shoulder is visible to the left of the girl tossing a ball. His transparent body fades into Anger, below, who can be seen through Avarice's right arm. Avarice has tiny horns atop his mostly bald head, which grows just a few wisps of hair appearing in front of his visible left ear. He may have a wisp of a beard under his chin as well. He seems to be nude.

Three vulture-like beasts fly or hover in a row above the children. The two vultures to the right face left and slightly forward, while the head of the leftmost vulture faces left. Together the three form a nightmarish mass of wings and claws out of which the three heads clearly emerge. The text panel partially hides the body of the foremost vulture (seemingly female), who leans or bends down with human-like arms outstretched toward the boy with a bat, below. Her hands appear, palms facing inward, to either side of the boy's head and shoulders. She holds the index finger of her right hand separate from the others, pointing. Her left arm is visible only below the elbow, but her slightly bent right arm is visible all the way up to the shoulder, before which a drooping breast hangs. Her head is clearly birdlike, with wide round eyes and a beak. Curly hair grows from the crown and hangs on either side of her face, merging with straighter locks of hair or feathers on the right side of her head. Bony shoulder blades appear above her head just to the left of the text panel. A second vulture-like creature's head looms to the left of this female, also looking down. It has a similar beak and round eyes, but where the first vulture has hair, this vulture has two horn-like growths. Its upper body extends upward to the right, as if it is peering down with outstretched neck. The large wing drawn forward above its head may belong to this vulture. Another wing above and to the left of the text panel may belong to this second vulture, or to the first. The head of a third vulture appears to the left of the second. This vulture's head looks left, with mouth open wide and long tongue visible. It is less clearly delineated than the first two. Toes with claws appear to the left of and below the middle vulture's beak and to the left and right of the foremost vulture's right upper arm. A large, feathered wing that may belong to the foremost vulture arches up from the upper right corner of the text box, while additional wing or tail feathers appear to the right of the text box. A foot with at least two clawed toes emerges to the right of the text box as well.

Five small birds or winged animals fly in the sky in the top half of the design. Two to the left of the vulture-like creatures, and one above near the top of the design, are simple schematic outlines suggesting the figure of a bird or bat. The final two, just above the leftmost wing of the vultures, are more clearly delineated as birds with open beaks and feathered wings. A clawed foot appears beneath the near wing of the largest and/or nearest bird.
A snake emerges from the right side of the text panel, curving rightward and down to hang above the heads of the children on the right.

The wide mouth of what seems to be a cave yawns near the lower right corner of the design. It is dark with shadow. If this is a cave, then the hill in which it appears may extend leftward across the bottom half of the design.
The coloring of the hill and the ground on which the children play suggests that both are covered with grass.
Shadows fall on the ground to the right of the girl tossing a ball, the right foot of the boy leaping forward, and the right foot of the boy holding the bat.
Wash in the top third of the design suggests the cloudy sky, perhaps at sunrise or sunset.

desc.objtitle: Ode on a Distant Prospect of Eton College: Page 7, Object 19 (Butlin 335.19)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 10 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The personification of "Ambition" (see Blake's text, Object 14) as a king or ruler sits in the upper right corner, atop a rocky cliff or hill that dominates the design. It rises from the lower left corner into the upper right corner. Facing left, he bends forward over his lap and holds his right arm out in front of him, bent upward. He clasps a leafy laurel(?) branch with the fingers of his right hand, extending it with a flourish as if presenting or displaying it to the young man below and to the left, scaling the crag. Ambition's bent left arm is down and drawn back, and he grasps a scepter with this hand. He is wearing a crown and a cape draped over his shoulders, on top of a gown or robe. A young man crawls up the crag near the left side of the design, facing right. His torso is roughly horizontal, but he tilts his head back to look up to the right. His left leg is bent and drawn up beneath him, and his right leg extended behind him; he is braced on his bent right arm. He is wearing tights or breeches and a shirt with a wide collar. A second young man is falling headfirst from the top of the crag on which Ambition sits. His body faces forward but he bends left at the waist, so that his legs and arms both extend diagonally leftward. He turns his head to the left and tips it back; his mouth is open and his eyes are raised to look down. His legs are spread and bent, and his arms are raised at 135 degrees. He is wearing transparent tights. A cloth or other drapery billows upward between his legs. A third young man, who has presumably already fallen from the top of the rocky crag, lies on his back in a cruciform posture near the lower right corner of the design at the base of the crag. He may be dead or dying. His head is toward the viewer, tipped back so that his face is visible upside down. His eyes are half closed. His arms and legs are spread wide, and his right leg and arm rest on a nearby rock or stone outcropping. The personified figures of Scorn and Infamy kneel together in the lower left corner. Infamy, an old woman, kneels in front. She faces forward with her lowered head turned slightly right. She hunches forward and extends her left arm at 45 degrees to the right, pointing with her left index finger at the young man to the right. Her right arm, at her side, is bent and drawn back slightly. She holds her right hand up and points with her right index finger toward the young man ascending the crag near the left side of the design. Her mouth is open in a "grinning" (see the letterpress text) smile. She is balding but has bedraggled gray hair falling from behind her ear over her shoulder. The neckline of the gown she wears falls open to reveal part of her left breast. Scorn kneels behind and to the left of her, his body mostly hidden by hers. He leans slightly left and tilts his head back to look up and to the right. His eyes are widened and his mouth is open to show his upper teeth. He has short, curly hair and a mustache. He holds his left arm out at 45 degrees to the right, pointing with his index finger at the young man in the lower right corner. Heavy shadow appears on the ground and the base of the crag between Scorn and Infamy and the left edge of the design. The ground along the bottom of the plate seems to be stone as well. Wash above the rocky crag suggests the sky, perhaps at sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: The personification of "Ambition" (see Blake's text, Object 14) as a king or ruler sits atop a cliff in the upper right corner, facing left. His visible left leg is bent. He bends forward over his lap and holds his right arm out in front of him, bent upward. He clasps a leafy laurel(?) branch with the fingers of his right hand, palm upward, extending it with a flourish as if presenting or displaying it to the young man below, and holds his head up to look to the left. His bent left arm is down and drawn back. He grasps the base of a scepter with this hand; the scepter's staff rests along his lower arm. His right index finger points along the base of the staff. The scepter has a fleur-de-lis ornament for its head. He is wearing a long-sleeved gown or robe, and some folds of its skirt drape down the left side of the crag on which he sits. Alternatively, this may be his extended right leg. He also wears a cape that is fastened with a button, brooch, or other ornament over his left shoulder, and falls to puddle on the rock behind him. His hair seemes to be braided and tucked up beneath the crown on his head.

A young man scales the crag near the left side of the design, facing right. His torso is roughly horizontal, but he tilts his head back to look up to the right. His left leg is bent and drawn up beneath him, with his knee and the toes of his right foot resting on the rock surface. His slightly bent right leg is extended behind him; his right knee rests on the crag while his foot dangles below, on tiptoe. He has drawn his bent right arm back and braced it for support so that his upper arm is horizontal and his right hand rests palm down, his fingers grasping the edge of the rock. His left arm reaches horizontally to the right, but is hidden behind the rock below the elbow. He is wearing tights or breeches and a shirt with a wide v-necked collar. A button fastens his breeches at his right knee. He has short, curly hair.

A young man is falling headfirst from the top of the crag on which Ambition sits. His body faces forward but he bends left at the waist, so that his legs and arms both extend diagonally leftward. He turns his head to the left and tips it back. His legs are spread and bent, and his arms are raised at 135 degrees. He holds both hands out with palms up. He seems to be wearing tights, perhaps with knee breeches. The muscles of his torso show through his clothing. A thin cloth emerges from the left side of his waist, wraps over his left thigh, and billows upward between his legs. His mouth is open and his eyes are raised to look down. His hair seems to be short.

A young man who presumably has fallen from the top of the rocky crag lies on his back in a cruciform posture near the lower right corner of the design, at the base of the crag. He may be dead or dying. His head is out towards the viewer and tipped back so that his face is visible upside down. His eyes are half closed, and may be rolled up into his head. His arms lie spread horizontally wide along the ground, the right one partially supported by a nearby rock or stone outcropping. His legs are spread as well; the left leg is bent upward, and the bent right leg lies propped the same nearby rock. He is wearing tights with a wide v-necked collar, and has short hair fanned over the ground. His body casts shadows along the ground above his arms, to the right of his head and right thigh, and along the right side of his lower right leg.

The personified figures of Scorn and Infamy kneel together in the lower left corner, pointing at the dead or dying young man lying on his back in the lower right corner. Infamy, an old woman, is in front, facing forward with her lowered head turned slightly to the right. Both of her legs are bent as she rests on her knees, but her left leg is slightly forward. She hunches forward and extends her left arm out at 45 degrees to the right, pointing with her left index finger at the young man to the right. Her right arm, at her side, is bent and drawn back slightly. She holds her right hand up and points with her right index finger toward the young man ascending the crag near the left side of the design. Her mouth is open in a "grinning" (see the letterpress text) smile. She is balding but has bedraggled gray hair falling from behind her ear over her shoulder. Her visible right ear is extended upward into a point. She wears a long-sleeved gown with a high waist and a wide neckline, which falls loosely open to reveal part of her left breast. Her visible fingernails are long and pointed like claws. Scorn kneels behind and to the left of her, his body mostly hidden by hers. He leans slightly left and tilts his head back to look up and to the right. His eyes are widened, with eyebrows raised, and his mouth is open as if in an expression of surprise or alarm. His upper teeth show. He holds his left arm out at 45 degrees to the right, pointing with his narrow index finger at the young man in the lower right corner. He seems to have long fingernails as well. His right leg is bent and his right upper leg and knee appear to the left of Infamy's right leg. His right arm is not clearly visible, but may be down by his side and slightly bent, with his right hand perhaps resting on the ground near his right knee. He has short, curly hair and a wide curled mustache. He may be nude, but a line at his left wrist suggests a sleeve, indicating that he may be wearing transparent tights.
Heavy shadows appears on the ground and the base of the crag between Scorn and Infamy and the left edge of the design.

The personified figure of Ambition sits atop a rocky cliff or hill that dominates the design. It rises from the lower left corner into the upper right corner. Another large rock or outcropping appears in the lower right corner, and partially supports the young man who lies on his back at the base of the crag. The ground along the bottom of the plate seems to be stone as well.
Wash above the rocky crag suggests the sky, perhaps at sunrise or sunset.

desc.objtitle: Ode on a Distant Prospect of Eton College: Page 8, Object 20 (Butlin 335.20)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 4 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The Queen of Death sits at the left side of the design, facing forward but turning her head slightly to the right. Her wrinkled visage and white hair suggest that she is old, though her body is muscled and strong. Her muscular right leg is bent and her left leg extends diagonally down to the right. Each foot rests on top of what looks like a gigantic starfish but may actually represent a star-shaped flame. She is nude, and an enormous serpent (or several) wrap her body, looping twice around her lower left leg, twice around her left thigh, and once around her waist. A tail lies across her upper right thigh, falling to rest on the ground between her legs. Both arms are down by her sides, bent forward, and in each fist she grasps a bundle of sticks. Her right fist rests on her right thigh, while her left rests a little lower, on a loop of the serpent wrapped around her left upper leg. Wearing a spiky crown, she has long hair falling over her shoulders. The dead in the train of the Queen of Death form a grisly crowd to the right of where she sits. They fill the lower right corner of the design and extend up past the bottom of the text panel. One final figure of the Queen's entourage appears in the lower left corner, with head tipped back and mouth open. Mourners for the dead grieve in the upper left corner of the design, appearing as huddled lowered heads. The heads of three figures are foremost: two women just to the left of the text panel, one of whom buries her face in her hands, and one man, with eyes closed, just above these women. The other mourners are largely indistinct and indistinguishable from one another, giving the impression of a crowd of lowered heads. A bearded figure, perhaps another god of death, hovers over the scene at the top of the design. His face appears at the top of the design, looking forward, while his vast wings reach to either side of the design. He is wearing a spiky crown through which strands of hair emerge in spikes; below his long hair blows to either side of his face. He has a long beard that appears above and to the right of the text panel. Areas of darkness or shadow appear in two different places within the design: along the lower left edge to the left of the Queen of Death, and at the upper right side beneath the hovering figure's left wing. Indistinct, faintly sketched lines in the area of shadow on the right suggests that more of the dead may lurk there.

component.illusobjdesc: The Queen of Death sits at the left side of the design, facing forward but turning her head slightly to the right. Her wrinkled visage and white hair suggest that she is old, though her body is muscled and strong. Her whole body leans left slightly. Her muscular right leg is bent, facing out toward the viewer. Her right foot rests flat on top of what looks like a gigantic starfish but may actually represent a star-shaped flame. Her slightly bent left leg, also thick with muscle, extends diagonally down to the right. The ball of her left foot rests on a second large starfish. An enormous serpent (or several) wrap her body, looping twice around her lower left leg, twice around her left thigh, and once around her waist. A tail lies across her upper right thigh, falling to rest on the ground between her legs. Both arms are down by her sides, bent forward, and in each fist she grasps a bundle of sticks. Her right fist rests on her right thigh, while her left rests a little lower, on a loop of the serpent wrapped around her left upper leg. Wearing a spiky crown, she has long hair falling over her shoulders. She is nude and her large breasts rest atop the snake's body where it wraps her torso

Mourners for the dead grieve in the upper left corner of the design, appearing as huddled lowered heads. The heads of three figures are foremost: two women just to the left of the text panel, and one man just above these women. The rightmost woman is also the lowest visible mourner. She faces right and hunches forward. Her head is lowered into her hands, which cover her face entirely. Her long hair is drawn over her shoulder. She may be wearing a gown or shirt. The woman to the left also faces right and hunches forward, but lifts her head slightly to look right. Her eye with its furrowed brow is all that is visible of her face. Like the first woman, her hair is drawn over her shoulder. She seems to be wearing a cloak over her right shoulder, above another garment that may be a shirt or gown. Above and to the right of these women, the man likewise faces right and slumps forward. His eyes are closed. He is bald but has a long beard. Only his head and neck and the suggestion of shoulders are visible, but a neckline suggests he is wearing a shirt. To the left of this man, the head of a second man seems to be looking to the right and mostly away from the viewer, but otherwise the other mourners are largely indistinct and indistinguishable from one another, giving the impression of a crowd of lowered heads. The head of one may appear to the right of the bald man, just above the top left corner of the text panel. Other heads appear to the left of the bald man and the woman looking to the right. Just to the left of the woman looking right, wavy lines suggest that one of these other lowered heads has curly hair.

A bearded male, perhaps another God of Death, hovers over the scene. His face appears at the top of the design, looking forward, while his vast wings with clearly delineated feathers reach to either side of the design. He is wearing a spiky crown through which strands of hair emerge in spikes; below, his long hair blows to either side of his face. He has a long beard that appears above and to the right of the text panel.

The dead in the train of the Queen of Death form a grisly crowd to the right of where she sits. Some are evidently in pain. Where their bodies are visible, they are nude unless otherwise noted. Immediately to the right of the Queen, one of the dead sits facing forward with knees drawn up to his chest. He wraps both bent arms around his knees and hugs them, with his hands clasped in front of him just below his chin. With his mouth open in a grimacing smile that reveals his teeth, he turns his head slightly to the right. His bulbous head is bald and his visible right ear pointed. To the right of this bulbous-headed figure appears the head and torso of another one of the dead, seen from behind. He faces away, but turns his head to the left so that his face is visible in profile. He leans slightly to the right; his right upper arm is visible raised and extended to the right. His mouth is open to display two rows of teeth and his extended tongue. The muscles in his back and the bones of his spinal column are clearly visible, as is the twisted, writhing, noodle-like mass of his exposed brain. In the space between his torso and raised upper arm a large eye and part of a nose belonging to another of the dead appears. Above and to the right of the figure with the visible brain is another figure whose head and left torso emerge from a ring of grimacing faces. This figure faces and leans forward, but turns his head left. Both of his arms are hidden. He smiles gruesomely. He is bald but has two rather globular horns atop his oddly short forehead.
