At least eight heads form a ring surrounding him. Above him appears a face looking up and slightly left. This face has open eye sockets like a skull, and long hair that extends upward. Above the face with skull-like features appears another face seen in profile looking up with eyes raised and mouth open. This face also seems to have hair that extends upward and merges with the hair from the skull-like face. To the left of the figure with globular horns a third face looks forward and slightly down. This face is also tilted backward slightly. He has long hair and a beard, and holds his mouth open. To the left of this face, below the text panel, diagonal lines suggest the effect of hair or possibly clothing belonging to this bearded face. To the right and below the figure with horns, three heads facing down appear in quick succession. The leftmost head is visible only below the hairline and above the nose. Its brow is heavily furrowed and its eye looks down. The head below and to the right has mouth and eyes open as if in surprise. The third head, below and to the right, also holds its mouth open. Its eyebrows are raised. The middle and rightmost head may each sprout thin hairs, but are otherwise bald. Below and to the right of the horned figure, near the right side of the design, a seventh head is visible looking forward and to the left, with mouth open. Lines below and to the right of this head's chin suggest clothing or muscle. He may be bald, or may have long hair that extends upward. Finally, a head looking upward above the horned figure's left shoulder completes the ring. This figure's mouth may be open, but it is half-hidden. This figure may also be either bald, or have long hair that falls down towards the head below. Above the Queen's left foot the head and part of the shoulders of another dead figure are visible, facing forward. This figure has short, curly hair and oddly distended temples. His mouth is open. Above and to the right of the Queen's left foot a member of her entourage crouches with body facing forward and slightly right, but head turned slightly left. His right knee is raised and he leans to the right. His left arm, slightly bent, is down by his side, and his right arm is drawn forward and to the right. He is bald. He is smiling and looks down without lowering his eyelids. A head seen in profile and facing up appears in the lower right corner of the design. This head's eyes are raised with brows furrowed, and its mouth is open. It seems to have long hair. Just above this head, also at the right side of the design, appears another that is facing forward and left. Its mouth is open and eyes raised as well. One final figure from the Queen's train of dead appears separately from the rest of the entourage. The head and neck of this figure appears to the left of the Queen's right leg. The suggestion of long hair may mean this figure is female. Alternatively, the figure may be wearing a hood. Her head faces forward, but is tipped back and turned to the right slightly. Her mouth is open.

Areas of darkness or shadow appear in two different places within the design: along the lower left edge to the left of the Queen of Death, and at the upper right side beneath left wing of the crowned figure at the top of the design. Indistinct, faintly sketched lines in the area of shadow on the right suggests that more of the dead may lurk there.

desc.objtitle: Ode on a Distant Prospect of Eton College: Page 9, Object 21 (Butlin 335.21)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 4 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A boy or young man runs facing right near the bottom of the design. He is leaning forward and his weight rests momentarily on his bent left leg; his straight right leg is extended behind him. He has raised his right arm over his head and holds the brim of his hat in this hand. His head is bent sharply back and he looks upward. He is wearing a shirt with a ruffled collar under a coat that flies behind him, as well as shoes, stockings, and pants or long breeches. He has short curly hair. A small, indistinct winged creature flies near the right side of the design, below the tree branch. The young man may be chasing this winged creature. The trunks of at least two large trees fill much of the design space. The foremost tree is rooted near the left edge of the design, curving to the right as it grows upward. Two small branches split from its trunk near the top of the design. The personification of Folly sits above the running boy in the crook of this tree, near the top of the design. She sits facing forward with knees drawn up, but bends forward and to the right, reaching both arms out to the right. Her right arm is raised horizontally and her left at 135 degrees. She may be leaning or resting her right arm on or against her left knee. In each hand she holds a vial upside down, allowing gusts of wind to escape and blow toward the winged creature. She looks down toward this wind and opens her mouth in a smile. Her long hair is blown to the right. She may be wearing tights, or perhaps a gown that is wrapped tightly around her left leg so that its shape shows clearly. To the right of the tree in which Folly sits grows another tree, farther away and partly hidden behind the text box. This tree's trunk also curves to the right and seems to split into several branches as it nears the right edge of the design. Between these two trees the base of a third trunk may appear below and to the left of the text panel. Alternatively this may be a large stone. Two leafy branches visible to the right of the rightmost tree may belong to yet another tree, whose foliage may also include the green wash to the right and left of the rightmost tree. Alternatively this green wash may be a bush. A strip of brown wash running along the bottom of the plate may be earth or sand, perhaps representing a road or path along which the young man runs. The trees rise from small hills or mounds that begin just to the far side of the path and extend into the middle distance. These hills seem to be covered with grass. Dark wash to the right of the running boy's torso and to the left of the leftmost tree may be hills in shadow. Other shadows appear below and to the right of the leftmost tree, below the running boy, and on the tree trunk below Folly. Wash around the tree trunks in the top two-thirds of the design suggests the sky, perhaps with clouds.

component.illusobjdesc: A boy or young man runs facing right near the bottom of the design. He is leaning forward and his weight rests momentarily on his bent left leg; his straight right leg is extended behind him with his foot pointed as if on tiptoe. His right arm is raised vertically and bent back over his head. He holds the brim of his hat in this hand. His head is bent sharply back and he looks upward. He may be chasing the winged creature above his head to the right. He is wearing a shirt with a ruffled collar under a coat that flies behind him, as well as shoes, stockings, and pants or long breeches. He has short curly hair.
A small, indistinct winged creature flies near the right side of the design, below the tree branch. It may be a bird or a bat, and may represent "happiness" (see the letterpress text).

The personification of Folly sits in the crook of a tree near the top of the design. She sits facing forward with knees drawn up, but bends forward and to the right, turning her upper body slightly to the right. Her left foot appears propped on the trunk of the tree, toes dangling, while her right foot is hidden. She reaches both arms out to the right: her right arm is raised horizontally and her left at 135 degrees. She may be leaning or resting her right arm on or against her left knee. In each hand she holds a vial upside down, allowing gusts of wind to escape and blow torwards the winged creature the young man seems to be chasing. She looks down towards this wind and opens her mouth in a smile. Her long hair is blown to the right. She may be wearing tights, or perhaps a gown that is wrapped tightly around her left leg so that its shape shows clearly. Part of her garments spills down the tree trunk to the left.

The trunks of at least two large trees fill much of the design space. The foremost tree is rooted near the left edge of the design, curving and leaning to the right as it grows upward. Two small branches split from its trunk near the top of the design; Folly sits in the crook formed by one of these. To the right grows another tree, farther away and partly hidden behind the text panel. This tree's trunk also curves and leans to the right and seems to split into several branches as it nears the right edge of the design. Between these two trees the base of a third trunk may appear below and to the left of the text panel. Alternatively this may be a large stone. Two leafy branches visible to the right of the rightmost tree may belong to yet another tree, whose foliage may also include the green wash to the right and left of the rightmost tree. Alternatively, this green wash may be a bush. The trees rise from small hills that begin just to the far side of the strip of earth or road running along the bottom of the design and extend into the middle distance. These hills seem to be covered with grass.

Dark wash to the right of the running boy's torso and to the left of the leftmost tree may be distant hills in shadow. The large trees rise from low hills or mounds. Other shadows appear below and to the right of the leftmost tree, below the running boy, and on the tree trunk below Folly.
A strip of brown wash running along the bottom of the plate may be earth or sand. It may represent a road.
Wash around the tree trunks in the top two-thirds of the design suggests the sky, perhaps with clouds.

desc.objtitle: Ode on a Distant Prospect of Eton College; Page 10: Blank Page Bearing List of Titles, Object 22 (Butlin 335.22)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A boy or young man kneels at the base of the tree, before a ball resting on a small stick or tee. He faces mostly left but his body is turned slightly forward. His left leg is bent down and he rests on his left knee and the toes of his left foot. His right leg is bent and drawn up and his right foot is on tiptoe. He bends over and reaches his right arm down past his right leg. His right hand, palm up, may be resting on the ground; his thumb and forefinger curve around the small tee in the ground, on which a ball sits. His slightly bent left arm is down and drawn back, and his left hand is palm down. He bends his head down and looks toward the ball. He has short, curly hair and is wearing shoes, stockings, breeches, and a shirt with a wide, ruffled collar. He casts shadows on the ground to the right of his body and beneath his left foot; a smaller shadow appears just below his right foot. Some lines just left of his right foot indicate a slightly different position for it. A smaller ball or marble lies on the ground to the left of the one resting on a tee. Two boys or young men stand shoulder to shoulder to the left of the text box. The young man on the right stands facing forward, but turns his head down and to the right. His eyes are lowered. He stands with his left leg straight and his right bent forward slightly. His left arm is down by his side, while his right is mostly hidden behind his companion to the left. He wears a shirt with a wide, ruffled collar, a tailcoat, and breeches over stockings and slim shoes. He has short, curly hair. The young man to the left stands facing forward and slightly right. Like his companion, his bent head is turned to the right and his eyes are lowered to look at the boy who kneels to the right. His left leg is crossed over his right leg and his left foot rests on tiptoe. He holds his right arm bent behind his back and raises his left horizontally to embrace the shoulders of the young man to the right. The fingers of the leftmost young man's left hand appear resting on the left shoulder of his fellow. He wears a shirt with a ruffled collar under a waistcoat and breeches. Alternatively he may be wearing knee-length tights with a wide neck through which his shirt shows. He is also wearing a tailcoat, stockings, and shoes. His hair is long and curly, and may be tied loosely behind his head. Shadows appear on the ground beneath the boy on the right and to the left of the boy on the left. A large tree, rooted in the lower right corner, grows up the right side of the design. Near the upper right corner, the trunk splits into two. One branch or section of the trunk grows to the right, out of the design. The other, a large branch, arches to the left across the top and down towards the left edge of the design. Smaller branches fill the spaces between the large branch, the standing boys, and the text panel. All of the branches are bare of leaves. Streaks of blue wash in the upper half of the design suggest the sky, perhaps with clouds. The ground on which the young men stand or kneel seems to be bare earth.

component.illusobjdesc: Two boys or young men stand shoulder to shoulder to the left of the text box. The young man on the right stands facing forward, but turns his head down and to the right. His eyes are lowered. He stands with his left leg straight and his right bent forward slightly. His left arm is down by his side, while his right is mostly hidden behind his companion to the left. He wears a shirt with a wide, ruffled collar, a tailcoat, and breeches over stockings and slim shoes. He has short, curly hair. The young man to the left stands facing forward and slightly right. Like his companion, his head and eyes are lowered to look at the boy who kneels to the right. His left leg is crossed over his right leg and his left foot rests on tiptoe. He holds his right arm bent behind his back and raises his left horizontally to embrace the shoulders of the young man to the right. The fingers of the leftmost young man's left hand appear resting on the left shoulder of his fellow. He wears a shirt with a ruffled collar under a waistcoat and breeches. Alternatively he may be wearing knee-length tights with a wide neck through which his shirt shows. He is also wearing a tailcoat, stockings, and shoes. His hair is long and curly, and may be tied loosely behind his head. Shadows appear on the ground beneath the boy on the right and to the left of the boy on the left.

A boy or young man kneels at the base of the tree, before a ball resting on a small stick or tee. He faces mostly left but his body is turned slightly forward. His left leg is bent down and he rests on his left knee and the toes of his left foot. His right leg is bent and drawn up and his right foot is on tiptoe. He bends over and reaches his right arm down past his right leg. His right hand, palm up, may be resting on the ground; his thumb and forefinger curve around a small peg in the ground, on which a ball sits. His slightly bent left arm is down and drawn back, and his left hand is palm down. He bends his head down and looks toward the ball. He has short, curly hair and is wearing shoes, stockings, breeches, and a shirt with a wide, ruffled collar. He casts shadows on the ground to the right of his body and beneath his right foot. Lines just left of his right foot indicate a different, but rejected, position for it. A smaller ball or marble lies on the ground to the left of the one resting on a tee.

A large tree, rooted in the lower right corner, grows up the right side of the design. Near the upper right corner, the trunk splits into two. One branch or section of trunk grows to the right, out of the design. The other, a large branch, arches to the left across the top and down towards the left edge of the design. Smaller branches growing from beneath this large branch fill the spaces between the large branch, the standing boys, and the text panel. All of the branches are bare of leaves.
Streaks of blue wash in the upper half of the design suggest the sky, perhaps with clouds.
The ground on which the young men stand or kneel seems to be bare earth.

lg.l: A Long Story
Design
1. A Circular Dance
2. Fairies riding on Flies
3.. "An Ancient Pile of Building whichLines 6-7 are quoted, with the addition of the word "which," from page [65] of the letterpress text (Object 25).
Employd the power of Fairy hands"
4. "The Seals & Maces dancd before him"The line is quoted, with minor variations, from page 66 of the letterpress text (Object 26).
5. "A brace of warriors"The line is quoted from page 66 of the letterpress text (Object 26).
6"Bewitchd the children of the Peasants"The line is quoted, with minor variations, from page 68 of the letterpress text (Object 28).
7. "Upstairs in a whirlwind rattle"The line is quoted, with minor variations, from page 69 of the letterpress text (Object 29).
8. "Out of the window whisk they flew"The line is quoted, with minor variations, from page 70 of the letterpress text (Object 30).
9. "At the Chapel door stand centry"The line is quoted, with minor variations, from page 71 of the letterpress text (Object 31).
10 ."A sudden fit of ague shook him"The line is quoted from page 72 of the letterpress text (Object 32).
11 ."My Lady rose & with a graceLines 15-16 are quoted, with minor variations, from page 73 of the letterpress text (Object 33).
She smild & bid him come to dinner"
12."Guard us from long winded lubbersLines 17-19 are quoted, with minor variations, from page 74 of the letterpress text (Object 34).
That to Eternity would sing
And keep my Lady from her rubbers"

desc.objtitle: A Long Story; Page 1: Title Page, Object 23 (Butlin 335.23)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Five youths—one male and four female—hold hands and dance or hover in a ring encircling the text panel. The nude young man or boy appears below the text panel and is seen from behind. His upper body faces away but his head faces left and his lower body is turned to face right. His arms are outstretched horizontally and each hand holds the hand of a figure to the right or left. He has drawn his bent left leg forward, while his straight right leg is extended behind him. A young woman appears to the right of the text panel, seen from behind. Her lower body faces away and slightly to the right; her right leg is extended down and drawn slightly behind her, and her left leg is bent at the knee and drawn forward slightly. She bends sharply left, turning her upper body to face down and bending her head down as well. Her right arm is raised vertically and she holds the hand of another figure above her. Her left arm is extended down, at slightly lower than 45 degrees. With her left hand she holds the right hand of the nude young man beneath the text panel. She wears a semi-transparent gown, and her hair is drawn up into a bun wrapped in a braid. A second young woman appears above the top right corner of the text panel. She is seen from behind on a diagonal, her body contorted around the corner of the text panel. Her lower body faces right. Her slightly bent right leg is extended down, while her left leg is bent up away from the viewer, though her pelvis faces right. She twists sharply away at the waist so that her upper body faces left and down. She extends her left arm down to hold the hand of the female below, and stretches her right arm overhead to the left, reaching her right hand towards the hand of a female to the left. Her upper body is nude, and she wears tights or pants below, as well as slim shoes. Her curly hair is short or piled on the top of her head in a bun. The third young woman appears above the text panel, upside down and with her body almost horizontal. She faces up, but bends backward slightly so that her upper body faces left and out toward the viewer. Her head may be bent back slightly. She holds her right arm out horizontally, reaching her open hand toward the figure to the right, and raises her left arm vertically over her head, down toward the figure below her. With her left hand she may be holding the hand of the figure below; alternatively, this hand may be merely stretched in this direction. Her right leg is extended horizontally across the design, while her left is bent and drawn up, knee to torso. She wears a long, semi-transparent gown or skirt that drapes her legs but allows both feet, clad in slim shoes, to emerge. This garment also leaves her breasts bare. Her hair is curly and short or drawn back into a bun. The fourth young woman appears upside down to the left of the text panel. She faces forward and left, but may also bend forward slightly, lowering her head to look up. Her right leg is extended, while her left is bent and drawn up, knee to torso. She extends her slightly bent right arm to hold the hand of the figure above her, and raises her bent left arm over her head to hold the hand of the figure below. She wears a long, semi-transparent gown or skirt that covers her legs but leaves her upper body and breasts bare. She has short hair or wears it in a bun.

component.illusobjdesc: The group of figures forms a circle.

A nude young man or boy flies, hovers, or dances below the text box, seen from behind. His upper body faces away but his head faces left and his lower body is turned to face right. His arms are outstretched horizontally and each hand holds the hand of a young person to the right or left. Both feet are on tiptoe. His lower body is positioned as if he is running on tiptoe: he has drawn his bent left leg forward, while his straight right leg is extended behind him. He has short, curly hair that seems to be tossing in the wind of his own movement.

A young woman flies, hovers, or dances to the right of the text panel, seen from behind. Her lower body faces away and slightly to the right; her right leg is extended down and drawn slightly behind her, and her left leg is bent at the knee and drawn forward slightly. Both feet are on tiptoe. The bottom of her left foot is visible. She bends sharply left, turning her upper body to face down and bending her head down as well. Her right arm is raised vertically and she holds the hand of another figure above her. Her left arm is extended down, at slightly lower than 45 degrees. With her left hand she holds the right hand of the nude boy beneath the text panel. She wears a semi-transparent gown through which the muscles of her back and legs are clearly visible. Her hair is drawn up into a bun wrapped in a braid.

A young woman flies, hovers, or dances to the right of the text panel, in the top right corner of the design. She is seen from behind on a diagonal, her body contorted around the corner of the text panel. Her lower body faces right. Her slightly bent right leg is extended down, while her left leg is bent up away from the viewer, though her pelvis faces right. Her right foot is on tiptoe. She twists sharply away at the waist so that her upper body faces left and down. She extends her left arm down to hold the hand of the female below, and stretches her right arm overhead to the left, reaching her right hand towards the hand of a female to the left. Her upper body is nude, and she wears tights or pants below, as well as slim shoes. Her curly hair is short or piled on the top of her head in a bun.

A young woman flies, hovers, or dances above the text panel, upside down and with her body almost horizontal. She faces up, but bends backward slightly so that her upper body faces left and out toward the viewer. Her head may be bent back slightly. She holds her right arm out horizontally, reaching her open hand toward the figure to the right, and raises her left arm vertically over her head, down towards the figure below her. With her left hand she may be holding the hand of the figure below; alternatively, this hand may be merely stretched in this direction. Her right leg is extended horizontally across the design, while her left is bent and drawn up, knee to torso. Her right foot is on tiptoe. She wears a long, semi-transparent gown or skirt that drapes her legs but allows both feet, clad in slim shoes, to emerge. This garment also leaves her breasts bare. Her hair is curly and short or drawn back into a bun.

A young woman flies, hovers, or dances upside down to the left of the text panel. She faces forward and left, but may also bend forward slightly, lowering her head to look up. Her right leg is extended, while her left is bent and drawn up, knee to torso. She extends her slightly bent right arm to hold the hand of the figure above her, and raises her bent left arm over her head to hold the hand of the figure below. She wears a long, semi-transparent gown or skirt that covers her legs but leaves her upper body and breasts bare. She has short hair or wears it in a bun.

desc.objtitle: A Long Story; Page 2: Editor's Note, Object 24 (Butlin 335.24)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A woman and four children stand on the top of the text panel. The woman, who stands near the middle of the panel's top edge, faces forward but turns her head to look left. She stands in a contrapposto position, with her weight resting on her right leg and her left bent forward. Her arms are down by her side and she may be holding hands with the children to either side. A male child, indistinctly drawn, stands to the left of this woman, facing forward and right with legs together. His right arm is down by his side, but he raises his left arm, probably to hold the woman's right hand. Another child stands to the right of the woman, facing left. This child is even more indistinct, but may be male. He may raise one of his hands to hold the woman's left hand. To the right of this child, another male child stands or dances on tiptoe while playing a fife or flute. He faces forward and slightly right, bending his head down to the mouthpiece of the flute, and raises both bent arms out to the right to support the instrument. His right leg is forward, while his left is drawn back to the left. To the right, near the top right corner of the text panel, stands or dances a girl holding a tambourine or drum. She faces forward and slightly right, but turns her head slightly left. Her extended left arm is raised at 135 degrees, and she holds the tambourine or drum up with this hand. Her right arm is bent across her torso; she grasps the stick with which she plays the tambourine or drum in her right hand. Her left leg may be extended behind her to the left. A wasp or bee flies to the left of the text panel, facing right. A diminutive figure sits astride the wasp, with its straight legs extended forward along either side of the wasp's thorax. The figure leans forward slightly and extends its right arm horizontally forward, holding a stinger(?) out toward the text. This figure wears tights and a hat with two antennae curling backward from its head. These antennae mimic the antennae of the wasp. A large butterfly flies or hovers with wings spread beneath the text panel. A woman, probably a fairy (see "Fairies," Blake's text, Object 22), is suspended or carried before the butterfly. She faces forward with a wide smile and extends her arms, slightly bent, at 135 degrees. Both hands are open with palms up; the fingers of her right hand are also parted. Her legs are spread and slightly bent; the right leg is slightly forward, while the left is drawn slightly back. Long curly hair spills down her back and shows on either side of her torso. She wears a semi-transparent long-sleeved gown with diaphanous skirts floating around her legs. Her right breast may be bare. Though the fairy woman obscures most of the butterfly's body, its large, hairy antennae appear above her head and the bottom of its abdomen is visible below her skirts. Wash across the top of the design suggests the sky, perhaps streaked with clouds.

component.illusobjdesc: A woman and four children stand on the top of the text panel. The woman, who stands near the middle of the panel's top edge, faces forward but turns her head to look left. She may also be bending her head down slightly. She stands in a contrapposto position, with her weight resting on her right leg and her left bent forward. Her arms are down by her side and she may be holding hands with the children to either side. She wears a long gown, and has short hair or hair pulled back into a bun. A male child, indistinctly drawn, stands to the left of this woman, facing forward and right with legs together. His right arm is down by his side, but he raises his left arm, probably to hold the woman's right hand. He may be bald or have short hair. Another child stands to the right of the woman, facing left. This child is even more indistinct, but may be male. He may raise one of his hands to hold the woman's left hand. He may be bald or have short hair. Both children seem to be wearing indistinct clothing. To the right of this child, another male child stands or dances on tiptoe while playing a fife or flute. He faces forward and slightly right, bending his head down to the mouthpiece of the flute, and raises both bent arms out to the right to support the instrument. His right leg is forward, while his left is drawn back to the left. He wears a shirt and pants or breeches with tights and shoes. He has short, curly hair. To the right, near the top right corner of the text panel, stands or dances a girl holding a tambourine or drum. She faces forward and slightly right, but turns her head slightly left. Her extended left arm is raised at 135 degrees, and she holds the drum up with this hand. Her right arm is bent across her torso; she grasps the stick with which she plays the tambourine or drum in her right hand. Her left leg may be extended behind her to the left. She wears a long gown, and has short hair or hair drawn into a bun.

A wasp or bee with double wings spread wide flies to the left of the text panel, facing right. A diminutive figure sits astride the wasp, with its straight legs extended forward along either side of the wasp's thorax. The figure leans forward slightly and extends its right arm horizontally forward, holding a stinger(?) out toward the text. This figure wears tights and a hat with two antennae curling backward from its head. These antennae mimic the antennae of the wasp.

A large butterfly flies or hovers with wings spread beneath the text panel. A woman, probably a fairy (see "Fairies," Blake's text, Object 22), is suspended or carried before the butterfly. She faces forward with a wide smile and extends her arms, slightly bent, at 135 degrees. Both hands are open with palms up; the fingers of her right hand are also parted. Her legs are spread and slightly bent; the right leg is slightly forward while the left is drawn slightly back. Long curly hair spills down her back and shows on either side of her torso. She wears a semi-transparent long-sleeved gown with diaphanous skirts floating around her legs. Her right breast may be bare. Though the fairy woman obscures most of the butterfly's body, its large, hairy antennae appear above her head and the bottom of its abdomen is visible below her skirts.
Wash across the top of the design suggests the sky, perhaps streaked with clouds.

desc.objtitle: A Long Story; Page 3: Beginning of Poem, Object 25 (Butlin 335.25)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 6 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This design shows a host of tiny fairies at work building a great house. Blake illustrates the "ancient pile of building" as if it has indeed been constructed by "Fairy hands" (see letterpress text). The cathedral-like space boasts a large stained glass window, pilasters or pillars, and ornate pointed arches. The stained glass window at the bottom of the design depicts the figures of Christ, several angels, the dove of the Holy Ghost, a serpent and a dragon in its panels. Two fairies, one male and one female, fly or hover on either side of the upper corners of the text box. Other fairies are busy with work: counter-clockwise from left to right, one carries a hod filled with sheets of stained glass, one sits on the window frame to carve an ornament on the nearby spire, a third stands braced on the other side of the frame with hammer and chisel poised, a fifth bears a large wicker basket on his back, and a sixth paints the base of an arch in the upper right corner of the design. The fairy upper left rests on an arch.

component.illusobjdesc: Blake illustrates the "ancient pile of building" as if it has indeed been constructed by "Fairy hands" (see the letterpress text). The Gothic and cathedral-like space boasts a large stained glass window at the bottom of the design. Conical or triangular spires rise from its ornate frame. Two carved leaves lie on the left side of the window frame; smaller carved leaves decorate the leftmost spire. Similar ornaments seem to appear on either side of the base of the rightmost spire. A pointed arch appears on either side of the window. The points of these arches and the arch over the window have tall decorative ornaments as well. They may incorporate carved leaves similar to those that appear above the window. Two pilasters or pillars are partly visible in the background, rising from above the lower arches nearly to the level of the top of the text box. A pointed arch supported by both pilasters spans the distance between the two; part of a second pointed arch extends beyond the right edge of the design. Ribs rise from the top of the rightmost pilaster to the top of the design to create a fan vault. The walls may be made of stone.

Tracery separates the large stained glass window at the bottom of the design into separate panels. The central panel pictures the hovering, robed figure of Christ, facing forward with arms down and hands raised slightly from his sides. Beams of light surround his body. His feet appear beneath the hem of his gown. The dove of the Holy Ghost hovers above his head. The bird has wings spread to either side of its body, and emits beams of light as well. The panels to either side of Christ's panel each display a figure, possibly an angel. The figure on the left stands facing left and holds its arms out at 45 degrees in front of its body. The figure on the right stands facing right and likewise extends its arms at 45 degrees in front of its body. Both figures hold a small object, difficult to distinguish, in their outstretched hands. They wear robes over long gowns. Two angels hover or fly in the panel above Christ's panel. They face forward and slightly towards each other, so that one faces slightly right and the other slightly left. They wear long gowns and emit beams of light from their heads. The figure on the left holds a small round object in its left hand. A serpent with an open mouth winds across the panel to the left of the angels' panel; it faces right and its body forms five curves. A dragon with upraised wings and a curved tail faces left in the panel to the right of the angels. It opens its mouth wide to display jagged teeth. Its back is crested. The other panels in the window are colored but empty of figures.

A tiny male fairy hovers or flies to the left of the text panel's upper left corner. He faces forward and slightly left, with his body positioned on a diagonal from upper left to lower right, but he turns and bends his head to the right. His right arm is extended roughly horizontally leftward, with palm up. His left arm is extended forward at about 45 degrees, with palm facing out and left. He extends his straight right leg forward and his bent left leg backward. Both feet are on tiptoe. He has short, curly hair, and wears tights with a tall collar and scarf at the neck.

A fairy carrying a hod appears just to the left of the text panel, facing away and slightly left. The hod he bears is filled with what appears to be sheets of stained glass. The base of this tool rests on his right shoulder and against the right side of his neck and head, which is bent to the left. The fairy's bent left arm is down and slightly out from his side; with his left hand he holds the handle of the hod as it extends diagonally down to the left. His straight left leg is extended behind him, while his right is bent and drawn up. His left foot is on tiptoe. He is nude and has short, curly hair.

A fairy sits on the frame of the window, in the triangular space formed by its shape and the base of the leftmost spire. He faces left. His bent right leg is drawn up slightly, while his slightly bent left leg extends down along the frame. His left arm is raised and bent upward and his left hand holds a tool, perhaps a chisel, against one of the ornaments on the spire, as if he is carving it. He bends and leans forward into the work. He has short curly hair and wears tights or a semi-transparent gown, through which his legs are clearly visible.

Another fairy stands braced between the window frame and one of the rightmost spires, on the opposite side of the window. He faces forward and slightly to the right, but turns his head to the right to look at his work. His slightly bent right leg is down, and his foot rests on the window frame. His left leg is bent and drawn up, foot resting on the spire. His left arm is extended at an angle horizontal from his body, and he holds a chisel in his upraised left hand. The tool may be suspended, or may rest on the pilaster to the left of the spire. His right arm is raised, bent upward at roughly 135 degrees from his body, and drawn back. He holds a stone hammer in his upraised right hand, as if poised to hit the chisel. He is nude and heavily muscled. He has short, curly hair.

A nude male fairy hovers or flies near the right side of the design, facing down and right. His body extends diagonally from top right to bottom left. Bending forward, he bears a large wicker basket on his back. His right arm is raised and bent backward over his shoulder, and he grasps the rim of the basket with this hand. His head may be bent forward. His left leg is bent and drawn up below his body, while his slightly bent right leg is extended behind him, with right foot in the tiptoe position. He has short, curly hair and well-defined musculature.

A female fairy hovers near the upper right corner of the design. Her lower body is horizontal, but she bends backwards at the waist so that her upper body faces left and slightly down. Her right arm is raised and bent upward, and she holds a brush in her upraised right hand. She paints the ribs of the rightmost upper arch with this brush. Her bent left arm is raised roughly horizontally, and in her left hand she holds an artist's palette. She wears a long gown with skirts that swirl past her extended foot or feet, visible in tiptoe position. Her hair may be short, or may be drawn back into a bun.

Another female fairy flies or hovers near the upper right corner of the text panel. Her body faces to the right and slightly forward, but she turns her head to the left. Her right arm is extended horizontally to the left and her hand (or perhaps an indistinct tool she carries) touches the edge of the text box. She bends backward at the waist slightly. She wears a long gown. A scarf covers her head and drapes over her left shoulder; it may be this material or an apron that also wraps around her waist and appears in folds to the right of her legs. One foot is visible in tiptoe position below the hem of her gown. Curly hair peeks from beneath her scarf above her forehead.
A fairy kneels, crouching, on the arch upper left. Probably male, he has curly hair and extends at least his left arm in front of him. He faces right with legs drawn up in a contracted posture.

desc.objtitle: A Long Story: Page 4, Object 26 (Butlin 335.26)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil crosses to the left of lines 5 and 16 of the letterpress text. The first cross indicates the line or passage illustrated on this page; the second cross indicates the line or passage illustrated on the next page, Object 27.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This design depicts a Tudor dance, also called a "Brawl" (see the letterpress text). The dancing figures include Sir Christopher Hatton, who was Lord-Keeper to Queen Elizabeth at the time, and the personified figures of the Great Seal and the Mace. Hatton dances facing right, his body turned slightly forward. He holds a red rose to his nose with elegant posturing. Hatton is richly dressed in a spiky ruff, a "doublet" (see letterpress text) with fur trim, breeches with a ribbon bow visible at the right knee, tights, and high-heeled shoes. He has short, curly hair and a curly beard, and is holding a hat with a large plume. The personified figure of the Great Seal dances beneath the text panel (see "Seals & Maces," Blake's text, Object 22) His body is the round seal with arms and legs attached. Two ribbons billow above and to the right of his head, which is wreathed with laurels. A third ribbon flies to the right from between his legs, becoming a devil's forked tail. The seal itself displays a shield in the center of a circlet of text (see the Textual Transcription). His left hand lies in the much larger hand of the dancing Mace, to the right. The head of this figure represents the ornately decorated royal Mace, with eyes, a scrollwork nose, and a smiling, partially open mouth added. The upper part of his head is in the shape of a crown. The rest of the Mace's body appears human, with a torso, arms, hands, legs and feet. The Mace dances with his right foot drawn up and his weight momentarily resting on his left toes. With the hand of his upraised left arm he grasps an enormous staff or mace. The head of this staff displays a bishop standing in a niche. The Mace wears a wide, spiky collar, a shirt with large buttons down the front, breeches with knee ties, stockings, and shoes with ribbon laces tied into bows. The wall visible in the background is decorated with a facade of two pillars supporting an arch and part of a second arch. Above each pillar, a different shield or heraldic crest appears in each spandrel. Decorative tracery, vaguely sketched, fills in wall space between crests and arches. The floor is bare, but baseboards appear along the base of the wall and pillar. Together these decorative elements suggest a palatial environment. Each of the three dancing figures casts a shadow on the floor below. Other, less definite shadows appear on the wall behind, especially near the arches.

component.illusobjdesc: The Lord-Keeper to Queen Elizabeth, Sir Christopher Hatton, appears at the left side of the design. Hatton dances facing right, his body turned slightly forward; he sniffs a red rose. Hatton's straight left leg is slightly forward, while his right is bent and drawn back. His right foot rests on tiptoe. His left arm is bent up in front of his torso, and he holds the rose elegantly with the thumb and middle finger of this hand, bending his head slightly to bring his nose near its petals. His left pinky finger is raised. His right arm is drawn back and bent, and his right hand is propped on his right hip or buttock. A tall hat with a large plume rests against his hip, as if he holds the brim with his right hand. He wears a spiky ruff, a "doublet" (see the letterpress text) with fur trim at the waist and possibly also on his right cuff, breeches with a ribbon bow at the right knee, and tights. His high-heeled shoes have "shoe-strings green" (see the letterpress text). He has short, curly hair and a curly beard.

The personified figure of the Great Seal dances beneath the text panel. His body, the round seal with arms and legs, faces forward on a diagonal from upper left to lower right. His legs are spread, with the right leg extended down and the left leg bent and drawn back. Neither foot touches the floor. He holds both arms out horizontally from his side. His right palm faces out and his left lies in the much larger hand of the dancing Mace, to the right. He turns his head, bald and wreathed with laurels, to the right. Two ribbons billow above and to the right of his head, while a third flies to the right from between his legs. This third ribbon becomes a devil's forked tail, looped once. The seal itself displays a shield in the center of a circlet of text (see the Textual Transcription).

The personified figure of the Mace dances at the right side of the design, facing forward. His head represents the head of the ornately decorated royal Mace, with eyes, a scrollwork nose, and a smiling, partially opened mouth added. The upper part of his head is in the shape of a crown. The rest of his body appears human, with a torso, arms, hands, legs, and feet. The Mace dances with his right leg bent and drawn up beneath him, balancing momentarily on the toes of his left foot. His left leg is slightly bent. His body with its large belly bends left slightly. He raises his slightly bent left arm vertically and grasps an enormous staff or mace with his left hand. The head of this staff displays a bishop, identified by his hat, standing in a niche. The Mace extends his bent right arm at 45 degrees to the left and holds the hand of the Great Seal in his own much larger right hand. The Mace wears a wide, spiky collar, a shirt with large buttons down the front, breeches with knee ties, stockings, and shoes with ribbon laces tied into bows.

The wall visible in the background is decorated with two pillars or pilasters supporting an arch and part of a second arch. Above each pillar, a different shield or heraldic crest appears in each spandrel. Decorative tracery, vaguely sketched, fills in wall space between crests and arches. The floor is bare, but baseboards appear along the base of the wall and pillars. Together these decorative elements suggest a palatial environment probably built of stone.
Each of the three dancing figures casts a shadow on the floor below. Other, less definite shadows appear on the wall behind, especially near the arches.

lg.l: ELIZABETH REX MCIIThe line is written in a circle on the seal carried by the figure below the text panel. The shape preceding the first word may be an asterisk, but it could also be a decorative device (rather than a textual feature) used to separate the beginning and ending of this circular line.

desc.objtitle: A Long Story: Page 5, Object 27 (Butlin 335.27)

objnote.p: The cross, inscribed by Blake in pencil, left of line 16 of the letterpress text on the previous page (Object 26) indicates the line or passage illustrated on this page.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Two young women walk arm in arm at the right side of the design, facing right. The body of the young woman on the left faces forward slightly. Her bent left arm is forward and the fingers of her left hand are visible resting in the crook of her companion's right arm. Her right arm is also down by her side and bent up and forward. She raises her right hand slightly and gesticulates with her index finger pointed. The young woman on the right faces to the right, but turns her head down and to the left to look at her companion. Her right arm is down by her side but bent upward and held forward. Like her companion she also lifts her right index finger to point upward. Her slightly bent left arm is vertically raised, and she holds a partially open fan above her head. Both women have long, curly hair and wear hats and short-sleeved gowns. A building or high wall fills much of the left side of the design and supports a leafy vine. Three stone steps rise leftward from the ground where the young women walk. A stone pillar runs the length of the side of the design from the top step to the upper left corner. Wash along the ground where the young women walk indicates grass. A grape(?) vine with four leaves (or clusters of leaves) and one loop in its tendrils climbs the wall at the left side of the design, above the text panel. Wash above and around the women suggest a cloudy sky, perhaps at sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: Two young women walk arm in arm at the right side of the design, facing right. The body of the young woman on the left faces forward slightly. Her bent left arm is forward and the fingers of her left hand are visible resting in the crook of her companion's right arm. Her right arm is also down by her side and bent up and forward. She raises her right hand slightly and gesticulates with her index finger pointed. She has long curly hair loose around her shoulders, over which she wears a bonnet or cap with two large feathers or plumes in the front. Transparent ties or a scarf falls from the cap around her face and down into the open neckline of her long, short-sleeved gown. More folds of drapery appear over her shoulders. A button decorates her right sleeve. A ribbon billows from her waist behind her to the left. Her feet, clad in shoes, appear beneath the hem of her gown, and the shape of her skirt indicates that her right knee is bent forward. The young woman on the right faces to the right, but turns her head down and to the left to look at her companion. Her right arm is down by her side but bent upward and held forward. Like her companion she also lifts her right index finger. Her slightly bent left arm is vertically raised, and she holds a partially open fan above her head. Her long, curly hair is down and on her head is a wide-brimmed hat with a small plume. Transparent ties or a scarf covers her head beneath the hat and falls over her shoulders and the front of her gown. This gown is long and has short sleeves, both of which boast a visible button. One shoe appears beneath the hem of her gown. A ribbon dangles from her waist and flies before her.

A building or high wall fills much of the left side of the design and supports a leafy vine. Three stone steps rise leftward from the ground where the young women walk. A stone pillar runs the length of the side of the design from the top step to the upper left corner.
Wash along the ground where the young women walk indicates grass.
A grape(?) vine with four leaves (or clusters of leaves) and one loop in its tendrils climbs the wall at the left side of the design, above the text panel.
Wash around and above the women suggests a cloudy sky, perhaps at sunrise or sunset.

desc.objtitle: A Long Story: Page 6, Object 28 (Butlin 335.28)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 7 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Several children and a small crowd of farm animals take fright at the poet, who strides leftward at the left side of the design. Garbed in a long floral gown and holding an open book in one hand, the wild-haired poet walks with head bent and arms crossed. To the left of his legs three small pigs flee away leftward. At his feet, a hen with wings spread and mouth open herds her six chicks away to the right. Three geese run rightward with flapping wings. In front of the geese, and partially obscuring them, are two girls who run arm-in-arm to the right. The leftmost girl faces right but turns her head back to the left. The rightmost girl also runs to the right, but her body is turned slightly forward. She extends her slightly bent left arm horizontally leftward; it supports the right arm of the leftmost girl. Both girls wear shoes and long gowns with sleeves that come to their elbows. They have long, curly hair. A small boy just below the text panel also moves away from the poet in fear. Facing forward and to the right, he steps forward with his right leg. Both arms are bent upward at the elbow, and he holds both hands up and open with fingers spread and palms facing toward one another. His spiky hair stands on end, and he wears an expression of fright with eyes opened wide, eyebrows raised, and mouth opened. He is dressed in a shirt and collar and buttons, knee breeches with a buttoned flap, stockings, and shoes. A small cottage or farmhouse with a thatched roof appears in the background at the right side of the design, behind the girls clutching arms. A patch of plaster has worn away to the left of the cottage's double window, exposing the brick and mortar beneath. A fence in the lower left quadrant of the design partially encloses the yard in which the children and the animals take fright at the poet. The fence consists of rough wooden beams stood on end. Between the fence and the cottage is a small hill or mound. The poets and children stand or run on a dirt path before the cottage, which begins in the lower left corner of the design and leads through a gap between the fence and the cottage in the background. Leafy branches of a large tree, its trunk partially visible above the roof of the cottage, arch over the top of the design. Grass covers the ground to the left and right of the path in the lower portion of the design. Wash above the fence and cottage and surrounding the tree's branches suggests the sky, perhaps with clouds. The color of the wash between the fence and cottage hints at a sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: The wizard poet appears at the left side of the design, just to the left of the text box. He walks facing forward and left, his right foot forward and his left leg slightly bent and extended backward. His left foot is on tiptoe. His arms are crossed over his chest, with his left arm bent up so that his left hand rests on his shoulder. He may be gently leaning his chin against this hand as he bends his head forward and down. His left hand holds an open book with its illegible text facing the viewer; he marks his place with his thumb. His short hair is curly and wild and his cheeks are flushed. He wears slippers and a long robe or gown decorated with a floral motif featuring vines, leaves, and blossoms. He casts a dark shadow that falls on the ground below and to the left of his feet.

A small boy, who appears just below the text panel, walks away from the wizard poet in fear. This boy faces forward and to the right, and steps forward with his right leg. His left leg may be extended slightly behind him, with this foot on tiptoe. Both arms are at his side but bent upward at the elbow, and he holds both hands up and open with fingers spread and palms facing toward one another. His spiky hair stands on end, and he wears an expression of fright with eyes opened wide, eyebrows raised, and mouth opened. He is dressed in a shirt with a collar and buttons, knee breeches with a buttoned flap, stockings, and shoes.

Two girls near the lower right corner of the design run arm-in-arm to the right, away from the wizard poet. The leftmost girl faces right but turns her head back to the left. She runs with her slightly bent left leg forward, and her bent right leg extended backward. Her right foot is on tiptoe. She embraces her companion with her visible right arm, which is raised forward horizontally and bent slightly, and lies along the extended arm of the other girl. Her right hand rests on the other girl's shoulder. Both feet of the girl on the left are visible beneath the hem of her gown. The rightmost girl also runs to the right, with her left leg in front, but her body is turned slightly forward. Her head is turned to the left, so that her face is visible in three-quarters profile. Her head is bent back slightly. Only her left foot is visible beneath her skirts. She extends her slightly bent left arm horizontally leftward; it supports the right arm of the leftmost girl. Both girls wear shoes and long gowns with sleeves that come to their elbows. They have long, curly hair.

Farm animals flee in three directions from the wizard poet. Three geese run with flapping wings to the right, near the lower right corner of the design. They are partially hidden behind the two embracing girls, but their wings are visible to the left of the girls, and to the right appear their three outstretched necks. They have open mouths and wide eyes. Three small spotted pigs run left to the left of the poet, near the left edge of the design. All three pigs have open mouths as well. Finally, a hen appears near the bottom of the design, guiding her chicks away from the poet to the right. She walks or runs rightward with wings spread wide, head down, and mouth open. Six little chicks run in her care, four to the right of her and two to the left. Though they are sketchily drawn, several of these chicks appear to have their wings spread as well.

A small cottage or farmhouse with a thatched roof appears in the background at the right side of the design, behind the girls clutching arms. A patch of plaster has worn away to the left of the cottage's double window, exposing the brick and mortar beneath.
A fence in the lower left quadrant of the design partially encloses the yard in which the children and animals take fright at the poet. The fence consists of rough wooden beams stood on end.
Between the fence and the cottage is a small hill or mound.

The poets and children stand or run on a dirt path before the cottage. This path begins in the lower left corner of the design and leads through a gap between the fence and the cottage in the background.
Leafy branches of a large tree, its trunk partially visible above the roof of the cottage, arch over the top of the design.
Grass covers the ground to the left and right of the path in the lower portion of the design.
Wash above the fence and cottage and surrounding the tree's branches suggests the sky, perhaps with clouds. The color of the wash between the fence and cottage hints at a sunrise or sunset.

desc.objtitle: A Long Story: Page 7, Object 29 (Butlin 335.29)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 5 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This design contrasts two very different pairs of sisters. The poet's "Mother" and "Aunt" (see letterpress text), two older women, huddle meekly and fearfully together at the lower left corner of the design. The leftmost of these older ladies sits facing right and slightly forward, her head bowed and her eyes lowered or closed. Her hands are folded together before her face and her mouth is slightly open; she may be praying. Her sister sits next to her, to the right, facing right but turning her torso forward and to the left. She hides her face and much of her head behind her sister's back, and may be resting her bent head on her sister's shoulders. She embraces her sister with her left arm, which is extended to encircle the other woman's body, hand resting on waist. Both older women are dressed in long-sleeved gowns and cloaks that drape their shoulders; their heads are covered in simple hoods or caps. The pair of marauding younger sisters strides towards the staircase at the right side of the design, caught in the doorway to the stairs just as they begin to "rattle" upstairs "in a whirlwind" (see the letterpress text). They are positioned side by side, facing away and slightly right, but each woman turns her head to look leftward over her shoulder at the older women. Each extends her slightly bent right leg behind her, with high-heeled right foot on tiptoe. The rightmost sister brandishes a closed fan in her vertically raised, slightly bent right arm. The arms of the sister on the left are down by her side; her left arm may be bent. Both women wear long gowns that billow around their legs with their brisk motion. The tails of sashes tied beltlike around their waists flutter like regimental standards in their wake. Both sisters wear large plumed hats and semi-transparent shawls or scarfs that cover their hair beneath. The scene takes place inside a lower story room of a cottage or small house, with floors and walls made of wide wooden beams. A mullioned window with muntin bars appears at the left side of the design. Its frame seems to be made of wood, with large round nails in the corners and below the single mullion. A small round work table sits before the older women; on it rest a pair of spectacles, a spool of thread, a piece of cloth, and a pincushion spiky with pins. Shadows partly cover the skirts of the older women and fall on the floor behind their chairs, beneath the work table, and below the younger sisters. A lighter shadow appears on the stairs to the right of the younger women and below and to the right of their feet. A small birdcage hangs on a wire, string, or thin chain from the ceiling in the upper left corner of the design. The bird inside sits on a perch and leans its head back, mouth open as if in song.

component.illusobjdesc: The poet's "Mother" and "Aunt" (see the letterpress text) huddle meekly and fearfully together in the lower left corner of the design. The leftmost of these older ladies sits facing right and slightly forward, legs bent. Her head is bowed and her eyes lowered or closed. Her arms are by her side, bent upward before her torso, and her hands are folded together before her face. Her mouth is parted slightly, and she may be praying. She is wearing a long-sleeved gown that falls to the floor, hiding her feet. A cloth or cloak drapes over her shoulders and her head is partly covered with a simple hood or cap that ties under her chin. The gray hair surrounding her face is pulled back beneath this head covering, and may be short, or long and drawn back. Her sister sits next to her, to the right, facing right but turning her torso forward and to the left. Her legs are bent as well. She hides her face and much of her head behind her sister's back, and may be resting her bent head on her sister's shoulders. She embraces her sister with her left arm, which is extended to encircle the other woman's body, hand resting on waist. Like her sister, she is dressed in a long-sleeved gown and wears a shawl over her visible shoulder. Her head is similarly covered, with a bit of gray hair peeking from beneath.

The two older women sit huddled on two chairs in the lower left corner of the design. The leftmost woman sits on a chair facing to the right; one of its legs appears to the left of her skirts and part of the back of this chair is visible behind her back. The back of her sister's chair is partly visible to the right of the women, facing forward and slightly right.

A small round work table sits before the older women huddled in the lower left corner of the design. On this table rest a pair of spectacles, a spool of thread, and a pincushion spiky with pins. A small piece of cloth lies puddled on the table and may spill slightly over the edge.

The two younger sisters stride towards the staircase at the right side of the design, caught just as they begin to "rattle" upstairs "in a whirlwind" (see the letterpress text). They are positioned side by side, facing away and slightly right, but each woman turns her head to look leftward over her shoulder at the older women. Each extends her slightly bent right leg behind her, with high-heeled right foot on tiptoe. The rightmost sister brandishes a closed fan in her vertically raised, slightly bent right arm. The arms of the sister on the left are down by her side; her left arm may be bent. Both women wear long gowns that billow around their legs with their brisk motion. The tails of sashes tied beltlike around their waists flutter like regimental standards in their wake. The sister on the right wears a wide-brimmed hat with two small plumes; a semi-transparent scarf or shawl falls from beneath this hat to drape over her shoulders. Her curly hair emerges from beneath this hat, and may be short or may be pulled into a low bun faintly visible just above her right shoulder. The leftmost sister wears a small-brimmed hat with two enormous plumes. Her semi-transparent scarf covers her hair and shoulders and falls to a point behind her back. Her curly dark hair is long and worn down; it peeks from beneath her hat and appears, slightly obscured, below her scarf.
A doorway at the right side of the design opens to show part of an ascending staircase.

Shadows partly cover the skirts of the older women and fall on the floor behind their chairs, beneath the work table, and below the younger sisters. A lighter shadow appears on the stairs to the right of the younger women and below and to the right of their feet.
A small birdcage hangs on a wire, string, or thin chain from the ceiling in the upper left corner of the design.
A bird perches on a bar inside the bird cage, its head bent back and its mouth wide open as if it is singing.
A mullioned window with muntin bars appears at the left side of the design. Its frame seems to be made of wood, with large round nails in the corners and below the single mullion.
The scene takes place inside a lower story room of a cottage or small house. Its floors and walls are made of wide wooden beams.

desc.objtitle: A Long Story: Page 8, Object 30 (Butlin 335.30)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 8 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: With flashes of lightning surrounding them, the two sisters flee through an open window that is positioned in the upper right corner of the design. Blake depicts the women suspended in parallel flight as they descend leftward from the window: the women's torsos face down but their backs are arched and their feet trail behind and above them. Each turns her head to look up and to the right, behind them; each wears a slight smile. Both sisters wear large hats with plumes, long gowns with sleeves that reach the elbow, and skirts that sweep behind them. Their beltlike sashes billow in the wind they create. The rightmost sister holds her bent arms before her, below her head, and grasps a partially open fan in her left hand. With her right index finger she makes a pointing gesture. Her sister, partially hidden behind her, extends her left arm up and to the right roughly horizontally and bends her right arm up in front of her torso. She makes a pointing gesture with both index fingers. Jagged lightning appears above, below, and behind the sisters. Wash around the leftmost sister's hat and to the right of the rightmost sister's hat suggests that the women also may emit light. The corner of a table is visible through the open window. On the table rests a letter of invitation for the poet; this is the "spell upon the table" (see the letterpress text) which the young women leave. The space inside the window, around the lightning and the table, is filled with shadow. A portion of a second window appears in the lower left corner of the design. The wall of the house or cottage in which the windows appear is made of brick and mortar. A leafy grape(?) vine climbs the brick wall from the lower right corner to the upper left corner of the design. The leaves of the plant cast shadows on the wall, especially to the left of the text panel and in the bottom right corner of the design.

component.illusobjdesc: With flashes of lightning surrounding them, the two sisters flee through an open window. Blake depicts the women suspended in parallel flight as they descend leftward from the window: the women's torsos face down but their backs are arched and their feet trail behind and above them. Each turns her head forward to look up and to the right, behind them; each wears a slight smile. Both sisters wear long gowns with sleeves that reach the elbow and skirts that sweep behind them. Their waists are tied with beltlike sashes that billow in the wind they create. Only one foot is visible, clad in a shoe. It belongs to the rightmost sister and appears just beyond the hem of her dress. The rightmost young woman partially hides the body of her sister, behind her. This rightmost sister holds her bent arms before her, below her head. She grasps a partially open fan in her left hand, which is extended slightly beyond her right. With her right index finger she makes a pointing gesture. She wears a wide-brimmed hat with two small plumes. Under this hat a semi-transparent scarf drapes over her hair and shoulders. Beneath this scarf her hair is long and curly. Her mouth may be slightly open. Her sister, behind her, extends her left arm up and to the right, roughly horizontally; it is visible below the elbow. This sister's right arm is bent up in front of her torso. She makes a pointing gesture with both index fingers. She wears a small-brimmed hat with two enormous feathered plumes, and a semi-transparent scarf that falls to her shoulders from below this hat. Her curly dark hair, perhaps long, escapes from beneath hat and scarf. Jagged lightning appears above, below, and behind the sisters. Wash around the leftmost sister's hat and to the right of the rightmost sister's hat suggests that the women also may emit light.

The open window through which the two young women fly appears near the upper right corner of the design. The fanlight above the window is arched. Part of another window, on the floor below, shows in the lower left corner of the design.

The corner of a table is visible through the open window. On the table rests a letter of invitation for the poet; this is the "spell upon the table" (see the letterpress text) which the two young women leave. The text on the letter is illegible.
The space inside the window, around the lightning and the table, is filled with shadow. The leaves of the vine lower right also cast shadows on the wall behind them.
The wall of the house or cottage in which the windows appear is brick and mortar.

A leafy grape(?) vine climbs the brick wall from the lower right corner to the upper left corner of the design. The leaves of the plant cast shadows on the wall, especially to the left of the text panel and in the bottom right corner of the design.

desc.objtitle: A Long Story: Page 9, Object 31 (Butlin 335.31)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 17 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A tall ghost or phantom stands "sentry" in the "chapel-door" (see the letterpress text) at the right side of the design, facing left and slightly forward. This phantom has a skull-like head with a wide, toothy grimace and a shadowed nasal aperture. A single flame shoots from each round eye socket. Long, sparse hairs grow from its cheeks and chin to form a thin beard. A shroud, cloth, or cloak drapes over its head, wraps its chin, and and falls to the floor like a gown. The phantom holds the butt of an enormous rifle with a hand or claw faintly visible down by its left side; the barrel of the rifle rests against the phantom's left side and shoulder. A bayonet attached to the end of the rifle extends beyond the top of the design. One foot or shoe may appear beneath the hem of the phantom's gown. Lines of the stone in the doorway are visible through the phantom's semi-transparent gown. Styack the housekeeper, in the lower left corner of the design, reacts to the phantom in fright. She leans and strides to the left with her bent right leg forward and her left leg extended backward. Her torso is turned slightly forward, and she twists her head back and up to the right to look back at the phantom. Her arms are bent up in front of her torso and her hands are raised with palms together. Her face is contorted in an expression of terror, with her mouth wide open. She wears a long gown with sleeves that come to her elbow. An apron circles her waist and falls to the floor over her gown. Her head is covered with a ruffled cap that ties beneath her chin; a cloak drapes her shoulders. Both of her feet appear beneath the hem of her gown. Her clearly visible right shoe has a buckle and a high heel. The open stone doorway of the chapel, in which the phantom stands, takes up most of the right side of the design. Arches forming a trefoil at the top of the doorway are partially visible between the top of the design and the text box. A single step leads to the doorway. The stone wall of the chapel fills the left side of the design. The housekeeper casts a dark shadow in the lower left corner of the design. The wall is also shadowed, and darker shadows fill the doorway especially to the right of the phantom. Beams of light extend up and to the left from the phantom's head.

component.illusobjdesc: A tall ghost or phantom stands "sentry" in the "chapel-door" (see the letterpress text) at the right side of the design, facing left and slightly forward. This phantom has a skull-like head with a wide, toothy grimace and a shadowed nasal aperture. A single flame shoots from each round eye socket. Long, sparse hairs grow from its cheeks and chin to form a thin beard. A shroud, cloth, or cloak drapes over its head, wraps its chin, and falls to the floor like a gown. The phantom holds the butt of an enormous rifle with a hand or claw faintly visible down by its left side; the barrel of the rifle rests against the phantom's left side and shoulder. A bayonet attached to the end of the rifle extends beyond the top of the design. One foot or shoe may appear beneath the hem of the phantom's gown. Lines of the stone in the doorway are visible through the phantom's semi-transparent gown.

Styack the housekeeper, in the lower left corner of the design, reacts to the phantom in fright. She leans and strides to the left with her bent right leg forward and her left leg extended backward. Her torso is turned slightly forward, and she twists her head back and up to the right to look back at the phantom. Her arms are bent up in front of her torso and her hands are raised with palms together. Her face is contorted in an expression of terror, with her mouth wide open. She wears a long gown with sleeves that come to her elbow. An apron circles her waist and falls to the floor over her gown. Her head is covered with a ruffled cap that ties beneath her chin; a cloak drapes her shoulders. Both of her feet appear beneath the hem of her gown. Her clearly visible right shoe has a buckle and a high heel.

The phantom stands in the open stone doorway of the chapel, which takes up most of the right side of the design. Arches forming a trefoil at the top of the doorway are partially visible between the top of the design and the text box. A single step leads to the doorway.
The stone wall of the chapel fills the left side of the design.
The housekeeper casts a dark shadow in the lower left corner of the design. The wall is also shadowed, and darker shadows fill the doorway especially to the right of the phantom.
Beams of light extend up and to the left from the phantom's head.

desc.objtitle: A Long Story: Page 10, Object 32 (Butlin 335.32)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 2 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The "Bard' stands "mute" (see the letterpress text) in the lower right corner of the design, facing left. His left leg is bent and his left foot is on tiptoe; he may be pacing. His arms are down by his side, but bent up at the elbows; he holds his forearms up and out in front of him with his hands up, palms out. He wears a shirt and ruffled ascot or scarf under a long coat with a large collar. His lower body is clad in breeches with buttons at the knee, stockings, and buckled shoes. His long, curly hair is tied back with a ribbon. He casts a shadow on the floor extending from his feet to the right. Lady Cobham, the "Peeress" (see the letterpress text), sits facing right and slightly forward in a chair on a stone dais or plinth in the upper left corner of the design. She leans forward and to the right, with her bent legs beneath her skirt drawn away from the viewer and her elbows propped on the arms of her chair. She wears a long gown with voluminous skirts that cover her feet, a wide belt, and a large hat with a band and two plumes. A scarf falls from under her hat, drapes her shoulders, and forms a v-shaped neckline over her gown. Strands of long curly hair escape from beneath her hat and scarf. Her chair has thick, rounded arms; no back is visible. A footrest draped in fabric with a scalloped hem appears beneath her skirts. Shadows fall across much of the right arm of the chair and part of her skirts. An audience of ten ladies sits shoulder to shoulder, facing right and slightly forward, beneath Lady Cobham's dais. The line they form begins in the lower left corner of the design and slants gently upward to the right, away from the viewer. All wear long gowns with a variety of necklines; all boast diverse headdresses except the three rightmost women, whose heads are hidden by the text box. Together they form a tribunal headed by Lady Cobham and convened to judge the poet. A large stone column or pilaster with Ionic scrolls fills much of the background at the right side of the design. The walls and floor of the room seem to be stone. Drapery or a curtain descends from the top left corner. Shadows fall between Lady Cobham's skirts and the text box, in the upper right corner of the design, and in the lower left corner of the design.

component.illusobjdesc: The poet stands "mute" (see the letterpress text) in the lower right corner of the design, facing left. His left leg is bent and his left foot is on tiptoe: he may be pacing. His arms are down by his side, but bent up at the elbows; he holds his forearms up and out in front of him with his hands up, palms out. His head is bent and his visible left eyebrow drawn. His mouth is open, with upper teeth visible. He wears a shirt and ruffled scarf or ascot under a long coat with a large collar. His lower body is clad in breeches with buttons at the knee, stockings, and buckled shoes. His long, curly hair is tied back. He casts a shadow on the floor extending from his feet to the right.

Lady Cobham, the "Peeress" (see the letterpress text), sits facing right and slightly forward in a chair on a stone dais or plinth in the upper left corner of the design. She leans forward and to the right, with her bent legs beneath her skirt drawn away from the viewer. Her bent right arm is drawn slightly back and rests along the arm of her chair; her right hand dangles or rests against the end of this arm. With her right index finger she makes a pointing gesture. She has drawn her left arm forward and props her left elbow on the chair's other arm, with her left forearm bent up and her left hand near her face. She wears a long gown with voluminous skirts that cover her feet, a wide belt, and a large hat with a band and two plumes. A scarf falls from under her hat, drapes her shoulders, and forms a v-shaped neckline over her gown. Strands of long curly hair escape from beneath her hat and scarf. Her chair has thick, rounded arms; no back is visible. A footrest draped in fabric with a scalloped hem appears beneath her skirts. Shadow falls across much of the right arm of the chair and part of her skirts.

An audience of ten ladies sits shoulder to shoulder, facing right and slightly forward, beneath Lady Cobham's dais. The line they form begins in the lower left corner of the design and slants gently upward to the right, away from the viewer. With Lady Cobham as their head, these women form a tribunal convened to judge the poet. The leftmost lady sits with her right arm bent, forearm resting along her lap, and her right hand up, palm out. She looks left and wears a long gown with elbow-length sleeves and a wide ruffled collar. Curls of long hair emerge at forehead and neck beneath her large hat. A long earring dangles from her visible right ear. Wrinkles on her forehead suggest she is older. Second from left sits a woman wearing a long gown and an architectural bonnet over a headpiece, possibly jeweled, that drapes down towards her forehead.
