Several curls appear on either side of her bonnet. The wide triangular lapels of her collar are closed at the neck with small buttons or a clasp. Her arms are not visible. She turns her head slightly forward, so that her face is seen in three-quarters profile, and seems to be smiling.
The woman third from left looks to the right and wears a feathered headdress and an Elizabethan ruff in addition to her gown. A flower pendant with stem and leaves hangs from her v-shaped neckline (alternatively, this may be a necklace). Her arms are not visible. Her forehead is wrinkled, suggesting age.
The woman fourth from left sits looking right with lowered eyes; her face is visible in three-quarters profile. She wears a long cloak with a pointed hood drawn over her head and clasped at the neck with a knot. A tighter collar appears at her neck inside this hood. Her hair is short or drawn up under a scarf or other headpiece just visible beneath her hood; a jewel or other ornament hangs from this scarf over her hair. Her arms do not appear.
The woman fifth from left sits with her arms bent at the elbows and her forearms held out in front of her; her hands are up with vertical palms facing out. She turns her head to look left at her neighbor and her face is visible in three-quarters profile. Her mouth is open. She wears a long gown with long cuffed sleeves and a wide, tall collar. Her hair is either short, or long and swept up into her pointed hat. An earring adorns her visible left ear.
The woman sixth from left sits looking right, with her head bent down and lips curved in a slight smile. Her left forearm rests along her lap and she holds her left hand up, palm out. She wears a short-sleeved gown with a wide belt and a high bonnet with a ruffled brim. Two curly strands of hair, or perhaps ribbon, appear over her left shoulder.
The woman seventh from left turns her upper body forward and to the left to look at the woman in a bonnet. Her left arm rests along her lap and she lifts her left fingers slightly. A wide, decorated collar surmounts her long gown and she wears a bonnet or other headdress on her head. Her gown is the only one with a decorative hem. Wrinkles on her forehead suggest that she is an older woman. Three other women complete the row, but their heads are hidden behind the text box and their arms do not appear. A ruff adorns the costume of the leftmost of these women; a circular collar appears on the gown of the middle woman, and a v-shaped collar tops the gown of the woman at the right. Their long gowns hide all the women's feet. One chair is partially visible, the support of the leftmost woman. Its back and rear right leg appear beneath and to the left of her skirts. Shadow covers much of the chair and also falls across this woman's skirts.
A large stone column or pilaster with Ionic scrolls fills much of the background at the right side of the design.

The walls and floor of the room seem to be stone. Drapery or a curtain descends from the top left corner. Shadows fall between Lady Cobham's skirts and the text box, in the upper right corner of the design, and in the lower left corner of the design.

desc.objtitle: A Long Story: Page 11, Object 33 (Butlin 335.33)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 12 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The poet stands or walks facing away from the viewer in the lower right corner of the design. His upper body is turned slightly left. With his weight on his right foot, he bends his left leg and extends it backwards, his left foot on tiptoe. His arms are by his side and bent at the elbow, with forearms horizontal and hands raised with palms out and fingers spread. He wears a long coat with a large collar, knee breeches, stockings, and shoes. His long curly hair is tied back. The Peeress, Lady Cobham, appears facing right just to the right of the text panel as she descends the stairs from her dais. The toes of her daintily-heeled left foot just touch the floor, while the shape of her skirts suggests that her right leg is bent, though her right foot is hidden. Smiling gently, she bends her head graciously and turns it slightly forward, towards the poet. Her arms are by her side but bent at the elbow, and she holds her lower arms raised at about 45 degrees before her. Her hands fall from her wrists with palms facing out. She wears a large, wide-brimmed hat with two plumes; a transparent scarf falls from beneath this hat and drapes over her shoulders. Her long curly hair appears beneath this scarf, and strands escape from it to frame her face. She wears a long gown, or shirt and skirt, with a wide belt at the waist. The sleeves of her top end at her elbows and may be decorated with a button or other ornament at the cuffs. Four of the ladies who form the tribunal convened under Lady Cobham to judge the poet are visible sitting side by side near the lower left corner of the design. All four women sit facing right and slightly forward. Lady Cobham's chair sits on a stone dais or plinth in the upper left corner of the design. Only one of its curved arms is visible. Several steps leading down from the dais in the upper left corner appear beneath the text panel. The steps, the walls, and the floor of the room seem made of stone. A stone column or pilaster is visible above the text panel. Shadows fall on the chair and the wall in the upper left corner of the design, on the floor and on the skirts of the leftmost lady in the lower left corner of the design, and on the wall to the left and right of Lady Cobham. Lighter shadows mark the wall in the upper right corner.

component.illusobjdesc: The poet stands or walks facing away from the viewer in the lower right corner of the design. His upper body is turned slightly left. With his weight on his right foot, he bends his left leg and extends it backwards, his left foot on tiptoe. His arms are by his side and bent at the elbow, with forearms horizontal and hands raised with palms out and fingers spread. He wears a long coat with a large collar, knee breeches, stockings, and shoes. His long curly hair is tied back.

The Peeress, Lady Cobham, appears facing right just to the right of the text panel as she descends the stairs from her dais. The toes of her daintily-heeled left foot just touch the floor, while the shape of her skirts suggests that her right leg is bent, though her right foot is hidden. Smiling gently, she bends her head graciously and turns it slightly forward, towards the poet. Her arms are by her side but bent at the elbow, and she holds her lower arms raised at about 45 degrees before her. Her hands fall from her wrists with palms facing out. She wears a large, wide-brimmed hat with two plumes; a transparent scarf falls from beneath this hat and drapes over her shoulders. Her long curly hair appears beneath this scarf, and strands escape from it to frame her face. She wears a long gown, or shirt and skirt, with a wide belt at the waist. The sleeves of her top end at her elbows and may be decorated with a button or other ornament at the cuffs.

Four of the ladies who form the tribunal convened under Lady Cobham to judge the poet are visible sitting side by side near the lower left corner of the design. All four women sit facing right and slightly forward, but the rightmost turns her head to the left to look at her neighbor. Her mouth is open and her eyebrow creased in an expression of surprise or concern. This rightmost woman wears a long gown that hides her feet and a large bonnet over a wimple. Her bent left arm is down by her side; her lower arm may rest partially on her lap. Her wrinkled visage suggests her age. A few curly strands of hair may be visible over her forehead; alternatively this may be a fringe on her wimple.
The face of the younger woman second to right is visible in three-quarters profile. She tilts her head back and lifts her eyes, her mouth open as if in prayer. She holds her folded hands before her, palms together; her arms are bent. She wears a long-sleeved gown, shoes with pointed toes, and a large headpiece that boasts draped fabric and two cross ornaments.
The woman second from left turns her head to the right, her mouth open and her eyebrows raised. Her arms are bent and she clasps her hands in front of her torso. She wears a large bonnet or mob cap and a long-sleeved gown with a large collar that is fastened at the neck with a button or other ornament. Her pointed shoes are visible beneath the hem of her gown. Her wrinkled neck and face suggests that she is older.
The leftmost woman is only partially visible; her face, turned to the left, and the right side of her body extend outside the border of the design. Her lower arms are raised and she holds her clasped hands in front of her torso. She wears a gown with long sleeves and cuffs and a large collar, and a pointed hat. A strand of curly hair or ribbon may appear over her left shoulder. Her gown hides her feet.
Lady Cobham's chair sits on a stone dais or plinth in the upper left corner of the design. Only one of its curved arms is visible.

Several steps leading down from the dais in the upper left corner appear beneath the text panel. The steps, the walls, and the floor of the room seem made of stone. A stone pillar or pilaster above the text panel.

Shadows fall on the chair and the wall in the upper left corner of the design, on the floor and on the skirts of the leftmost lady in the lower left corner of the design, and on the wall to the left and right of Lady Cobham. Lighter shadows mark the wall in the upper right corner.

desc.objtitle: A Long Story: Page 12, Object 34 (Butlin 335.34)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 7 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The poet stands at the right side of the design, facing left and reading his poetry. His dress seems Grecian or Roman, including a crown of laurels over his short curly hair and a long gown. One bare foot, his left, appears beneath the hem of this gown. His left arm is by his side, bent at the elbow with forearm horizontal; he holds a manuscript in the form of an open book or stack of papers in his left hand. He extends his right arm forward, bent slightly up, and holds his right hand up with vertical palm facing out. Shadows fall down the back of his gown. His audience consists of three representatives of upper class society, seated at a card table near the lower left corner of the design; their reactions range from surprise to boredom. One of these, a well-dressed man, sits facing forward and to the right behind the table, to the left of the text panel. He looks at the poet with surprise, his eyebrows raised and his mouth open. His right arm is bent and his right elbow may rest on the table; both forearms are raised and his hands are lifted with palms facing out. The man wears an enormous neck scarf, ruffled ascot, possibly a vest, and coat with a large collar. His hair is short and curly. His lower body is hidden behind the table. To the left of this man sits a woman positioned at the end of the table farthest from the poet, near the left edge of the design. She faces right but may be looking at the man seated at the table rather than at the poet. Her right forearm is visible, raised horizontally above the table, with cards held in her right hand. Under her hat, her hair is curly and short, or drawn back. Shadows fall below her right arm. Her lower body is hidden. The third figure at the table, a woman, sits in front of the table and faces away and to the right. She leans back in her chair and bends her head down slightly. Her head is turned to the right so that her face is visible in profile, and her mouth shape suggests she may be smiling slightly as she looks toward the table. Her bent right arm is raised and extended roughly horizontally; she rests her forearm on the table and holds six cards in her upraised right hand. She wears a long gown with voluminous skirts that hides her feet, though its shape reveals that her right leg is bent. A scarf drapes her shoulders. Her long hair is gathered into a snood behind her head, while shorter curls frame her face. She seems to be ignoring the poet completely. The backrest of her chair faces the viewer, and only its rear legs are visible under her skirts. The chair casts shadows on the back of her dress. Shadows fall diagonally across the top of the design from top right to lower left edge, and fill the space under the table and to the right of the poet.

component.illusobjdesc: Three representatives of upper class society play cards at a table in the lower left corner of the design. A well-dressed man sits behind the table, to the left of the text panel, facing forward and to the right. He looks at the poet with surprise, his eyebrows raised and his mouth open. His right arm is bent and his right elbow may rest on the table; both forearms are raised and his hands are lifted with palms facing out. The man wears an enormous neck scarf, ruffled ascot, possibly a vest, shirt, and coat with a large collar. His hair is short and curly. His lower body is hidden behind the table.

A woman sits in front of the table, facing away and to the right. She leans back in her chair and bends her head down slightly. Her head is turned to the right so that her face is visible in profile, and her mouth shape suggests she may be smiling slightly as she looks towards the table. Her bent right arm is raised and extended roughly horizontally; she rests her forearm on the table and holds six cards in her upraised right hand. She wears a long gown with voluminous skirts that hide her feet, though its shape reveals that her right leg is bent. A scarf drapes her shoulders. Her long hair is gathered into a snood behind her head, while shorter curls frame her face. She seems to be ignoring the poet completely. The backrest of her chair faces the viewer, and only its rear legs are visible under her skirts. The chair casts shadows on the back of her dress.

The third figure seated at the table is a woman positioned at the end farthest from the poet, near the left edge of the design. She faces right but may be looking at her seated male companion to the right, rather than at the poet. Her right forearm is visible, raised horizontally above the table, with cards held in her right hand. Under her hat, her hair is curly and short, or drawn back. Her clothing is not easily determined; possibly a gown. Shadows fall below her right arm. Her lower body is hidden.
A large table near the lower left corner of the design supports a game of cards played by three figures. A single card and a stack of cards lies near the middle of this table.

The poet stands at the right side of the design, facing left and reading his poems to a disinterested audience. His dress seems Grecian or Roman, including a crown of laurels over his short curly hair and a long gown. One bare foot, his left, appears beneath the hem of this gown. His left arm is by his side, bent at the elbow with forearm horizontal; he holds a manuscript in the form of an open book or stack of papers in his left hand. He extends his right arm forward, bent slightly up, and holds his right hand up with vertical palm facing out. Shadows fall down the back of his gown.
Shadows fall diagonally across the top of the design from top right to lower left edge of the design, and fill the space under the table and to the right of the poet.

desc.objtitle: Ode to Adversity; Page 1: Title-Page, Object 35 (Butlin 335.35)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A tall man in mourning, probably "A Widower" (see Blake's text, Object 36), stands at the right side of the design, facing forward. His arms are down but bent upward at the elbows and crossed over his chest. His left hand seems to be hidden inside his clothing, but his right hand makes a loose fist. He tilts his head back slightly and raises his eyes to look upward. His mouth is open slightly. He has short curly hair and a similar beard. He wears a long gown or robe that falls past his feet and puddles slightly on the ground; it seems to be semi-transparent as his left knee and foot are visible through it, positioned slightly forward. Two children huddle close on either side of the man, who may be their father. The child on the left faces right and slightly forward. Long hair suggests that this child may be a girl. She wears a long cloak that covers her upraised arms and hands as she buries her face in its folds. This garment hides the rest of her body, including her feet. The child on the right, who seems to be a boy, faces left and slightly away; he is seen partially from behind. He lowers his head and wraps his slightly bent left arm, raised at 45 degrees, around his father's knee. His left leg is bent and his bare left foot is on tiptoe; his right arm and leg are not visible. He is wearing tights with a belt or well-defined waist and a wide collar seen from behind. His hair is short and curly. The man's clothing partially drapes over the back of the boy at his side. A tombstone juts out of the ground at an angle in the lower left corner of the design. Scrolling lines at the top of the tombstone suggest decorations or perhaps inscriptions. The stone is otherwise blank of writing, though a shadow cuts across it diagonally. The ground on which the tombstone and the grieving family stands is covered with grass. Its hilly little mounds suggest a graveyard. Wash at the top of the design and to the left of the text box suggests the sky, perhaps with clouds interspersed near the top of the design and gathered more thickly to the left of the text box. Shadow fills the design to the left of the tombstone, between the stone and the grieving family, and between the family and the right edge of the design.

component.illusobjdesc: A tall man in mourning, probably "A Widower" (see the Textual Transcription, Object 36), stands at the right side of the design, facing forward. His arms are down but bent upward at the elbows and crossed over his chest. His left hand seems to be hidden inside his clothing, but his right hand makes a loose fist. He tilts his head back slightly and raises his eyes to look upward. His mouth is open slightly. He has short curly hair and a similar beard. He wears a long gown or robe that falls past his feet and puddles slightly on the ground; it seems to be semi-transparent as his left knee and foot are visible through it, positioned slightly forward. Two children huddle close on either side of the man, who may be their father. The child on the left faces right and slightly forward. Long hair suggests that this child may be a girl. She wears a long cloak that covers her upraised arms and hands as she buries her face in its folds. This garment hides the rest of her body, including her feet. The child on the right, who seems to be a boy, faces left and slightly away; he is seen partially from behind. He lowers his head and wraps his slightly bent left arm, raised at 45 degrees, around his father's knee. His left leg is bent and his bare left foot is on tiptoe; his right arm and leg are not visible. He is wearing tights with a belt or well-defined waist and a wide collar seen from behind. His hair is short and curly. The man's clothing partially drapes over the back of the boy at his side.

A tombstone juts out of the ground at an angle in the lower left corner of the design. Scrolling lines at the top of the tombstone suggest decorations or perhaps inscriptions. The stone is otherwise blank of writing, though a shadow cuts across it diagonally.
The ground on which the tombstone and the grieving family stands is covered with grass. Its hilly little mounds suggest a graveyard.

Wash at the top of the design and to the left of the text box suggests the sky, perhaps with clouds interspersed near the top of the design and gathered more thickly to the left of the text box. Shadow fills the design to the left of the tombstone, between the stone and the grieving family, and between the family and the right edge of the design.

desc.objtitle: Ode to Adversity; Page 2: Blank Page Bearing List of Titles, Object 36 (Butlin 335.36)

illustration.illusobjdesc: This cross-sectional design displays the stumps of several large trees, above ground, and the spreading roots of the largest stump below ground. The largest stump, belonging to what was once an enormous tree, appears to the right of the text panel. Its roots fan out below: one large root branch stretches to the left and sends two large tendrils downward before it curves down itself and ends near the left edge of the design; another large root branch extends down below the stump and splits into several smaller offshoots. Two more stumps appear to the left of the text box, on the same level as the largest stump. The larger of these two stumps, on the right, sends out roots that seem to extend above ground to the left and right, above the roots of the largest tree. The personified figure of Grief (see the Textual Transcription) appears as a gowned, seated woman curled within the underground embrace of several additional roots near, but not clearly connected to the roots of the largest tree stump. Grief sits facing forward and to the right, with her legs bent away from the viewer. Twisting her torso forward and lowering her left shoulder, she cradles an infant in the crook of her left arm with her left elbow and forearm resting along her lap. Her right arm is by her side and bent, forearm horizontal, and she holds her left breast between her right index and middle fingers as if guiding it towards the child in her other arm. The tiny nude infant, which seems to have sparse, short, curly hair, lies face up with its head back and its left arm dangling over Grief's arm. This limp posture and its facial expression, with eyes closed and mouth open, suggests that it is dead. But Grief bends over it carefully, lowering her head to gaze fixedly at the child's face. Her long wild hair falls over her shoulders and merges with the roots that encircle woman and child. Shadows below Grief and to the right suggest the darkness of an underground cave-like hollow. Wash surrounding the roots below ground suggest dirt. Above ground, the handle of an ax is propped against the stump of the largest tree. Its blade rests facing downward to the left of the text box, against the roots of the first and second largest stumps. The text box hides a large section of the ax's handle. Wash in the upper half of the design suggests the sky, perhaps streaked with clouds.

component.illusobjdesc:
This cross-sectional design displays the stumps of several large trees, above ground, and the spreading roots of the largest stump below ground. The largest stump, belonging to what was once an enormous tree, appears to the right of the text panel. Its roots fan out below: one large root branch stretches to the left and sends two large tendrils downward before it curves down itself and ends near the left edge of the design; another large root branch extends down below the stump and splits into several smaller offshoots.
Additional roots, nearby but not clearly connected to these large tendrils, embrace the figure of Grief personified as a woman near the bottom of the design.
Two more stumps appear to the left of the text box, on the same level as the largest stump. The larger of these two stumps, on the right, sends out roots that seem to extend above ground to the left and right, above the roots of the largest tree.

The personified figure of Grief (see the Textual Transcription) appears as a gowned, seated woman curled within the embrace of several roots below ground. She sits facing forward and to the right, with her legs bent away from the viewer. Twisting her torso forward and lowering her left shoulder, she cradles an infant in the crook of her left arm with her left elbow and forearm resting along her lap. Her right arm is by her side and bent, forearm horizontal, and she holds her left breast between her right index and middle fingers as if guiding it towards the child in her other arm. The tiny nude infant, which seems to have sparse, short, curly hair, lies face up with its head back and its left arm dangling over Grief's arm. This limp posture and its facial expression, with eyes closed and mouth open, suggests that it is dead. But Grief bends over it carefully, lowering her head to gaze fixedly at the child's face. Her long wild hair falls over her shoulders and merges with the roots that encircle woman and child. Shadows below Grief and to the right suggest the darkness of an underground hollow.

The handle of an ax is propped against the stump of the largest tree, on the right. Its blade rests facing downward to the left of the text box, against the roots of the first and second largest stumps. The text box hides a large section of ax's handle.
Wash in the upper half of the design suggests the sky, perhaps streaked with clouds.
Wash surrounding the roots below ground suggests dirt. The area below the roots where the figures appear is cave-like.

lg.l: Ode to Adversity
Design
1. A Widower & children
2. Grief among the roots of trees
3. "Purple tyrant vainly groans"The line is quoted, with "tyrants" and "groan" in the letterpress text changed to "tyrant" and "groans," from page [77] of the letterpress text (Object 37).
4. "Stern rugged Nurse"The line is quoted from page 78 of the letterpress text (Object 38).
Virtue Nursd in the Lap of Adversity
5. "In thy Gorgon terrors cladLines 9-11 are quoted, with minor variations, from page 79 of the letterpress text (Object 39).
Screaming horrors funeral cry
Despair & Fell Disease & ghastly Poverty"
6. Oh gently on thy suppliants headLines 12-13 are quoted, with minor variations, from page 79 of the letterpress text (Object 39).
Dread Goddess lay thy chastening hand

desc.objtitle: Ode to Adversity; Page 3: Beginning of Poem, Object 37 (Butlin 335.37)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 10 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A "purple tyrant" (see the letterpress text) or king sits facing forward on a stone block in the lower right corner of the design. He bends his head back and looks up and to the left with brows creased, presumably in pain (see letterpress text). His torso is slightly twisted, with right shoulder slightly forward and left shoulder drawn slightly back. He holds his right arm forward and rests this elbow on his lap, bending his forearm up and raising his right hand in a fist. He may be resting this arm and hand on his chest. His left arm is down by his side, with left hand dangling or perhaps resting against the stone block. His lower left leg and bare left foot are forward. He wears a long gown that hides his lower right leg and right foot. Left wrist and ankle bear heavy shackles attached to enormous chains. The chain from his wrist falls down and to the left, where it is hidden behind the tyrant's clothing. The ankle chain extends along the floor to the left of his foot and attaches to a floor ring near the edge of the stone block. He is a prisoner. He has short curly hair, a wispy curled mustache, and a goatee. Spikes on his head indicate a crown. The tyrant is imprisoned within a stone cell. A pointed arch of stone blocks fills the design above and to the left of him. The floor below the prisoner is made of stone, and the wall behind him seems to be made of stone blocks. A small barred window appears above the tyrant's head, partially blocked or limited by the arch. Shadow fills much of the cell, darkening the wall behind the tyrant, the lower left portion of the stone arch, and part of the floor to the left of the tyrant's seat.

component.illusobjdesc: A "purple tyrant" (see the letterpress text) or king sits facing forward on a stone block in the lower right corner of the design. He bends his head back and looks up and to the left with brows creased, presumably in pain (see the letterpress text). His torso is slightly twisted, with right shoulder slightly forward and left shoulder drawn slightly back. He holds his right arm forward and rests this elbow on his lap, bending his forearm up and raising his right hand in a fist. He may be resting this arm and hand on his chest. His left arm is down by his side, with left hand dangling or perhaps resting against the stone block. His lower left leg and bare left foot are forward. He wears a long gown that hides his lower right leg and right foot. Left wrist and ankle bear heavy shackles attached to enormous chains. The chain from his wrist falls down and to the left, where it is hidden behind the tyrant's clothing. The ankle chain extends along the floor to the left of his foot and attaches to a floor ring near the edge of the stone block. He is a prisoner. He has short curly hair, a wispy curled mustache, and a goatee. Spikes on his head indicate a crown.
The tyrant sits on a stone block near the lower right corner of the design.

The tyrant is imprisoned within a stone cell. A pointed arch of stone blocks fills the design above and to the left of the tyrant. The floor below the prisoner is made of stone, and the wall behind him seems to be made of stone blocks. A small barred window appears above the tyrant's head, partially blocked or limited by the arch. Blue sky appears through the window. Shadow fills much of the cell, darkening the wall behind the tyrant, the lower left portion of the stone arch, and part of the floor to the left of the tyrant's seat.

desc.objtitle: Ode to Adversity: Page 4, Object 38 (Butlin 335.38)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 4 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The sitting figure of "Adversity" (see Blake's text, Object 36), personified as an old woman, fills much of this design. Adversity sits facing forward on a low bench, positioned below and to the left of the text box. Her knees are bent and her legs are crossed, right leg behind left leg. She holds her arms extended out before her, slightly bent; her right forearm rests on her right knee, while her left inner elbow is propped over her left knee. In her right hand she holds a compass or dividers. Her right index finger extends in a pointing gesture along one side of this instrument, the ends of which may rest on the ground. A large tome representing the Book of the Law stands on its end near her foot; she holds the other end with her left hand. Adversity wears a turban, or a scarf wrapped turban-like around her head, and a long-sleeved gown with voluminous folds that drape her knees, cover her legs, and fall to the floor below her. Her bare left foot, on tiptoe, emerges from beneath these folds. Her long white hair falls from beneath her turban and cascades over her right shoulder; her left shoulder is hidden behind the text box. Her wrinkled face and neck indicate her age, while her drawn expression, creased eyebrows, and straightforward gaze suggest an attitude of austere pity. The personification of Virtue appears as a nude young female (see the letterpress text) sitting on Adversity's shadowed lap. Virtue sits with her legs bent and drawn up together underneath her, resting a large closed book on her lap. Her legs face right and slightly forward, and she twists her torso further forward. The book she supports may be meant to represent the Book of Experience. Virtue's left arm is bent and lies extended along her lap, underneath the book; the fingers of her left hand hold the far end of the tome. Her right arm is by her side and bent, with forearm raised horizontally and right hand lying on the book. She holds a pen or similar instrument in this hand and seems to be writing on the cover of the book: she may be inscribing its title. She lowers her head and looks intently at her work. Her hair is drawn up into a bun behind her head. Her breasts are visible, but not prominent. A wall, perhaps made of stone, extends the length of the right side of the design. The ground on which Adversity's bench rests also seems to be made of stone. Wash filling the area above and to the left of Adversity suggests the sky, perhaps with clouds. Light shadow falls on the wall in the lower right corner of the design.

component.illusobjdesc: The sitting figure of "Adversity" (see Blake's text, Object 36), personified as an old woman, fills much of this design. Adversity sits facing forward on a low bench, positioned below and to the left of the text box. Her knees are bent and her legs are crossed, right leg behind left leg. She holds her arms extended out before her, slightly bent; her right forearm rests on her right knee, while her left inner elbow is propped over her left knee. In her right hand she holds a compass or dividers. Her right index finger extends in a pointing gesture along one side of this instrument, the ends of which may rest on the ground. A large tome representing the Book of the Law stands on its end near her foot; she holds the other end with her left hand. Adversity wears a turban, or a scarf wrapped turban-like around her head, and a long-sleeved gown with voluminous folds that drape her knees, cover her legs, and fall to the floor below her. Her bare left foot, on tiptoe, emerges from beneath these folds. Her long white hair falls from beneath her turban and cascades over her right shoulder; her left shoulder is hidden behind the text box. Her wrinkled face and neck indicate her age, while her drawn expression, creased eyebrows, and straightforward gaze suggest an attitude of austere pity. The personification of Virtue sits on Adversity's shadowed lap.

The personification of Virtue appears as a nude young female (see the letterpress text) sitting on Adversity's lap. Virtue sits with her legs bent and drawn up together underneath her, resting a large closed book on her lap. Her legs face right and slightly forward, and she twists her torso further forward. The book she supports may be meant to represent the Book of Experience. Virtue's left arm is bent and lies extended along her lap, underneath the book; the fingers of her left hand hold the far end of this tome. Her right arm is by her side and bent, with forearm raised horizontally and right hand lying on the book. She holds a pen or similar writing implement in this hand and seems to be writing on the cover of the book: she may be inscribing its title. She lowers her head and looks intently at her work. Her hair is drawn up into a bun behind her head. Her breasts are visible, but not prominent.
Adversity sits on a low bench or seat, positioned near the bottom of the design.

A wall, perhaps made of stone, extends the length of the right side of the design. The ground on which Adversity's bench rests also seems to be made of stone. Wash filling the area above and to the left of Adversity suggests the sky, perhaps with clouds. Light shadow falls on the wall in the lower right corner of the design.

desc.objtitle: Ode to Adversity: Page 5, Object 39 (Butlin 335.39)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 12 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The personified figure of "Adversity" as a "Gorgon" (see Blake's text, Object 36) fills much of the design. Facing forward she crouches with both her hands raised. She leans slightly to the right. Her bent left arm is raised over her head; her right arm is raised at 135 degrees. Both hands grasp a scarf or long cloth with flame-like ends that extends over her head and falls in folds on either side of the design. Or is this object dark and smoky fire? Adversity's left leg is bent and drawn up in front of her body; her right leg, mostly hidden behind other figures in the foreground, extends left. Her mouth is open and her eyes are wide and staring beneath unkempt white eyebrows. These and the wrinkles visible on her face and neck suggest her age. Instead of hair, snakes writhe in twists and coils in all directions from the top of her head. Adversity wears a garment, perhaps a gown, with long sleeves and a wide neckline open to reveal her bony ribcage. Folds of her clothing cover much of her body and form a whirlwind shape surrounding the personified figure of Despair in the lower left corner of the design. Despair (see the letterpress text) appears as a dark-skinned demon below and to the left of the text box, facing forward. The figure seems to be male. He raises both arms vertically overhead, and grasps a short, sharp, deadly-looking dagger in each fist. Notably, these daggers point inward, as if poised for self-harm. His teeth are bared in a grimace and he draws his eyebrows together menacingly. His nude upper torso, which is all that is visible of his body below the shoulders, emerges from the whirlpool-like spiral of cloth from Adversity's garments. The personified figure of Disease (see the letterpress text) as an old woman hovers or flies in the foreground, near the bottom of the design. Her body seems to extend away from the viewer but she bends her head back to look forward. She wears a long-sleeved gown that hides her lower body completely and stretches to the left beyond the border of the design. Both arms are extended straight down and to the left from her shoulders. She supports the body of an upside-down pitcher with her left hand and holds its neck loosely with the fingers of her right hand. Her right wrist may rest on the pitcher. Yellowish liquid pours from the pitcher's open mouth and streams leftward. A wimple covers her head and drapes down over her shoulders before joining the streaming folds of her other garments. Her face, with its wrinkles, drooping eyelids, and down-turned mouth, suggests her age. A thin old man personifies Poverty (see the letterpress text), visible in the lower right corner of the design. He faces forward, with his body extended away from the viewer and slightly down. His slightly bent arms are raised vertically overhead. He grasps a scourge in each upraised fist. His right leg stretches down and to the left, while his bent left leg seems to be drawn up slightly behind and beneath him. The top of his left foot is visible on tiptoe; this foot may rest on the ground or hover in the air. Poverty himself may hover or fly, or may be crouching on the ground. He is bald and nude from the torso up; his waist and lower limbs are wrapped pant-like in cloth. His mouth is open. His wrinkled face indicates that he old. Dark shadows fill the design around Adversity and her band.

component.illusobjdesc: The personified figure of "Adversity" as a "Gorgon" (see Blake's text, Object 36) fills much of the design. Facing forward she crouches with both her hands raised. She leans slightly to the right. Her bent left arm is raised over her head; her right arm is raised at 135 degrees. Both hands grasp a scarf or long cloth with flame-like ends that extends over her head and falls in folds on either side of the design. Or is this object dark and smoky fire? Adversity's left leg is bent and drawn up in front of her body. Her bare left foot, on tiptoe, appears beneath her garments. Her right leg, mostly hidden behind other personified figures in the foreground, extends left; her bare right foot is visible on tiptoe near the lower left corner of the design. Her mouth is open, showing upper and lower teeth and her tongue. Her eyes are wide and staring beneath unkempt white eyebrows. These and the wrinkles visible on her face and neck suggest her age. Instead of hair, snakes writhe in twists and coils in all directions from the top of her head. In particular, one snake tail forms a spiral to the right of Adversity's chin. Six of them have visible heads; five of these hold their mouths open, with extended tongues. Adversity wears a garment, perhaps a gown, with long sleeves and a wide neckline open to reveal her bony ribcage. Folds of her clothing cover her much of her lower body and form a whirlwind shape surrounding the personified figure of Despair in the lower left corner of the design.

Despair (see the letterpress text) is personified as a dark-skinned demon below and to the left of the text box, facing forward. The figure seems to be male. He raises both arms vertically overhead, and grasps a short, sharp, deadly-looking dagger in each fist. Notably, these daggers point inward, as if poised for self-harm. His teeth are bared in a grimace and he draws his eyebrows together menacingly. He wears a gootee and has short, spiky hair. His nude upper torso, which is all that is visible of his body below the shoulders, emerges from a whirlpool-like spiral of cloth from Adversity's garments.

The personified figure of Disease (see the letterpress text) as an old woman hovers or flies in the foreground, near the bottom of the design. Her body seems to extend away from the viewer but she bends her head back to look forward. She wears a long-sleeved gown that hides her lower body completely and stretches to the left beyond the border of the design. Both arms are extended straight down and to the left from the shoulders. She supports the body of an upside-down pitcher with her left hand and holds its neck loosely with the fingers of her right hand. Her right wrist may rest on the pitcher. Yellowish liquid pours from the pitcher's open mouth and streams leftward. A wimple covers her head and drapes down over her shoulders before joining the streaming folds of her other garments. Her face, with its wrinkles, drooping eyelids, and down-turned mouth, suggests her age.

A thin old man personifies Poverty, visible in the lower right corner of the design. He faces forward, with his body extended away from the viewer and slightly down. His slightly bent arms are raised vertically overhead. He grasps a scourge in each upraised fist. His right leg stretches down and to the left, while his bent left leg seems to be drawn up slightly behind and beneath him. The top of his left foot is visible on tiptoe; this foot may rest on the ground or hover in the air. Poverty himself may hover or fly, or may be crouching on the ground. He is bald and nude from the torso up; his waist and lower limbs are wrapped pant-like in cloth. His mouth is open. His wrinkled face indicates that he is old.
Dark shadows fill the design around Adversity and her "vengeful band" (see the letterpress text).

desc.objtitle: Ode to Adversity: Page 6, Object 40 (Butlin 335.40)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 2 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A man reclines on a bed near the bottom of the design. He lies facing left with his legs stretched to the left along the bed and his curved back propped against a pillow or a headboard. His head is bent and his eyes are lowered, with visible left brow creased. A cloak, blanket, or other cloth covers his head and drapes over his shoulders. He is wrapped in a sheet reminiscent of a shroud that covers his body completely, even his arms and feet. Shapes beneath this sheet suggest that his straight legs are extended together, and at least his left arm is by his side, bent upward at the elbow, with his left hand held before his chest. His short, curly hair emerges from beneath his hood. The bed on which the man reclines extends from one side of the design to the other. This bed may be covered with a sheet. A pillow or headboard appears at the right side of the design. Adversity here appears in "form benign" (see the letterpress text). Her upper body hovers near the middle of the design, just to the left of the text box; her lower body is not visible. Her head is bent down slightly and her body seems to extend away from the viewer. She turns her face slightly to the right, and her eyes are lowered as if she is looking toward the man reclined on the bed below. Her left arm extends horizontally to the right and down slightly and she rests the tips of the fingers of her left hand behind the man's head. She holds her right arm out to the left, bent upward at the elbow, with her hand raised and her right index finger pointing upward. She wears a wimple under a cloak or cloth that covers her head and drapes over her right arm. The folds of this cloak join the folds of her wimple and the habit or gown she wears. A sleeve covers her left arm to the wrist. Darkness fills much of the design, surrounding the figures. Dark clouds help to buoy Adversity, appearing between her upper body and the reclining body of the man below. Wash suggests additional clouds to the upper right of the text box, extending up towards the upper right corner of the design. Shadow fills the upper left corner of the design and also appears to the right of Adversity's left hand and to the left of the reclining man's torso.

component.illusobjdesc: A man reclines on a bed near the bottom of the design. He lies facing left with his legs stretched to the left along the bed and his curved back propped against a pillow or a headboard. His head is bent and his eyes are lowered, with visible left brow creased. A cloak, blanket, or other cloth covers his head and drapes over his shoulders. He is wrapped in a sheet reminiscent of a shroud that covers his body completely, even his arms and feet. Shapes beneath this sheet suggest that his straight legs are extended together, and at least his left arm is by his side, bent upward at the elbow, with his left hand held before his chest. His short, curly hair emerges from beneath his hood.

Adversity here appears in "form benign" (see the letterpress text). Her upper body hovers near the middle of the design, just to the left of the text box; her lower body is not visible. Her head is bent down slightly, so that her face is seen partly from above, and her body seems to extend away from the viewer. She turns her face slightly to the right, and her eyes are lowered as if she is looking toward the man reclined on the bed below. Her left arm extends horizontally to the right and down slightly and she rests the tips of the fingers on her left hand behind the man's head. She holds her right arm out to the left, bent upward at the elbow, with her hand raised and her right index finger pointing upward. She wears a wimple under a cloak or cloth that covers her head and drapes over her right arm. The folds of this cloak join the folds of her wimple and the habit or gown she wears. A sleeve covers her left arm to the wrist.
The bed on which the man reclines extends from one side of the design to the other. This bed may be covered with a sheet. A pillow or headboard appears at the right side of the design.

Darkness fills much of the design, surrounding the figures. Dark clouds help to buoy Adversity, appearing between her upper body and the reclining body of the man below. Wash suggests additional clouds to the upper right of the text box, extending up towards the upper right corner of the design. Shadow fills the upper left corner of the design and also appears to the right of Adversity's left hand and to the left of the reclining man's torso.

desc.objtitle: The Progress of Poesy; a Pindaric Ode; Page 1: Title-Page, Object 41 (Butlin 335.41)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The figure of Homer fills much of the design; see the "blind ... Bard" in the Textual Transcription, Object 42. He appears to the right of (and slightly obscured by) the text box, facing and walking right. His bent right leg is forward and his left leg is extended backward, with left foot on tiptoe. Leaning forward slightly with head bent back and eyes closed, he walks with an enormous lyre-shaped harp before him, propped against his left side. His right arm is down by his side, bent at the elbow with forearm extended. The bent fingers of his right hand seem to rest on the strings of the harp. He wears a long gown and sandals. He has short, curly hair and a beard. A boy steps forward at the right side of the design, before Homer, with his right arm extended roughly horizontally to the left as if he is guiding the blind poet's steps. The boy's right foot is forward and his left leg is extended backward, with left foot perhaps on tiptoe. His left arm is by his side, bent at the elbow with forearm before his torso. He holds the brim of a hat in his left hand; his thumb is visible. The boy's right hand is hidden behind Homer's harp. He wears a long-sleeved gown that extends to his knees; his feet are bare. He has short, curly hair. Grass extends across the bottom of the design, under the feet of Homer and the boy.

component.illusobjdesc: The figure of the blind poet Homer fills much of the design; see the "blind ... Bard" in the Textual Transcription, Object 42. He appears to the right of (and slightly obscured by) the text box, facing and walking right. His bent right leg is forward and his left leg is extended backward, with left foot on tiptoe. Leaning forward slightly with head bent back and eyes closed, he walks with an enormous lyre-shaped harp before him, propped against his left side. His right arm is down by his side, bent at the elbow with forearm extended. The bent fingers of his right hand seem to rest on the strings of his harp. He wears a long gown and sandals. He has short, curly hair and a beard.

A boy steps forward at the right side of the design, before Homer, with his right arm extended roughly horizontally to the left as if he is guiding the blind poet's steps. The boy's right foot is forward and his left leg is extended backward, with left foot perhaps on tiptoe. His left arm is by his side, bent at the elbow with forearm before his torso. He holds the brim of a hat in his left hand; his thumb is visible. The boy's right hand is hidden behind Homer's harp. He wears a long-sleeved gown that extends to his knees; his feet are bare. He has short, curly hair.
Grass extends across the bottom of the design, under the feet of Homer and the boy.

desc.objtitle: The Progress of Poesy; Page 2: Blank Page Bearing List of Titles, Object 42 (Butlin 335.42)

objnote.p: This page of the letterpress text, the verso of the fly-title to "The Progress of Poesy" (Object 41), bears a brief letterpress "Advertisement." Blake covered this with a sheet of blank paper to provide a support for his inscribed titles.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The poet sits slumped in a chair positioned in the lower left corner of the design. He faces right but turns his torso slightly forward. He sits with his shoulders hunched and his head bent down; he props his left elbow forward on his lap or the left arm of his chair with his left forearm bent upward and his left hand raised. His extended left index finger lies along his forehead, while the other fingers of his left hand curl inward. A large book lies open on his lap. He is wrapped in a cloak or cloth that drapes his shoulders and envelops his body. His right foot, clad in a shoe, emerges from beneath its fabric. His eyes are lowered to look at the book as though reading. His hair, through short, curls in an unruly fashion over his forehead, the tip of his visible right ear, and the nape of his neck. A Corinthian pillar rises on the left side of the text box, behind the poet. Its capital appears just to the left of the upper left corner of the text box. Ribs rise from the capital and arch towards the top and upper left corner of the design to create a fan vault. The rightmost of these ribs forms an arch over the top of the room's large Gothic window. The wall that fills the rest of the design seems to be made of stone, as is the floor. Shadows fall on the wall or floor behind the poet's chair, and on the wall beneath the window and near the left side of the design. A stained glass window fills much of the design around and to the right of the text box. Two muntin bars separate the window into three visible panes, each with Gothic tracery at the top. The design of the middle pane displays an angel or cherub, which may be male, hovering near the top of the window with its vertical body facing forward. It has at least three pairs of wings spread on either side of its body. The cherub's left arm is down by its side. Its right arm is bent at the elbow, with forearm across its torso; in this hand it supports a butterfly, or perhaps a double flame. Its legs are difficult to distinguish, but may extend downward together. Beams of flame-like light surround the cherub in the design and extend downward towards the figure of a Muse who is created to look as if she sits on the sill, facing forward with her legs folded beneath her. She tilts her head up and back as if she is looking at the cherub above. Her bent right arm is held forward before her torso, and she holds a quill pen in this raised hand as if poised to write. A scroll lies unfolded across her lap. She has short, curly hair and wears a long-sleeved gown with skirts that spread over her lower body and fall to the ground on the right. A separate cloak seems to drape her shoulders and fall in folds past her waist; it reaches the ground on the left.

component.illusobjdesc: The poet sits slumped in a chair positioned in the lower left corner of the design. He faces right but turns his torso slightly forward. He sits with his shoulders hunched and his head bent down; he props his left elbow forward on his lap or the left arm of his chair with his left forearm bent upward and his left hand raised. His extended left index finger lies along his forehead, while the other fingers of his left hand curl inward. A large open book lies open on his lap, extending from upper thighs to bent knees. He is wrapped in a cloak or cloth that drapes his shoulders, hides his right arm, and envelops his lower body. His right foot, clad in a shoe, emerges from beneath its fabric. Folds of the cloak lie on or perhaps between the pages of the open book, as if the poet uses it or a hidden finger to hold his place. His eyes are lowered to look at the book as though reading. His hair, though short, curls in an unruly fashion over his forehead, the tip of his visible right ear, and the nape of his neck.

A Corinthian pillar rises on the left side of the text box, behind the poet. Its capital appears just to the left of the upper left corner of the text box. Ribs rise from the capital and arch towards the top and upper left corner of the design to form a fan vault. The rightmost of these ribs forms an arch over the top of the room's large Gothic window. The wall that fills the the rest of the design seems to be made of stone, as is the floor.
Shadows fall on the wall or floor behind the poet's chair, and on the wall beneath the window and near the left side of the design.

A stained glass window fills much of the design around and to the right of the text box. Two muntin bars separate the window into three visible panes, each with Gothic tracery at the top. The design of the middle pane displays an angel or cherub, which may be male, hovering near the top of the window with its vertical body facing forward. It has at least three pairs of wings spread on either side of its body. The cherub's left arm is down by its side. Its right arm is bent at the elbow, with forearm across its torso; in this hand it supports a butterfly, or perhaps a double flame. Its legs are difficult to distinguish, but may extend downward together. Beams of light surround the cherub in the design and extend downward towards the figure of a Muse who is created to look as if she sits on the sill, facing forward with her legs folded beneath her. She tilts her head up and back as if she is looking at the cherub above. Her bent right arm is held forward before her torso, and she holds a quill pen in this raised hand as if poised to write. A scroll lies unfolded across her lap. She has short, curly hair and wears a long-sleeved gown with skirts that spread over her lower body and fall to the ground to the right. A separate cloak seems to drape her shoulders and fall in folds past her waist; it reaches the ground on the left.

lg.l: The Progress of Poesy
1. The Beginning of Poesy.The blind
begging Bard
2. Study
3. "The Laughing flowers that round them blow"Lines 6-7 are quoted, with minor variations, from page [83] of the letterpress text (Object 43).
Drink life & fragrance as they flow
4. "Perching on the Scepterd handLines 8-9 are quoted, with minor variations, from page 84 of the letterpress text (Object 44).
Of Jove, thy magic lulls the featherd king"
5. "Cythereas Day.The line is quoted from page 85 of the letterpress text (Object 45).
6. "Hyperions march they spy & glittering shafts of war"The line is quoted, with minor variations, from page 86 of the letterpress text (Object 46).
7. "Shaggy forms oer Ice built mountains roam"The line is quoted, with minor variations, from page 87 of the letterpress text (Object 47).
8"Alike they scorn the pomp of Tyrant powerLines 13-14 are quoted, with minor variations, from page 88 of the letterpress text (Object 48).
And coward Vice that revels in her chains
9. "To him the mighty Mother did unveilLines 15-16 are quoted, with minor variations, from page 89 of the letterpress text (Object 49).
Her awful Face"
10.."Dryden.Lines 17-18 are quoted, with "Dryden's" in the letterpress text changed to "Dryden" and minor variations, from page 90 of the letterpress text (Object 50).
"Bright Eyd Fancy hovering oe'r"
11. Oft before his Infant eyes would runLines 19-20 are quoted, with minor variations, from page 91 of the letterpress text (Object 51).
Such forms as glitter in the Muses ray
12. A Muse.

desc.objtitle: The Progress of Poesy; Page 3: Beginning of Poem, Object 43 (Butlin 335.43)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 10 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A hill or small cliff fills the background of the design, and leaves only a small space for open sky above the text panel. Its craggy surfaces suggest rock. The Helicon splashes down the hill to the left of the panel, meets another small stream that emerges from the left side of the design halfway down, and reaches level ground near the lower left corner of the design. From there the little stream curves around to flow past the bottom edge of the design. Grass lines its banks here at the base of the hill. Flowers flourish along the top of the cliff and along the banks of the stream at the bottom, where they are fed by the Helicon's waters. Fairies appear in many of the blooms, representing the spirits of "The laughing flowers" that "Drink life and fragrance" from the Helicon (see the letterpress text). A Grecian woman, who represents the "rich stream of music" in the form of both poetry and also the Helicon (see the letterpress text), steps leftward from the lower right corner of the design. She faces left and walks on her tiptoes, with her bent right leg forward and her bent left leg extended slightly backward. The toes of her left foot rest on the far bank of the Helicon, while her right foot just touches a tiny island of green ground amid the river's waters. She holds a lyre before her body, resting against her right side. Her bent left arm is down by her side and her fingers touch the instrument's strings as she plays. Her right hand and wrist appear before her torso on the other side of the lyre; this hand is raised slightly with palm facing forward. It may rest on the lyre's strings as well. With bowed shoulders she lowers her head to look forward and down. Her hair is swept up into a bun, though curly strands escape at forehead and temple. She wears a long sleeveless gown, belted at the waist. The flowing skirts of her garment merge gracefully with the river's ripples. A lily rises to the right of her skirts. Two blooms appear on gracefully curving stems. Wash above the cliff suggests the sky, perhaps streaked with clouds.

component.illusobjdesc: A hill or small cliff fills the background of this design, and leaves only a small space for open sky above the text panel. Its craggy surfaces suggest rock. The Helicon splashes down the hill to the left of the panel, meets another small stream that emerges from the left side of the design halfway down, and reaches level ground near the lower left corner of the design. From there the little stream curves around to flow past the bottom edge of the design. Grass lines its banks here at the base of the hill.

A Grecian woman, who represents the "rich stream of music" in the form of both poetry and also the Helicon (see the letterpress text), steps leftward from the lower right corner of the design. She faces left and walks on her tiptoes, with her bent right leg forward and her bent left leg extended slightly backward. The toes of her left foot rest on the far bank of the river Helicon, while her right foot just touches a tiny island of green ground amid the river's waters. She holds a lyre before her body, resting against her right side. Her bent left arm is down by her side and her fingers touch the instruments's strings as she plays. Her right hand and wrist appear before her torso on the other side of the lyre; this hand is raised slightly with palm facing forward. It may rest on the lyre's strings as well. With bowed shoulders she lowers her head to look forward and down. Her hair is swept up into a bun, though curly strands escape at forehead and temple. She wears a long sleeveless gown, belted at the waist. The flowing skirts of her garment merge gracefully with the river's ripples.

Flowers flourish across the top of the cliff, where they are fed by the Helicon's waters. Fairies appear in many of the blooms, representing the spirits of "The laughing flowers" that "Drink life and fragrance" from the Helicon (see the letterpress text). The rightmost plant on the cliff is a lily with many curving leaves and a large forward-facing blossom near the ground. A fairy sits within its petals, facing forward but turning her head to look to the left and stretching her right arm horizontally to the left. She wears a hat and a gown with skirts that hide her legs. To the right, another fairy stands facing right and bending forward, head bent back. This fairy, perhaps female, wears a gown that merges with the lily's graceful leaves. She holds her right arm down but bent up at the elbow, and may rest her right hand on her neck or chest. She bends over another fairy seated to the right, who bends her head up to look at her companion above. This fairy may have long hair. To the left of the forward-facing blossom, another fairy stands facing forward and to the left within a blossom that faces up; its petals and her skirts are one. She raises both arms vertically overhead in a gesture that suggests stamen. A vial, urn, vase,or hat on her head suggests petals. Her hands seem to rest on either side of the objct. A third lily blossom depends leftward from a stem that curves over the standing fairy. A fairy emerges from the blossom like stamen, facing down and to the left with head bent back and arms stretched vertically down. She wears a gown that merges with the flower, though at least her left leg is visibly bent back to rest on the lily's highest petal. She may be wearing a hat, or may have her hair in a bun. Far to the left is another flowering plant. Two flowers appear above the cliff; a third flower, hangs from a stem that curves to left and down past the top of the cliff. The upper body of a fairy emerges upside down from between the petals of this third blossom, bending to the right to look down to the right. She seems to be female with her hair drawn back into a bun or similar coiffure behind her head. Her right arm is down and bent. Leaves grow above the text panel between the leftmost flower and the lily on the right. A third flower grows from the side of the stream near the upper left corner of the text panel. Its leaves grow up and to the left. A long stem with several more leaves depends from the left side of the plant before curling up again in a spiral that forms one loop. A flower, perhaps honeysuckle, blooms facing up to the right. A fairy emerges from between its petals, facing forward and to the right. She bends gracefully backwards and twists her head partly to the left; she may be looking up to the upside down fairy in the blossom above. Her left arm is extended out to the right and she holds an object, perhaps a vase, bowl, or pot, in her left hand. Her right arm is down and bent across her torso; her right hand holds a corner of the scroll. She wears a long gown and her hair seems to be drawn back into a bun.

More vegetation grows on either side of the banks of the Helicon on the flat ground at the bottom of the design. Fairies appear within these blooms as well. On the far bank, at the left side of the design, two blooms appear next to the water. The head and shoulders of a fairy emerge from each bloom. The shoulders of the fairy on the right face forward and to the right, though she turns her head slightly left. Only part of her upper right arm is visible above the petals. Her left arm is raised at 135 degrees and she lifts a bowl or cup up with her left hand. She has long hair. The fairy on the left faces forward and to the right, with long hair falling over her shoulders. Her slightly bent right arm is down, resting on the petals of her flower. She extends her slightly bent left arm to the right and dips a bowl or cup into the waters of the stream with her left hand. Above these two fairies a cluster of leaves grows upward. The upper body of a fairy emerges from the leaves, facing away and slightly right, leaning away and reaching his or her right arm horizontally to the right. He or she, who may be nude, holds a pitcher out towards or into the waterfall to the right. This fairy may be male, and/or may wear a hat. On the near side of the bank, just below the waterfall, two fairies face left and bend forward over the water. The leftmost fairy stands within the petals of a flower on the bank, bending forward and stretching her left arm down to the left. She holds a pitcher over the water with her left hand. She turns her head forward. She wears a gown with a belt or a gathered waistline. She wears a hat of petals. Above her and slightly to the right, the second fairy faces left and bends forward, her head bent back. The rest of her body is hidden behind the first fairy. Her hair is drawn back into a bun. To the right of them a fairy emerges from a cluster of petals and leaves, as if she is another petal. Her lower body faces left but at the waist she twists away and to the right. Her left leg is extended backwards, her left foot on tiptoe. Her slightly bent right arm is raised at 135 degrees and she holds a goblet up with her right hand. Her head is bent back and her long hair streams leftward over her shoulder. She wears a long gown with a belt or a well-defined waist. To the left another fairy faces forward and to the left, supported by several leaves. She raises her right arm nearly vertically. With her right hand she holds a goblet next to the upraised goblet of the fairy to the left. This pair may be toasting each other. Her long, curly hair streams past her left shoulder and along her left arm, raised horizontally with palm up. She wears a gown and a wreath of flowers or jewels on her head. Her slightly bent legs curve behind her to the right, along the leaves. Just to the left of the Grecian woman's gown, two stems with three leaves grow up and curl down to the left. A blossom appears at the end of each stem. The upper body of a fairy appears within the blossom on the left, stretching down to the right and reaching her right arm vertically overhead to the right. She is seen from behind, but bends her head back so that her face is seen from above. She may be wearing a gown and a hat, perhaps with petals. Another fairy's upper body emerges from the blossom on the right, upside down with her torso facing away and her head bent back to look down. She seems to be wearing a gown and has her hair drawn back in a bun. Her arms are stretched down past her head. Her right arm is bent around a vase or similar vessel and her right hand supports its base. Her left arm is also bent and she rests her left hand on the side of the vase. Below this fairy, another fairy's upper body faces away and raises her slightly bent arms vertically overhead. Her hands rest on the vase above as well. She bends her head back sharply to look at the fairy above. Her hair is short or drawn back, and she wears a garment that merges with the petals of a flower below. two lilies rise on curving stems near the lower right margin of the design.
Wash above the cliff suggests the sky, perhaps streaked with clouds.

desc.objtitle: The Progress of Poesy: Page 4, Object 44 (Butlin 335.44)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 15 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Jove's giant figure (see the letterpress text here and Blake's text, Object 42) fills much of the design. He is seated facing forward, with his lower body turned slightly to the left. He sits with his knees bent, his lower right leg angled back towards his seat and his lower left leg crossed in front of the right. He leans right and props his left elbow on a short pillar. A curling ram's horn decorates the capital of this pillar, which also boasts a decorative border of scrolling vegetation, including vines and leaves. Jove's lower left arm is bent up and his left hand is raised. He holds his head turned slightly to the right and bent forward; his left forefinger rests on his left temple and he may lean his cheek on the knuckles of this hand. His mouth is open. His right forearm appears extended vertically to the left and he grasps the enormous head of a large scepter with his right hand. Carved oak leaves and acorns adorn the head of this scepter. Jove has a curly beard and long curly hair. He wears a long gown or robe; the robe's thick folds of rich fabric drape his shoulders and fall past his right knee. An ornate border of small figures hems the bottom of his robe. His left foot, clad in a sandal, emerges from beneath this border. Light surrounds or perhaps emanates from Jove's head in the upper right corner of the design. The effect suggests a halo. A large eagle hunches with claws resting on Jove's extended right arm. The bird perches facing forward and slightly right, with wings half-folded and powerful head and beak lowered. The floor below Jove and the wall behind him seem to be made of stone. Jove casts a shadow on the floor to the right of his foot. Shadow fills the space to the left of Jove's scepter and to the right of his left elbow, and darkens the wall above the eagle.

component.illusobjdesc: The giant figure of Jove (see the letterpress text here and Blake's text, Object 42) fills much of the design. He is seated facing forward, with his lower body turned slightly to the left. He sits with his knees bent, his lower right leg angled back towards his seat and his lower left leg crossed in front of the right. He leans right and props his left elbow on a short pillar. His lower left arm is bent up and his left hand is raised. He holds his head turned slightly to the right and bent forward; his left forefinger rests on his left temple and he may lean his cheek on the knuckles of this hand. His mouth is open. His right forearm appears extended vertically to the left and he grasps the enormous head of a large scepter with his right hand. Jove has a curly beard and long curly hair. He wears a long gown or robe; the robe's thick folds of rich fabric drape his shoulders and fall past his right knee. An ornate border of small figures hems the bottom of his robe. His left foot, clad in a sandal, emerges from beneath this border. The human figures that decorate the border appear in various positions: two just left of Jove's foot stand or dance with arms extended horizontally; several to the right of his foot seem to stand or sit; several to the left of the pillar on the right seem to hover or lie horizontally. Other figures are more difficult to distinguish.
Light surrounds or perhaps emanates from Jove's head in the upper right corner of the design. The effect suggests a halo.
A large eagle hunches with claws resting on Jove's extended right arm. The bird perches facing forward and slightly right, with wings half-folded and powerful head and beak lowered.
Jove rests his right hand on a grand scepter, which stands next to his knees with its other end resting on the floor. Carved oak leaves and acorns adorn its large head.

Jove props his left elbow on a short pillar that stands near the right side of the design. A curling ram's horn decorates the capital of the pillar. A decorative border of scrolling vegetation, including vines and leaves, appears at the top of the pillar.
The floor below Jove and the wall behind him seem to be made of stone.
Jove casts a shadow on the floor to the right of his foot. Shadow fills the space to the left of Jove's scepter and to the right of his left elbow, and darkens the wall above the eagle.

desc.objtitle: The Progress of Poesy: Page 5, Object 45 (Butlin 335.45)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 7 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A winged boy or cherub hovers beneath the text box, facing forward but twisting to the right in a slightly contrapposto pose. His left leg may be slightly bent, but is extended downward with his foot on tiptoe. His right leg is bent and crossed behind his left; his right foot is also on tiptoe and is visible just to the right of the left leg. A violin is propped beneath the boy's chin. The fingers of his left hand rest on the neck of the violin as he plays. His right arm is by his side and bent up across his torso; he holds a bow across the violin's strings with his right hand. His head is bent and turned to the right, so that his cheek helps to hold the violin in place. His wings are spread on either side of his body. He is nude with visible genitals, and he has short, curly hair. Five female figures appear in a line, facing away, hovering above the ground to the right of the text box. The nearest figure, which is also the leftmost figure, dances with her right leg forward and her left leg bent backwards. Her legs are crossed below the knees and her feet are on tiptoe. Her slightly bent right arm is raised nearly vertically; she holds a tambourine in her upraised right hand. Her body is twisted into a slight, graceful contrapposto. She wears a semi-transparent gown that leaves her right arm and shoulder bare and swirls around her ankles. Her hair is drawn back into a bun. The text panel hides her left arm and shoulder. The next four figures are staggered to the right, so that only the right half of each dancer's body is visible. The position of each echoes the first, with right arm raised and upraised hand holding a tambourine. Each wears a gown. None has visible feet. Four more dancing figures, the mirror opposite of those facing away, hover and proceed forward in a line at the left of the text box. The nearest figure is also the rightmost figure. Her right leg is forward and her left leg is bent. Her legs are crossed below the knees and her feet are on tiptoe. She bends to the right slightly, her body in a gentle contrapposto position. Her slightly bent right arm is raised vertically overhead, and she holds a tambourine aloft. Her head is turned slightly to the left and bent back, and she smiles with a slightly open mouth that reveals her teeth. Her eyes are raised. Her hair is short and curly. Her long, transparent gown swirls around her legs. It is cut to leave her right arm and breast bare. A high slit over her thigh exposes her bare right leg. A button or similar ornament appears above the slit. The three dancers behind her are staggered so that only their right sides are visible. Their positions mimic the leaders': each raises her right arm and holds a tambourine over her head. Their heads and lower bodies are mostly hidden, though the swirling skirts of the leftmost dancer appear just to the right of the left edge of the design. A young woman stands or walks at the left side of the design, facing forward and to the left. She steps forward with her left leg; her right foot is visible extended behind her on tiptoe. Her right arm is held out from her body slightly and bent at the elbow. Her left arm is down but bent up at the elbow. Both hands support a flute. She bends her head slightly to bring her lips near the flute. Her curly hair is drawn up into a bun and a braid wraps her head. She wears a long gown with a belt or well-defined waistline. A similar young woman stands at the right side of the design, facing forward and to the right. In a mirror of the woman at the other side, she steps forward with her right leg; her left foot appears on tiptoe extended behind her. Her arms are by her side and bent up at the elbow. Her hands support a flute in front of her torso. Her head is bent. Her short curly hair is drawn into a bun; a ribbon or band wraps her hair. Her long, semi-transparent dress swirls around her legs. The ground at the bottom of the design is covered with grass. A tree grows up the right side of the design. Near the top right corner of the design, this tree sends a limb arching leftward towards the middle. It breaks into smaller branches that support sparse leaves. Several more limbs arch from the left side of the design into the middle, bearing similar sparse leaves. A six pointed star glimmers between the branches at the top of the design. Wash around the figures below hints at a nighttime sky.

Her right arm is held out from her body slightly and bent at the elbow. Her left arm is down but bent up at the elbow. Both hands support a flute. She bends her head slightly to bring her lips near the flute. Her curly hair is drawn up into a bun and a braid wraps her head. She wears a long gown with a belt or well-defined waistline. A similar young woman stands at the right side of the design, facing forward and to the right. In a mirror of the woman at the other side, she steps forward with her right leg; her left foot appears on tiptoe extended behind her. Her arms are by her side and bent up at the elbow. Her hands support a flute in front of her torso. Her head is bent. Her short curly hair is drawn into a bun; a ribbon or band wraps her hair. Her long, semi-transparent dress swirls around her legs.

The ground at the bottom of the design is covered with grass. A tree grows up the right side of the design. Near the top right corner of the design, this tree sends a limb arching leftward towards the middle. It breaks into smaller branches that support sparse leaves. Several more limbs arch from the left side of the design into the middle, bearing similar sparse leaves.
A six pointed star glimmers between the branches at the top of the design.
Wash around the figures below hints at a nighttime sky.

desc.objtitle: The Progress of Poesy: Page 6, Object 46 (Butlin 335.46)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 17 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Hyperion (see "Hyperions," Blake's text, Object 42) the bowman fills much of the design.
