He sits half-kneeling and facing forward and slightly right, riding within the shallow bowl of a sun-like chariot that flies or hovers in the sky. Much of his body is hidden by the text panel, but his head and shoulders are fully visible above it. His right arm is stretched out roughly horizontally to the left, and he grasps the center of a magnificent golden bow with his right hand. His left arm is raised and bent across his chest, but drawn back; his left hand holds the end of a golden arrow against the bowstring. The shaft of the arrow, near the arrowhead, rests against the knuckles of his right hand. The bow is flexed and ready to shoot, although Hyperion turns his head to the right instead of aiming his weapon. His face is visible in three-quarters profile; his eyes are raised and his mouth is slightly open. His right leg appears at the left side of the text box, bent up. Though his limbs are bare, folds of an impressive cloak billow to the right of the text panel and below his outstretched right arm. He has short golden curls. He and his chariot are superimposed over, or are one with, a blazing sun; sharp beams of light burst in all directions from Hyperion himself and along the edges of the sun's globe. These rays are also spears, the "shafts of war" mentioned in the text. Shadowy figures representing the "spectres wan" (see the letterpress text) of night and darkness appear at the bottom of the design, fleeing from Hyperion's sunburst above. They are mostly disembodied heads with wide eyes and open mouths. Dark shadows fill the edges of the design between the beams of light, and particularly surround the spectres at the bottom of the design.

component.illusobjdesc: Hyperion (see "Hyperions," Blake's text, Object 42) the bowman fills much of the design. He sits half-kneeling and facing forward and slightly right, riding within the shallow bowl of a sun-like chariot that flies or hovers in the sky. Much of his body is hidden by the text panel, but his head and shoulders are fully visible above it. His right arm is stretched out roughly horizontally to the left, and he grasps the center of a magnificent golden bow with his right hand. His left arm is raised and bent across his chest, but drawn back; his left hand holds the end of a golden arrow against the bowstring. The shaft of the arrow, near the arrowhead, rests against the knuckles of his right hand. The bow is flexed and ready to shoot, although Hyperion turns his head to the right instead of aiming his weapon. His face is visible in three-quarters profile; his eyes are raised and his mouth is slightly open. His right leg appears at the left side of the text box, bent up. Though his limbs are bare, folds of an impressive cloak billow to the right of the text panel and below his outstretched right arm. The cloak may pass over his right shin, though it is transparent here. A button, brooch, or similar ornament appears in the folds of the cloak just to the right of the text panel. Hyperion has short golden curls. He and his chariot are superimposed over, or may be one with, a blazing sun; sharp beams of light burst in all directions from Hyperion himself and along the edges of the sun's globe. These rays are also spears, the "shafts of war" mentioned in the text.

Shadowy figures representing the "spectres wan" (see the letterpress text) of night and darkness appear at the bottom of the design, fleeing from Hyperion's sunburst above. They are mostly disembodied heads. The one nearest the lower left corner faces up and to the right, though it is tilted slightly forward so as to be visible in three-quarters profile. This head, with eyes raised and mouth open, is wrapped in a cloak or similar cloth that extends up to the right. Its tongue is visible. Above this head a second head with open mouth and raised eyes looks forward and to the right, tilted back to face up slightly. Its teeth and tongue are visible in its open mouth. Hair or folds of fabric are indistinctly visible to the left and right of this head. A third head, in between and to the right of the first two, appears in profile facing down and slightly left. Its mouth is open. The hair of its long beard streams past its cheeks and up to the right. This head may also have hair on the top of its head. Below this third head, fainter lines suggest the staring eyes and open nasal socket of an upside down skull, facing forward and up. To the right of the third head, another clearly outlined head appears upside down and facing up and to the right. This head has wide eyes and open mouth under a mop of wavy hair. A cloak or similar cloth circles its neck and surrounds its hair. Its shoulders may be just visible beneath the nearest rays of the sun. Below and to the right of this upside down head appears another upside down head, facing away so that its long hair faces the viewer. In the lower right corner, two more upside down heads appear side by side. The leftmost of these two seems to have wavy hair, and faces forward and slightly right. Its bald partner is seen in profile, facing up. Both have open mouths. Just below them, as if partly hidden behind them, the eyes and nose of yet another upside down face look forward. Finally, above this grouping of three, one eye and a curved line suggesting the bald pate of another upside down head appear between beams of light.
Dark shadows fill the edges of the design between the beams of light, and particularly surround the spectres at the bottom of the design.

desc.objtitle: The Progress of Poesy: Page 7, Object 47 (Butlin 335.47)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 4 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A "savage youth" (see the letterpress text) who faces and walks right appears in the lower corner of the design. He steps forward with his right leg; his left leg is extended backward with his left foot on tiptoe. His right hand is raised in front of his torso, holding a horn or trumpet to his mouth. He bends his head slightly to play the instrument. The youth wears the skin of a wolf(?) as a cloak: the animal's head forms his hood and its fur robes his body. Its head retains ears, teeth, and at least one visible eye. One front paw drapes over the youth's right shoulder and dangles large claws downward. Its hind feet hang behind the youth, dragging more claws; its long tail drapes over the youth's left leg and trails on the ground behind him. The youth's legs emerge from beneath his furry cloak, and are dressed in tight pants or thick leggings with stitches visible at the right knee. He also wears snowshoes laced over heavy boots. Mountains covered in ice ("ice-built mountains" in the letterpress text) fill the rest of the design with their jagged shapes.

component.illusobjdesc: A "savage youth" (see the letterpress text) who faces and walks left appears in the lower corner of the design. He steps forward with his right leg; his left leg is extended backward with his left foot on tiptoe. His right hand is raised in front of his torso, holding a horn or trumpet to his mouth. He bends his head slightly to play the instrument. The youth wears the skin of a wolf(?) as a cloak: the animal's head forms his hood and its fur robes his body. Its head retains ears, teeth, and at least one visible eye. One front paw drapes over the youth's right shoulder and dangles large claws downward. Its hind feet hang behind the youth, dragging more claws; its long tail drapes over the youth's left leg and trails on the ground behind him. The youth's legs emerge from beneath his furry cloak, and are dressed in tight pants or thick leggings with stitches visible at the right knee. He also wears snowshoes laced over heavy boots.
Mountains covered in ice ("ice-built mountains" in the letterpress text) fill the rest of the design with their jagged shapes.

desc.objtitle: The Progress of Poesy: Page 8, Object 48 (Butlin 335.48)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 13 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A queen representing tyranny sits in the lower left corner of the design, facing forward and to the right. She wears a long-sleeved gown under a cloak or robe that drapes from her right shoulder over her right side and knee. The folds of these garments envelop her lower body and puddle on the ground beneath her, but underneath the fabric her legs seem to be bent with knees drawn slightly up. Her legs may be crossed at the ankles. She extends her slightly bent left arm horizontally right and points at Vice, who sits on the ground to the right. The queen's right arm is bent and held in front of her torso, with her elbow perhaps propped on her right knee. She holds the head of a scepter loosely with her right hand. Long curly locks of hair fall over her shoulders, and she wears a crown on her head. Vice sits facing right and slightly forward, turning his head up and to the left to look at the tyrant. His eyes are raised, and his mouth is open and may be smiling. Vice's legs are bent with his knees splayed apart. His right arm is down by his side but bent across his torso; he plays a harmonium (or small organ) with the fingers of his right hand. His left forearm is bent upward and he holds his left index finger in his left ear as if to block out the noise of his own playing. Both of his ears are the ears of an ass, and his visible right foot is a hoof, though Vice is otherwise human in form. A wreath of laurels rests on his head over his short curly hair. He wears a shirt and a kind of skirt or similar garment draped over his lower body. A shackle around his waist bears a chain that extends down to the ground and leftward towards the queen. The Muses ("the sad Nine" in the letterpress text) rise into the sky in a procession to the left of and above the text box. The foremost Muse faces away, curving her body in a "C" shape. Her slightly bent right arm is extended up and to the right; her raised right palm faces up and supports a large closed book. Her legs dangle down and to the right. Her left foot, on tiptoe, appears just to the left of the text box, while her right foot is hidden behind it. The middle of her body curves out to the left. A ring of loosely delineated flowers, leaves, or other ornaments circles her head. Her long hair emerges from beneath it, floating left. She wears a long-sleeved transparent gown that drapes her figure fluidly. The body of the next Muse forms a similar shape, slightly to the left of and above the foremost Muse but mostly hidden behind her. The feet of this Muse are not visible. Her right arm extends up to the right, though her hand is hidden behind the book. Though she faces away, she turns her head to the right so that the top half of her face is visible in partial profile. Her long hair drapes her left shoulder, and she seems to wear a gown. The heads of the other Muses, increasingly indistinct, extend up and to the right from the two foremost of their sisters. A curved line above the back of the second nearest Muse indicates another curved body or bodies. Wash surrounding the figures suggests the sky, perhaps with clouds. The queen and Vice sit on ground colored to suggest bare earth. Vice casts a shadow that falls below him and to the right.

component.illusobjdesc: A queen representing tyranny sits in the lower left corner of the design. Her lower body faces forward and right, but she turns her head to the right to look at the figure of Vice, who is seated on the ground to the right. The queen's head may be bent down slightly. She wears a long-sleeved gown under a cloak or robe that drapes from her right shoulder over her right side and knee. The folds of these garments envelop her lower body and puddle on the ground beneath her, but underneath the fabric her legs seem to be bent with knees drawn slightly up. Her legs may be crossed at the ankles. She extends her slightly bent left arm horizontally right and points at Vice with her left index finger. This arm may rest on her left leg or knee. Her right arm is bent and held in front of her torso, with his elbow perhaps propped on her right knee. She holds the fleur-de-lis head of a scepter loosely with her right hand. Long curly locks of hair fall over her shoulders, and she wears a crown on her head.

Vice sits facing right and slightly forward, turning his head up and to the left to look at the tyrant. His eyes are raised, and his mouth is open and may be smiling. Vice's legs are bent with his knees splayed apart. His right arm is down by his side but bent across his torso; he plays a harmonium with the fingers of his right hand. His left forearm is bent upward and he holds his left index finger in his left ear as if to block out the noise of his own playing. Both of his ears are the ears of an ass, and his visible right foot is a hoof, though Vice is otherwise human in form. A wreath of laurels rests on his head over his short curly hair. He wears a shirt and a kind of skirt or similar garment draped over his lower body. A shackle around his waist bears a chain that extends down to the ground and leftward towards the queen.
A small harmonium, or pump organ, sits in the lower right corner of the design. Vice plays this instrument with his right hand while he blocks his left ear with his left index finger.

The Muses ("the sad Nine" in the letterpress text) rise into the sky in a procession to the left of and above the text box. The foremost Muse faces away, curving her body in a "C" shape. Her slightly bent right arm is extended up and to the right; her raised right palm faces up and supports a large closed book. Her legs dangle down and to the right. Her left foot, on tiptoe, appears just to the left of the text box, while her right foot is hidden behind it. The middle of her body curves out to the left. She twists at the waist, so that her lower body faces slightly left while her upper body faces slightly down and to the right. Her head may be bent slightly back. A ring of loosely delineated flowers, leaves, or other ornaments circles her head. Her long hair emerges from beneath it, floating left. She wears a long-sleeved transparent gown that drapes her figure fluidly. The body of the next Muse forms a similar shape, slightly to the left of and above the foremost Muse but mostly hidden behind her. The feet of this Muse are not visible. Her right arm extends up to the right, though her hand is hidden behind the book. Though she faces away, she turns her head to the right so that the top half of her face is visible in partial profile. Her long hair drapes her left shoulder, and she seems to wear a gown. The heads of the other Muses, increasingly indistinct, extend up and to the right from the two foremost of their sisters. A curved line above the back of the second nearest Muse indicates another curved body or bodies.
Wash surrounding the figures suggests the sky, perhaps with clouds.
The queen and Vice sit on ground colored to suggest bare earth. Vice casts a shadow that falls below him and to the right.

desc.objtitle: The Progress of Poesy: Page 9, Object 49 (Butlin 335.49)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 6 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The torso of Nature, shown here as a mother, emerges from inside a golden bowl that surrounds the text box and fills the top two-thirds of the design. Although Nature's body faces forward, she leans down to the right and her head, appearing to the right of the text box, is bent down to the right so that she can gaze at her child below. Her right arm is raised and bent upward to the left of the text box. The fingers of her raised right hand hold up the edge of a cloak or other cloth, which drapes over her raised right arm to the left, and down to the right over her head and left arm, where its folds meet the ground. Her left arm is down but forward, over the edge of the bowl. The fingers of her left hand rest on the large "golden keys" that "can unlock the gates of Joy" (see the letterpress text). Her long, slightly curly hair falls past her left shoulder, while folds of the cloak or the long-sleeved shirt or gown she wears underneath drape over this shoulder and the edge of the bowl. In the crook of her elbow sits her nude child, facing left and slightly forward but bending his head far back to look up at his mother. This is Shakespeare in his infancy. He has short curly hair. He sits with his left leg bent and drawn up beneath him and his left foot on tiptoe, while his right leg is extended leftward with knee bent up. Both arms are raised at 135 degrees. His hands are hidden in the folds of his mother's garments overhead. His legs cast shadows on the ground below him. The waters of the Avon river flow across the bottom of the design. Nature's child is thus sitting on a riverbank, which is covered with grass. Hedges or small trees appear at either side of the design above the bank. Shadow darkens the underside of the hedge on the left, and a corner of riverbank at the right. The figure of Sympathy, a young woman, runs leftward through the knee-high waters of the Avon. The river is transparent enough that her lower body and even her feet remain visible. She is seen in profile, facing left and leaning forward with her bent left leg forward, foot flat on the ground, and her right leg extended behind her. Her right foot is on tiptoe. Her head is bent back slightly. Her left arm is down by her side and bent forward at the elbow. Her open left hand, with palm facing up, supports the lip of a bowl or vase tipped up on its side in front of her torso. Liquid, perhaps symbolizing tears, pours from the open mouth of this vessel and streams down and to the right into the Avon. Sympathy wears a long-sleeved gown. Her long hair flows over her shoulders and down her back. Wash around the edges of the golden bowl suggests the sky.

component.illusobjdesc: The figure of Sympathy, a young woman, runs leftward through the knee-high waters of the Avon, which flows across the bottom of the design. The river is transparent enough that her lower body and even her feet remain visible. She is seen in profile, facing left and leaning forward with her bent left leg forward, foot flat on the ground, and her right leg extended behind her. Her right foot is on tiptoe. Her head is bent back slightly. Her left arm is down by her side and bent forward at the elbow. Her open left hand, with palm facing up, supports the lip of a bowl or vase tipped up on its side in front of her torso. Liquid, perhaps symbolizing tears, pours from the open mouth of this vessel and streams down and to the right into the Avon. Sympathy wears a long-sleeved gown. Her long hair flows over her shoulders and down her back.
The semi-transparent waters of the Avon river flow across the bottom of the design. The coloring of the water on the right hints at waves.

The torso of Nature, shown here as a mother, emerges from inside a golden bowl that surrounds the text box. Although her body faces forward she leans down to the right and her head, appearing to the right of the text box, is bent down to the right so that she can gaze at her child below. Her right arm is raised and bent upward to the left of the text box. The fingers of her raised right hand hold up the edge of a cloak or other cloth, which drapes down to the left over her raised right arm, and down to the right over her head and left arm, where its folds meet the ground. Her left arm is down but forward, over the edge of the bowl. The fingers of her left hand rest on the large "golden keys" that "can unlock the gates of Joy" (see the letterpress text), which lie on the riverbank. Her long, slightly curly hair falls past her left shoulder, while folds of the cloak or the long-sleeved shirt or gown she wears underneath drape over this shoulder and the edge of the bowl. In the crook of her elbow sits her nude child, facing left and slightly forward but bending his head far back to look up at his mother. This is Shakespeare in his infancy. He has short curly hair. He sits with his left leg bent and drawn up beneath him and his left foot on tiptoe, while his right leg is extended leftward with knee bent up. Both arms are raised at 135 degrees. His hands are hidden in the folds of his mother's garments overhead. His legs cast shadows on the ground below him.
A golden bowl fills much of the top two-thirds of the design. Nature's torso emerges from within it. Shadows fill its depths around Nature's figure.

Grass covers the riverbank on which Nature's child sits. Hedges or small trees appear at either side of the design above the bank. Shadow darkens the underside of the hedge on the left, and a corner of riverbank at the right.
Wash around the edges of the golden bowl suggests the sky.

desc.objtitle: The Progress of Poesy: Page 10, Object 50 (Butlin 335.50)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 13 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The poet "Dryden" (see Blake's text, Object 42) sits on a stool in the lower left corner of the design. He faces right, but bends forward and lowers his head to look at an approaching swarm of small flying figures. A lyre, decorated with a spiral carving along one side of the frame, rests lightly on his lap. His bent right arm is down by his side and he plays the strings of the lyre with the fingers of this hand. One slightly bent leg is extended along the floor. The curly-haired poet wears a long-sleeved gown or robe with a collar. The folds of this garment gather on the floor beneath his chair. "Bright-eyed Fancy" is shown "hov'ring o'er" Dryden, releasing "Thoughts" and "words" from her "pictur'd urn" (see the letterpress text). Her lower body is roughly horizontal, facing down, but she bends down at the waist and turns her torso to the right and away from the viewer. Her torso, upside down, is thus seen from behind. Her head is bent back toward the viewer and twisted left, and she seems to look down at Dryden below. Both arms are extended down and to the right. She wears a long-sleeved gown with skirts that swirl up and away to the right, hiding her feet. She has short curly hair. She holds an upside-down urn, on which is pictured two tiny figures: one is crowning the other with a wreath of laurels. A wreath of laurel leaves also decorates the urn just below its lip. Flames pour from the mouth of the urn and light the area nearby. Within the flames appear the swarm of small flying female figures, which represent "the "Thoughts that breathe, and words that burn" that flow from the urn (see the letterpress text). Most of the women bear gifts. The foremost woman has just set free a bird that flies with its beak open as if in song. The next woman supports a large grasshopper on her upraised right palm. Above her another woman holds two serpents, one in each hand; the creatures writhe around her arms with open mouths. A fourth woman bears a trailing branch of laurel. The heads of three other women appear in the stream as well. Together they all approach the poet. The stool on which the poet sits rests on a floor that seems to be made of earth, and extends the length of the bottom of the design. Part of a rainbow appears arching up from behind Dryden to meet Fancy. Shadow fills much of the design around the figures, particularly at the left side of the design and in the upper right corner. The poet and his stool also cast a shadow along the floor in the lower left corner.

component.illusobjdesc: The poet "Dryden" (see Blake's text, Object 42) sits on a stool in the lower left corner of the design. He faces right, but bends forward and lowers his head to look at an approaching swarm of small flying figures. A lyre, decorated with a spiral carving along one side of the frame, rests lightly on his lap. His bent right arm is down by his side and he plays the strings of the lyre with the fingers of this hand. One slightly bent leg is extended along the floor. The curly-haired poet wears a long-sleeved gown or robe with a collar. The folds of this garment gather on the floor beneath his chair. A shoe is visible on his extended foot. The stool on which he sits bears intricately carved forms, including a leaf-like decoration.

"Bright-eyed Fancy" is shown "hov'ring o'er" Dryden, releasing "Thoughts" and "words" from her "pictur'd urn" (see the letterpress text). Her lower body is roughly horizontal, facing down, but she bends down at the waist and turns her torso to the right and away from the viewer. Her torso, upside down, is thus seen from behind. Her head is bent back toward the viewer and twisted left, and she seems to look down at Dryden below. Both arms are extended down and to the right. She wears a long-sleeved gown with skirts that swirl up and away to the right, hiding her feet. This gown may have a belt, or at least a well-defined waist. She has short curly hair. She holds an upside- down urn. Only her left hand is visible on the right side of the urn; her right hand is hidden behind the text box.

The urn that Fancy holds is partially visible to the right of the text box. A wreath of laurel leaves decorates the urn just below its lip; two tiny figures are pictured on its side between the edge of the text box and Fancy's arm. The upper body of one figure faces to the left. A head and upraised arm, lifted at 135 degrees, are visible to the right of the first figure. This second figure is lifting a laurel wreath above the head of the first, to crown him. Both figures appear upside down. Flames cascade downward from the urn.
Part of a rainbow appears arching up from behind Dryden to meet Fancy.

The "Thoughts that breathe, and words that burn" (see the letterpress text) that flow from the urn appear as young women amidst the flames. Most bear gifts. The leftmost woman flies or hovers with her body facing down and away, though she bends backward at the waist and tilts her head back to look up to the left. She wears a loosely delineated gown and her hair is drawn back into a bun. Her left leg extends out towards the viewer, so that the base of her foot is visible and the leg is foreshortened. Her right arm and right leg are not visible. She extends her left arm up with hand raised and palm vertical. A bird flies rightward from this upraised hand, with its wings spread and its beak open as if in song. The next woman to the right is visible only above the waist; the rest of her body is hidden by a woman next to her. Her head is bent back and her hair is either short or drawn back. She extends her right arm out roughly horizontally and supports a large grasshopper on her upraised right palm. The insect's antennae are pictured. The third woman to the right flies or hovers shoulder-to-shoulder with the second-most woman. Her torso faces down and to the right but her lower body merges upward with the flames pouring from the urn above. Her left arm is extended along her side and she holds a trailing laurel branch in her left hand. Her head is bent back and turned slightly away; she looks down to the left. Her hair is drawn back into a bun or similar coiffure. She is nude or wears a gown that leaves her breasts mostly exposed. Above the two shoulder-to-shoulder women flies or hovers another woman, upside down with her torso facing out and to the right. Her lower body merges into the flames. Both of her arms are extended past her head and she holds a serpent in each hand; each snake has its mouth open and twists its body around one of the woman's arms. The snake in her right hand makes a spiral with its writhing body. The woman's head is tilted back and she looks before her to the left. Her hair seems to be long and to fall behind her shoulders. She seems to be nude. The heads of three other women appear between the woman with the snakes and the woman with the laurel branch. All three of the heads are extended out towards the viewer. The face of the leftmost head looks to the left and slightly down; its hair is drawn back into a bun or similar hairstyle. The face of the rightmost head looks up to the right. This woman may be wearing a bonnet, scarf, or similar headcovering over her hair. The third head looks to the right and only slightly up; her hair seems to be drawn back. The eyes of all three women may be closed or downcast.
The poet's stool sits on a floor that seems to be made of earth. It extends the length of the bottom of the design.

Shadow fills much of the design around the figures, particularly at the left side of the design and in the upper right corner. The poet and his chair also cast a shadow along the floor in the lower left corner.

desc.objtitle: The Progress of Poesy: Page 11, Object 51 (Butlin 335.51)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 7 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A rainbow arcs across the sky at the top of the design, above and to the left and right of the text box. The semi-transparent figures of two children and a woman (perhaps their mother) appear within the rainbow. They may be "such forms as glitter in the Muse's ray" (see the letterpress text) and the woman may be the muse. She lies on her side or hovers roughly horizontally, facing forward with her legs extending to the right of the text box and her head appearing slightly above it to the left. Her right arm is bent up at the elbow and propped out to the left, and she seems to be resting the side of her face in her right hand. Her head is turned up and to the right and her eyes are raised. Her mouth is open slightly. Her long hair is caught in her right hand on the left, but it flutters freely away from the right of her head. She is clad in a garment, perhaps a gown, that drapes her legs. Her feet are indistinct. To the left of the woman hovers a child, probably male, facing right and wearing a long gown that swathes his lower body. His right arm is raised vertically and may rest along the woman's lower right arm. The child's hand is hidden in the woman's hair but the shape of her locks suggests he may be touching her face. He has short curly hair with longer lengths that blow leftward. The second child, perhaps female, flies or hovers with her body in a horizontal position, facing down, above and to the right of the text box. She wears a long gown that flutters rightward, hiding her feet. Her arms are extended horizontally out from her body and she holds her hands out with palms facing up. Her head is bent back and her face looks forward and to the left; she may be gazing at the woman nearby. Her long hair flies rightward. Wash above and below the rainbow indicates a stormy sky. Wavy lines extending down from the rainbow suggest rain. Shadows beneath the rainbow on the right add to the impression of rain. Near the bottom of the design, a nude boy or young man lies prone on a field of grain stems that has been knocked down. The boy's body is stretched horizontally over the shafts, which likewise lie roughly horizontally along the ground. His legs extend out to the right, and his arms are stretched vertically over his head to the left. His curly hair falls over the side of his face, obscuring it from view. A poet stands in contrapposto, facing away and slightly to the right, in the lower left corner of the design. His weight rests on his right leg, which is straight; his left leg is bent slightly and his left foot is on tiptoe. His bent arms are down by his side, and he holds his hands out slightly from his body with the palms facing down. He wears a shirt and breeches and has short curly hair.

component.illusobjdesc: The poet stands in contrapposto, facing away and slightly to the right, in the lower left corner of the design. His weight rests on his right leg, which is straight; his left leg is bent slightly and his left foot is on tiptoe. His bent arms are down by his side, and he holds his hands out slightly from his body with the palms facing down. He wears a shirt and short and breeches and has short curly hair.

Near the bottom of the design, a nude boy or young man lies prone on a field of wheat that has been knocked down. The boy's body is stretched horizontally over the shafts of wheat, which likewise lie roughly horizontally along the ground. His legs extend out to the right, and his arms are stretched vertically over his head to the left. His curly hair falls over the side of his face, obscuring it from view.
The field of grain stems near the bottom of the design has been knocked down, and the shafts lie roughly horizontally along the ground. Grain tassels are pictured.
A rainbow arcs across the sky at the top of the design, above and to the left and right of the text box.

The semi-transparent figures of two children and a woman (perhaps their mother) appear within the rainbow. They may be "such forms as glitter in the Muse's ray" (see the letterpress text) and the woman may be the muse. She lies on her side or hovers roughly horizontally, facing forward with her legs extending to the right of the text box and her head appearing slightly above it to the left. Her right arm is bent up at the elbow and propped out to the left, and she seems to be resting the side of her face in her right hand. Her head is turned up and to the right and her eyes are raised. Her mouth is open slightly. Her long hair is caught in her right hand on the left, but it flutters freely away from the right of her head. She is clad in a garment, perhaps a gown, that drapes her legs. Her feet are indistinct. To the left of the woman hovers a child, probably male, facing right and wearing a long gown that swathes his lower body. His right arm is raised vertically and may rest along the woman's lower right arm. The child's hand is hidden in the woman's hair but the shape of her locks suggests he may be touching her face. He has short curly hair with longer lengths that blow leftward. The second child, perhaps female, flies or hovers with her body in a horizontal position, facing down, above and to the right of the text box. She wears a long gown that flutters rightward, hiding her feet. Her arms are extended horizontally out from her body and she holds her hands out with palms facing up. Her head is bent back and her face looks forward and to the left; she may be gazing at the woman nearby. Her long hair flies rightward.
Wash above and below the rainbow indicates a stormy sky. Wavy lines extending down from the rainbow suggest rain. Shadows beneath the rainbow on the right add to the impression of rain.
The ground surrounding the wheatfield may be raw earth.

desc.objtitle: The Progress of Poesy; Page 12: Blank Page Bearing List of Titles, Object 52 (Butlin 335.52)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A single "Muse" (see Blake's text, Object 42) fills much of the design. Seen mostly from behind, she hovers or flies with her body in a "C" shape to the left of the text box. Her lower body faces away and slightly to the left, while she twists at the waist to turn her upper body to the right. Both of her arms are raised almost vertically, in relation to her body, and stretched out in front of her to the right. She holds the frame of a lyre with her right hand and touches its strings with her left. She may be playing the instrument. She bends or leans forward and to the right, and tilts her head back with her eyes raised, as if she is looking up at the instrument that she stretches to hold aloft. Her mouth may be open slightly. Her slightly bent left leg is extended down to the right and out towards the viewer, and her right leg is bent and drawn up. The bottoms of both feet face the viewer. She wears a long-sleeved gown that drapes her figure closely, wrapping her legs with folds of fabric that billow past her feet. A laurel wreath graces her head. Her long curly hair flies leftward. Wash surrounding the muse and the text box suggests the sky.

component.illusobjdesc: A single "Muse" (see Blake's text, Object 42) fills much of the design. Seen mostly from behind, she flies or hovers with her body in a "C" shape to the left of the text box. Her lower body faces away and slightly to the left, while she twists at the waist to turn her upper body to the right. Both of her arms are raised almost vertically, in relation to her body, and stretched out in front of her to the right. She holds the frame of a lyre with her right hand and touches its strings with her left. She may be playing the instrument. She bends or leans forward and to the right, and tilts her head back with her eyes raised, as if she is looking up at the instrument that she stretches to hold aloft. Her mouth may be open slightly. Her slightly bent left leg is extended down to the right and out towards the viewer, and her right leg is bent and drawn up. The bottoms of both feet face the viewer. She wears a long-sleeved gown that drapes her figure closely, wrapping her legs with folds of fabric that billow past her feet. A laurel wreath graces her head. Her long curly hair flies leftward.
Wash surrounding the muse and the text box suggests the sky.

lg.l: The Bard.
1. A Welch Bard.
2. The Slaughterd Bards, taken from the line
"The famishd Eagle screams & passes by" Page 98.As the page reference indicates, the words in quotation marks are quoted, with minor variations, from page 98 of the letterpress text (Object 58).
3. The Bard weaving Edwards fate
4. Edward & his Queen and Nobles astonishd at the
Bards Song
5. "Hark how each Giant Oak & Desart CaveLines 8-9 are quoted, with minor variations, from page 97 of the letterpress text (Object 57).
Sigh to the Torrents awful voice beneath"
6. "On yonder Cliff.. "I see them Sit"The line is quoted, with minor variations, from page 98 of the letterpress text (Object 58).
7. "Oer' thy country hangs" The scourge of heaven"The line is quoted, with minor variations, from page [99] of the letterpress text (Object 59).
8. The Whirlwind. "Hushd in grim repose"The words within quotation marks are quoted, with minor variations, from page 100 of the letterpress text (Object 60).
9. "Fell thirst & Famine scowlLines 13-14 are quoted, with minor variations, from page 101 of the letterpress text (Object 61).
A baleful smile upon their baffled guest"
10. The Death of Edwards Queen Eleanor from this line
"Half of thy heart we consecrate"The line is quoted from page 102 of the letterpress text (Object 62).
11. Elizabeth. "Girt with many a Baron bold"The words within quotation marks are quoted from page 103 of the letterpress text (Object 63).
12. Spenser Creating his Fairies.
13. "Headlong from the Mountains heightLines 19-20 are quoted, with minor variations, from page 105 of the letterpress text (Object 65).
Deep in the roaring tide he plungd to endless night"
14. A poor Goatherd in Wales.-

desc.objtitle: The Bard; a Pindaric Ode; Page 1: Title-Page, Object 53 (Butlin 335.53)

illustration.illusobjdesc: "A Welch Bard" (see Blake's text, Object 52) stands at the right side of the design, next to an enormous harp. He faces forward with his left arm extended down by his side and his right arm down but bent up at the elbow. The fingers of his right hand appear on the frame of his instrument. He wears a long-sleeved robe decorated with small stars. Though the robe puddles on the ground beneath him, the shape of his legs is partly visible and both of his feet emerge from under its hem. His weight rests on his left foot and his right leg is bent slightly at the knee. His right foot is on tiptoe. He has long white hair and a large white beard. The Bard's instrument is an enormous harp that stands to the left of him. Its stringed frame extends up to the upper left corner of the design. The figure of an angel playing his(?) own harp decorates the top left corner of the instrument. He faces and leans left with wings folded behind his back. His legs are extended down and slightly back, and merge with the frame of the harp. His left arm is down by his side but bent up so that his left hand touches the strings of his smaller harp, which is positioned in front of his body as if it extends the larger instrument's frame. His right hand is visible through the strings of this smaller mock harp and may be playing them. He may be wearing a gown with skirts that hide his feet. The Bard stands on a small bit of sand in front of a rocky beach. Large boulders appear to the left and right of the Bard, in the background, and perhaps form a cliff. Smaller rocks or tangled driftwood lines the shore to the left of the base of the harp. The waves of the sea lap the shore. Wash surrounding the Bard and his harp suggests the sky, perhaps with clouds. A tree branch bearing thick leaves appears in the upper right corner of the design, stretching left.

component.illusobjdesc: "A Welch Bard" (see Blake's text, Object 52) stands at the right side of the design, next to an enormous harp. He faces forward with his left arm extended down by his side and his right arm down but bent up at the elbow. The fingers of his right hand appear on the frame of his instrument. He wears a long-sleeved robe decorated with small stars. Though the robe puddles on the ground beneath him, the shape of his legs is partly visible and both of his feet emerge from under its hem. His weight rests on his left foot and his right leg is bent slightly at the knee. His right foot is on tiptoe. He has long white hair and a large white beard.

The Bard's instrument is an enormous harp that stands to the left of him. Its stringed frame extends up to the upper left corner of the design. The figure of an angel playing his(?) own harp decorates the top left corner of the instrument. He faces and leans left with wings folded behind his back. His legs are extended down and slightly back, and merge with the frame of the harp. His left arm is down by his side but bent up so that his left hand touches the strings of his smaller harp, which is positioned in front of his body as if it extends the larger instrument's frame. His right hand is visible through the strings of this smaller mock harp and may be playing them. He may be wearing a gown with skirts that hide his feet.
A tree branch bearing thick leaves appears in the upper right corner of the design, stretching left.

The Bard stands on a small space of sand in front of a rocky shore. Large boulders appear to the left and right of the Bard, in the background, perhaps forming a cliff. Smaller rocks or tangled driftwood lines the shore to the left of the base of the harp. The waves of the sea lap the shore. Wash surrounding the Bard and his harp suggests the sky, perhaps with clouds.

desc.objtitle: The Bard; Page 2: Advertisement, Object 54 (Butlin 335.54)

illustration.illusobjdesc: An eagle flies or hovers at the top of the design, its wings spread wide. It faces left and slightly forward, and lowers its head down to the left. Its beak is open and its tongue is extended; it may be screaming. One clawed foot is visible beneath its body. Lines near the upper left corner of the design suggest birds in flight. Three dead bards lie on the ground near the bottom of the design with their heads out toward the viewer and their bodies extending away. They may represent the past (center), present (left), and future (right); see also the design on Object 63. The leftmost bard is young and lies facing down. His short, slightly curly hair fans out over his head and hides his face from view. His right arm seems to be down by his side. He may be nude. The old bard in the center lies facing up, his head bent back so that his features are visible upside down. His eyes are closed. His long white hair spreads out on the ground on either side of his head. His long beard is split; its halves lie to the left and right over his shoulders and the shoulders of the bards on either side of him. His knees are bent up and he wears a gown or other garment that drapes his torso and lower limbs and extends down to the left of his legs. The young bard to the right lies face up. His eyes seem to be closed. His curly hair pools on the ground beneath his head. His knees are also bent up and he wears garments that cover his limbs and torso. The bards lie in the wreckage of a broken harp. One angular piece with a shattered end lies on the ground beneath the bards on the right. Another piece appears at the lower left side of the design, slanting up to the right toward the eagle. The ground on which the bards lie is covered with vegetation, probably grass. A mountain peak appears upper right. A heavy gray cloud fills much of the top of the design and extends down to the left. Wash below this sky on the left suggests a sunrise or sunset. The darkness of the scene suggests storm or night.

component.illusobjdesc: An eagle flies or hovers at the top of the design, its wings spread wide. It faces left and slightly forward, and lowers its head down to the left. Its beak is open and its tongue is extended; it may be screaming. One clawed foot is visible beneath its body.

Three dead bards lie on the ground near the bottom of the design with their heads out toward the viewer and their bodies extending away. They may represent the past (center), present (left), and future (right); see also the design on Object 63. The leftmost bard is young and lies facing down. His short, slightly curly hair fans out over his head and hides his face from view. His right arm seems to be down by his side. He may be nude. The old bard in the center lies facing up, his head bent back so that his features are visible upside down. His eyes are closed. His long white hair spreads out on the ground on either side of his head. His long beard is split; its halves lie to the left and right over his shoulders and the shoulders of the bards on either side of him. His knees are bent up and he wears a gown or other garment that drapes his torso and lower limbs and extends down to the left of his legs. The younger bard to the right lies face up. His eyes seem to be closed. His curly hair pools on the ground beneath his head. His knees are also bent up and he wears garments that cover his limbs and torso.

The bards lie in the wreckage of a broken harp. One angular piece with a shattered end lies on the ground beneath the bards on the right. Another angular piece appears at the lower left side of the design, slanting up to the right toward the eagle.
The bards lie on a ground covered with vegetation, probably grass.

A mountain peak appears upper right just below the tip of the eagle's left wing. A heavy gray cloud fills much of the top of the design and extends down to the left. Wash below this sky on the left suggests a sunrise or sunset. The darkness of the scene suggests storm or night.
Lines near the upper left corner of the design suggest birds in flight.

desc.objtitle: The Bard; Page 3: Beginning of Poem, Object 55 (Butlin 335.55)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil two crosses in the top left corner of the page bearing the inset letterpress text. These are probably meant to indicate that the illustration is a portrayal of the titular figure, "The Bard." See also the marked passages on Objects 56 and 58 for lines relevant to this design.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Five enormous strings of a huge harp or "lyre" (see the letterpress text, Object 56) slant across the design from the upper left corner to the bottom of the design. As thick as rope, they are coated with blood. These may represent the warp of a symbolic loom on which Gray says the Bard will "weave with bloody hands the tissue of [King Edward's] line" (see the letterpress text on Object 58). The figure of the old bard fills much of the design. His body faces forward and left, but he turns his head to the right and bends it to look down to the right. His right arm is extended and raised at 135 degrees. His bent left arm is raised and extended to the left. He grasps a bloody lyre cord in his left fist, which is partly hidden behind the text box. The fingers and thumb of his raised right hand rest on two different cords. His left leg is bent forward and drawn up to the right; his left foot rests flat on the ground near one of the lyre cords. His right leg, which may also be bent, is extended down behind him to the left. His right foot is visible on lower ground in the lower left corner of the design, and seems to be on tiptoe. He leans forward and to the right, and may be bending forward slightly at the waist. The Bard wears a long-sleeved gown that drapes his lower body though both bare feet are visible. He has a long beard and staring eyes. His long wild hair flies to either side of his head. His mouth may be open slightly. Shadows appear between the lyre strings especially in the lower left corner of the design, on the ground, and at the right side of the design. Shadow also casts parts of the Bard's clothing in darkness. A lighter area near the top of the design seems to shed light on the bard's hair as well. The surfaces on which the bard steps seem to be made of stone.

component.illusobjdesc: Five enormous strings of a huge harp or "lyre" (see the letterpress text, Object 56) slant across the design from the upper left corner to the bottom of the design. As thick as rope, they are coated with blood. These may represent the warp of a symbolic loom on which Gray says the Bard will "weave with bloody hands the tissue of [King Edward's] line" (see the letterpress text on Object 58).

The figure of the old bard fills much of the design. His body faces forward and left, but he turns his head to the right and bends it to look down to the right. His right arm is extended and raised at 135 degrees. His bent left arm is raised and extended to the left. He grasps a bloody harp cord in his left fist, which is partly hidden behind the text box. The fingers and thumb of his raised right hand rest on two different cords. His left leg is bent forward and drawn up to the right; his left foot rests flat on the ground near one of the lyre cords. His right leg, which may also be bent, is extended down behind him to the left. His right foot is visible on lower ground in the lower left corner of the design, and seems to be on tiptoe. He leans forward and to the right, and may be bending forward slightly at the waist. The bard wears a long-sleeved gown that drapes his lower body though both bare feet are visible. He has a long beard and staring eyes. His long wild hair flies to either side of his head. His mouth may be open slightly.

Shadows appear between the lyre strings especially in the lower left corner of the design, on the ground, and at the right side of the design. Shadow also casts parts of the bard's clothing in darkness. A lighter area near the top of the design seems to shed light on the bard's hair as well.
The surfaces on which the bard steps seem to be made of stone.

desc.objtitle: The Bard: Page 4, Object 56 (Butlin 335.56)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil the number "2" and a cross to the left of line 5 of the letterpress text, and the number "1" and a cross to the left of line 12. The number and cross left of line 5 probably indicates the lines or passages illustrated by this design; the number and cross left of line 12 probably indicates the lines or passage illustrated by the previous design (Object 57).

illustration.illusobjdesc: Dressed for battle, King Edward the First looks up in fear and "wild dismay" (see the letterpress text); he has heard the bard's voice overhead. He sits astride a horse, his lower body facing left. Leaning far forward over its withers, he turns his body forward and twists his head to look up and slightly to the right. His mouth is open and his eyes are wide. His left arm is drawn back, slightly bent, and his left hand rests on the horse's hip. His right shoulder is down but his right hand is partly visible over the front of the horse's saddle, grasping its reins. He wears a long-sleeved tunic over a coat of mail, visible where it covers his left leg and foot, and where it forms a hood over his neck and head. Alternatively, this head covering may be a helmet with chin and partial cheek guards. A crown circles his head, over the mail or helmet, and a large plume surmounts both. King Edward's horse kneels on the ground facing left. Its three visible legs are bent and drawn up beneath its body, which rests on a kind of ledge near the bottom of the design. It has lowered its head down past the ledge, and its eyes are closed. Its mane cascades down over its arching neck and past its lowered head. The king grasps its reins, though it does not wear a bridle. A simple saddle sits on its back, and Edward's left foot is in a stirrup. The horse's one visible hoof, the left rear, bears a heavy horseshoe. The head and torso of King Edward's queen, Eleanor of Castile, appears to the left of his head. The queen faces forward and slightly to the right, but leans left. Her head is bent back slightly. Her mouth is open and her eyes are raised. Her right arm, slightly bent, extends horizontally across her torso to the right; her right hand may be resting on King Edward's right shoulder. She wears a crown over long, slightly curly hair that flows past her shoulders. Her garment, a shirt or gown, has long sleeves. Its folds may appear to the left of King Edward's horse's mane. Alternatively, this area may represent part of another horse. Two other soldiers in Edward's army are partly visible to the right of the text box. These may be Mortimer and Gloucester, named in the letterpress text. The head of the leftmost soldier faces forward and to the right. It is bent back slightly and the soldier's eyes are raised to look up. This soldier has curly hair and a curly beard. His shoulders, clad in a tunic, are visible above part of the back of a horse below. Only the head of the rightmost soldier appears, bent back and looking up to the right. This soldier has a beard and longer hair. Both men seem to be looking up and listening to the bard's song in trepidation. Four spears appear above the text box and the heads of Edward and his soldiers. Raised in parallel, they point from lower right to upper left. The heads of two are hidden behind a branch thick with leaves above. Edward's horse kneels on what seems to be a rocky ledge. Wash in the background of the design may indicate the rocky face of a rising mountain, atop which the bard stands and sings. Alternatively this wash may represent sky, perhaps at sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: Dressed for battle, King Edward the First looks up in fear and "wild dismay" (see the letterpress text); he has heard the bard's voice overhead. He sits astride a horse, his lower body facing left. Leaning far forward over its withers, he turns his body forward and twists his head to look up and slightly to the right. His mouth is open and his eyes are wide. His left arm is drawn back, slightly bent, and his left hand rests on the horse's hip. His right shoulder is down but his right hand is partly visible over the front of the horse's saddle, grasping its reins. He wears a long-sleeved tunic over a coat of mail, visible where it covers his left leg and foot, and where it forms a hood over his neck and head. Alternatively, this head covering may be a helmet with chin and partial cheek guards. A crown circles his head, over the mail or helmet, and a large plume surmounts both.

King Edward's horse kneels on the ground facing left. Its three visible legs are bent and drawn up beneath its body, which rests on a kind of ledge near the bottom of the design. It has lowered its head down past the ledge, and its eyes are closed. Its mane cascades down over its arching neck and past its lowered head. The king grasps its reins, though it does not wear a bridle. A simple saddle sits on its back, and Edward's left foot is in a stirrup. The horse's one visible hoof, the left rear, bears a heavy horseshoe.

The head and torso of King Edward's queen, Eleanor of Castile, appears to the left of his head (see "Edward & his Queen," Blake's text, Object 52). The Queen faces forward and slightly to the right, but leans left. Her head is bent back slightly. Her mouth is open and her eyes are raised. Her right arm, slightly bent, extends horizontally across her torso to the right; her right hand may be resting on King Edward's right shoulder. She wears a crown over long, slightly curly hair that flows past her shoulders. Her garment, a shirt or gown, has long sleeves. Its folds may appear to the left of King Edward's horse's mane. Alternatively, this area may represent part of another horse.

Two other soldiers in Edward's army are partly visible to the right of the text box. These may be Gloucester and Mortimer, named in the text. The head of the leftmost soldier faces forward and to the right. It is bent back slightly and the soldier's eyes are raised to look up. This soldier has curly hair and a curly beard. His shoulders, clad in a tunic, are visible above part of the back of a horse below. Only the head of the rightmost soldier appears, bent back and looking up to the right. This soldier has a beard and longer hair. Both men seem to be looking up and listening to the bard's song in trepidation. c

Four spears appear above the text box and the heads of Edward and his soldiers. Raised in parallel, they point from lower right to upper left. The heads of two are hidden behind a branch above, but the points of the leftmost two are visible. T
A branch thick with leaves extends across most of the top of the design, from top right corner almost to the top left corner.

King Edward's horse kneels on what seems to be a rocky ledge. Wash in the background of the design may indicate the rocky face of a rising mountain, atop which the Bard stands and sings. Alternatively this wash may represent sky, perhaps at sunrise or sunset.

desc.objtitle: The Bard: Page 5, Object 57 (Butlin 335.57)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 2 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The personification of a "giant-oak" (see the letterpress text) as a nude, thickly muscled man crouches to the right of the text box, facing forward with bent left leg drawn up beneath him and slightly bent right leg extended down to the left. He bends or leans forward slightly and raises both arms overhead at roughly 135 degrees. His left arm, raised slightly higher than the right, extends beyond the edge of the design and is thus visible only to the elbow. The right arm is slightly bent, and his raised right hand, palm down, hangs slightly from the wrist. An oak branch curves up to the left from behind the giant-oak's back before arching down to the left over his right arm, splitting into smaller branches and scattered oak leaves that fill much of the space between the text box and the left side of the design. Another branch follows the giant-oak's left arm up into the top right corner of the design, sending two smaller branches with leaves to the right. Nearer the top of the design, it splits leftward into leafless branches; leaves that descend from the top of the design may hang from higher parts of this branch. Additional leaves appear above the giant-oak's right shoulder and below his left arm. He turns his head slightly left and wears a crown or hat made of leaves, with an acorn at each temple. He has a long beard that merges with the lines of his body to suggest the curved trunk of an ancient tree. The shape of his mustache suggests the shape of the oak leaves on his head; two additional oak leaf shapes appear where his beard grows from each cheek. The hair at his temples suggests his hair is short. His left foot seems to become a root growing rightward and down over the body of the personification of a cave, below. His right foot is not visible. The face of a second personified giant oak appears beneath the left armpit of the first. This face looks forward and right, with open mouth and raised eyes. He wears a similar crown or wreath of oak leaves. The personification of "the torrent" (see the letterpress text) appears in the lower left corner of the design. It is difficult to tell whether this figure is male or female (probably the former). Its face looks forward, tilted slightly down. Its mouth is open and its teeth are visible. Its long hair is parted in the middle over its forehead and extends down on either side of the face. From there the hair blends into the lines of flowing water that run from beneath the text box down the left side and across the bottom of the design. A beard may grow from the figure's cheeks and chin; alternatively these lines may be water lines that create a small waterfall. The female(?) personification of the "desert-cave" (see the letterpress text) appears lying on her side in the lower right corner of the design. Her head faces forward, but is also tilted back to look left. Her mouth is open and her eyes are raised. Her bent right arm is raised and propped beneath her head to the left; her right hand is beneath her forehead. A wreath of thin leaves or similar ornament is on her head. Her long hair streams over her left shoulder and her right hand. She may be wearing a gown that suggests the appearance of rocks beside the waters of the torrent. Her head and shoulder support the weight of the foremost "giant-oak" above. The oak's roots curl over her left shoulder. Wash around the figures, particularly near the left side of the design, suggests the sky, perhaps with clouds. Shadow fills the space between the right side of the design and the foremost giant-oak's left leg.

component.illusobjdesc: The personification of a "giant-oak" (see the letterpress text) as a nude, thickly muscled man crouches to the right of the text box, facing forward with bent left leg drawn up beneath him and slightly bent right leg extended down to the left. Although this is not, strictly speaking, a vegetating human figure, since the transformation is in the other direction, the figure is similar in appearance to vegetating figures elsewhere in Blake's art. He bends or leans forward slightly and raises both arms overhead at roughly 135 degrees. His left arm, raised slightly higher than the right, extends beyond the edge of the design and is thus visible only to the elbow. The right arm is slightly bent, and his raised right hand, palm down, hangs slightly from the wrist. An oak branch curves up to the left from behind the giant-oak's back before arching down to the left over his right arm, splitting into smaller branches and scattered oak leaves that fill much of the space between the text box and the left side of the design. Another branch follows the giant-oak's left arm up into the top right corner of the design, sending two smaller branches with leaves to the right. Nearer the top of the design, it splits leftward into leafless branches; leaves that descend from the top of the design may hang from higher parts of this branch. Additional leaves appear above the giant-oak's right shoulder and below his left arm. He turns his head slightly left and wears a crown or hat made of leaves, with an acorn at each temple. He has a long beard that merges with the lines of his body to suggest the curved trunk of an ancient tree. The shape of his mustache suggests the shape of the oak leaves on his head; two additional oak leaf shapes appear where his beard grows from each cheek. The hair at his temples suggests his hair is short. His left foot seems to become a root growing rightward and down over the body of the personification of a cave, below. His right foot is not visible. The face of a second personified giant oak appears beneath the left armpit of the first. This face looks forward and right, with open mouth and raised eyes. He wears a similar crown or wreath of oak leaves; one leaf descends into the space between his beard, the first giant oak's knee, and the edge of the design.

The personification of "the torrent" (see the letterpress text) appears in the lower left corner of the design. It is difficult to tell whether this figure is male or female (probably the former). Its face looks forward, tilted slightly down. Its mouth is open and its teeth are visible. Its long hair is parted in the middle over its forehead and extends down on either side of the face. From there the hair blends into the lines of flowing water that run from beneath the text box down the left side and across the bottom of the design. A beard may grow from the figure's cheeks and chin; alternatively these lines may be water lines that create a small waterfall.

The female(?) personification of the "desert-cave" (see the letterpress text) appears lying on her side in the lower right corner of the design. Her head faces forward, but is also tilted back to look left. Her mouth is open and her eyes are raised. Her bent right arm is raised and propped beneath her head to the left; her right hand is beneath her forehead. A wreath of thin leaves or similar ornament is on her head. Beneath it her long hair streams over her left shoulder and her right hand. She may be wearing a gown that suggests the appearance of rocks beside the waters of the torrent. Her head and shoulder support the weight of the foremost "giant-oak" above. The oak's roots curl over her left shoulder.

Wash around the figures, particularly near the left side of the design, suggests the sky, perhaps with clouds. Shadow fills the space between the right side of the design and the foremost giant-oak's left leg.

desc.objtitle: The Bard: Page 6, Object 58 (Butlin 335.58)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 11 of the letterpress text, and inscribed two crosses left of line 15, to indicate the lines or passages illustrated. The crosses left of line 15 may also be relevant to the design on Object 55.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In this design, three bards crouch clinging to the side of a "cliff" (according to the letterpress text). The body of the foremost bard faces right and leans backward, but he turns his head to look forward and down to the left. His right leg is bent and drawn up and his right foot rests not on the cliff but on a giant cord or rope the bards are weaving (see "And weave with bloody hands the tissue of [King Edward's] line" in the letterpress text). His right arm is extended straight out to the right, at an angle between horizontal and 135 degrees, though it is partially hidden by the text box. His right hand grasps the rope. His left lower arm and hand are visible to the right of the text box in a similar position. The color of both hands suggests that they may be wet with blood. He may be seated on, or partially supported by, the stony cliff visible beneath his body. He wears a long gown with folds of fabric that drape his lower body. His long hair and beard are swept up to the right; additional strands of his hair blow down to the left in the wind. Lines extending from his shoulder and knee, as well as the rock below, also suggest wind or perhaps folds of his garment blowing in the wind. The head and arms of the Bard in the middle are visible just above and to the right of the foremost bard. The second bard's head also faces forward and down to the left. His arms, clad in sleeves, are extended up at 135 degrees and his one visible hand, the right, grasps the rope. The color of this hand suggests blood as well. This bard has short curly hair and a curly beard. The head of the bard in the rear faces forward and down to the left as well. His hair and beard are long and blow up to the right. Wash at the left side of the design suggests a cloudy, perhaps stormy sky. Lines and streaks running diagonally from top right to bottom left suggest wind.

component.illusobjdesc: Three bards crouch clinging to the side of a "cliff" (according to the letterpress text). The body of the foremost bard faces right and leans backward, but he turns his head to look forward and down to the left. His right leg is bent and drawn up and his right foot rests not on the cliff but on a giant cord or rope the bards are weaving (see "And weave with bloody hands the tissue of [King Edward's] line" in the letterpress text). His right arm is extended straight out to the right, at an angle between horizontal and 135 degrees, though it is partially hidden by the text box. His right hand grasps the rope. His left lower arm and hand are visible to the right of the text box in a similar position. The color of both hands suggests that they may be wet with blood. He may be seated on, or partially supported by, the stony cliff visible beneath his body. He wears a long gown with folds of fabric that drape his lower body. His long hair and beard are swept up to the right; additional strands of his hair blow down to the left in the wind. Lines extending from his shoulder and knee, as well as the rock below, also suggest wind or perhaps folds of his garment blowing in the wind. The head and arms of the Bard in the middle are visible just above and to the right of the foremost bard. The second bard's head also faces forward and down to the left. His arms, clad in sleeves, are extended up at 135 degrees and his one visible hand, the right, grasps the rope. The color of this hand suggests blood as well. This bard has short curly hair and a curly beard. The head of the bard in the rear faces forward and down to the left as well. His hair and beard are long and blow up to the right.

The bards cling to the side of a cliff, according to the text. However, the two leftmost bards clearly hold the giant and perhaps bloody rope they are weaving. These recall the strings of the harp or lyre in Object 55 and are a continuation of them.
The figures are positioned on the side of a cliff. A stony outcrop from the cliff is visible below the frontmost bard.
Wash at the left side of the design suggests a cloudy, perhaps stormy sky. Lines and streaks running diagonally from top right to bottom left suggest wind.

desc.objtitle: The Bard: Page 7, Object 59 (Butlin 335.59)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 11 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The giant hovering figure of Edward the Third, bent on avenging his father, fills much of this design. His head and torso face forward and slightly to the right; his body bends backwards at the waist and extends, roughly horizontally, away from the viewer and slightly left. Of his lower body only his right leg, bent slightly upward, is clearly visible. His slightly bent left arm is raised at about 45 degrees, and he makes a pointing gesture with his left index finger. His slightly bent right arm, which is partly obscured by the text box, is raised at 135 degrees. He brandishes a scourge in his upraised right hand. The weapon has three thongs with star-like spikes at their ends. He wears a crown on his head, and has short hair and a short beard that stands on end in spiky points. His eyes are cast down and he seems to be frowning. His upper body is nude, but his lower body seems to be wrapped in a transparent garment that extends past his right leg. The bent figure of Sorrow appears in the lower left corner of the design. She walks facing right, bent over heavily at the waist. Her arms are held forward and bent up at the elbow, and she buries her lowered face in her hands. Her weight rests on her left leg and her right leg is extended backward, slightly bent, with right foot on tiptoe. She wears a long gown below which her bare feet are visible. Her hair is drawn back into a bun. Amazement and Flight personified flee rightward in the lower quadrant of the design. Their bodies are nearly horizontal. Flight's body is foremost. His left leg is bent and drawn up sharply beneath his body; his left foot is on tiptoe. His bent right leg is extended behind him. Both arms are stretched out straight in front of his lowered head. His upper body is nude but he wears tights on his lower body. Thin lines delineate shapes suggesting clouds of dust, perhaps caused by his rapid movement, to the right of his left foot. Amazement, behind him and partly hidden by his body, cranes her head forward and up to the left to look at the menacing figure of Edward the Third above. Her mouth is open wide and her long hair streams to the left. She wears a long gown that extends behind her. The small figure of Solitude stands in the lower left corner of the design, facing forward. The figure's arms are down by his or her side, and seem to be clasped in front. Other features of the figure's face, hair, and clothing are difficult to discern. Rolling hills constitute the landscape at the bottom of the design. Sorrow, Amazement, and Flight move rightward over a gentle rise. The ground here seems to be dirt or sand. Solitude stands in a low area between distant hills. The lowering sky in which Edward the Third hovers is heavy with clouds. Penciled lines around the avenging king's figure, particularly below his chest, add to the effect, or may indicate movement. The cloud cover breaks most noticeably in the upper left corner of the design, where an ominous light hints at a sunset or sunrise.

component.illusobjdesc: The giant hovering figure of Edward the Third, bent on avenging his father, fills much of this design. His head and torso face forward and slightly to the right; his body bends backwards at the waist and extends, roughly horizontally, away from the viewer and slightly left. Of his lower body only his right leg, bent slightly upward, is clearly visible. His slightly bent left arm is raised at about 45 degrees, and he makes a pointing gesture with his left index finger. His slightly bent right arm, which is partly obscured by the text box, is raised at 135 degrees. He brandishes a scourge in his upraised right hand. The weapon has three thongs with star-like spikes at their ends. He wears a crown on his head, and has short hair and a short beard that stands on end in spiky points. His eyes are cast down and he seems to be frowning. His upper body is nude, but his lower body seems to be wrapped in a transparent garment that extends past his right leg.

The bent figure of Sorrow appears in the lower left corner of the design. She walks facing right, bent over heavily at the waist. Her arms are held forward and bent up at the elbow, and she buries her lowered face in her hands. Her weight rests on her left leg and her right leg is extended backward, slightly bent, with right foot on tiptoe. She wears a long gown below which her bare feet are visible. Her hair is drawn back into a bun.

Amazement and Flight personified flee rightward in the lower quadrant of the design. Their bodies are nearly horizontal. Flight's body is foremost. His left leg is bent and drawn up sharply beneath his body; his left foot is on tiptoe. His bent right leg is extended behind him. Both arms are stretched out straight in front of his lowered head. His upper body is nude but he wears tights on his lower body. Thin lines delineate shapes suggesting clouds of dust, perhaps caused by his rapid movement, to the right of his left foot. Amazement, behind him and partly hidden by his body, cranes her head forward and up to the left to look at the menacing figure of Edward the Third above. Her mouth is open wide and her long hair streams to the left. She wears a long gown that extends behind her. Between this garment and the figure of Flight in front of her, Amazement's limbs are difficult to discern, but at least her right arm seems to be extended in front of her, and one foot, extended behind her, may be just visible beneath the hem of her gown.

The small figure of Solitude stands in the lower left corner of the design, facing forward. The figure's arms are down by his or her side, and seem to be clasped in front. Other features of the figure's face, hair, and clothing are difficult to discern.

Rolling hills constitute the landscape at the bottom of the design. Sorrow, Amazement, and Flight move rightward over a gentle rise. The ground here seems to be dirt or sand. Solitude stands in a low area between distant hills.

The lowering sky in which Edward the Third hovers is heavy with clouds. Penciled lines around the avenging king's figure, particularly below his chest, add to the effect, or may indicate movement. The cloud cover breaks most noticeably in the upper left corner of the design, where an ominous light hints at a sunrise or sunset.

desc.objtitle: The Bard: Page 8, Object 60 (Butlin 335.60)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 13 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The personified figure of Whirlwind reclines on a bed made of swirling gusts of wind near the bottom of the design. The bed floats on the surface of the sea. Whirlwind lies facing up and slightly forward, with his arms crossed over his chest. His legs appear to be bent. A robe, cloak, or blanket swathes his body, hiding his hands and his legs below the knee. A large horn curls around his right forearm. Whirlwind's eyes are closed in sleep. What seems to be the limb (an arm or leg) of a previous victim emerges from between his closed lips. His short, spirally curly hair springs in all directions, as does the curly hair of his beard and eyebrows. Whirlwind's bed floats on a calm sea of gentle waves stretching to the horizon in the distance. Dark, heavy clouds fill much of the sky in the top half of the design, especially to the left side of the text box. The sun rises over the horizon at the right side of the design. It sends out beams of light that fill the sky where it is not obscured by cloud. A tiny sailing ship appears to the right of the text box, between the box and the rising sun. This ship in full sail represents the "gilded vessel" in "gallant trim" mentioned in the letterpress text.

component.illusobjdesc: The personified figure of Whirlwind reclines on a bed made of swirling gusts of wind near the bottom of this design. The bed floats on the surface of the sea. Whirlwind lies facing up and slightly forward, with his arms crossed over his chest. His legs appear to be bent. A robe, cloak, or blanket swathes his body, hiding his hands and his legs below the knee. A large horn curls around his right forearm. Whirlwind's eyes are closed in sleep. What seems to be the limb (an arm or leg) of a previous victim emerges from between his closed lips. His short, spirally curly hair springs in all directions, as does the curly hair of his beard and eyebrows.
Whirlwind's bed floats on a calm sea of gentle waves stretching to the horizon in the distance.

A tiny sailing ship appears to the right of the text box, between the box and the rising sun. This ship in full sail represents the "gilded vessel" in "gallant trim" mentioned in the letterpress text.
The sun rises over the water at the right side of the design. It sends out beams of light that fill the sky where it is not obscured by cloud.
Dark, heavy clouds fill much of the sky in the top half of the design, especially to the left side of the text box.

desc.objtitle: The Bard: Page 9, Object 61 (Butlin 335.61)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 2 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The starving King Richard the Second sits on his throne near the middle of the design.
