He faces forward but leans to the right; his left elbow rests on the arm of his throne. His bent left leg is forward, with his left foot resting on the ground beneath his seat, while his bent right leg is down, lower leg extended away. His right arm is hidden beneath his garments, but seems to be bent across his chest with right hand resting near his left shoulder. The king wears a robe that envelops his limbs almost entirely, although his left foot appears beneath its hem, clad in a shoe. A crown sits atop his head, over short, raggedly curly hair. His mouth is open and his eyes are raised; his cheeks are drawn and wan. Although they almost appear to be accidental, the smudges or blotches covering his clothing suggest his dirty, possibly diseased, condition. The figure of Thirst personified sits in the lower right corner of the design, facing forward. Both her(?) legs are bent; her right knee is drawn up while her left leg lies on the ground. Her bony left foot emerges from beneath her skirts. Her partly hidden right arm is bent across her lap and may be resting against her right leg. With the fingers of her right hand she grasps the stem of a goblet, upside down to signal its emptiness. She bends her head back and twists it to the left to look up at Richard II in his throne. Her mouth is slightly open. Her wrinkled face and neck suggest age and/or dehydration. Her hair is drawn up into an unkempt coiffure. She wears a shirt, through which her ribs are visible, and a skirt. Famine, personified as an old man, sits facing right in the lower left corner of the design. His right leg is bent and may be crossed or folded beneath his body. His right arm is extended down and rests against his right knee. With his right index finger he points to three maddeningly bread-like stones on the ground in front of the king's throne. The other knuckles of Famine's right hand rest on the ground. Famine is balding but has a long white beard and long hair growing from the back of his head. His mouth may be open. He wears a robe or tunic that may be belted at the waist and that hides his lower body. Additional fabric, perhaps a cloak, falls from his right shoulder to puddle on the ground behind him. The king and his spectre-like companions sit inside the stone walls of Pontefract Castle. Mounted knights arrayed in opposing lines charge each other near the top of the design. These forces represent the battles of the Wars of the Roses. The top quarter of the design is dark with dust the knights have raised, or with storm, or perhaps due to the time of day. A boar appears in the upper right corner of the design, facing forward and to the right. It sits with its head lowered near to the ground, and "wallows" in clouds of dust and "infant gore" (see the letterpress text). The boar is the emblem of Richard the Third.

component.illusobjdesc: The starving King Richard the Second sits on his throne near the middle of the design. He faces forward but leans to the right; his left elbow rests on the arm of his throne. The sides of the throne are decorated with the outlines of Gothic arches. His bent left leg is forward, with his left foot resting on the ground beneath his seat, while his bent right leg is down, lower leg extended away. Alternatively his lower right leg may be resting on a footstool visible before or inside his throne on the left. The top of his right foot may be visible to the right of his right knee. He twists slightly to the left at the waist. His right arm is hidden beneath his garments, but seems to be bent across his chest with right hand resting near his left shoulder. The king wears a robe that envelops his limbs almost entirely, although his left foot appears beneath its hem, clad in a shoe. A crown sits atop his head, over short, raggedly curly hair. His mouth is open and his eyes are raised; his cheeks are drawn and wan. Although they appear to be accidental, smudges or blotches covering his clothing hint at his dirty, perhaps diseased, condition.

The figure of Thirst personified sits in the lower right corner of the design, facing forward. This figure seems to be a woman, although her bony chest and limbs and her drawn face seem purposefully more androgynous than feminine. Both her legs are bent; her right knee is drawn up while her left leg lies on the ground. Her bony left foot emerges from beneath her skirts. Her partly hidden right arm is bent across her lap and may be resting against her right leg. With the fingers of her right hand she grasps the stem of a goblet, upside down to signal its emptiness. Her upper left arm is visible by her side, and her left shoulder is raised as though she rests her weight against this arm. She bends her head back and twists it to the left to look up at Richard II in his throne. Her mouth is slightly open. Her wrinkled face and neck suggest age and/or dehydration. Her hair is drawn up into an unkempt coiffure. She wears a shirt, through which her ribs are visible, and a skirt.

Famine, personified as an old man, sits facing right in the lower left corner of the design. His right leg is bent and may be crossed or folded beneath his body. His right arm is extended down and rests against his right knee. With his right index finger he points to three maddeningly bread-like stones on the ground in front of the king's throne. The other knuckles of Famine's right hand rest on the ground. Famine is balding but has a long white beard and long hair growing from the back of his head. His mouth may be open. He wears a robe or tunic that may be belted at the waist and that hides his lower body. Additional fabric, perhaps a cloak, falls from his right shoulder to puddle on the ground behind him.
The king and his spectre-like companions sit inside the stone walls of Pontefract Castle. The left side of the room is in shadow, and Famine casts a shadow on the ground below him.

Mounted knights arrayed in opposing lines charge each other near the top of the design. These forces represent the battles of the Wars of the Roses. On the left the head, forelegs, and body of the foremost horse is clearly visible, lunging rightward. An armored knight astride this horse holds a shield facing forward and a spear lowered on the far side of the horse's head. The head and foreleg of a second horse is visible behind and to the right of this foremost horse and knight. At least three other knights' helmeted heads are visible to the left and right of the foremost knight's head. On the right, the foremost horse leaps left with head lowered and front leg extended. This horse is partly hidden behind a boar near the right side of the design. The knight astride this horse leans forward over its neck and bears a lowered spear. Two more horses' heads and two more lowered spears appear to the left of the foremost horse's head. There may be two more knights partially visible to the right of the foremost knight's body. Clouds of dust kicked up by the horses' hooves appear beneath the foremost horse on each side. The top quarter of the design is dark with dust, storm, or the time of day.

A boar appears in the upper right corner of the design, facing forward and to the right. It sits with its head lowered near to the ground, and "wallows" in clouds of dust and "infant gore" (see the letterpress text). The boar is the emblem of Richard the Third.

desc.objtitle: The Bard: Page 10, Object 62 (Butlin 335.62)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of the space between lines 4 and 5 of the letterpress text to indicate the lines or passages illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: King Edward the First kneels in the lower right corner of the design. He supports his queen, Eleanor of Castile, with his lowered right arm; his right hand is visible, palm forward, below her head. His left arm is bent upward, and his left elbow seems to be propped on his knee or leg. He rests his forehead in his raised left hand, bending low over his queen's upturned face. His cloak, clasped over his right shoulder with a button or similar ornament, drapes his figure so completely that his lower body is impossible to distinguish. He wears a crown and a large plume over his helmet and/or the chain mail that cloaks his head and neck. His mouth may be open slightly. The queen, dying, lies supine along the ground at the bottom of the design. Her upper body is propped against and supported by the kneeling king. Her slightly bent legs extend together to the left. Her bent left arm hangs at her side; her left hand lies palm up on the ground. Her head sags backward and her long hair drapes over her left shoulder. Her eyes are closed. She wears a crown and a long gown with a high waist or belt. Her left foot, visible beneath her gown, may be bare or may be clad in a slim shoe. The rears of the royals' two horses are visible to the left of the king. Both horses rest on the ground with their tails to the left. Both wear saddles. Images of the heads of the three bards appear in the clouds above the king and queen. The heads are arranged in a line facing down. The two foremost bards hold their mouths open; the text box hides the lower half of the third bard's face. The long hair and beards of all three bards stand on end, merging with the surrounding clouds that fill much of the top half of the design. Coloring makes their hair look flame-like. Dark shadows lurk at the clouds' edges, particularly in the upper left corner of the design, just to the left of the text box, and along the right side of the design. Shadow also fills some of the lower left corner of the design. The sky visible above and to the left of the horses suggests sunrise or sunset. Grass covers the ground on which the queen lies. A leafy tree branch appears to the left of the text box.

component.illusobjdesc: King Edward kneels in the lower right corner of the design. He supports his queen, Eleanor, with his lowered right arm; his right hand is visible, palm forward, below her head. His left arm is bent upward, and his left elbow seems to be propped on his knee or leg. He rests his forehead in his raised left hand, bending low over his queen's upturned face. His cloak, clasped over his right shoulder with a button or similar ornament, drapes his figure so completely that his lower body is impossible to distinguish. He wears a crown and a large plume over his helmet and/or the chain mail that cloaks his head and neck. His mouth may be open slightly.

The dying queen, Eleanor of Castile, lies supine along the ground at the bottom of the design. Her upper body is propped against and supported by the kneeling king. Her slightly bent legs extend together to the left. Her bent left arm hangs at her side; her left hand lies palm up on the ground. Her head sags backward and her long hair drapes over her left shoulder. Her eyes are closed. She wears a crown and a long gown with a high waist or belt. Her left foot, visible beneath her gown, may be bare or may be clad in a slim shoe.
The rears of the royals' two horses are visible to the left of the king. Both horses rest on the ground with their tails to the left. Both wear saddles.

Images of the heads of the three bards appear in the clouds above the king and queen. The heads are arranged in a line facing down. The two foremost bards hold their mouths open; the text box hides the lower half of the third Bard's face. The long hair and beards of all three bards stand on end, merging with the surrounding clouds. Coloring makes their hair look flame-like.

Clouds fill much of the top half of the design. Dark shadows lurk at the clouds' edges, particularly in the upper left corner of the design, just to the left of the text box, and along the right side of the design. Shadow also fills some of the lower left corner of the design. The sky visible above and to the left of the horses suggests sunrise or sunset.
Grass covers the ground on which the queen lies.
A leafy tree branch appears to the left of the text box.

desc.objtitle: The Bard: Page 11, Object 63 (Butlin 335.63)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 3 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: At the top of this design appears the head and shoulders of Queen "Elizabeth" (see Blake's text, Object 52), facing forward though her head is turned slightly to the right. Her curly hair is loose beneath a crown of golden oak leaves. She wears a large ruff and a gown or robe. Beams of light emit from her head and fill the top half of the design, gilding the edges of the clouds at the right. The armored head and upper body of a "Baron bold" (see the letterpress text) appears to the left of the text box, facing forward and slightly to the right. He wears a helmet and body armor, and raises his bent right arm across his torso. His raised right hand is partially hidden behind the text box. Feathered plumes surmount his helmet and cascade down behind his neck and shoulders. He has a beard and mustache. The head of a second baron, hidden below the eyes, appears above and behind the first. This baron faces left and wears a helmet with a large plume. The heads and upper bodies of Past, Present, and Future appear below the text box (see also Object 54). All three wear gowns or similar garments. Present, on the far left, is seen from behind looking away from the viewer. His long hair is blown to the right. Past, in the middle, looks forward. He has a long beard and long white hair, suggesting his age. Future, on the right, looks forward but turns his head slightly to the left. He has short curly hair and a curly beard. His bent right arm is raised horizontally across his torso, and his right hand rests on the strings of a lyre visible at the right. Present and Future seem much younger in age. Clouds fill the spaces around the edges of the bottom two-thirds of the design, and are especially noticeable to the right of the text box. A single star appears over Future's head.

component.illusobjdesc: At the top of this design appears the head and shoulders of Queen "Elizabeth" (see Blake's text, Object 52), facing forward though her head is turned slightly to the right. Her curly hair is loose beneath a crown of golden oak leaves. She wears a large ruff and a gown or robe. Beams of light emit from her head and fill the top half of the design, gilding the edges of the clouds at the right.

The armored head and upper body of a "Baron bold" (see the letterpress text) appears to the left of the text box, facing forward and slightly to the right. He wears a helmet and body armor, and raises his bent right arm across his torso. His raised right hand is partially hidden behind the text box. Feathered plumes surmount his helmet and cascade down behind his neck and shoulders. He has a beard and mustache. The head of a second baron, hidden below the eyes, appears above and behind the first. This baron faces left and wears a helmet with a large plume.

The heads and upper bodies of Past, Present, and Future appear below the text box (see also Object 54). All three wear gowns or similar garments. Present, on the far left, is seen from behind looking away from the viewer. His long hair is blown to the right. Past, in the middle, looks forward. He has a long beard and long white hair, suggesting his age. Future, on the right, looks forward but turns his head slightly to the left. He has short curly hair and a curly beard. His bent right arm is raised horizontally across his torso, and his right hand rests on the strings of a lyre visible at the right. Present and Future seem much younger in age.
Clouds fill the spaces around the edges of the bottom two-thirds of the design, and are especially noticeable to the right of the text box. A single star appears over Future's head.

desc.objtitle: The Bard: Page 12, Object 64 (Butlin 335.64)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 5 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The poet Edmund "Spenser" (see Blake's text, Object 52) sits at the center of the design, to the left of (and partially hidden by) the text box. He may be seated on the steps that are visible to the right. He faces forward, but bends his head down and to the left. His legs are bent: his right foot is forward and his left foot drawn back. He may be leaning forward slightly. His right arm, bent at the elbow, rests on his right leg. His left hand, palm up, is visible just to the left of the text box and may rest against his right knee. A tiny fairy figure stands in Spenser's open left palm, facing forward. Spenser is dressed in a robe or gown, with extra fabric lying over his lap and draping his legs. Two figures, personifying Truth and Fiction, stand at the top of the stairs on the right. On the left, Truth is a young woman facing forward and stepping forward with her left foot, which is just visible beneath the long robe or gown she wears. Her hair is long and loose. Her eyes are lowered or closed. She holds an open book before her. Fiction stands or walks to the right in a slightly contrapposto position, with his weight resting on his left leg and his right leg bent backwards. He clasps a partially unrolled scroll with both hands. He wears a spiked ruff or collar. He is nude or wears tights. His eyes are raised and he has short curly hair and a similar beard. Two tiny figures, reminiscent of fairies or cherubs, hover over the heads of Truth and Fiction. One plays a pipe and the other plays a horn. In the lower left corner, three figures enact a scene from "Sir Guyon in the cave of Mammon," one of Spenser's poems. Surrounding clouds create a cave-like space. Sir Guyon stands in the middle, facing left and holding a sword. He is dressed in armor and wears a helmet with a large plume. Mammon, an old man, stands on the left, facing forward but turning his head to the right to look at the knight. With his slightly bent right arm, raised at 45 degrees, he points down at a mass of golden coins heaped on the floor below. More coins lie scattered on the ground before Mammon's feet. He has long hair and a long beard and wears a gown. A demon or devil walks to the left at the right side of the group. He strides forward with his right leg; his left is bent and extended backward, with left foot on tiptoe. Both arms are down by his side but bent forward at the elbow. Two horns spiral backwards from above his forehead. He has two large batlike wings. Above this grouping, three figures enact "Redcrosse in the cave of Despair." Clouds form a shadowy cave-like space as the setting for this scene. Despair, an old man, sits on the left. He bends forward and reaches his bent right arm up at 135 degrees; in his upraised right hand he holds a dagger pointed back at himself. His head is bent back and he may be looking up at Redcrosse, who stands to the right and walks left. Redcrosse's left arm is forward and bent up; he buries his face in his upraised left hand. He is nude and has short hair. A third figure lies dead in front of Redcrosse and Despair, with a dagger buried in his bloody chest. Clouds create "C" shapes that fills much of the design and connects the disparate scenes of tiny figures. The sky upper left is dark.

component.illusobjdesc: The poet Edmund "Spenser" (see Blake's text, Object 52) sits at the center of the design, to the left of (and partially hidden by) the text box. He may be seated on the steps that are visible to the right. He faces forward, but bends his head down and to the left. His legs are bent: his right foot is forward and his left foot drawn back. He may be leaning forward slightly. His right arm, bent at the elbow, rests on his right leg. He holds his right hand up, with his palm vertical and facing right. His left hand, palm up, is visible just to the left of the text box and may rest against his right knee. A tiny fairy figure stands in Spenser's open left palm, facing forward with right leg extended forward and left leg bent backwards. This figure turns his head up to the right, as if looking at the poet. The figure's mouth is open. His arms are extended and raised at 45 degrees, with palms down. He may be nude or wearing tights. Spenser himself is dressed in a robe or gown, with extra fabric lying over his lap. This fabric hangs to the left of his right knee and drapes either side of his left leg. Both Spenser and the tiny figure have short curly hair.
A set of three stairs or steps appears just below and to the right of the text box.

Two figures, personifying Truth and Fiction, stand at the top of the stairs on the right. On the left, Truth is a young woman facing forward and stepping forward with her left foot, which is just visible beneath the long robe or gown she wears. Her arms, at her sides, are bent forward and her hands support the book she holds before her. Her hair is long and loose. Her eyes are lowered or closed. Fiction stands or walks to the right in a slightly contrapposto position, with his weight resting on his left leg and his right leg bent backwards. His right foot may be on tiptoe. His upper body is twisted slightly to the right, but his head is turned slightly to the left. His left arm is extended down by his side; his right forearm is visible bent across his body. With both hands he clasps a partially unrolled scroll. He wears a spiky collar or ruff. He is nude or wears tights. His eyes are raised and he has short curly hair and a similar beard.

Two tiny figures, reminiscent of fairies or cherubs, hover over the heads of Truth and Fiction. The figure on the right seems to be female and faces right and down. Her right arm is down and bent forward and she holds a pipe to her mouth; her left hand is visible on the pipe above her right. She wears a long gown that hides her legs and feet, which extend to the left. Her hair seems to be drawn back into a bun. The second figure is nude and faces away. This figure may be male or female. Its left leg is bent and drawn up; its right leg is extended to the left. Its head is turned to the right, and it plays a flute. Its right arm is bent and raised at roughly 45 degrees and it supports the instrument with this hand. Its left hand is visible on the flute as well. It may have short hair, or its hair may be in a bun.

In the lower left corner, three figures enact a scene from "Sir Guyon in the cave of Mammon," one of Spenser's poems. Surrounding clouds create a cave-like space. Sir Guyon stands in the middle, facing left. His weight rests on his left leg and his right is extended backwards, with right foot on tiptoe. His left arm is down by his side, and he holds a sword in his left hand. He wears a full suit of armor and a helmet with a large plume. Mammon, an old man, stands on the left, facing forward but turning his lowered head to the right to look at the knight. His left arm is down by his side. With his slightly bent right arm, raised at 45 degrees, Mammon points down at a mass of golden coins heaped on the floor below. More coins lie scattered on the ground before Mammon's feet. Mammon is balding, but has long hair and a long beard. His mouth is open slightly. One foot, perhaps clad in a shoe, is visible beneath the hem of the long gown he wears. A demon or devil walks to the left at the right side of the group. His body is turned slightly forward. He strides forward with his right leg; his left is bent and extended backward, with left foot on tiptoe. Both arms are down by his side but bent forward at the elbow. He holds his hands up, palms out. The demon seems to be nude. Two horns spiral backwards from above his forehead. He has two large batlike wings.

Three figures to the left of Spenser enact the poet's "Redcrosse in the cave of Despair." Clouds form a shadowy cave-like space as the setting for this scene. Despair, an old man, sits on the left. His bent legs extend to the right over a rocklike shape that merges with the clouds surrounding the figures. He bends forward and reaches his bent right arm up at 135 degrees; in his upraised right hand he holds a dagger pointed back at himself. He may be balding on the top of his head, but he has long hair that falls to his shoulders. Cloth partially covers his back and drapes over his hips. His head is bent back and he may be looking up at Redcrosse, who stands to the right and walks left. Redcrosse's left arm is forward and bent up; he buries his face in his upraised left hand. He is nude and has short hair. A third figure lies dead in front of Redcrosse and Despair. Nude, this figure's horizontal body rests facing up along the ground formed by rocklike clouds. His leg is bent upward and his arm is resting by his side. His head is bent back and his long hair falls to the ground. A dagger has been plunged into his bloody chest.
Clouds create "C" shapes that fills much of the design and connects the disparate scenes of tiny figures together. The sky upper left is dark.

desc.objtitle: The Bard: Page 13, Object 65 (Butlin 335.65)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 6 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The bard is shown upside down in mid-dive as he casts himself into the sea. His torso faces right but he bends at the waist so that his slightly bent leg curves backwards towards the left. His head is bent back as well and he looks down. His left arm is extended vertically down over his head, and his left hand rests on the strings of his enormous harp. He may be playing the instrument as he descends. The tip of the harp has already broken the surface of the water below. The Bard's long hair and beard stream behind him in the wind from his fall. He wears a transparent gown that ripples along his form, revealing the lines of his body. A rough sea awaits the bard at the bottom of the design. One large white-capped wave rises towards his falling figure. The rocky face of a cliff rises along the right side of the design. Wash surrounding the text box and the figure of the Bard indicates a cloud-filled sky in the background.

component.illusobjdesc: The Bard is shown upside down in mid-dive as he casts himself into the sea. His torso faces right but he bends at the waist so that his slightly bent leg curves backwards towards the left. His head is bent back as well and he looks down. His left arm is extended vertically down over his head, and his left hand rests on the strings of his enormous harp. He may be playing the instrument as he descends. The tip of the harp has already broken the surface of the water below. The Bard's long hair and beard stream behind him in the wind from his fall. He wears a transparent gown that ripples along his form, revealing the lines of his body.
A rough sea awaits the Bard at the bottom of the design. One large white-capped wave rises towards his falling figure.
The rocky face of a cliff rises along the right side of the design.
Wash surrounding the text box and the figure of the Bard indicates a cloud-filled sky in the background.

desc.objtitle: The Bard; Page 14: Blank Page Bearing List of Titles, Object 66 (Butlin 335.66)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A goatherd is seated at the bottom of the design, facing left. His right leg is extended out along the ground to the left; his left leg is crossed over the right at the knee. His bent left arm is by his side and his left hand rests on the ground. He holds a musical pipe loosely in this hand. He bends his head, a melancholy expression on his face. He wears a tunic over a shirt and knee breeches with a button at the left knee. His hair is short and slightly curly. A large tree is rooted in the lower left corner and grows up the left side of the design. A thick limb branches away near the top of the design and arches to the right, over the goatherd. Near the right side of the design it becomes smaller branches that hang down and bear sparse leaves. This may be a willow. Two goats stand near the goatherd. One goat, just beyond his legs, grazes facing left with head lowered to the grass. The head of the other goat appears to the right of the nearby tree, facing right with mouth slightly open. Both goats have horns and shaggy coats. Dark, craggy mountains cross the design in the background. A similar stone or boulder may provide some support for the back of the seated goatherd. Grass covers the ground on which the goatherd sits and his goats graze. A leafy branch or palm frond lies along the ground just below the goatherd, in the lower right corner of the design. Similar vegetation may appear across the bottom of the design.

component.illusobjdesc: A goatherd is seated at the bottom of the design, facing left. His right leg is extended out along the ground to the left; his left leg is crossed over the right at the knee. His bent left arm is by his side and his left hand rests on the ground. He holds a pipe loosely in this hand. He bends his head, a melancholy expression on his face. He wears a tunic over a shirt and knee breeches with a button at the left knee. His hair is short and slightly curly.

A large tree is rooted in the lower left corner and grows up the left side of the design. A thick limb branches away near the top of the design and arches to the right, over the goatherd. Near the right side of the design it becomes smaller branches that hang down and bear sparse leaves. This may be a willow. The trunk, or perhaps another limb, continues up beyond the top edge of the design.

Two goats stand near the goatherd. One goat, just beyond his legs, grazes facing left with head lowered to the grass. The head of the other goat appears to the right of the nearby tree, facing right with mouth slightly open. Both goats have horns and shaggy coats.
Dark, craggy mountains cross the design in the background. A similar stone or boulder may provide some support for the back of the seated goatherd.

Grass covers the ground on which the goatherd sits and his goats graze. A leafy branch or palm frond lies along the ground just below the goatherd, in the lower right corner of the design. Similar vegetation may appear across the bottom of the design.

lg.l: The Fatal Sisters
1. The Three Fatal Sisters
2. A Muse
3. Sigtryg with the Silken beard

4. "Persons of Horseback riding full speed towardLines 5-6 are quoted, with minor variations and "on" in the letterpress text changed to "of" (in error?) in line 5, from page [109] of the letterpress text (Object 69).
a hill & seeming to Enter into it"
5. "Iron sleet of arrowy showerLines 7-8 are quoted, with one minor variation in spelling, from page [111] of the letterpress text (Object 71).
Hurtles in the darkend air"
6. "Shafts for shuttle dipd in goreLines 9-10 are quoted, with minor variations, from page 112 of the letterpress text (Object 72).
Shoot the trembling chords along"
7. "We the reins to Slaughter give"The line is quoted from page 113 of the letterpress text (Object 73).
8. The Fatal Sisters riding thro the Battle. they
are calld in Some Northern poems
"Choosers of the Slain."The words within quotation marks do not appear in the letterpress text of this poem.
9"Hurry Hurry to the field"The line is quoted, with minor variations, from page 115 of the letterpress text (Object 75).
10. A Battle.

desc.objtitle: The Fatal Sisters; an Ode (From the Norse Tongue); Page 1: Title-Page, Object 67 (Butlin 335.67)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Three women, representing three of the "Fatal Sisters" (see the letterpress text and "The Three Fatal Sisters," Blake's text, Object 66), stand shoulder-to-shoulder across the design. These may be the three named in the letterpress text, Object 72: Mista, Sangrida, and Hilda. They face forward with solemn expressions, arms at their sides. The sister on the right holds hands with the middle sister. The middle sister may also clasp the hand of the sister on the left, but their hands are mostly hidden behind the text box. Each sister wears a turban, neckguard, and armored breastplate over a long-sleeved gown. The rightmost and leftmost sisters hold tall spears with their outside hands. The sister on the left steps forward with her left foot, which is just visible beneath the hem of her gown, while the middle and rightmost sisters step forward with their similarly visible right feet. Each foot is clad in a sandal. The ground on which the sisters walk seems to be covered with grass. The area of the design around and between the sisters is filled with shadow.

component.illusobjdesc: Three women, representing three of the "Fatal Sisters" (see the letterpress text and "The Three Fatal Sisters," Blake's text, Object 66), stand shoulder to shoulder across the design. These may be the three named in the letterpress text, Object 72: Mista, Sangrida, and Hilda. They face forward with solemn expressions, arms at their sides. The sister on the right holds hands with the middle sister. The middle sister may also clasp the hand of the sister on the left, but their hands are mostly hidden behind the text box. Each sister wears a turban, neckguard, and armored breastplate over a long-sleeved gown. The rightmost and leftmost sisters hold tall spears with their outside hands. The sister on the left steps forward with her left foot, which is just visible beneath the hem of her gown, while the middle and rightmost sisters step forward with their similarly visible right feet. Each foot is clad in a sandal.
The ground on which the sisters walk seems to be covered with grass.
The area of the design around and between the sisters is filled with shadow.

desc.objtitle: The Fatal Sisters; Page 2: Advertisement, Object 68 (Butlin 335.68)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A female figure fills this design. She is named a "Muse" in Blake's text on Object 66 (see the Textual Transcription, line 3). Seen from behind, she faces away and to the right. Her arms are not shown, but her large wings stretch from one side of the design to the other. Her left leg is extended down to the left and out towards the viewer. Her right leg is bent up. A diaphanous gown drapes her figure and floats behind her to the left. Her long curly hair flies leftward. Wash surrounding the winged figure suggests the sky at sunrise or sunset, or perhaps that she emits light.

component.illusobjdesc: A female figure fills this design. She is named a "Muse" in Blake's text on Object 66 (see the Textual Transcription, line 3). Seen from behind, she faces away and to the right. Her arms are not shown, but her large wings stretch from one side of the design to the other. Her left leg is extended down to the left and out towards the viewer. Her right leg is bent up. A diaphanous gown drapes her figure and floats behind her to the left. Her long curly hair flies leftward.
Wash surrounding the winged figure suggests the sky at sunrise or sunset, or perhaps that she emits light.

desc.objtitle: The Fatal Sisters; Page 3: Beginning of Preface, Object 69 (Butlin 335.69)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The giant figure of Sigtryg fills this design. He faces forward with legs spread: his bent left leg is slightly forward, while his bent right leg is extended backwards and his right foot is on tiptoe. He holds the haft of an enormous spear in his upraised right fist. The butt of the spear may rest on the ground by his right foot. His bent left arm is at his side and supports a huge shield. He wears a crown over long hair. His extremely long beard covers his entire torso. He is dressed in a suit of armor. Sigtryg stands on a small mound covered with grass. Wash surrounding his figure suggests the sky, perhaps with clouds.

component.illusobjdesc: The giant figure of Sigtryg fills this design. He faces forward with legs spread: his bent left leg is slightly forward, while his bent right leg is extended backwards and his right foot is on tiptoe. He holds the haft of an enormous spear in his upraised right fist. The butt of the spear may rest on the ground by his right foot. His bent left arm is at his side and supports a huge shield. He wears a crown over long hair. His extremely long beard covers his entire torso. He is dressed in a suit of armor.
Sigtryg stands on a small mound covered with grass.
Wash surrounding Sigtryg suggests the sky, perhaps with clouds.

desc.objtitle: The Fatal Sisters: Page 4, Object 70 (Butlin 335.70)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Two riders, probably female although not identifiable as such from the design, on horseback plunge away and to the right, apparently right into the face of a large hill or cliff. The rears of their horses appear below and to the left of the text box, with legs extended backwards far enough that the undersides of their hooves are visible. The animals' tails fly behind them. Both riders seem to be female, sitting astride like men but clad in red dresses. Saddles are just visible beneath their garments. The text panel hides most of the rider on the right, whose bare, bent right leg extends from below skirts that billow over the horse's haunches. This rider's right foot rests in a stirrup. The rider on the left is visible from behind, leaning or bending forward over her mount and wearing a dark bonnet or hat and a scarf over her shoulders. Both horses cast shadows on the hill below, but neither animal's body is visible past the midsection, as if horses and riders are disappearing into the cliff. The young male "native of Caithness" (see the letterpress text, Object 69) stands in the lower right corner of the design, his body language expressing stupefaction at the flight of the riders into the hill. He faces away and to the left, his head turned further to the left to watch the women. His mouth may be slightly open. Both arms are by his side, but bent forward at the elbow, and he holds his hands up with palms out and fingers spread. He stands with his legs spread in a wide stance, and may lean slightly to the right, away from the women. He has short curly hair, and is dressed in a tunic and cloak; the fabric of his cloak swirls to the right as if carried by the wind of sudden movement. He casts a small shadow on the ground near his right foot. The hill or cliff into which the riders plunge fills much of the design, rising from lower left to upper right. Its craggy surfaces suggest rock. The ground along the bottom of the design seems to be covered with grass. Wash in the upper left corner and across the top of the design suggests the sky, perhaps streaked with clouds.

component.illusobjdesc: Two riders, probably female but not identifiable as such from the design, on horseback plunge away and to the right, apparently right into the face of a large hill or cliff. The rears of their horses appear below and to the left of the text box, with legs extended backwards far enough that the undersides of their hooves are visible. The animals' tails fly behind them. The rider on the left is visible from behind, leaning or bending forward over her mount and wearing a dark bonnet or hat and a scarf over her shoulders. Both horses cast shadows on the hill below, but neither animal's body is visible past the middle, as if horses and riders are disappearing into the cliff.

The young male "native of Caithness" (see the letterpress text, Object 69) stands in the lower right corner of the design, his body language expressing stupefaction at the flight of the riders into the hill. He faces away and to the left, his head turned further to the left to watch the women. His mouth may be slightly open. Both arms are by his side, but bent forward at the elbow, and he holds his hands up with palms out and fingers spread. He stands with his legs spread in a wide stance, and may lean slightly to the right, away from the women. He has short curly hair, and is dressed in a tunic and a cloak; the fabric of his cloak swirls to the right as if carried by the wind of sudden movement. He casts a small shadow on the grass near his right foot.
The hill or cliff into which the riders plunge fills much of the design, rising from lower left to upper right. Its craggy surfaces suggest rock.
The ground along the bottom of the design seems to be covered with grass.
Wash in the upper left corner and across the top of the design suggests the sky, perhaps streaked with clouds.

desc.objtitle: The Fatal Sisters; Page 5: Beginning of Poem, Object 71 (Butlin 335.71)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 6 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Three Fatal Sisters sit shoulder to shoulder, facing left and bending forward slightly. These may be the three named in the letterpress text, Object 72: Mista, Sangrida, and Hilda. They weave giant lances or arrowed spears like threads on a "loom" (see the letterpress text). The foremost sister's bent left leg is extended so that her left foot rests on the floor at a distance from her seat. She raises her left arm at 135 degrees and holds one giant spear or arrow in her upraised left hand. This arm is hidden between wrist and shoulder by the text box. She bends her head back slightly and looks up at her hand. Her mouth is open slightly. Her hair is drawn back into a bun and she wears a belted gown. She may also wear a high-heeled shoe on her foot. The backs of her sisters are visible to the right, and they seem to wear belted gowns like the foremost sister. These two sisters' faces are hidden, but both grasp spears in their upraised left hands. Each sister makes a pointing gesture with her index finger along the shaft of the spear she holds. The middle sister's hair is braided and twisted into a bun. The rightmost sister's hair seems to be drawn into a bun-like coiffure. The three sisters are seated on a low object, perhaps a stone or bench, in the lower right corner of the design. A multitude of other spears fills the top and left side of the design.

component.illusobjdesc: Three Fatal Sisters sit shoulder to shoulder, facing left and slightly away, and bending forward. These may be the three named in the letterpress text, Object 72: Mista, Sangrida, and Hilda. They weave giant lances or arrowed spears like threads on a "loom" (see the letterpress text). The foremost sister's bent left leg is extended so that her left foot rests on the floor at a distance from her seat. She raises her left arm at 135 degrees and holds one giant spear or arrow in her upraised left hand. This arm is hidden between wrist and shoulder by the text box. She bends her head back slightly and looks up at her hand. Her mouth is open slightly. Her hair is drawn back into a bun and she wears a belted gown. She may also wear a high-heeled shoe on her foot. The backs of her sisters are visible to the right, and they seem to wear belted gowns like the foremost sister. These two sisters' faces are hidden, but both grasp spears in their upraised left hands. Each sister makes a pointing gesture with her index finger along the shaft of the spear she holds. The middle sister's hair is braided and twisted into a bun. The rightmost sister's hair seems to be drawn into a bun-like coiffure.

The three Fatal Sisters weave giant lances or arrowed spears like threads on a "loom" (see the letterpress text). They each hold the shaft of one such spear. A multitude of other spears fills the top and the left side of the design.
The three sisters are seated on a low object, perhaps a stone or bench, in the lower right corner of the design.

desc.objtitle: The Fatal Sisters: Page 6, Object 72 (Butlin 335.72)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 2 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The "grisly" work of weaving from the previous design continues here. The threads that form the warp at the left side of the design are made "of human entrails" (see the letterpress text). They are weighted with four human heads that hang upside down near the lower left corner of the design. All four heads face forward with closed eyes and open mouths. They are the heads of male "warrior[s]." Three Fatal Sisters, still shoulder to shoulder, here kneel facing left on a kind of shelf or step in the lower right corner of the design. These may be the three named in the letterpress text, Object 72: Mista, Sangrida, and Hilda. The foremost sister's left leg is bent and drawn up beneath her body; her left foot is on tiptoe. Her right leg is also bent, but her right foot is extended and rests on the chins of the human heads. The foremost sister leans forward and extends her left arm out at an angle between horizontal and 135 degrees. With this hand she grasps the handle of a large sword, pointing downward. This may be the sword "that once a monarch bore," which the text mentions should "[k]eep the tissue close and strong." It is wrapped with cloth or perhaps human entrails. The foremost sister extends her right arm backwards at 135 degrees; with this hand she may be holding one of the arrowed spears that is poised over the sisters' heads. This foremost sister wears a semi-transparent gown that drapes her form but reveals the position of her legs. She also seems to be wearing sandals. The text box hides her face below the eyes. Her long hair streams backwards over her shoulders and upraised right arm. Her sisters are visible above her and to the right, in positions that echo hers nearly exactly. Both of these sisters in the rear raise their left arms in front at 135 degrees. They may be helping to hold the warp threads. Both also extend their right arms behind them at 135 degrees, and probably each grasp one of the three spears poised above, which they may be throwing or are about to throw. The middle sister's loose curly hair is visible just above the head of the foremost sister. The rearmost sister's braid appears just below the spears. Shadow fills much of the empty spaces around the figures. A particularly dark area appears to the right of the three sisters. There may be the outlines of three severed(?) heads, two turned upward, in the lower right corner of the design.

component.illusobjdesc: Three Fatal Sisters, still shoulder to shoulder, here kneel facing left. These may be the three named in the letterpress text, Object 72: Mista, Sangrida, and Hilda. The foremost sister's left leg is bent and drawn up beneath her body; her left foot is on tiptoe. Her right leg is also bent, but her right foot is extended and rests on the chins of human heads that serve as gruesome weights for the loom's warp threads. The foremost sister leans forward and extends her left arm out at an angle between horizontal and 135 degrees. With this hand she grasps the handle of a large sword, pointing downward. This may be the sword "that once a monarch bore," which the text mentions should "[k]eep the tissue close and strong." It is wrapped with cloth or perhaps human entrails. The foremost sister extends her right arm backwards at 135 degrees; with this hand she may be holding one of the arrowed spears that is poised over the sisters' heads. This foremost sister wears a semi-transparent gown that drapes her form but reveals the position of her legs. She also seems to be wearing sandals. The text box hides her face below the eyes. Her long hair streams backwards over her shoulders and upraised right arm. Her sisters are visible above her and to the right, in positions that echo hers nearly exactly. Both of these sisters in the rear raise their left arms in front at 135 degrees. They may be helping to hold the warp threads. Both also extend their right arms behind them at 135 degrees, and probably each grasp one of the three spears poised above, which they may be throwing or about to throw. The middle sister's loose curly hair is visible just above the head of the foremost sister. The rearmost sister's braid appears just below the spears. Pencil lines above the sisters' hands indicate that Blake first drew the shaft(?) further to the right.

The threads that form the warp at the left side of the design are made "of human entrails" (see the letterpress text). They are weighted with four human heads that hang upside down near the lower left corner of the design. All four heads face forward with closed eyes and open mouths. They are the heads of male "warrior[s]." The leftmost head has a curly beard. This head and the one second from right have short curly hair. The other two heads have short straight hair.
The three sisters crouch on a kind of shelf or step in the lower right corner.
Shadow fills much of the empty spaces around the figures. A particularly dark area appears to the right of the three sisters.
There may be the outlines of three severed(?) heads, two facing up, in the lower right corner of the design.

desc.objtitle: The Fatal Sisters: Page 7, Object 73 (Butlin 335.73)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 10 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A warrior rides an enormous horse that leaps down to the right from the top left corner of the design, with tail and mane flying. The animal's bent forelegs are raised and extended forward; its rear legs disappear out of the design. The rider leans forward over his mount's neck. He wears armor, a helmet with a large plume, and a cloak or robe that billows in the wind of his movement. His sandaled right foot appears to the left of the text box, in a stirrup. A second horse's head is visible to the right of the first, also facing down to the right. The heads of two more soldiers are also visible just above this second horse's mane. They are both wearing helmets with plumes, and look forward and down to the right. A lance or spear carried by one of the riders emerges from between the horses' heads. There may be a second weapon to the right of the second horse's head. Casualties of battle lie across the bottom of the design. In the lower left corner, a man's head with closed eyes and open mouth faces down and to the left in the shadows. He has short curly hair and a curly beard. Surrounding shapes may represent clothing or fallen armor, or perhaps rocks. To the right another head is extended out toward the viewer, facing up with closed eyes. This head is likewise bearded and has slightly curly hair. The torso and arm of this man extend up and to the right before becoming indistinguishable. Sketched lines in the lower right corner of the design indicate other dead. The clearest head within this sketched mass faces up with closed eyes. The overall impression is one of jumbled bodies in the dirt. The leaping horses kick up clouds of dust that billow in the spaces between the animals and the casualties of battle below. Shadows fill the other spaces around the design, particularly in the lower left corner and upper right corner.

component.illusobjdesc: A warrior rides an enormous horse that leaps down to the right from the top left corner of the design, with tail and mane flying. The animal's bent forelegs are raised and extended forward; its rear legs disappear out of the design. The rider leans forward over his mount's neck. He wears armor, a helmet with a large plume, and a cloak or robe that billows in the wind of his movement. His sandaled right foot appears to the left of the text box, in a stirrup. A second horse's head is visible to the right of the first, also facing down to the right. The heads of two more soldiers are also visible just above this second horse's mane. They are both wearing helmets with plumes, and look forward and down to the right. A lance or spear carried by one of the riders emerges from between the horses' heads. There may be a second weapon to the right of the second horse's head. The warriors may be the Fatal Sisters, as in Object 74, although not identified as such in Blake's text on Object 66. Thus these may be the three named in the letterpress text, Object 72: Mista, Sangrida, and Hilda.

Casualties of battle lie across the bottom of the design. In the lower left corner, a man's head with closed eyes and open mouth faces down and to the left in the shadows. He has short curly hair and a curly beard. Surrounding shapes may represent clothing or fallen armor, or perhaps rocks. To the right another head is extended out toward the viewer, facing up with closed eyes. This head is likewise bearded and has slightly curly hair. The torso and arm of this man extend up and to the right before becoming indistinguishable. Sketched lines in the lower right corner of the design indicate other dead. The clearest head within this sketched mass faces up with closed eyes. The overall impression is one of jumbled bodies in the dirt.

The leaping horses kick up clouds of dust that billow in the spaces between the animals and the casualties of battle below. Shadows fill the other spaces around the design, particularly in the lower left corner and upper right corner.

desc.objtitle: The Fatal Sisters: Page 8, Object 74 (Butlin 335.74)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 5 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Three "Fatal Sisters" (see Blake's text, Object 66) ride horses over the carnage of a battlefield. These may be the three named in the letterpress text, Object 72: Mista, Sangrida, and Hilda. They face right but turn their heads slightly forward, so that their faces are visible in three-quarters profile. Each sister extends her straight right arm out horizontally, pointing with her right index finger. The foremost sister wears a suit of armor, including a helmet with a plume. A large shield hangs from her right shoulder, hiding much of her body, but her armored right foot is visible in a stirrup below the text box. Her horse faces right and steps forward with one bent and raised foreleg. The horse wears a saddle; reins slope from its mouth. Its tail and rear leg extend beyond the left edge of the design. Only the heads and right arms of the other two sisters are visible, to the right of the foremost sister. Both wear helmets with plumes. Similarly, the other two horses appear as increasingly indistinct lines suggesting the heads, chests, and perhaps forelegs of animals to the right of the foremost horse. Jumbled bodies, the casualties of battle, lie across the bottom of the design. One in the lower left corner with a crown on his head may be the "King" mentioned in the letterpress text who "shall bite the ground." This king indeed faces down with teeth bared and parted in a grimace. His elbows rest on the ground on either side of his head and his lower arms reach upward; his hands clutch at his long hair. He wears a shirt or some similar garment. His torso extends up and to the right before becoming indistinguishable in the crowd of dead and dying figures. An upside down head, facing out and slightly right, appears to the right of the king. This figure's mouth is open, showing teeth. His short hair falls to the ground. He may be wearing a shirt. A third head to the right faces up with open mouth and perhaps closed eyes. Sketchy lines above and to the right of both of these heads may indicate the bodies to which they belong, and/or the bodies of other dead. Another figure lies face down at the bottom of the design, with head towards the viewer and arms outstretched to either side. This figure's hair falls to the ground, obscuring his face. He wears a shirt. The area around the figures and the edges of the design are dark as with shadow or stormy sky.

component.illusobjdesc: Three "Fatal Sisters" (see Blake's text, Object 66) ride horses over the carnage of a battlefield. These may be the three named in the letterpress text, Object 72: Mista, Sangrida, and Hilda. Each sister extends her straight right arm out horizontally, pointing with her right index finger. The foremost sister wears a suit of armor, including a helmet with a plume. Similarly, the other two horses appear as increasingly indistinct lines suggesting the heads, chests, and perhaps forelegs of animals to the right of the foremost horse.

Jumbled bodies, the casualties of battle, lie across the bottom of the design. One in the lower left corner with a crown on his head may be the "King" mentioned in the letterpress text who "shall bite the ground." This king indeed faces down with teeth bared and parted in a grimace. His elbows rest on the ground on either side of his head and his lower arms reach upward; his hands clutch at his long hair.
