An upside down head, facing out and slightly right, appears to the right of the king. This figure's mouth is open, showing teeth. His short hair falls to the ground. He may be wearing a shirt. A third head to the right faces up with open mouth and perhaps closed eyes. Sketchy lines above and to the right of both of these heads may indicate the bodies to which they belong, and/or the bodies of other dead. Another figure lies face down at the bottom of the design, with head towards the viewer and arms outstretched to either side. This figure's hair falls to the ground, obscuring his face. He wears a shirt.
The area around the figures and the edges of the design are dark as with shadow or stormy sky.

desc.objtitle: The Fatal Sisters: Page 9, Object 75 (Butlin 335.75)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 9 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Three Fatal Sisters are seen from behind as they step towards their horses. These may be the three named in the letterpress text, Object 72: Mista, Sangrida, and Hilda. The rightmost sister rests her weight on her straight left leg. Her bent right leg is extended behind her and to the left, and her right foot is on tiptoe. Though her lower body faces away to the right, she twists her torso away to the left. Her head is turned to look away to the left as well. She raises her straight right arm at 135 degrees and may be resting her right hand on the top of her horse's head. The vertical shaft of a weapon, perhaps a spear, appears to the right of her torso. Two similar shafts appear evenly spaced to the left, above the right shoulder of each of the other two sisters. The sister in the middle appears in the same position, with right foot extended backwards on tiptoe and right arm raised. The leftmost sister is likewise positioned, although her legs are not visible. Both the sister in the middle and the sister on the left rest their right hands on their horses' heads. All three sisters wear hats or turbans and armored breastplates with overlapping scales over long gowns. Strands of hair escape from the leftmost sister's headgear. The Fatal Sisters' three horses await their riders. The head, chest, and front legs of the rightmost horse appear at the right side of the design. It faces forward and to the right, and raises one bent foreleg. Only part of the heads of the other two horses are visible above the sisters, to the left of the rightmost horse. Wash above the heads of the horses and the sisters suggests the sky.

component.illusobjdesc: Three Fatal Sisters are seen from behind as they step towards their horses. These may be the three named in the letterpress text, Object 72: Mista, Sangrida, and Hilda. The rightmost sister rests her weight on her straight left leg. Her bent right leg is extended behind her and to the left, and her right foot is on tiptoe. Though her lower body faces away to the right, she twists her torso away to the left. Her head is turned to look away to the left as well. She raises her straight right arm at 135 degrees and may be resting her right hand on the top of her horse's head. The vertical shaft of a weapon, perhaps a spear, appears to the right of her torso. Two similar shafts appear evenly spaced to the left, above the right shoulder of each of the other two sisters. The sister in the middle appears in the same position, with right foot extended backwards on tiptoe and right arm raised. The leftmost sister is likewise positioned, although her legs are not visible. Both the sister in the middle and the sister on the left rest their right hands on their horses' heads. All three sisters wear hats or turbans and armored breastplates with overlapping scales over long gowns. Strands of long hair escape from the leftmost sister's headgear.

The Fatal Sisters' three horses await their riders. The head, chest, and front legs of the rightmost horse appear at the right side of the design. It faces forward and to the right, and raises one bent foreleg. Only part of the heads of the other two horses are visible above the sisters, to the left of the rightmost horse.
Wash above the heads of the horses and the sisters suggests the sky.

desc.objtitle: The Fatal Sisters; Page 10: Blank Page, Object 76 (Butlin 335.76)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Mounted warriors fill much of the top half of the design. The foremost warrior sits astride a horse that rears or lunges facing left. The animal lifts its bent front legs into the air and lowers its head so that its nose is on a level with its knees. The heads of two other horses, behind the foremost horse, appear in an identical position to the left. Diagonal lines crossing their noses may indicate reins. The forelegs and abdomen of the next nearest horse may be just visible beneath the first horse's front legs; similarly, the far horses' rears may appear above the first horse's rump. The soldier riding the first horse leans forward slightly over its neck. His right arm is raised and drawn back, bent sharply behind his head so that the sword he grasps in his right hand points diagonally down towards the ground. This rider wears armor and a helmet with a long plume that either merges with a cape, or flies behind his back like a cape. The text box hides most of the rider's body but his armored left foot is visible in a stirrup just below the box's lower right corner. The fingers of his left hand hold his horse's reins just to the left of the text box. He has a mustache, and his short curly hair is just visible at his temple. His mouth is open. The head of a second mounted soldier, visible above the nose, appears facing left above the manes of the horses. This soldier wears a helmet over short curly hair as well. He holds a spear in his right hand, raised and drawn back above his head. Round shapes to the left of his head may indicate more riders. A knight on the ground tries to defend himself against the mounted knights above. This knight faces forward and leans his weight on his straight right arm, which is braced against the ground or perhaps against a fallen comrade. Though his right leg is mostly hidden, his legs seem to be spread. His bent left leg extends to the right and his left foot rests on the head or helmet of another fallen soldier. He leans back and tilts his head sharply back to look up at the soldier astride a horse above him. His mouth is open and his eyes are wide with terror. His bent left arm is raised and drawn back, and with his left hand he grasps the hilt of a sword that points down at the ground behind him. He is wearing a tunic over armor, or perhaps tights. His head is covered by a helmet. As in previous designs, a jumble of dead and dying bodies across the bottom of this design conveys the carnage of the battlefield. The lower body of one such casualty appears in the lower right corner of the design. Both knees are bent, and the soldier's feet rest on the back of another figure whose torso and head extend out towards the viewer. This figure seems to face down, with right arm extended to the left along the ground, and left arm by his side or caught beneath his torso. A spear or similar weapon emerges from beneath his body and lies on the ground pointing toward the viewer. This figure wears armor, including a breastplate. A helmet that may or may not encase a head, visible near the lower right corner of the design, supports the foot of the soldier who brandishes a sword against the mounted warriors above. A head with closed eyes and short hair fanned out on the ground faces up next to this helmet. Another shape near the left edge of the design, supporting the hand of the living soldier, may be another head with face hidden by hair. The heads of many spears or arrows fill the top of the design. Wash surrounding them and the figures suggests the sky, perhaps cloudy with storm or the dust of battle.

component.illusobjdesc: Mounted warriors fill much of the top half of the design. The foremost warrior sits astride a horse that rears or lunges facing left. The animal lifts its bent front legs into the air and lowers its head so that its nose is on a level with its knees. The heads of two other horses, behind the foremost horse, appear in an identical position to the left. Diagonal lines crossing their noses may indicate reins. The forelegs and abdomen of the next nearest horse may be just visible beneath the first horse's front legs; similarly, the far horses' rears may appear above the first horse's rump. The soldier riding the first horse leans forward slightly over its neck. His right arm is raised and drawn back, bent sharply behind his head so that the sword he grasps in his right hand points diagonally down towards the ground. This rider wears armor and a helmet with a long plume that either merges with a cape, or flies behind his back like a cape. The text box hides most of the rider's body but his armored left foot is visible in a stirrup just below the box's lower right corner. The fingers of his left hand hold his horse's reins just to the left of the text box. He has a mustache, and his short curly hair is just visible at his temple. His mouth is open. The head of a second mounted soldier, visible above the nose, appears facing left above the manes of the horses. This soldier wears a helmet over short curly hair as well. He holds a spear in his right hand, raised and drawn back above his head. Round shapes to the left of his head may indicate more riders.

A knight on the ground tries to defend himself against the mounted knights above. This knight faces forward and leans his weight on his straight right arm, which is braced against the ground or perhaps against a fallen comrade. Though his right leg is mostly hidden, his legs seem to be spread. His bent left leg extends to the right and his left foot rests on the head or helmet of another fallen soldier. He leans back and tilts his head sharply back to look up at the soldier astride a horse above him. His mouth is open and his eyes are wide with terror. His bent left arm is raised and drawn back, and with his left hand he grasps the hilt of a sword that points down at the ground behind him. He is wearing a tunic over armor, or perhaps tights. His head is covered by a helmet.

As in previous designs, a jumble of dead and dying bodies across the bottom of this design conveys the carnage of the battlefield. The lower body of one such casualty appears in the lower right corner of the design. Both knees are bent, and the soldier's feet rest on the back of another figure whose torso and head extend out towards the viewer. This figure seems to face down, with right arm extended to the left along the ground, and left arm by his side or caught beneath his torso. A spear or similar weapon emerges from beneath his body and lies on the ground pointing toward the viewer. This figure wears armor, including a breastplate. A helmet that may or may not encase a head, visible near the lower right corner of the design, supports the foot of the soldier who brandishes a sword against the mounted warriors above. A head with closed eyes and short hair fanned out on the ground faces up next to this helmet. Another shape near the left edge of the design, supporting the hand of the living soldier, may be another head with face hidden by hair.
The heads of many spears or arrows fill the top of the design. Wash surrounding them and the figures suggests the sky, perhaps cloudy with storm or the dust of battle.

desc.objtitle: The Descent of Odin; an Ode (From the Norse Tongue); Page 1: Title-Page, Object 77 (Butlin 335.77)

illustration.illusobjdesc: "The Serpent who girds the Earth" (see Blake's text, Object 78) fills this design. The creature's coiled body emerges from the right side of the design, spirals twice to form two loops, curves up past the left side of the design, and turns back to the right. The serpent's head appears to the right of the text box, facing right. Its mouth is open wide, displaying menacing teeth. Its forked tongue is extended. Large scales cover its body. White-capped waves cross the bottom of the design, suggesting a sea or lake; the serpent seems to be floating on the top of this water. Wash near the top of the design suggests clouds in a dark sky.

component.illusobjdesc: "The Serpent who girds the Earth" (see Blake's text, Object 78) fills this design. The creature's coiled body emerges from the right side of the design, spirals twice to form two loops, curves up past the left side of the design, and turns back to the right. The serpent's head appears to the right of the text box, facing right. Its mouth is open wide, displaying menacing teeth. Its forked tongue is extended. Large scales cover its body. It seems to be floating on the top of several waves visible at the bottom of the design.
White-capped waves cross the bottom of the design, suggesting a sea or lake.
Wash near the top of the design suggests clouds in a dark sky.

desc.objtitle: The Descent of Odin; Page 2: Blank Page Bearing List of Titles, Object 78 (Butlin 335.78)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Three winged creatures are the "Spectres" to which Blake refers in his name for this design, listed here as the second item in his "Descent of Odin" series. One butterfly or moth "spectre" hovers or flies above the text box. The insect has two large antennae and a double set of wings open towards the viewer. A second butterfly or moth "spectre" hovers or flies facing left at the left side of the text box. A fairy rests on its back, also facing left. She(?) turns her head slightly forward. Her arms are down in front of her, with her hands resting on the insect's head. Her long hair, perhaps blown by the wind of their movement, stands on end. One or perhaps both of her legs appear extended down the insect's back just beneath its near wing. The fairy may be nude, or the shape behind her legs and between the butterfly's wings may be her skirt or gown. The butterfly has large antennae and three visible bent legs. Its mouth is open. Its wings are decorated with stars and eye-like spots. The third "spectre" flies or hovers facing forward beneath the text box. The most frightening of the flying creatures, this one suggests a bat. Its decidedly batlike wings are spread to either side of its body. Claw hands appear on either side of its face. Its mouth is open in a threatening smile and a furry beard hangs from its chin. A fairy woman rides the bat, facing forward and to the right with her left foot resting between the spectre's large ears. Her left leg is slightly bent and her left foot may be on tiptoe; her right leg is bent and extended backwards. She leans to the right and extends her left arm up at 135 degrees; she may be pointing with her left index finger, palm facing up. Her right arm is down by her side and bent up at the elbow. Though her right hand is difficult to distinguish, at least one finger seems to rest on her chin. She turns her head to the left, smiling with a sneer. She is nude with visible breasts; her long hair blows to the left. Pencil lines above her indicate that Blake first drew this figure slightly higher on the leaft, perhaps with wings. Alternatively, this is a different bat-like creature not further developed.

component.illusobjdesc: A butterfly or moth "spectre" hovers or flies above the text box. The insect has two large antennae and a double set of wings open towards the viewer.

A second butterfly or moth "spectre" hovers or flies facing left at the left side of the text box. A fairy rests on its back, also facing left. She(?) turns her head slightly forward. Her arms are down in front of her, with her hands resting on the insect's head. Her long hair, perhaps blown by the wind of their movement, stands on end. One or perhaps both of her legs appear extended down the insect's back just beneath its near wing. The fairy may be nude, or the shape behind her legs and between the butterfly's wings may be her skirt or gown. The butterfly has large antennae and three visible bent legs. Its mouth is open. Its wings are decorated with stars and eye-like spots. A few pencil lines above th fairy's head, below the insect's head, and above and below its tail indicate preliminary positions for these motifs.

The third "spectre" flies or hovers facing forward beneath the text box. The most frightening of the flying creatures, this one suggests a bat. Its decidedly batlike wings are spread to either side of its body. Claw hands appear on either side of its face. Its mouth is open in a threatening smile and a furry beard hangs from its chin. A fairy woman rides the bat, facing forward and to the right with her left foot resting between the spectre's large ears. Her left leg is slightly bent and her left foot may be on tiptoe; her right leg is bent and extended backwards. She leans to the right and extends her left arm up at 135 degrees; she may be pointing with her left index finger, palm facing up. Her right arm is down by her side and bent up at the elbow. Though her right hand is difficult to distinguish, at least one finger seems to rest on her chin. She turns her head to the left, smiling with a sneer. She is nude with visible breasts; her long hair blows to the left. Pencil lines above her indicate that Blake first drew this figure slightly higher on the leaft, perhaps with wings. Alternatively, this is a different bat-like creature not further developed. Other light pencil lines left and right of the large bat-like creature indicate that he was originally sketched at a larger size.

lg.l: The Descent of Odin
1. The Serpent who girds the Earth
2. Spectres
3. "Him the Dog of Darkness spied"The line is quoted, with minor variations, from page [119] of the letterpress text (Object 79).
4. "Right against the eastern gateLines 6-7 are quoted, with minor variations, from page 120 of the letterpress text (Object 80).
By the moss grown Pile he sat."
5. The Prophetess Rising from her Grave
6. "Tis the drink of Balder bold"The line is quoted from page 122 of the letterpress text (Object 82).
7. "A Wondrous boy shall Rinda bearLines 10-13 are quoted, with minor variations, from page 123 of the letterpress text (Object 83).
Who neer shall comb his raven hair
Nor wash his visage in the stream
Till he on Hoders corse shall smile"
8. "Ha! No traveller art thouLines 14-15 are quoted, with minor variations, from page 124 of the letterpress text (Object 84).
King of Men I know thee Now"
9. "Hie thee hence"The line is quoted from page 125 of the letterpress text (Object 85).
10. The Serpent & the Wolvish Dog. two
terrors in the Northern Mythology

desc.objtitle: The Descent of Odin; Page 3: Beginning of Poem, Object 79 (Butlin 335.79)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 6 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Astride his horse, Odin rides forward and slightly left, filling the right side of the design. He brandishes a sword in his upraised right fist. A large shield obscures his torso and left arm. His bent left leg, foot in a stirrup, is visible below the shield. He wears armor and a close-fitting helmet. The animal's eyes are raised. Reins extend from its mouth. The "dog of darkness" (see the letterpress text) accompanies Odin and his horse. This animal runs or walks forward and to the left, a little ahead of Odin's mount. The dog turns his head back and up to the right to look at Odin. His mouth is open, displaying sharp teeth and a long tongue, and he may be barking. His ribs show under a rough coat of ragged fur. Odin and his horse and the dog of darkness proceed through what seems to be a cave. Its stone walls and floor are dark with shadow. Since Odin is traveling through the "portals nine of hell" (see letterpress text, Object 80), this may be an underground passageway.

component.illusobjdesc: Astride his horse, Odin rides forward and slightly left, filling the right side of the design. He brandishes a sword in his upraised right fist. A large shield obscures his torso and left arm. His bent left leg, foot in a stirrup, is visible below the shield. He wears armor and a close-fitting helmet. His horse steps forward with one foreleg, and bends one foreleg and one back leg up. The animal's eyes are raised and open wide. Reins extend from its mouth.

The "dog of darkness" (see the letterpress text) accompanies Odin and his horse. This animal runs or walks forward and to the left, a little ahead of Odin's mount. The dog turns his head back and up to the right to look at Odin. His mouth is open, displaying sharp teeth and a long tongue, and he may be barking. His ribs show under a rough coat of ragged fur. The dog may be related to Cerberus.

Odin and his horse and the dog of darkness proceed through what seems to be a cave. Its stone walls and floor are dark with shadow. Since Odin is traveling through the "portals nine of hell" (see letterpress text, Object 80), this may be an underground passageway.

desc.objtitle: The Descent of Odin: Page 4, Object 80 (Butlin 335.80)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 9 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Odin is seated before the "eastern gate" to hell (see the letterpress text), a large carved stone archway that fills the right side of the design. He sits on a rock or low stone ledge, facing right. His legs are bent and his knees drawn up slightly. He hunches forward and rests his bent right elbow and lower arm along his lap, pointing with his raised right index finger. His left arm is extended out horizontally in front of him; he grasps the handle of a downward pointing sword with his left hand. He uses the point of the sword to draw a "Runic rhyme" in the dirt that covers the grave of "the prophetic Maid" (see the letterpress text). Where the sword touches the dirt over the grave, flames spring up. Odin looks forward intently at his work with lowered eyes and slightly bent head, his mouth open as he recites "[t]he thrilling verse that wakes the dead" (see the letterpress text). He wears a full suit of armor, including a helmet, that encases his entire body from head to toe and leaves only his face and hands bare. A shield is strapped around his shoulder and rests against the far side of his body, facing away. The head and chest of Odin's horse emerge in the upper left corner of the design from behind the edge of the stone gateway. The horse faces left and lowers its head. Reins extend from the bit in the horse's mouth. Darkness fills the upper left corner and surrounds the figures in the left side of the design. This shadow may symbolize the location, at the gates of hell.

component.illusobjdesc: Odin is seated before the "eastern gate" to Hell (see the letterpress text). He sits on a rock or stone ledge, facing right. His legs are bent and his knees drawn up slightly. He hunches forward and rests his bent right elbow and lower arm along his lap, pointing with his raised right index finger. His left arm is extended out horizontally in front of him; he grasps the handle of a downward pointing sword with his left hand. He uses the point of the sword to draw a "Runic rhyme" in the dirt that covers the grave of "the prophetic Maid" (see letterpress text). Odin looks forward intently at his work with lowered eyes and slightly bent head, his mouth open in as he recites "[t]he thrilling verse that wakes the dead" (see the letterpress text). He wears a full suit of armor, including a helmet, that encases his entire body from head to toe and leaves only his face and hands bare. A shield is strapped around his shoulder and rests against the far side of his body, facing away.
Where the point of Odin's sword touches the dirt, flames spring up and hide part of the weapon's blade. The ground beneath is the grave of the Prophetess mentioned in the text.
A large carved stone archway fills the right side of the design. This is the "eastern gate" to hell (see the letterpress text).

The head and chest of Odin's horse emerge in the upper left corner of the design from behind the edge of the stone gateway. The horse faces left and lowers its head. Reins extend from the bit in the horse's mouth.
Darkness fills the upper left corner and surrounds the figures in the left side of the design. This shadow may symbolize the location at the gate of hell.

desc.objtitle: The Descent of Odin: Page 5, Object 81 (Butlin 335.81)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 3 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Odin's figure fills the design, seen from behind. He faces away and bends his head down; he may be bending forward slightly. His slightly bent legs are spread to reveal the "Prophetess" (see Blake's text, Object 78) whom he summoned (in the previous design) rising from the ground before him. His bent left arm is at his side, with shield strapped to elbow and wrist. His bent right arm is down, lower arm extended slightly to the right. He grasps a sword in his right fist. The tip of the sword, which points down, may rest on the ground near Odin's right foot. He is wearing a full suit of armor, including helmet. The head and shoulders of the Prophetess emerge from her grave in the ground, facing forward. She tilts her head back slightly, exposing her throat, and raises her eyes, perhaps to look up at Odin. Her mouth is open. Her long hair stands on end, forming a kind of spiky or flame-like halo around her head. Her hands in loose fists are crossed in front of her chest, right over left, just above the ground. She may be nude, or may be wearing a gown. Spiky shapes suggesting blue flame or gusts of air emerge from the ground on either side of the prophetess' body. The area around her figure is lighter than surrounding areas, as if she emits light. The head and one straight front leg of Odin's horse appears at the right side of the design, facing left. The horse lowers his head slightly and may be looking at the prophetess' startling appearance. In the light from the prophetess, Odin's legs cast shadows on the ground near his feet. Except for lighter areas around the prophetess and in the upper right corner, darkness fills the design, perhaps reflecting the setting near the gates of hell.

component.illusobjdesc: Odin's figure fills the design, seen from behind. He faces away and bends his head down; he may be bending forward slightly. His slightly bent legs are spread to reveal the Prophetess whom he summoned (in the previous design) rising from the ground before him. His bent left arm is at his side, with shield strapped to elbow and wrist. His bent right arm is down, lower arm extended slightly to the right. He grasps a sword in his right fist. The tip of the sword, which points down, may rest on the ground near Odin's right foot. He is wearing a full suit of armor, including helmet.

The head and shoulders of the "Prophetess" (see Blake's text, Object 78) emerge from her grave in the ground, facing forward. She tilts her head back slightly, exposing her throat, and raises her eyes, perhaps to look up at Odin. Her mouth is open. Her long hair stands on end, forming a kind of spiky or flame-like halo around her head. Her hands in loose fists are crossed in front of her chest, right over left, just above the ground. She may be nude, or may be wearing a gown. Spiky shapes suggesting blue flame or gusts of air emerge from the ground on either side of the prophetess' body. The area around her figure is lighter than surrounding areas, as if she emits light.

The head and one straight front leg of Odin's horse appears at the right side of the design, facing left. The horse lowers his head slightly and may be looking at the Prophetess' startling appearance.

The area below the prophetess is her grave from which she emerges. In the light from the prophetess, Odin's legs cast shadows on the ground near his feet. Except for lighter areas around the Prophetess and in the upper right corner, darkness fills the design, perhaps reflecting the setting near the gates of hell.

desc.objtitle: The Descent of Odin: Page 6, Object 82 (Butlin 335.82)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 6 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The prophetess, holding a goblet, flies or hovers beneath the text box. Her body is mostly horizontal, facing down. Her legs trail away to the left. She twists and bends backwards at the waist so that her upper body turns forward; she further turns her head to look forward and to the left. Her head is also bent back slightly. Her left arm is raised straight overhead, and her left hand is open with vertical palm facing forward. Her right arm, which may be straight or may be slightly bent, is extended horizontally forward and to the left. She grasps the stem of the goblet with her right hand. Her mouth is open and her eyes are raised; she is probably speaking. Her long hair blows backwards and to the left. She wears a gown with a sleeve for her left arm, but that seems to leave her right arm exposed. The fabric of her garment obscures her legs and feet. The goblet the Prophetess holds contains honey, the "pure bev'rage of the bee" (see the letterpress text). The goblet is shaped like a chambered nautilus and may be made of that shell. The "shield of gold" (see the letterpress text) hangs in the upper left corner of the design. It is decorated with a scalloped border and a starlike engraving at the center. Shadows fill much of the design. They are particularly dark near the bottom, where there may be clouds, and become increasingly lighter nearer the top of the design.

component.illusobjdesc: The Prophetess, holding a goblet, flies or hovers beneath the text box. Her body is mostly horizontal, facing down. Her legs trail away to the left. She twists and bends backwards at the waist so that her upper body turns forward; she further turns her head to look forward and to the left. Her head is also bent back slightly. Her left arm is raised straight overhead, and her left hand is open with palm facing forward. Her right arm, which may be straight or may be slightly bent, is extended horizontally forward and to the left. She grasps the stem of the goblet with her right hand. Her mouth is open and her eyes are raised; she is probably speaking. Her long hair blows backwards and to the left. She wears a gown with a sleeve for her left arm, but that seems to leave her right arm exposed. Her breasts are partly visible as well. The fabric of her garment obscures her legs and feet.
The goblet the Prophetess holds contains honey, the "pure bev'rage of the bee" (see the letterpress text). The goblet is shaped like a chambered nautilus and may be made of that shell.
The "shield of gold" (see the letterpress text) hangs in the upper left corner of the design. It is decorated with a scalloped border and a starlike engraving at the center.
Shadows fill much of the design. They are particularly dark near the bottom, where there may be clouds, and become increasingly lighter nearer the top of the design.

desc.objtitle: The Descent of Odin: Page 7, Object 83 (Butlin 335.83)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 13 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The "wondrous boy" mentioned in the poem sits bathing "in the stream" and combing his hair, signaling that he has accomplished his task (see the letterpress text). Nude, he sits on a bank with his bent right leg down and his right foot submerged below the surface of the water. His left leg is crossed over his right, left ankle resting on right knee. He bends forward or hunches over slightly and lowers his head. His slightly bent right arm is extended and rests against his left ankle. His left arm is raised and bent upward, and he holds a comb poised over his curly dark hair with his left hand. He sits on a grassy bank in the lower left corner of the design. Below the grass the bank consists of rock, dirt, or sand. Across the stream the opposite bank appears, extending a little over halfway across the design from the right edge. A thin line of dirt or sand is visible there just above the waterline and beneath a line of trees or bushes. A hill or mountain rises above the vegetation. A wide stream crosses the bottom of the design. Gentle waves ripple its surface. Dark clouds fill much of the top of the design, particularly the upper right corner. The setting sun at the horizon, over the water, completes the prophetess' prophecy that the "wondrous boy" will bathe and "see the sun's departing beams" only after he has finished his mission (see the letterpress text). Its beams of light fill the sky between the stream and the clouds.

component.illusobjdesc: The "wondrous boy" mentioned in the poem sits bathing "in the stream" and combing his hair, signaling that he has accomplished his task (see the letterpress text). Nude, he sits on a bank with his bent right leg down and his right foot submerged below the surface of the water. His left leg is crossed over his right, left ankle resting on right knee. He bends forward or hunches over slightly and lowers his head. His slightly bent right arm is extended and rests against his left ankle. His left arm is raised and bent upward, and he holds a comb poised over his curly dark hair with his left hand.

The nude boy sits on a grassy bank in the lower left corner of the design. Below the grass the bank consists of rock, dirt, or sand. Across the stream the opposite bank appears, extending a little over halfway across the design from the right edge. A thin line of dirt or sand is visible there just above the waterline and beneath a line of trees or bushes. A hill or mountain rises above the vegetation.
A wide stream crosses the bottom of the design. Gentle waves ripple its surface.
Dark clouds fill much of the top of the design, particularly the upper right corner.

The setting sun at the horizon, over the water, completes the Prophetess' prophecy that the "wondrous boy" will bathe and "see the sun's departing beams" only after he has finished his mission (see the letterpress text). Its beams of light fill the sky between the stream and the clouds above.

desc.objtitle: The Descent of Odin: Page 8, Object 84 (Butlin 335.84)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 13 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Odin stands at the right side of the design, facing left. His weight rests largely on his left leg; his right is slightly bent and forward. His extended right arm is raised at 135 degrees, and his right hand is out with palm down. He wears a stern expression and a full suit of armor, including a helmet. The large shield he bears hides most of his torso. The blade of a sword appears to the left of his left leg. He looks at the prophetess on the left. The prophetess, standing or walking forward at the left side of the design, suddenly realizes Odin's true identity. Her body faces forward, but she turns her head to the right to look at Odin. Her mouth is open and she wears an expression of surprise on her face. She may be speaking. Her arms are down by her side but bent up at the elbow, and her lower arms are raised with vertical palms forward. Her left leg is forward and her slightly bent right leg is extended backward. She wears a long, semi-transparent gown that swirls around her ankles. It reveals the shape of her breasts and legs. Dark shadows and her left foot are visible beneath its hem. The flame-like hair on the top of her head stands on end; longer locks are visible on either side of her body as they cascade down her back. Spiky shapes suggesting blue flame or gusts of air emerge from the ground on either side of the prophetess' feet. Lighter areas around these shapes and around the prophetess' head suggest that she emits light. Odin casts a dark shadow on the ground between his feet. Lighter shadows surround the figures and fill the empty spaces of the design except around the prophetess' head; the shadows are particularly dark in the lower right corner. The darkness may be due to the setting, in hell.

component.illusobjdesc: Odin stands at the right side of the design, facing left. His weight rests largely on his left leg; his right is slightly bent and forward. His extended right arm is raised at 135 degrees, and his right hand is out with palm down. He wears a stern expression and a full suit of armor, including a helmet. The large shield he bears hides most of his torso. The blade of a sword appears to the left of his left leg. He looks at the prophetess on the left.

The prophetess, standing or walking forward at the left side of the design, suddenly realizes Odin's true identity. Her body faces forward, but she turns her head to the right to look at Odin. Her mouth is open and she wears an expression of surprise on her face. She may be speaking. Her arms are down by her side but bent up at the elbow, and her lower arms are raised with vertical palms forward. Her left leg is forward and her slightly bent right leg is extended backward. She wears a long, semi-transparent gown that swirls around her ankles. It reveals the shape of her breasts and legs. Dark shadows and her left foot are visible beneath its hem. The flame-like hair on the top of her head stands on end; longer locks are visible on either side of her body as they cascade down her back. Spiky shapes suggesting blue flame or gusts of air emerge from the ground on either side of the Prophetess' feet. Lighter areas around these shapes and around the prophetess' head suggest that she emits light.

desc.objtitle: The Descent of Odin: Page 9, Object 85 (Butlin 335.85)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 3 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Odin sits astride a horse that runs or leaps to the right. Alternatively, the animal may be rearing. Odin's body faces right, but he turns his head forward and lowers his eyes to look at the prophetess below. She is shown at the bottom of the design, descending back into her grave past two slabs of rock, or perhaps a crack in the earth. Only her head and right arm are visible above the ground. Seen from behind, she faces away and to the left, tilting her head back as if she looks at Odin on his horse above. Her mouth may be slightly open. Her right arm is raised vertically over her head and she points up at Odin with her right index finger. Her long hair blows to the left. She may be nude, or may be wearing a gown. Flames spring from the ground where the prophetess descends. Wash between the prophetess and Odin's horse suggests that the horse leaps over or past more fire. Odin on his horse leans forward slightly. His right leg is bent and his right foot rests in a stirrup. The text box hides most of Odin's body but his slightly bent right arm is clearly extended forward. His right hand, positioned near his horse's nose, grasps the reins or bit in the animal's mouth. Odin's shield, facing away, is visible on the far side of his body. His left hand appears above the horse's neck, holding the shield's handle. Odin wears a full suit of armor, including a helmet, and a cloak or cape that falls from his shoulder over his horse's rear. Only part of one of the horse's front legs is visible, bent and raised. Shadows fill the space in the upper left corner of the design and below Odin's horse's leg at the right side of the design.

component.illusobjdesc: Odin sits astride a horse that runs or leaps to the right. Alternatively, the animal may be rearing. Odin's body faces right, but he turns his head forward and lowers his eyes to look at the Prophetess below. (His shoulders may be twisted slightly forward as well.) He leans forward slightly. His right leg is bent and his right foot rests in a stirrup. The text box hides most of Odin's body but his slightly bent right arm is clearly extended forward. His right hand, positioned near his horse's nose, grasps the reins or bit in the animal's mouth. Odin's shield, facing away, is visible on the far side of his body. His left hand appears above the horse's neck, holding the shield's handle. Odin wears a full suit of armor, including a helmet, and a cloak or cape that falls from his shoulder over his horse's rear. Only part of one of the horse's front legs is visible, bent and raised.

The prophetess is shown at the bottom of the design, descending back into her grave. Only her head and right arm are visible above the ground. Seen from behind, she faces away and to the left, tilting her head back as if she looks at Odin on his horse above. Her mouth may be slightly open. Her right arm is raised vertically over her head and she points up at Odin with her right index finger. Her long hair blows to the left. She may be nude, or may be wearing a gown.

The prophetess descends back into her grave past two slabs of rock, or perhaps a crack in the earth. Flames spring from the ground where the Prophetess descends. Wash between the prophetess and Odin on his horse suggests that the horse leaps over or past more fire.
Shadows fill the space in the upper left corner of the design and below Odin's horse's leg at the right side of the design.

desc.objtitle: The Descent of Odin; Page 10: Blank Page Bearing List of Titles, Object 86 (Butlin 335.86)

illustration.illusobjdesc: An enormous serpent, partly hidden by the text box, fills much of this design. The creature's scaly body is coiled into a circle. Its head appears upside down below the text box, facing left. Its mouth is open, and it bites its own tail with sharp, tiny teeth. This configuration suggests an ouroboros. The head and paws of the "Wolvish Dog" (see Blake's text, Object 78) appear resting on a small hill or mound at the bottom of the design. The animal's head is tilted back and its eyes are raised to look up at the serpent above. Its mouth is open, displaying its tongue and fierce teeth. Spiky fur surrounds its head. Its paws have large claws. Tongues of fire rise from either side of the Wolvish Dog to surround the serpent above. Beyond the flames, darkness fills the edges of the design.

component.illusobjdesc: An enormous serpent, partly hidden by the text box, fills much of this design. The creature's scaly body is coiled into a circle. Its head appears upside down below the text box, facing left. Its mouth is open, and it bites its own tail with sharp, tiny teeth. This configuration suggests an ouroboros. Its one pictured eye is enormous.

The head and paws of the "Wolvish Dog" (see Blake's text, Object 78) appear resting on a small hill or mound at the bottom of the design. The animal's head is tilted back and its eyes are raised to look up at the serpent above. Its mouth is open, displaying its tongue and fierce teeth. Spiky fur surrounds its head. Its paws have large claws.
Tongues of fire rise from either side of the Wolvish Dog to surround the serpent above. Beyond the flames, darkness fills the edges of the design.

battle
2. A Festal board
3. The Bard singing Owens praise
4. "Dauntless on his native sandsLines 7-8 are quoted, with minor variations, from page 130 of the letterpress text (Object 90).
The Dragon son of Mona stands"
5"Fear to Stop & Shame to fly"The line is quoted, with minor variations, from page 131 of the letterpress text (Object 91).

into his house

desc.objtitle: The Triumphs of Owen; a Fragment; Page 1: Title-Page, Object 87 (Butlin 335.87)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A young man in armor runs to the right through a battlefield, carrying a large standard. He leans forward in his haste, with his bent left leg drawn forward and up and his bent right leg extended behind him. His right foot is on tiptoe. Indistinctly outlined casualties of battle litter the bottom of the design, and the ground is not clearly delineated, giving the impression that the runner leaps or even flies through or over his fallen comrades. He raises his bent right arm upward at approximately 135 degrees, and grasps the diagonally slanted pole of his flag with his right hand. He crushes some of the flag's material in his grip. His head is bent back and turned partway forward, and his mouth is open as if in a cry. Though he is dressed from neck to toes in armor, his head is bare; his rather long hair flies free. The fabric of his flag ripples past him and billows in his wake. The scattered bodies of soldiers, the casualties of battle, lie on the ground extending into the distance. Some are alive while others seem to be dead or dying. The upper body of one such casualty appears to the right of the running standard-bearer's left leg. This soldier leans on his elbow, right arm bent, facing down with his head lowered. His eyes are closed. He may be lying across a body, difficult to distinguish, beneath his torso. He wears armor, including a helmet. Above him is visible the head and shoulders of a soldier who faces forward and to the left, his head tilted back, his eyes raised, and his mouth open wide. He may be crying out in pain. This soldier wears a helmet. Three other helmeted heads are faintly visible above his, receding into the distance. The nearest may be facing away. Another head appears lying on the ground and looking up, beneath the standard-bearer's right knee. This helmeted head extends out towards the viewer. Other tangled lines along the ground suggest additional crumpled bodies. The top of a spear, pointing diagonally upward, appears in the upper left corner of the design. The shafts of additional raised weapons are visible below, between the left edge of the design and the billowing flag. Wash near the top of the design suggests the sky, perhaps with dark clouds in the upper right corner and down the right side of the design. Alternatively this may be battlefield dust or smoke. The running standard-bearer casts a shadow on the ground, which joins other shadows amidst the scattered bodies below him.

component.illusobjdesc: A young man in armor runs to the right bearing a large standard. He leans forward in his haste, with his bent left leg drawn forward and up and his bent right leg extended behind him. His right foot is on tiptoe. Indistinctly outlined casualties of battle litter the bottom of the design, and the ground is not clearly delineated, giving the impression that the runner leaps or even flies through or over his fallen comrades. He raises his bent right arm upward at approximately 135 degrees, and grasps the diagonally slanted pole of his flag with his right hand. He crushes some of the flag's material in his grip. His head is bent back and turned partway forward, and his mouth is open as if in a cry. Though he is dressed from neck to toes in armor, his head is bare; his rather long hair flies free. The fabric of his flag ripples past him and billows in his wake.

The scattered bodies of soldiers, the casualties of battle, lie on the ground extending into the distance. Some are alive while others seem to be dead or dying. The upper body of one such casualty appears to the right of the running standard-bearer's left leg. This soldier leans on his elbow, right arm bent, facing down with his head lowered. His eyes are closed. He may be lying across a body, difficult to distinguish, beneath his torso. He wears armor, including a helmet. Above him is visible the head and shoulders of a soldier who faces forward and to the left, his head tilted back, his eyes raised, and his mouth open wide. He may be crying out in pain. This soldier wears a helmet. Three other helmeted heads are faintly visible above his, receding into the distance. The nearest may be facing away. Another head appears lying on the ground and looking up, beneath the standard-bearer's right knee. This helmeted head extends out towards the viewer, and is seen upside down. Other tangled lines along the ground suggest additional crumpled bodies.

The top of a spear, pointing diagonally upward, appears in the upper left corner of the design. The shafts of additional raised weapons are visible below, between the left edge of the design and the billowing flag.

Wash near the top of the design suggests the sky, perhaps with dark clouds in the upper right corner and down the right side of the design. Alternatively this may be battlefield dust or smoke. The running standard-bearer casts a shadow on the ground, which joins other shadows amidst the scattered bodies below him.

desc.objtitle: The Triumphs of Owen; Page 2: Advertisement, Object 88 (Butlin 335.88)

illustration.illusobjdesc: In this design, young and old men sit around a banquet table located in the lower right corner. At the left side of the table, one man sits facing right with his slightly bent right arm lying on his lap and his right hand resting on his knee. He holds a large goblet before his torso with his raised left hand. His right leg is bent and drawn back, right foot on tiptoe, while his left foot rests on the ground beneath the table. He is wearing tights, perhaps with a belt, and has a beard and short curly hair. His feet are clad in slim shoes. To the right appears the head and torso of a second man, facing forward and to the right. This man also has a beard and short curly hair. Below the table his garment seems to be a gown. The head of a third man is visible between the text box and the head of the second man. This man faces right and has a long beard and longer hair. Behind the table, to the right of the text box, a fourth man sits facing forward. He turns his head slightly to the left, and has a short beard and short hair. He is dressed in a shirt or gown with a decorative collar, or perhaps a gorget or necklace hung around his neck. A fifth man, far right, rests his chin on his right hand, which rests in turn on the left shoulder of the man who faces forward. This older man, balding with white hair at his temples and a long beard, seems to be the oldest at the table. Only his head and hand are visible. The heavy wooden table around which the men sit at the lower right corner of the design has an ornately carved leg, or central pillar, the top of which is in shadow. A large bowl, decorated with scrollwork vines and blossoms(?), sits on its surface. The diagonal lines extending out of the bowl to the right may be the handle of a serving instrument of some sort, perhaps a spoon or ladle. A young man stands or walks at the left side of the design. He faces to the right but turns his head away, so that his face is not visible. He rests his weight on his left leg and extends his bent right leg backwards slightly; his right foot is on tiptoe. He wears tights or a short tunic or gown; his lower legs and feet are bare. His right arm is down by his side and he holds the handle of a pitcher with his right hand. He has short curly hair. Both he and the leftmost seated man cast shadows on the ground below. The outdoor feast seems to be taking place within a building, possibly a gazebo, that is open on at least one side. The top of a pillar appears above the text box, supporting an arched partial wall. At the left a taller pillar or post forms part of a doorway that extends beyond the left edge of the design. A cypress-like tree appears within this open doorway. The trunks and leafy branches of at least four other trees are visible between the arches of the gazebo. Grass covers the ground on which the table rests. Mountain peaks appear in the distance, above the heads of the seated men.

component.illusobjdesc: In this design, young and old men sit around a banquet table located in the lower right corner. At the left side of the table, one man sits facing right with his slightly bent right arm lying on his lap and his right hand resting on his knee. He holds a large goblet before his torso with his raised left hand. His right leg is bent and drawn back, right foot on tiptoe, while his left foot rests on the ground beneath the table. He is wearing tights, perhaps with a belt, and has a beard and short curly hair. His feet are clad in slim shoes. To the right appears the head and torso of a second man, facing forward and to the right. This man also has a beard and short curly hair. His gown is visible below the table. The head of a third man is visible between the text box and the head of the second man. This man faces right and has a long beard and longer hair. Behind the table, to the right of the text box, a fourth man sits facing forward. He turns his head slightly to the left, and has a short beard and short hair. He is dressed in a shirt or gown with a decorative collar, or perhaps a gorget or necklace hung around his neck. A fifth man, far right, rests his chin on his right hand, which rests in turn on the left shoulder of the man who faces forward. This older man, balding with white hair at his temples and a long beard, seems to be the oldest at the table. Only his head and hand are visible.

A young man stands or walks at the left side of the design. He faces to the right but turns his head away, so that his face is not visible. He rests his weight on his left leg and extends his bent right leg backwards slightly; his right foot is on tiptoe. He wears tights or a short tunic or gown; his lower legs and feet are bare. His right arm is down by his side and he holds the handle of a pitcher with his right hand. He has short curly hair.
The standing man and the leftmost seated man cast shadows on the ground below.

The heavy wooden table around which the men sit at the lower right corner of the design has an ornately carved single leg, or central pillar, the top of which is in shadow. A large bowl, decorated with scrollwork vines and blossoms(?), sits on its surface. The diagonal lines extending out of the bowl to the right may be the handle of a serving instrument of some sort, perhaps a spoon or ladle.

The outdoor feast seems to be taking place within a building, possibly a gazebo, that is open on at least one side. The top of a pillar appears above the text box, supporting an arched partial wall. At the left a taller pillar or post forms part of a doorway that extends beyond the left edge of the design.

A cypress-like tree appears within the open doorway at the left side of the design. The trunks and leafy branches of at least four other trees are visible between the arches of the gazebo. Grass covers the ground on which the table rests.
Mountain peaks appear in the distance, above the heads of the seated men.

desc.objtitle: The Triumphs of Owen; Page 3: Beginning of Poem, Object 89 (Butlin 335.89)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 4 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The bard sits before his harp, which nearly fills the design though it is partly hidden behind the text box. He faces left and extends his arm horizontally. It is hidden by the text box below the elbow. He bends his head slightly and lowers or closes his eyes. He may be blind. His mouth is open and he may be singing or speaking, as well as playing the harp. He has long hair and a beard, and wears a robe that drapes his body completely and rests on the floor below; its shape reveals that at least his left leg is bent. The robe is decorated with small stars. The bard's audience appears between his instrument and the left side of the design. The foremost man sits facing right, with his head turned slightly forward as though he looks towards the bard. He raises his slightly bent right arm up and extends it horizontally; his right hand is hidden behind the text box. He wears a long gown and has a beard and short curly hair. His legs are bent. The backrest and back leg of his chair appear lower left. A second head, which seems to belong to a man with a beard and short hair looking to the right, is visible between the first man's head and the text box. A third head, even less distinct than the second, appears between the first man's head and the left side of the design. Behind the bard, a dark shadow extends up to the right side of the design. Lighter shadows appear around the figures of the audience. The bard and his audience are seated on a bare floor.

component.illusobjdesc: The bard sits before his harp, which nearly fills the design though it is partly hidden behind the text box. He faces left and extends his left arm horizontally. It is hidden by the text box below the elbow. He bends his head slightly and lowers or closes his eyes. He may be blind. His mouth is open and he may be singing or speaking, as well as playing the harp. He has long hair and a beard, and wears a robe that drapes his body completely and rests on the floor below; its shape reveals that at least his left leg is bent. The robe is decorated with small stars.

The bard's audience appears between his instrument and the left side of the design. The foremost man sits facing right, with his head turned slightly forward as though he looks towards the bard. He raises his slightly bent right arm up and extends it horizontally; his right hand is hidden behind the text box. He wears a long gown and has a beard and short curly hair. His legs are bent. The backrest and back leg of his chair appear lower left. A second head, which seems to belong to a man with a beard and short hair looking to the right, is visible between the first man's head and the text box. A third head, even less distinct than the second, appears between the first man's head and the left side of the design.
Behind the bard, a dark shadow extends up to the right side of the design. Lighter shadows appear around the figures of the audience. The bard and his audience are seated on a bare floor.

desc.objtitle: The Triumphs of Owen: Page 4, Object 90 (Butlin 335.90)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 12 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A formidable warrior lunges forward and to the right at the left side of this design. This may be "The Dragon Son of Mona" (see Blake's text, Object 86). His bent left leg is forward and his bent right leg is extended backward, with his right foot on tiptoe. He bends forward and slightly to the right. He raises his bent right arm up at 135 degrees and brandishes a sword in his upraised right fist. His left hand appears above the top of the text box, holding up a shield. His mouth is open, perhaps in a shout. He wears a full suit of armor, including a helmet with a large feathered plume. Lines visible between his legs, below his right arm, to the lower left of the text box, and to the right of his upraised sword suggest his quick movement. The twisting or spiraling lines above his head are flame-like. Several vanquished warriors lie in contorted positions at the right side of the design. The foremost lies, or is propped, supine on the ground, his broken body twisted into a gruesome ring. He is bent backward sharply at the waist, his head bent even further backward, so that his shoulders face forward and to the right and his face is planted in the earth. His slightly bent right leg is extended away from his body, while his left leg is bent sharply back and out towards the viewer at an unnatural angle. The body of the second casualty appears above the first. This figure faces away with his body upside down and his head and shoulders hidden behind the first. His lower body is twisted slightly to the left. His right leg is bent forward and drawn up with the bottom of his right foot prominent. His left leg is bent but leans to the right; the lower leg extends beyond the edge of the design. His right arm and bent elbow are visible extended horizontally to the left. Both of these soldiers are nude. The head and arm of an upright soldier are visible near the upper right corner of the design. This soldier wears a helmet and faces left. His right arm is lifted overhead and bent backwards sharply, so that his fist is behind his head. He grasps the handle of a downward pointing sword with this hand. This arm seems to be clad in armor. A large shield hides the rest of his torso from view. The ground beneath the soldiers is pocked as if with the imprints of many feet. Above, the space around the figures is dark with shadow.

component.illusobjdesc: A formidable warrior lunges forward and to the right at the left side of this design. This may be "The Dragon son of Mona" (see Blake's text, Object 86). His bent left leg is forward and his bent right leg is extended backward, with his right foot on tiptoe. He bends forward and slightly to the right. He raises his bent right arm up at 135 degrees and brandishes a sword in his upraised right fist. His left hand appears above the top of the text box, holding up a shield. His mouth is open, perhaps in a shout. He wears a full suit of armor, including a helmet with a large feathered plume. Lines visible between his legs, below his right arm, to the lower left of the text box, and to the right of his upraised sword suggest his quick movement.
The twisting or spiraling lines above the head of the soldier on the left are flame-like.

A vanquished warrior lies, or is propped, supine on the ground at the bottom of the design, his broken body twisted into a gruesome ring. He is bent backward sharply at the waist, his head bent even further backward, so that his shoulders face forward and to the right and his face is planted in the earth. His mouth seems to be open. His bent left arm falls forward to the left, resting from elbow to hand on the ground. His upper right arm is just visible beside his head before it disappears beyond the edge of the design. His slightly bent right leg is extended away from his body, while his left leg is bent sharply back and out towards the viewer at an unnatural angle. He seems to be nude.

The body of a second casualty appears above the first at the right side of the design. This figure faces away with his body upside down and his head and shoulders hidden behind the first dead soldier. His lower body is twisted slightly to the left. His right leg is bent forward and drawn up with the bottom of his right foot prominent. His left leg is bent but leans to the right; the lower leg extends beyond the edge of the design. His right upper arm and bent elbow are visible extended horizontally to the left. This figure is nude.

The head and arm of an upright soldier are visible near the upper right corner of the design. This soldier wears a helmet and faces left. His right arm is lifted overhead and bent backwards sharply, so that his fist is behind his head. He grasps the handle of a downward pointing sword with this hand. This arm seems to be clad in armor. A large shield hides the rest of his torso from view.
The ground beneath the soldiers is pocked as with the imprints of many feet. Above, the space around the figures is dark with shadow.

desc.objtitle: The Triumphs of Owen: Page 5, Object 91 (Butlin 335.91)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 7 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A line of soldiers crosses the bottom half of the design. They face forward with legs spread wide and shields raised to hide their torsos. They seem paused, as if unsure about which way to proceed. They wear armor; two on the right have helmets. Clouds of dust rise between them, which may be why the spaces between their legs are dark with shadow. Two enormous flags billow above the line of soldiers. A forest of sharp spears points diagonally to the right above the heads of the soldiers on the right. Wash in the upper left corner of the design suggests dark clouds.

component.illusobjdesc: A line of soldiers crosses the bottom half of the design. They face forward but seem paused, as if unsure about which way to proceed. The leftmost soldier is visible only as a head, which appears next to the left edge of the design. This short-haired soldier faces forward. His mouth is open and his eyes may be crossed. The top of his shield appears above and to the left of the shield held by the soldier in front of him. This second soldier stands with bent legs spread and shield held up to hide his torso. He looks forward and to the left with his mouth open and his eyebrows drawn into a frown. He wears armor and has short hair and a beard. The armored right leg of a third soldier, whose torso is hidden behind his shield and whose head is hidden behind the text box, is partly visible behind the second soldier's left leg. Part of this third soldier's left leg appears to the left of a fourth soldier's right thigh. This fourth soldier stands next in line with his bent legs spread and braced. His head, which appears above his raised shield, faces mostly left and is visible in three-quarters profile. He has short hair. The soldier second from the right faces forward and slightly right. He leans to the right slightly. Like his fellows, his bent legs are spread. A shield hides his right arm and part of his torso. His left arm is by his side and bent forward; he holds the handle of a downward pointing sword in his left hand. He wears a full suit of armor, including a helmet. His head, bent back slightly, faces forward and slightly left. His eyes are raised and his mouth is open. Only the head and perhaps the left shoulder of the rightmost soldier are visible over his own shield. He too looks forward and to the left, with head bent slightly back and mouth open. Those with open mouths may be shouting or screaming.
Clouds of dust rise between the soldiers. This may be why the spaces between their legs are dark with shadow.
Two enormous flags billow above the line of soldiers. A forest of sharp spears points diagonally to the right above the heads of the soldiers on the right.
Wash in the upper left corner of the design suggests dark clouds.

desc.objtitle: The Triumphs of Owen; Page 6: Blank Page, Object 92 (Butlin 335.92)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The "liberal Man" (see Blake's text, Object 86) of the title stands near the left side of the design, just to the right of his own front steps. His body faces forward and to the left, but he turns his bent head to the right to look at the figure on the right. He bends to the right gracefully, and extends his arms out at 45 degrees before him and to the left. He wears a long gown that hides his legs, but its shape suggests that his left leg is bent forward slightly. His feet are just visible beneath the hem, and his left foot may be on tiptoe. Mostly bald, he has hair at his temples and a long beard. A "traveller" (see Blake's text, Object 86) faces and walks left at the right side of the design. His weight is on his left leg; his bent right leg is extended backward and his right foot is on tiptoe. His left arm is down by his side and he holds the brim of a hat with his left hand. The fingers of his right hand, forming a loose fist, appear to the left of his left elbow. He may grasp the head of the walking stick that appears between his legs, on the far side of his body, with this hand. His head is lowered slightly, but his eyes are raised to look forward at the other man. He has short curly hair and a beard. He wears a long tunic over pants or tights. He casts a slight shadow on the ground to the right of his left foot. A gentle mound or hill rises in the background. The ground on which the traveler and his host stand seems to be covered with grass, as is the low hill behind them. A hedge of bushes or small trees appears above the hill on the right. Wash above the hill and hedge suggests the sky, perhaps streaked with clouds.

component.illusobjdesc: The "liberal Man" (see Blake's text, Object 86) of the title stands near the left side of the design, just to the right of his own front steps. His body faces forward and to the left, but he turns his bent head to the right to look at the figure on the right. He bends to the right gracefully, and extends his arms out at 45 degrees before him and to the left. His vertical palms are out. He wears a long gown that hides his legs, but its shape suggests that his left leg is bent forward slightly. His feet are just visible beneath the hem, and his left foot may be on tiptoe. Mostly bald, he has hair at his temples and a long beard. A few light lines left and right of his legs indicate alternative, but rejected, positions for them.

A "traveller" (see Blake's text, Object 86) faces and walks left at the right side of the design. His weight is on his left leg; his bent right leg is extended backward and his right foot is on tiptoe. His left arm is down by his side and he holds the brim of a hat with his left hand. The fingers of his right hand, forming a loose fist, appear to the left of his left elbow. He may grasp the head of the walking stick that appears between his legs, on the far side of his body, with this hand. His head is lowered slightly, but his eyes are raised to look forward at the other man. He has short curly hair and a beard. He wears a long tunic over pants or tights. He casts a slight shadow on the ground to the right of his left foot. Light lines left of the figure's chest, right of his back, and around his right leg indicate alternative, but rejected, positions for his body.
Two small steps in the lower left corner of the design represent the entrance to the home of the "liberal Man" (see Blake's text, Object 86) into which he invites the traveler.
A gentle mound or hill rises in the background.
The ground on which the traveler and his host stand seems to be covered with grass, as is the hill in the background. A hedge of bushes or small trees appears above the hill on the right.
Wash above the hill and hedge suggests the sky, perhaps streaked with clouds.

desc.objtitle: Ode for Music; Page 1: Title-Page, Object 93 (Butlin 335.93)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The personified figure of "Fame" (see Blake's text, Object 94) as an angel fills most of this design. She flies or hovers on the right of the text box, facing forward and holding her arms out wide at 135 degrees. She holds a trumpet in each upraised hand, although her left hand partly extends beyond the edge of the design; the instrument in this hand is similarly only partly visible. Her right leg is down, with her foot on tiptoe, but she holds her left leg back and to the left. Her large wings are spread on either side of her body, and a pair of eyes and ears, one on each wing, appear above her head. A long gown drapes her figure, revealing as much as it conceals though its trailing skirt hides her left foot. This garment has a belt or high waistline from which folds of fabric or ribbon drape in graceful loops. Fame's long hair falls past her shoulders and ripples behind her to the left of her feet. Her eyes are raised and her mouth is open. A star glimmers above her head, between her wings. Other stars stud the dark night sky. One shoots up from the lower left corner of the design towards the lower left corner of the text box, leaving a wake of light in its path. The buildings and walls of Cambridge appear along the bottom of the design.

component.illusobjdesc: The personified figure of "Fame" (see Blake's text, Object 94) as an angel fills most of this design. She flies or hovers on the right of the text box, facing forward and holding her arms out wide at 135 degrees. Her left arm may be slightly bent. She holds a trumpet in each upraised hand, although her left hand partly extends beyond the edge of the design; the instrument in this hand is similarly only partly visible. Her right leg is down, with her foot on tiptoe, but she holds her left leg back and to the left. Her large wings are spread on either side of her body, and a pair of eyes and ears, one on each wing, appear above her head. A long gown drapes her figure, revealing as much as it conceals though its trailing skirt hides her left foot. This garment has a belt or high waistline from which folds of fabric or ribbon drape in graceful loops. Fame's long hair falls past her shoulders and ripples behind her to the left of her feet. Her eyes are raised and her mouth is open. Her head may be tilted slightly back. A star glimmers above her head, between her wings.
The buildings and walls of Cambridge, including spires, domes, and a pyramid, appear along the bottom of the design. There may be a cross at the top of the leftmost spire.

Fame hovers in a dark night sky. Stars like the one over Fame's head stud its depths. One star or comet shoots up from the lower left corner of the design towards the lower left corner of the text box, leaving a wake of light in its path.

desc.objtitle: Ode for Music; Page 2: Blank Page Bearing List of Titles, Object 94 (Butlin 335.94)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A slender leafless vine rises from the lower right corner of the design, curves across the design, and spirals up past the left side of the text box. It curls back to the right over the top of the text box and ends in a thin tendril to the right of the box. Along the way it forms six loops. A bird perches on the vine beneath the text box. It tilts its head back, beak wide open in song. Its tongue protrudes from its mouth.

component.illusobjdesc: A slender leafless vine rises from the lower right corner of the design, curves across the design, and spirals up past the left side of the text box. It curls back to the right over the top of the text box and ends in a thin tendril to the right of the box. Along the way it forms six loops.
A bird perches on the vine beneath the text box. It tilts its head back, beak wide open in song. Its tongue protrudes from its open mouth.

lg.l: Ode for Music.
1. Fame.
2. A bird singing
3. A Genius driving away "Comus & hisThe words in quotation marks in lines 5-6 are quoted, with minor variations, from page [135] of the letterpress text (Object 95).
midnight crew"

4.Milton struck the corded ShellLines 7-8 are quoted, with "deep-ton'd" in the letterpress text change to "corded" in line 7 and with minor variations, from pages 136-37 of the letterpress text (Objects 96-97).
Newtons self bends from his State Sublime

5. "I wood the gleam of Cynthia silver brightLines 9-10 are quoted, with the first word in line 9 changed from "Oft" in the letterpress text to "I" and with minor variations, from page 137 of the letterpress text (Object 97).
Where willowy Camus lingers with delight"

6. "Great Edward with the lillies on his browLines 11-12 are quoted, with "their Fitzroy's" in the letterpress text changed to "the" in line 12 and with minor variations, from page 138 of the letterpress text (Object 98).
To hail the festal morning come"
7. "Leaning from her golden cloudLines 13-14 are quoted, with minor variations, from page 139 of the letterpress text (Object 99).
The venerable Margaret"
8. "The Laureate wreathe"The line is quoted from page 140 of the letterpress text (Object 100).
9. "Nor fear the rocks nor seek the shore"The line is quoted from page 141 of the letterpress text (Object 101).
10. Fame.

desc.objtitle: Ode for Music; Page 3: Beginning of Poem, Object 95 (Butlin 335.95)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 3 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: "A Genius" dispels "Comus & his midnight crew" (see Blake's text, Object 94), the latter huddled near the lower right corner of the design. The Genius stands on higher ground to the left, his body largely hidden by the text box. He faces forward and to the right, and seems to bend forward slightly with slightly lowered head. He holds both arms out straight, the right raised at 135 degrees and drawn back, the left at 45 degrees and drawn forward. With his right he holds what may be flames or a stack of lightning bolts like the jagged bolts that appear to either side of his body. He holds his left hand out flat, palm down. He may have just cast the bolt to the right with his extended left hand. His long curly hair flies wildly behind him. He wears a long gown that trails on the ground. His right foot is visible emerging from beneath it. The foremost figure in the "midnight crew" below is the personification of Servitude as a woman whose legs are becoming a scaly demon's tail (see the letterpress text for this figure and the others identified here). A weighty chain loops her twisted body. At her feet lies the female figure of Flattery, whose body curls into a "serpent-train" (see the letterpress text) partly visible through Servitude's tail. Her face is made up garishly. A serpent's head replaces her right hand. The remaining two figures are not easily identified. To the right of Servitude may be the upper body and head of Ignorance, whose body faces right but whose face is turned up to the left, mouth open. His short hair is curly. Below him may be the head and shoulders of a personification of Sloth, facing up. Comus himself does not appear to be pictured. Flattery, Sloth, and Ignorance all seem to be wrapped in cloth-like garments, as is Servitude's upper body. The ground at the bottom of the design rises gently from right to left, into a slight hill. It appears to be covered with grass. The sky above the hill is mostly dark, perhaps with clouds or night. A particularly dark shadow appears behind the Genius. Another dark shadow falls on the ground near the lower left corner of the design. Lightning bolts appear left and right of the text panel.

component.illusobjdesc: "A Genius" dispels "Comus & his midnight crew" (see Blake's text, Object 94), the latter huddled near the lower right corner of the design. The Genius stands on higher ground to the left, his body largely hidden by the text box. He faces forward and to the right, and seems to bend forward slightly with slightly lowered head. He holds both arms out straight, the right raised at 135 degrees and drawn back, the left at 45 degrees and drawn forward. With his right he holds what may be flames or a stack of lightning bolts like the jagged bolts that appear to either side of his body. He holds his left hand out flat, palm down. He may have just cast the bolt to the right with his extended left hand. His long curly hair flies wildly behind him. He wears a long gown that trails on the ground. His right foot is visible emerging from beneath it.

The foremost figure among "Comus & his midnight crew" (see Blake's text, Object 94) in the lower right corner is the personification of Servitude (see the letterpress text for this figure and the others identified here). She is a woman whose body faces forward and to the right, though she bends her head back and twists it up to the left. Her legs are blending together below the waist into a scaly demon tail, which curves up to the left and back down again into a spiral loop. Her tail ends in an arrow or spear point. Her arms are raised in front of her torso and bent up. The sleeves of the shirt she wears seems to hide her hands. Alternatively, her upper body may be wrapped with cloth. A weighty chain emerges from between her wrists and loops around her back. A segment of chain is visible to the right of her tail as well. Her hair is long and flies in jagged shapes around and behind her torso. At her feet appears the female figure of Flattery, who lies prone along the ground.
