Her body curls into a "serpent-train" (see the letterpress text) partly visible through Servitude's tail. She turns her head, which extends out to the right, to the left. Her face is made up garishly. Her extended right arm rests on the ground beneath her head; she may be partly resting her head on this arm. Her right hand is a serpent's head facing away. She seems to be wrapped in cloth or a similarly draped garment. Her hair is short, or long and swept back behind her head. The remaining two figures are not easily identified. Above Flattery may be the head and shoulders of Sloth, extended out towards the viewer. Sloth's face is seen from above, turned up to the left. He is bald except for the suggestion of wispy hair above his temples. Above him may be Ignorance, his body facing right and his head raised to look forward and to the left. Ignorance's mouth is open and his eyes are raised. He has short, curly hair. Both he and Sloth are wrapped in cloth below the neck. Pencil lines around the figures indicate different, but rejected, positions for them. Comus himself does not seem to be pictured.
The ground at the bottom of the design rises gently from right to left, into a slight hill. It appears to be covered with grass.

The sky above the hill is mostly dark, perhaps with clouds or night. A particularly dark shadow appears behind the Genius. Another dark shadow falls on the ground near the lower left corner of the design. Lightning bolts appear left and right of the text panel.

desc.objtitle: Ode for Music: Page 4, Object 96 (Butlin 335.96)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 18 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Newton's head and shoulders appear above the text box, as if he rests on or within the puffy cloud that fills the sky in this design (see "Newtons," Blake's text, Object 94). The sky seems to be a daytime one, but it nevertheless boasts four stars. Newton faces forward, turning his head slightly left. His right elbow is propped on the cloud, slightly away from his body, and his lower arm is bent up. He rests his chin on his raised right hand and lowers his eyes slightly. He has short curly hair and wears a gown or robe with a decorative border at the hem of his sleeve. "Milton" (see Blake's text, Object 94) sits in a chair below and to the left of the text box. He faces forward. Both of his legs are bent; his right leg is forward and his left leg is drawn back and to the side. His left foot may be on tiptoe. Milton's lyre, a "deep-ton'd shell" (see the letterpress text), rests on his lowered left knee. The poet supports the instrument with his left arm: his left elbow is visible just to the right of the shell and his upper arm is bent upward behind and to the right side of the instrument. His right elbow is forward, resting on his right leg, and his right lower arm is bent up across his torso. He plays the strings of the lyre with his right hand. His head is inclined and turned slightly to the right but his eyes are raised. He has flowing long locks of hair and wears a robe or gown. The lower frame of the lyre is in the shape of a shell. The arms and the right front leg of the chair in which Milton sits are visible. To the left of Milton's chair a vine grows up beside the left edge of the design. It forms a loop to the left of Milton's shoulder. On the right side of Milton's chair grow two flowers. A sunflower is rooted near his left foot, bearing a single flower and three leaves. Near the right side of the design grows a lily, its slender stem curving left over the top of the sunflower plant. The lily bears a single blossom, which hangs facing downward to the left of the sunflower. Three leaves grow from the ground where the lily is rooted. A fourth appendage may be a dead leaf or a truncated stem. The ground below Milton is covered with grass.

component.illusobjdesc: Newton's head and shoulders appear above the text box, as if he rests on or within the puffy cloud that fills the sky in this design (see "Newtons," Blake's text, Object 94). Newton faces forward, turning his head slightly left. His right elbow is propped on the cloud, slightly away from his body, and his lower arm is bent up. He rests his chin on his raised right hand and lowers his eyes slightly. He has short curly hair, and wears a gown or robe with a decorative border at the hem of his sleeve.

"Milton" (see Blake's text, Object 94) sits in a chair below and to the left of the text box. He faces forward. Both of his legs are bent; his right leg is forward and his left leg is drawn back and to the side. His left foot may be on tiptoe. Milton's lyre, a "deep-ton'd shell" (see the letterpress text), rests on his lowered left knee. The poet supports the instrument with his left arm: his left elbow is visible just to the right of the shell and his upper arm is bent upward behind and to the right side of the instrument. His right elbow is forward, resting on his right leg, and his right lower arm is bent up across his torso. He plays the strings of the lyre with his right hand. His head is inclined and turned slightly to the right but his eyes are raised. He has flowing long locks of hair and wears a robe or gown. The lower frame of the lyre is in the shape of a shell. The arms and the right front leg of the chair in which Milton sits are visible. Shadows appear on the ground to the right of his left foot and near the right foot of his chair.

To the left of Milton's chair a vine grows up beside the left edge of the design. It forms a loop to the left of Milton's shoulder. On the right side of Milton's chair grow two flowers. A sunflower is rooted near his left foot, bearing a single flower and three leaves. Near the right side of the design grows a lily, its slender stem curving left over the top of the sunflower plant. The lily bears a single blossom, which hangs facing downward to the left of the sunflower. Three leaves grow from the ground where the lily is rooted. A fourth appendage may be a dead leaf or a truncated stem. The ground below Milton is covered with grass.
Newton's upper body rests above a large puffy cloud that fills much of the design. It floats in a daytime sky that nevertheless boasts four stars.

desc.objtitle: Ode for Music: Page 5, Object 97 (Butlin 335.97)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 9 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The poet Milton stands or walks beside the river Cam, which glides across the bottom of the design (see "Camus" in the letterpress text here and "Camus," Blake's text, Object 94). He faces forward and slightly right, with his head lowered. His arms are crossed over his chest, right over left, and his hands are hidden within the sleeves of the robe he wears. His posture and expression suggest "Melancholy" (see the letterpress text). Two large trees are rooted on the bank of the river. Their trunks rise to either side of Milton. The tree on the right grows up past the right side of the design, sending large leafless branches up into the right corner. The bare roots of the second tree clutch the edge of the bank and dangle in the water below. The tree's trunk leans to the left. Its bare branches fill the top left corner of the design. Each tree sends a branch diagonally into the middle of the design; they cross above the text box to form a pointed, Gothic-style arch over the scene, which echoes the Gothic architecture of the building in the distance. It represents the buildings of the University of Cambridge in the distance. The central, highest spire is surmounted with a cross. A line of smaller trees crosses the design in the middle ground, behind the figure of Milton but before the spire. Their trunks support leafy foliage. Dark shadow fills the spaces between their trunks. Grass covers the bank where Milton walks, though bare earth is visible at the edge. Wash beneath the arching tree branches and over the text box, and also beneath the tree branches at the right side of the design, suggests the nighttime sky. A crescent moon appears in the sky above the text box.

component.illusobjdesc: The poet Milton stands or walks beside the river Cam, to the right of the text box. He faces forward and slightly right, with his head lowered. His arms are crossed over his chest, right over left, and his hands are hidden within the sleeves of the robe he wears. The shape of this garment indicates that his right knee is bent forward slightly and he may be in a contrapposto position. His feet, clad in shoes, are visible beneath its hem. His right foot is on tiptoe. He has short curly hair. His eyes are lowered or closed; his mouth may be open. The robe's large collar muffles his neck. His posture and expression suggest "Melancholy" (see the letterpress text).
The river Cam and its bank run across the bottom of the design (see "Camus" in the letterpress text here and "Camus," Blake's text, Object 94).

Two large trees are rooted on the bank of the river. Their trunks rise to either side of Milton. The tree on the right grows up past the right side of the design, sending large leafless branches up into the right corner. The bare roots of the second tree clutch the edge of the bank and dangle in the water below. This tree's trunk leans to the left. Its bare branches fill the top left corner of the design. Each tree sends a branch diagonally into the middle of the design; they cross above the text box to form a pointed, Gothic-style arch over the scene, which echoes the Gothic architecture of the spire in the distance. A line of smaller trees crosses the design in the middle ground, behind the figure of Milton but before the spire. Their trunks support leafy foliage. Dark shadow fills the spaces between their trunks. Grass covers the bank where Milton walks, though bare earth is visible at the edge.

A building with Gothic spires rises above the trees and represents the buildings of the University of Cambridge in the distance. The highest, central spire is surmounted with a cross. Vertical pencil lines left of the highest spire may indicate a different, but rejected, position for it.

Wash beneath the arching tree branches and over the text box, and also beneath the tree branches at the right side of the design, suggests the nighttime sky. A crescent moon appears in the sky above the text box.

desc.objtitle: Ode for Music: Page 6, Object 98 (Butlin 335.98)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 2 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: King Edward the Third, probably Margaret of Anjou (wife of Henry the Sixth), and a third figure who may be King Henry the Sixth seem to hover in mid-air in this design (see the letterpress text here and Blake's text, Object 94). Edward the Third, partly hidden by the text panel, faces forward and slightly to the left. He holds his arms out at 45 degrees on either side of his body; his hands are out with palms down. Lily blossoms tumble down from his open hands. Semi-circular lines below and to the left of his left hand suggest the sweeping motion he has just made with this limb as he casts the flowers. His legs are bent and extend downward at an angle towards the lower left corner of the design, giving the impression that he leans to the right. His right leg may be bent slightly more than his left, as his right foot seems farther back. He may bend forward slightly at the waist, or his legs may be drawn up slightly. His head is turned to the left so that his face is seen in three-quarters profile. He has long hair and a long beard that covers most of his torso, although the text box hides part of both beard and body. A wreath of lilies and leaves circles his head like a crown, and frames his face. Lines at his wrists suggest that he is wearing a shirt, but whatever garment may clothe his lower body is difficult to distinguish; he may wear tights. Margaret of Anjou's head and shoulders appear to the right of Edward's left shoulder. Her shoulders face forward and to the right; she turns her head forward and cuts her eyes to the left. Her torso and lower body, just visible to the right of Edward's body, extend diagonally down towards the lower left corner of the design. She raises her left arm up; her upper arm is lifted at 135 degrees and her lower arm is bent to vertical. Her left hand extends beyond the edge of the design. A spiky crown boasting small jewels rests on her head. Her long hair appears to be drawn back at the nape of her neck, from where it flows past her right shoulder. She wears a gown with a flowing skirt; its folds may appear between and to the right of Edward's feet. The head and upper body of a man at the left side of the design may be Henry the Sixth. His torso faces forward and perhaps slightly left, while he turns his head slightly right. His right arm is by his side and bent across his chest, supporting a large "Holy Bible" (see the Textual Transcription). The fingers of his left hand, visible just to the left of Richard's right hand, hold the book from below. Henry the Sixth wears a shirt and pleated breeches or perhaps a gown, with folds of fabric visible just below his lower right arm. He is bearded and a wreath of laurels sits on his short curly hair. A faint, indistinct face is partially visible to the left of Henry the Sixth's head. The face seems to have long hair and may be female. She looks forward and to the left. She is hidden below the nose. Her left shoulder may be just visible over Henry's left shoulder. She may be "Chatillon," the Countess of Pembroke (see the letterpress text). Wash surrounding the figures suggests the sky, perhaps at sunrise or sunset. The figures themselves are largely in shadow. Particularly dark shadows appear below Edward's right arm, to the left of his right hand, below the text box, and to the right of Margaret of Anjou.

component.illusobjdesc: Edward The Third, partly hidden by the text panel, faces forward and slightly to the left (see the letterpress text here and Blake's text, Object 94). He holds his arms out at 45 degrees on either side of his body; his hands are out with palms down. Lily blossoms tumble down from his open hands. Semi-circular lines below and to the left of his left hand suggest the sweeping motion he has just made with this limb as he casts the flowers. His legs are bent and extend downward at an angle towards the lower left corner of the design, giving the impression that he leans to the right. His right leg may be bent slightly more than his left, as his right foot seems farther back. He may bend forward slightly at the waist, or his legs may be drawn up slightly. His head is turned to the left so that his face is seen in three-quarters profile. He has long hair and a long beard that covers most of his torso, although the text box hides part of both beard and body. A wreath of lilies and leaves circles his head like a crown, and frames his face. Lines at his wrists suggest that he is wearing a shirt, but whatever garment may clothe his lower body is difficult to distinguish: he may wear tights.

The head and shoulders, probably of Margaret of Anjou, the wife of Henry the Sixth, appear to the right of Edward's left shoulder (see Blake's text, Object 94). Her shoulders face forward and to the right; she turns her head forward and cuts her eyes to the left. Her torso and lower body, just visible to the right of Edward's body, extend diagonally down towards the lower left corner of the design. She raises her left arm up; her upper arm is lifted at 135 degrees and her lower arm is bent to vertical. Her left hand extends beyond the edge of the design. A spiky crown boasting small jewels rests on her head. Her long hair appears to be drawn back at the nape of her neck, from where it flows past her right shoulder. She wears a gown with a flowing skirt; its folds may appear between and to the right of Edward's feet.

The head and upper body of a man at the left side of the design may be Henry the Sixth. His torso faces forward and perhaps slightly left, while he turns his head slightly right. His right arm is by his side and bent across his chest, supporting a large "Holy Bible" (see the textual transcription). The fingers of his left hand, visible just to the left of Richard's right hand, hold the book from below. Henry wears a shirt and pleated breeches or perhaps a gown, with folds of fabric visible just below his lower right arm. He is bearded and a wreath of laurels sits on his short curly hair.

A faint, indistinct face is partially visible to the left of Henry the Sixth's head. The melancholy(?) face seems to have long hair and may be female. She looks forward and to the left. She is hidden below the nose. Her left shoulder may be just visible over Henry's left shoulder. She may be "Chatillon," the Countess of Pembroke, who "wept her bleeding Love" on her "bridal morn" (see the letterpress text.

Wash surrounding the figures suggests the sky, perhaps at sunrise or sunset. The figures themselves are largely in shadow. Particularly dark shadows appear below Edward's right arm, to the left of his right hand, below the text box, and to the right of Margaret of Anjou. There may be a diagonal beam of light lower right.

lg.l: HolyThis and the following line of text are inscribed on the cover of the book held by the second figure from the left.
BIBLThe final letter of "BIBLE" is covered by the arm of the man to the right of this text

desc.objtitle: Ode for Music: Page 7, Object 99 (Butlin 335.99)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 12 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The Countess of Richmond and Derby "lean[s] from her golden cloud" to greet a new student at Cambridge (see the letterpress text here and Blake's text, Object 94). The Countess founded St. John's and Christ's Colleges at the university. Here her torso indeed appears above a golden cloud at the right of the text box. She leans forward and to the right. Her head may be lowered slightly, and she looks at the young man below her with a somber expression on her face. Her right hand is raised before her and she holds up two fingers. She wears a scarf draped over her head and shoulders, and what seems to be a gown beneath. The edges of her hair are just visible around her face, though it is impossible to tell whether her locks are long or short. Wash around the fluffy golden cloud and the figures suggests the sky, perhaps with additional clouds. A young man wearing the black robe of a university student stands in the lower right corner of the design, facing left. His head is on a level with the Countess' shoulders, and he tilts his head back to look up at her face. He stands with his weight on his right foot; his slightly bent left leg is extended backwards and his left foot is on tiptoe. His left arm is bent up across his torso and his open left hand is raised, palm facing away. He has short curly hair and wears shoes and a shirt and pants beneath his wide-collared robe.

component.characteristic: Margaret, Countess of Richmond and Derby
component.illusobjdesc: The Countess of Richmond and Derby "lean[s] from her golden cloud" to greet a new student at Cambridge (see the letterpress text here and Blake's text, Object 94). The Countess founded St. John's and Christ's Colleges at the university. Here her torso indeed appears above a golden cloud at the right of the text box. She leans forward and to the right. Her head may be lowered slightly, and she looks at the young man below her with a somber expression on her face. Her right hand is raised before her and she holds up two spread fingers. She wears a scarf draped over her head and shoulders, and what seems to be a gown beneath. The edges of her hair are just visible around her face, though it is impossible to tell whether her locks are long or short.
The Countess' fluffy golden cloud is partially hidden behind the text box. Wash around it and the figures suggests the sky, perhaps with additional clouds.

A young man wearing the black robe of a university student stands in the lower right corner of the design, facing left. His head is on a level with the Countess' shoulders, and he tilts his head back to look up at her face. He stands with his weight on his right foot; his slightly bent left leg is extended backwards and his left foot is on tiptoe. His left arm is bent up across his torso and his open left hand is raised, palm facing away. He has short curly hair, and wears shoes and a shirt and pants beneath his wide-collared robe.

desc.objtitle: Ode for Music: Page 8, Object 100 (Butlin 335.100)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 15 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Granta, a female symbol of Cambridge, stands at the left side of the design and faces right. She crowns "Augustus-Henry Fitzroy, Duke of Grafton" (see the letterpress text, Object 93) with a laurel wreath that signifies his new position as Chancellor (see "Granta" in the letterpress text). Her right arm is extended before her to the right at 135 degrees and with this hand she holds the wreath over Grafton's head. Ribbon in a bow ties the laurel branches together at the right side of the wreath. Granta wears a long gown with a belt or clearly defined waistline. It puddles slightly on the ground but her right foot emerges from beneath its hem. She wears her own wreath of laurels over long curly hair that falls down her back. This wreath may circle her head over a crown, visible above its leaves. The Duke stands at the right side of the design, facing left. His head is bent to receive the laurel wreath that Granta holds above. His left arm is bent up and his left hand rests on his chest. He wears a long-sleeved shirt beneath his black university robe. This shirt seems to have a high collar; alternatively this may be a ribbon or necktie. Shoes are on his feet. The ground on which Granta and the Duke stand seems to be bare earth. Granta casts a small shadow on the ground to her left. Faint shadows also appear between and below the Duke's feet. Wash between and around the figures suggests the sky, perhaps with clouds.

component.illusobjdesc: Granta, a female symbol of Cambridge, stands at the left side of the design and faces right. She crowns "Augustus-Henry Fitzroy, Duke of Grafton" (see the letterpress text, Object 93) with a laurel wreath that signifies his new position as Chancellor (see "Granta" in the letterpress text). Her right arm is extended before her to the right at 135 degrees and with this hand she holds the wreath over Grafton's head. Ribbon in a bow ties the laurel branches together at the right side of the wreath. Granta wears a long gown with a belt or clearly defined waistline. It puddles slightly on the ground but her right foot emerges from beneath its hem. She wears her own wreath of laurels over long curly hair that falls down her back. This wreath may circle her head over a crown, visible above its leaves.

"Augustus-Henry Fitzroy, Duke of Grafton" (see the letterpress text, Object 93) stands at the right side of the design, facing left. His head is bent to receive the laurel wreath that Granta holds above. His left arm is bent up and his left hand rests on his chest. He wears a long-sleeved shirt beneath his black university robe. This shirt seems to have a high collar; alternatively this may be a ribbon or necktie. Shoes are on his feet.
The ground on which Granta and the Duke stand seems to be bare earth. Granta casts a small shadow on the ground to her left. Faint shadows also appear between and below the Duke's feet.
Wash between and around the figures suggests the sky, perhaps with clouds.

desc.objtitle: Ode for Music: Page 9, Object 101 (Butlin 335.101)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 9 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: "Augustus-Henry Fitzroy, Duke of Grafton" (see the letterpress text, Object 93), the new Chancellor of Cambridge, steers a boat "Thro' the wild waves as they roar" (see the letterpress text). He is visible from the waist up, facing left. His left arm is down but bent and drawn back; the fingers of his left hand rest on the boat's tiller. His left elbow may be braced or propped against the boat's stern. He wears a shirt and has short, slightly curly hair. His mouth is open slightly and he tilts his head back slightly to look up. The stern half of the boat and its large rudder are visible cutting through the choppy white waves of the water that flows across the bottom of the design. The craft extends beyond the left edge of the design. Its sail rises up the left side to the top left corner of the design. Two pennants fly diagonally rightward from this corner. The "star of Brunswick" (see the letterpress text) shines between the ship's pennants and the text box. The star is the only bright spot in a sky dark with night or storm clouds.

component.illusobjdesc: "Augustus-Henry Fitzroy, Duke of Grafton" (see the letterpress text, Object 93), the new Chancellor of Cambridge, steers a boat "Thro' the wild waves as they roar" (see the letterpress text). He is visible from the waist up, facing left. His left arm is down but bent and drawn back; the fingers of his left hand rest on the ship's tiller. His left elbow may be braced or propped against the ship's stern. He wears a shirt and has short, slightly curly hair. His mouth is open slightly and he tilts his head back slightly to look up.

The stern half of the boat and it large rudder is visible cutting through the choppy white waves of the water that flows across the bottom of the design. The craft extends beyond the left edge of the design. Its sail rises up the left side to the top left corner of the design. Two pennants fly diagonally rightward from this corner.
The "star of Brunswick" (see the letterpress text) shines between the ship's pennants and the text box. The star is the only bright spot in a sky dark with night or storm clouds.

desc.objtitle: Ode for Music; Page 10: Blank Page Bearing List of Titles, Object 102 (Butlin 335.102)

illustration.illusobjdesc: "Fame" (see Blake's text, Object 94), a graceful winged angel, fills much of this design. A female figure, she flies or hovers facing forward and slightly to the left. She bends backwards and to the right at the waist and her legs bend to the right, so that her body forms a gentle curve. Her slightly bent arms are raised vertically overhead; her neck is bent back sharply so that her face looks up and is not visible to the viewer. She holds a horn or trumpet to her mouth as if she is playing it. Her hands rest on the instrument near the top of the design. Her left leg is gently bent and her left foot may be on tiptoe. Her right leg is hidden below the knee. Her enormous wings are spread wide on either side of her body. Her hair is short or drawn back. She wears a gown with skirts that drape her figure closely and fly to the right of her foot. This garment has a decorative belt with indistinct shapes that may be tiny figures or leaves. Larger, but still sketchily drawn figures appear on her skirt. At least three of these figures stand next to each other with arms raised at 135 degrees and hands clasped. Sketched shapes below the standing figures on her left leg may be seated figures, some with arms raised.

component.illusobjdesc: "Fame" (see Blake's text, Object 94), a graceful winged angel, fills much of this design. A female figure, she flies or hovers facing forward and slightly to the left. She bends backwards and to the right at the waist and her legs bend to the right, so that her body forms a gentle curve. Her slightly bent arms are raised vertically overhead; her neck is bent back sharply so that her face looks up and is not visible to the viewer. She holds a horn or trumpet to her mouth as if she is playing it. Her hands rest on the instrument near the top of the design. Her left leg is gently bent and her left foot may be on tiptoe. Her right leg is hidden below the knee. Her enormous wings are spread wide on either side of her body. Her hair is short or drawn back. She wears a gown with skirts that drape her figure closely and fly to the right of her foot. This garment has a decorative belt with indistinct shapes that may be tiny figures or leaves. Larger, but still sketchily drawn figures appear on her skirt. At least three of these figures stand next to each other with arms raised at 135 degrees and hands clasped. Sketched shapes below the standing figures on her left leg may be seated figures, some with arms raised. Light pencil lines left and right of her lower legs suggest alternative, but rejected, positions for them.

lg.l: Epitaph
1. The mourner at the tomb
2. Her infant image here belowLines 4-5 are quoted, with minor variations, from page 146 of the letterpress text (Object 104).
Sits smiling on a Fathers woe

desc.objtitle: Epitaph on Mrs. Clarke; Page 1: Beginning of Poem, Object 103 (Butlin 335.103)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A large stone or marble monument fills most of this design and represents a "tomb" (see Blake's text, Object 102). A large urn or covered bowl sits atop the monument. The urn is decorated with small human figures of indeterminate gender, delineated indistinctly. "The mourner at the tomb" (see Blake's text, Object 102) stands at the right side of the tomb, facing left. He may be the husband of "Mrs. Clarke" (see the letterpress text). He bows his head. A long cloak draped over his shoulders covers his body almost entirely, falling to touch the ground behind him. His left foot is visible below its hem. His left arm also emerges from the cloak, bent up before his torso with lower left arm and left hand resting gently against his chest. The spaces around the tomb and the mourner are dark with shadow or night. There may be tall, slender trees vaguely indicated left and right of the tomb.

component.illusobjdesc: A large stone or marble monument fills most of this design and represents a "tomb" (see Blake's text, Object 102). A large urn or covered bowl sits atop the tomb. The urn is decorated with small human figures of indeterminate gender, delineated indistinctly. One of these figures, on the right, reclines or perhaps hovers in air with arms spread wide and raised just above the horizontal and lower body curving leftward. On the left a second figure sits or perhaps hovers with legs extended to the right and bent arms at its sides. One of this figure's arms, on the right, may be bent up with hand raised to the face. A third figure is suggested to the right of the second, with body extending rightward. The lower reaches of the monument constitute a plinth.

"The mourner at the tomb" (see Blake's text, Object 102) stands at the right side of the tomb, facing left. He may be the husband of "Mrs. Clarke" (see the letterpress text). He bows his head. A long cloak draped over his shoulders covers his body almost entirely, falling to touch the ground behind him. His left foot is visible below its hem. His left arm also emerges from the cloak, bent up before his torso with lower left arm and left hand resting gently against his chest. His hair is short.
The spaces around the tomb and the mourner are dark with shadow or night.
There may be vague suggestions of tall, slender trees left and right of the tomb.

desc.objtitle: Epitaph on Mrs. Clarke: Page 2, Object 104 (Butlin 335.104)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 2 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The grieving husband of "Mrs. Clarke" (see the letterpress text, Object 103) sits in a chair before his hearth, facing right. His right leg is bent and crossed over his bent left leg. He bends his head and looks down at his daughter, who is seated on the floor below him to the right. His entire body is enveloped in a cloak or blanket that covers him from neck to ankles. The shape of the fabric suggests that his arms are by his side but bent up at the elbows so his lower arms cross his chest; his left hand rests on and perhaps holds the right. He wears shoes and has long hair that may be plaited behind his head. The right arm and legs of his armchair are visible. Mrs. Clarke's daughter sits on the floor before the hearth with an open book on her lap. She faces forward and to the right, her legs bent and the book spread on her knees. Her left hand is down by her side, bent forward with her lower left arm supporting the book and her left hand holding its corner. Her right arm is likewise by her side but bent; her right hand rests on her knee and holds the edge of the book. She tilts her head and turns it to the left to look up with raised eyes at her father. Her long curly hair is loose over her shoulders. She wears a long gown with skirts that sweep left on the floor. A large, ornate fireplace appears at the right side of the design. Scrollwork decorates the fireplace surround (which includes pictures of a few human figures) and the panel above the mantel. A low fender separates the hearth from the rest of the floor. A grate with glowing coals or embers appears within the fireplace. Two fire implements rest against the side of the fireplace. On the mantel shelf rest three objects: a small statue and two small obelisks. Like the obelisks, the statue is depicted only sketchily, but it appears to be of a standing human figure facing forward. The room in which father and daughter sit is otherwise stark and bare. The floor appears to be made of stone. Shadows fill the spaces above the father and daughter and around the text panel. The father's chair casts a particularly dark shadow on the floor below and behind him. Diagonal lines across the design from top edge to left edge suggest a curtain or similar drapery.

component.illusobjdesc: The grieving husband of "Mrs. Clarke" (see the letterpress text, Object 103) sits in a chair before his hearth, facing right. His right leg is bent and crossed over his bent left leg. He bends his head and looks down at his daughter, who is seated on the floor below him to the right. His entire body is enveloped in a cloak or blanket that covers him from neck to ankles. The shape of the fabric suggests that his arms are by his side but bent up at the elbows so his lower arms cross his chest; his left hand rests on and perhaps holds the right. He wears shoes and has long hair that may be plaited behind his head. The right arm and legs of his armchair are visible.

Mrs. Clarke's daughter sits on the floor before the hearth with an open book on her lap. She faces forward and to the right, her legs bent and the book spread on her knees. Her left hand is down by her side, bent forward with her lower left arm supporting the book and her left hand holding its corner. Her right arm is likewise by her side but bent; her right hand rests on her knee and holds the edge of the book. She tilts her head and turns it to the left to look up with raised eyes at her father. She smiles slightly. Her long curly hair is loose over her shoulders. She wears a long gown with skirts that sweep left on the floor.

A large, ornate fireplace appears at the right side of the design. A grate with glowing coals or embers appears within the fireplace. Scrollwork decorates the fireplace surround and the panel above the mantel. This decoration includes the picture of a seated figure in a circle at the top left corner of the surround. The figure hunches over, facing right. The decoration below the mantle would seem to include vague indications of other human figures. The one furthest left may be floating, facing forward, with arms raised horizontally. A low fender separates the hearth from the rest of the floor. Two fire implements rest against the side of the fireplace. One looks like a shovel, the other a bit like an oversize ladle. On the mantel shelf rest three objects: a small statue and two small obelisks. Like the obelisks, the statue is depicted only sketchily, but it appears to be of a standing human figure facing forward.

The room in which the father and daughter sit is otherwise stark and bare. The floor appears to be made of stone. Shadows fill the spaces above the father and daughter and around the text panel. The father's chair casts a particularly dark shadow on the floor below and behind him. Diagonal lines across the design from top edge to left edge suggest a curtain or similar drapery.

desc.objtitle: Elegy Written in a Country Church-Yard; Page 1: Title-Page, Object 105 (Butlin 335.105)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The poet Thomas Gray is shown, in the lower left corner of the design, sitting on a bench or plinth inside a church (see "The author," Blake's text, Object 106). He is seated facing right, hunched over the work that lies on his lap. The surface on which he writes is thin but stiff, as if it is a notebook or easel. His right arm is down, bent at the elbow so that his lower arm lies along his leg and his writing surface. He holds a pen in this hand, which is raised slightly from the writing surface. His head is bent down and turned slightly forward; his face is visible in three-quarters profile. He wears a robe or gown that pools on the floor at his feet. A cloak drapes over his back, left shoulder, and the left side of his head. Its fabric falls past the left side of his face. The stone interior of the church is decorated in a Gothic style. The church's hooded pulpit is partly visible near the right side of the design. Purple liturgical hangings decorate its second platform. Behind and to the right of the poet a Gothic arch surmounts a wall with an entry further into the church on the right. One or two steps appear at the foot of this entry. Pillars at the left side of the design support nearer arches overhead. Additional pillars appear to the left of the pulpit. Boxes of pews, probably made of wood, appear below the pulpit.

component.illusobjdesc: The poet Thomas Gray is shown, in the lower left corner of the design, sitting on a bench or plinth inside a church (see "The author," Blake's text, Object 106). He is seated facing right, hunched over the work that lies on his lap. The surface on which he writes is thin but stiff, as if it is a notebook or easel. His right arm is down, bent at the elbow so that his lower arm lies along his leg and his writing surface. He holds a pen in this hand, which is raised slightly from the writing surface. His head is bent down and turned slightly forward; his face is visible in three-quarters profile. He wears a robe or gown that pools on the floor at his feet. A cloak drapes over his back, left shoulder, and the left side of his head. Its fabric falls past the left side of his face. His hair is short, or long and swept back beneath the cloak. Lines across his bent neck suggest that he wears a high collar or necktie.

The church's hooded pulpit is partly visible near the right side of the design. Purple liturgical hangings decorate its second platform. The boxes of pews, probably made of wood, appear below the pulpit.

The stone interior of the church is decorated in a Gothic style. Behind and to the right of the poet a Gothic arch surmounts a wall with an entry further into the church on the right. One or two steps appear at the foot of this entry. Pillars at the left side of the design support nearer arches overhead. Additional pillars appear to the left of the pulpit.

desc.objtitle: Elegy Written in a Country Church-Yard; Page 2: Blank Page Bearing List of Titles, Object 106 (Butlin 335.106)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The poet Thomas Gray walks through the graveyard of the church. He is shown facing forward beneath a tree at the left side of the design. He steps forward with his left foot and turns his head slightly to the right, raising his eyes. His head may be tilted back slightly as well. His arms are by his side and folded over his chest, with his right hand resting on and above his left. He holds a partly open book in his right hand, his index finger marking his page. He has short, curly hair and wears a long robe or gown. Two graves appear side by side below the text panel, to the right of the poet. A stone tomb appears just below and partly hidden by the text panel. The sculpture atop this tomb represents the figure of a helmeted soldier, probably a knight, reposing facing up. His arm is by his side and his head rests on a stone pillow. The humble grave nearer the bottom of the design is a low mound covered with grass and criss-crossed with thorny briars. Both graves extend beyond the right edge of the design. The triangular object lower right may be a tombstone tilted toward the right. The trunk of a large tree grows up the left side of the design. It supports a mass of leaves in the upper left corner of the design. To the left of the poet's head, a limb branches to the right. A longer limb, above, arches over the text box and down towards the right side of the design. Grass covers the ground of the graveyard. Wash on either side of the text box and surrounding the poet suggests the sky, perhaps streaked with clouds.

component.illusobjdesc: The poet Gray walks through the graveyard of the church. He is shown facing forward beneath a tree at the left side of the design. He steps forward with his left foot and turns his head slightly to the right, raising his eyes. His head may be tilted back slightly as well. His arms are by his side and folded over his chest, with his right hand resting on and above his left. He holds a partly open book in his right hand, his index finger marking his page. He has short, curly hair and wears a long robe or gown. His right foot, visible beneath the garment, wears a shoe.

Two graves appear side by side below the text panel, to the right of the poet. A stone tomb appears just below and partly hidden by the text panel. The sculpture atop this tomb represents the figure of a helmeted soldier, probably a knight, reposing facing up. His arm is by his side and his head rests on a stone pillow. The humble grave nearer the bottom of the design is a low mound covered with grass and criss-crossed with thorny briars. Both graves extend beyond the right edge of the design. The triangular object lower right may be a tombstone fallen toward the right.

The trunk of a large tree grows up the left side of the design. It supports a mass of leaves arching below the upper left corner of the design. To the left of the poet's head, a limb branches to the right. A longer limb, above, arches over the text box and down towards the right side of the design. Grass covers the ground of the graveyard.
Wash on either side of the text box and surrounding the poet suggests the sky, perhaps streaked with clouds. The setting is a graveyard.

lg.l: Elegy
1. The author writing
2. Contemplation among Tombs
3. "The Plowman homeward plods his weary wayLines 5-6 are quoted, with minor variations, from page [149] of the letterpress text (Object 107).
And leaves the world to darkness & to me"

4. "For him no more the blazing hearth shall burnLines 7-8 are quoted from page 150 of the letterpress text (Object 108). In line 7, Blake has changed "them" in the letterpress text to "him;" in line 8, he has changed the first word from "No" to "Nor." There are as well minor variations.
Nor children run to lisp their sires return"
5. "Oft did the Harvest to their sickle yield"The line is quoted from page 151 of the letterpress text (Object 109).
6. "Chill penury repressed their noble rage"The line is quoted, with minor variations, from page 152 of the letterpress text (Object 110).
7. "Some Village Hampden that with dauntless breastLines 11-12 are quoted, with minor variations, from page 153 of the letterpress text (Object 111).
The little Tyrant of his Fields withstood"
8. "Many a holy text around she strews"The line is quoted from page 154 of the letterpress text (Object 112).
9. "Some kindred spirit shall enquire thy fateLines 14-16 are quoted, with minor variations, from page 155 of the letterpress text (Object 113).
Haply some hoary headed swain may say
Oft &c"
10. "Slow thro the Churchway path we saw him borne"The line is quoted, with minor variations, from page 156 of the letterpress text (Object 114).
11. A Shepherd reading the Epitaph
12A Spirit conducted to Paradise

desc.objtitle: Elegy Written in a Country Church-Yard; Page 3: Beginning of Poem, Object 107 (Butlin 335.107)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 6 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The personified figure of Darkness hovers at the top of the design. She seems to be about to envelop the scene below. She faces down, her head perhaps tilted partly back so that her face is visible from above. Her body is entirely hidden by her garments, which sweep up to the left. She seems to wear a hood, wimple, and gown. Her eyes may be lowered or closed. The poet Gray stands in the lower right corner of the design, facing away and to the left. He bends his head to look up at the figure of Darkness hovering above. He wears a voluminous robe or gown that hides much of his body. His left arm is by his side and bent up with hand raised and palm out. His left foot is on tiptoe and his left leg may be slightly bent and extended backwards. He may be wearing a shoe on this foot. The other foot is not visible. He has short, curly hair. The right side of his body is in shadow, and he casts a shadow on the ground below him to the right. In the middle distance, a plowman bent over with exhaustion walks to the right, just below the text box. He steps forward with his bent right leg, his bent left leg extended behind him and his left foot on tiptoe. His right arm is down by his side and he holds a strap around a small cask or barrel with his right hand. His body is bent and leaning forward markedly, and his head is lowered but bent back to look forward. He wears a hat over his bedraggled hair, and is dressed in tights and buttoned boots. His eyes are closed or lowered. A tired plowhorse walks on his far side, its head lowered to the ground. The shaggy animal is still wearing a harness. Its eyes are closed or lowered as well. A second horse, drawn less distinctly, walks ahead of the first plowhorse. This animal is partly hidden behind the poet's figure in the foreground. At its head a second figure stands, facing away and slightly to the right. This figure, probably male, may have short curly hair. Similarly, he may wear a shirt and pants with a belt. His left leg is bent forward slightly and his left arm is by his side, bent. His right arm is down but bent up at the elbow, and he holds a large bow, staff, or other implement with this hand. The men and horses walk at the edge of a plowed field that stretches from the right edge of the design nearly across to the left edge. An abandoned plow rests in the plowed earth at the left side of the field. The poet stands on a dirt path or road that winds up from the bottom edge of the design past the field towards the church in the distance. A stone mile marker sits in the field at the edge of the path, below the plow and to the left of the poet. It appears to be inscribed, rather crudely, "22" (see the Textual Transcription). The ground slopes gently upward from left to right across the design, suggesting a small hill or rise. A large church with a steeple rises in the background, to the left of the text box. The "Curfew" may toll from this church's bell (see the letterpress text). The ground on either side of the field and path is covered with grass. Trees or a hedge hides the lower part of the church in the distance. Wash between the horizon and the figure of Darkness at the top of the design suggests the sky. Appropriately, the sky above Darkness is darker than the sky below, as if she does indeed trail the darkness of night after her descending form.

component.illusobjdesc: The personified figure of Darkness hovers at the top of the design. She seems to be about to envelop the scene below. She faces down, her head perhaps tilted partly back so that her face is visible from above. Her body is entirely hidden by her garments, which sweep up to the left. She seems to wear a hood, wimple, and gown. Her eyes may be lowered or closed.

The poet Gray stands in the lower right corner of the design, facing away and to the left. He bends his head back to look up at the figure of Darkness hovering above. He wears a voluminous robe or gown that hides much of his body. His left arm is by his side and bent up with hand raised and palm out, fingers slightly spread. His left foot is on tiptoe and his left leg may be slightly bent and extended backwards. He may be wearing a shoe on this foot. The other foot is not visible. He has short, curly hair. The right side of his body is in shadow, and he casts a shadow on the ground below him to the right.

In the middle distance, a plowman bent with exhaustion walks to the right past the poet, just below the text box. He steps forward with his bent right leg, his bent left leg extended behind him and his left foot on tiptoe. His right arm is down by his side and he holds a strap around a small cask or barrel with his right hand. His body is bent and leaning forward markedly, and his head is lowered but bent back to look forward. He wears a hat over his bedraggled hair, and is dressed in tights and buttoned boots. His eyes are closed or lowered. A tired plowhorse walks on his far side, its head lowered to the ground. The shaggy animal is still wearing a harness. Its eyes are closed or lowered as well. A second horse, drawn less distinctly, walks ahead of the first plowhorse. This animal is partly hidden behind the poet's figure in the foreground. At its head a second figure stands, facing away and slightly to the right. This figure, probably male, may have short curly hair. Similarly, he may wear a shirt and pants with a belt. His left leg is bent forward slightly and his left arm is by its side, bent. His right arm is down but bent up at the elbow, and he holds a large bow, staff, or other implement with this hand.

The farmers and horses walk at the edge of a plowed field that stretches from the right edge of the design nearly across to the left edge. An abandoned plow rests in the plowed earth at the left side of the field. The poet stands on a dirt path or road that winds up from the bottom edge of the design past the field towards the church in the distance. A stone mile marker sits in the field at the edge of the path, below the plow and to the left of the poet. It seems to be inscribed, rather crudely, "22" (see the Textual Transcription). The ground slopes gently upward from left to right across the design, suggesting a small hill or rise.

A large church with a steeple rises in the background, to the left of the text box. The architecture is basically Gothic. The arched form below the spire may be a window or door with a window above. The "Curfew" may toll from this church's bell (see the letterpress text).
The ground on either side of the field and path is covered with grass. Trees or a hedge hides the lower part of the church in the distance.

Wash between the horizon and the figure of Darkness at the top of the design suggests the sky. Appropriately, the sky above Darkness is darker than the sky below, as if she does indeed trail the darkness of night after her descending form.

lg.l: 22This number is somewhat crudely inscribed on the mile marker in the lower part of the design.

desc.objtitle: Elegy Written in a Country Church-Yard: Page 4, Object 108 (Butlin 335.108)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 16 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A widow, dressed in black, makes a striking image standing at the left side of the design with her three children. She faces right and bows her head deeply; her arms are by her side, bent across her chest with hands raised and clasped beneath her head as if she is praying. She wears a black cloak or robe that envelops her form entirely. Even her face is hidden by its hood. Her three children are also all dressed in black cloaks or robes with hoods. The little family grouping stands beside a newly dug grave, which yawns across the bottom of the design. Shadow fills its open mouth. A clergyman stands on the far side of the grave, at the right side of the design. He faces forward and slightly left, with eyes raised and mouth open, perhaps leading the grieving family through the burial service. Both arms are down. His lower right arm is bent up across his body, and his right hand rests palm down on his chest. His lower left arm is bent forward and he holds a book, perhaps a Bible, with this hand. His thumb marks his place in the open book, which faces out. He wears a neck scarf and a clerical gown or robe over shoes. He has short curly hair. The sexton or grave digger stands between the clergyman and the grieving family, and is mostly hidden behind the text box. He faces forward. His bent right arm and hand, which grasps the handle of a shovel, appears to the left of the text panel. His left hand is visible below the text box, holding the shaft of the shovel, which is poised with a load of dirt over the open grave. His legs are also visible below the text box; his right leg is bent slightly forward and his right foot rests on the ball and toes in a near-tiptoe position. From his visible limbs it appears the sexton wears a long coat over a shirt, breeches, and stockings. His shoes have buckles. A pile of earth lies, ready to be shoveled back into the grave, at the left of his feet. A stone wall appears in the middle distance, behind the family and the churchmen. It runs from the left edge of the design nearly all the way across the design, ending just to the right of the clergyman. This may be the side of a tomb. The odd shape just left of the grave digger's right knee may be something, such as an angel's wing, decorating the tomb. The ground on which the family and the churchmen stand is mostly bare earth, but some grass grows around the feet of the clergyman at the right side of the design. The trunk of a tree grows up the right side of the design, sending a leafy branch leftward from the top right corner. The leafy canopies of two more trees appear in the background, to the left of the text panel. The tree in the middle, next to the panel, also has visible branches. Wash in the background suggests the sky, perhaps with clouds. The color of the wash between the clergyman and the tree branch above hints that the time may be sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: A widow, dressed in black, makes a striking image standing at the left side of the design with her three children. She faces right and bows her head deeply; her arms are by her side, bent across her chest with hands raised and clasped beneath her head as if she is praying. She wears a black cloak or robe that envelops her form entirely. Even her face is hidden by its hood. Her three children are also all dressed in black cloaks or robes with hoods. The leftmost child stands in front of her mother; she is foremost of the group and nearest the left edge of the design. This child faces right and bows her head slightly. Her eyes are lowered and her mouth is open slightly. The shape of her cloak suggests that one or both arms may be bent and folded or crossed over her chest. Long hair escapes from the edges of her hood. The second child stands to the right of the mother and lowers his or her head more deeply, facing forward and to the right. Beneath the gown he or she wears, this child raises one or both hands to his or her face, hiding it below the eyes. He or she may be crying. The rightmost child faces forward with head slightly bowed and eyes lowered or closed. Long hair visible at the edges of her hood suggests that her gender is female. Her mouth is open as if she is also praying. She may have folded hands raised beneath her gown.
The little family grouping stands beside a newly dug grave, which yawns across the bottom of the design. Shadow fills its open mouth.

A clergyman stands on the far side of the grave, at the right side of the design. He faces forward and slightly left, with eyes raised and mouth open, perhaps leading the grieving family through the burial service. Both arms are down. His lower right arm is bent up across his body, and his right hand rests palm down on his chest. His lower left arm is bent forward and he holds a book, perhaps a Bible, with this hand. His thumb marks his place in the open book, which faces out. He wears a neck scarf and a clerical gown or robe over shoes. He has short curly hair.
