His bent right arm and hand, which grasps the shaft of a shovel, appears to the left of the text panel. His left hand is visible below the text box, holding the shovel, which is poised with a load of dirt over the open grave. His legs are also visible below the text box; his right leg is bent slightly forward and his right foot rests on the ball and toes in a near-tiptoe position. From his visible limbs it appears the sexton wears a long coat over a shirt, breeches, and stockings. His shoes have buckles. A pile of earth lies, ready to be shoveled back into the grave, at the left of his feet.

A low stone wall appears in the middle distance, behind the family and the churchmen. It runs from the left edge of the design nearly all the way across the design, ending just to the right of the clergyman. This may be the side of a tomb. The odd shape just left of the grave digger's right knee may be something, such as an angel's wing, decorating the tomb.

The ground on which the family and the churchmen stand is mostly bare earth, but some grass grows around the feet of the clergyman at the right side of the design. The trunk of a tree grows up the right side of the design, sending a leafy branch leftward from the top right corner. The leafy canopies of two more trees appear in the background, to the left of the text panel. The tree in the middle, next to the panel, also has visible branches.
Wash in the background suggests the sky, perhaps with clouds. The color of the wash between the clergyman and the tree branch above hints that the time may be sunrise or sunset.

desc.objtitle: Elegy Written in a Country Church-Yard: Page 5, Object 109 (Butlin 335.109)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 2 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A farmer crouches near the bottom of the design, facing right and poised to reap a handful of grain stems. He bends low over his bent right leg. His left leg is down and bent backward, with his left foot on tiptoe. His left arm is extended out horizontally and bent down; he grasps a handful of grain stems with his large left hand. His bent right arm is down and drawn back slightly, and he holds the handle of a sickle with this hand. He wears a shirt, breeches knotted with ribbon at the knee, stockings, and shoes. His clothing cannot hide his well- developed musculature, which is particularly visible in his strong right arm. He has short, curly hair. He bends his head back and lowers his eyes to look at the wheat. He may wear gloves, particularly on his right hand. A girl stands or walks at the left edge of the design, facing right. Her right arm is down by her side and she holds the strap of a small cask or barrel in this hand. Her right leg is bent and her right foot is on tiptoe. She has long hair drawn back behind her head, and is dressed in a gown that slips over her right shoulder. Beneath its hem her stockings and shoes are visible. The hat on her head is tied with a ribbon below her chin. Her long hair is drawn back behind her head. Her head and eyes are lowered slightly, and she seems to be watching the man work. A line of grain stems crosses the bottom of the design, behind both figures. Stubble at the field's edge indicates where the man has begun to harvest it. He stands on bare earth at the edge of the field. Wash above the wheat represents a partly cloudy sky.

component.illusobjdesc: A farmer crouches near the bottom of design, facing right and poised to reap a handful of wheat. He bends low over his bent right leg. His left leg is down and bent backward, with his left foot on tiptoe. His left arm is extended out horizontally and bent down; he grasps a handful of wheat with his large left hand. His bent right arm is down and drawn back slightly, and he holds the handle of a sickle with this hand. He wears a shirt, breeches knotted with ribbon at the knee, stockings, and shoes. His clothing cannot hide his well developed musculature, which is particularly visible in his strong right arm. He has short, curly hair. He bends his head back and lowers his eyes to look at the wheat. He may wear gloves, particularly on his right hand. He casts a shadow on the ground beneath him and to the left.

A girl stands or walks at the left edge of the design, facing right. Her right arm is down by her side and she holds the strap of a small cask or barrel in this hand. Her right leg is bent and her right foot is on tiptoe. She has long hair drawn back behind her head, and is dressed in a gown that slips over her right shoulder. Beneath its hem her stockings and shoes are visible. The hat on her head is tied with a ribbon below her chin. Her long hair is drawn back behind her head. Her head and eyes are lowered slightly, and she seems to be watching the man work. Her small shadow appears on the ground between her feet.

A line of grain stems with tassels crosses the bottom of the design, behind both figures. Stubble at the field's edge indicates where the man has begun to harvest it. He stands on bare earth at the edge of the field.
Wash above the wheat represents a partly cloudy sky.

desc.objtitle: Elegy Written in a Country Church-Yard: Page 6, Object 110 (Butlin 335.110)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 12 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A man, perhaps a farmer, digs with a shovel in the lower left corner of the design. His body faces forward and to the right. He rests his weight on his slightly bent right leg; his left leg is bent and drawn up and his left foot rests on a shovel, helping to drive it into the ground. He bends forward at the waist with the effort, twisting his torso forward and leaning into the work. His right arm is bent and drawn back and he holds the handle of the shovel with this hand. His left arm, slightly bent, is down. He grasps the shaft of the implement with this hand. His left elbow may be braced against the inside of his left thigh. His head is bent and he looks down at his work. He is dressed in a shirt, breeches, stockings, and shoes. His muscular frame shows clearly through the clothes, particularly in his arms, and above the open neckline of his shirt. He has short curly hair beneath a hat. His shadow falls on the ground below him and to the left of his feet. A boy beneath the text panel walks to the left. He faces away and to the left, so is seen partly from behind. His weight rests on his right foot; his slightly bent left leg is extended behind him with his left foot on tiptoe. His left arm, at his side, is bent at the elbow. His head is bent slightly. He wears a shirt and breeches, or perhaps tights with a belt, with stockings and shoes. His shirt has a wide collar. His short, curly hair is unruly beneath his hat. He walks along the edge of grass, perhaps in the middle of a path although the coloring hints at water. Two windswept trees grow in the middle distance, near the right edge of the design. Their branches are partly bare and partly covered with leaves. The path on which the boy walks includes a patch of grass, which also grows on the smaller hill or hills behind the trees. Larger hills or mountains appear in the distance, on the horizon. Wash to the right of the text box indicates the sky. A dark cloud fills the upper left corner of the design. Streaks descending diagonally rightward from this cloud suggest rain blown to the right by wind. The left edge of the design is dark with shadow or perhaps more rain.

component.illusobjdesc: A man, perhaps a farmer, digs with a shovel in the lower left corner of the design. His body faces forward and to the right. He rests his weight on his slightly bent right leg; his left leg is bent and drawn up and his left foot rests on a shovel, helping to drive it into the ground. He bends forward at the waist with the effort, twisting his torso forward and leaning into the work. His right arm is bent and drawn back and he holds the handle of the shovel with this hand. His left arm, slightly bent, is down. He grasps the shaft of the implement with this hand. His left elbow may be braced against the inside of his left thigh. His head is bent and he looks down at his work. He is dressed in a shirt, breeches, stockings, and shoes. His muscular frame shows clearly through the clothes, particularly in his arms, and above the open neckline of his shirt. He has short curly hair beneath a hat. His shadow falls on the ground below him and to the left of his feet.

A boy beneath the text panel walks to the left. He faces away and to the left, so is seen partly from behind. His weight rests on his right foot; his slightly bent left leg is extended behind him with his left foot on tiptoe. His left arm, at his side, is bent at the elbow. His head is bent slightly. He wears a shirt and breeches, or perhaps tights with a belt, with stockings and shoes. His shirt has a wide collar. His short, curly hair is unruly beneath his hat.
The boy walks along the edge of a patch of grass dividing a path, although the coloring hints at water.

Two windswept trees grow in the middle distance, near the right edge of the design. Their branches are partly bare and partly covered with leaves. The boy walks near a patch of grass, which also grows on the hill behind the trees.

The man in the foreground digs into what seems to be bare earth. Hills or mountains appear in the distance, on the horizon. A smaller hill, or perhaps two, rise between the distant hills and the trees at the right side of the design.

Wash to the right of the text box indicates the sky. A dark cloud fills the upper left corner of the design. Streaks descending diagonally rightward from this cloud suggest rain swept to the right by wind. The limbs of the trees on the right also indicate wind. The left edge of the design is dark with shadow or perhaps more rain.

desc.objtitle: Elegy Written in a Country Church-Yard: Page 7, Object 111 (Butlin 335.111)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 2 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In this design a farmer boldly turns away a visiting bailiff who appears in the lower left corner of the design, walking forward and to the left but turning to look at the farmer at the right. The bailiff's left leg is forward and his right is extended backwards, with his right foot on tiptoe. He twists at the waist so that his torso faces forward, and turns his head further to the right to look behind him with a cross expression. Both arms are down by his side and bent forward. He holds a legal document in his left hand; its official seal hangs from the edge of the paper. Indecipherable text appears on the document. He wears a hat and a robe with fur trim over an ascot or similar necktie. The sturdy farmer stands at the right side of the design, facing forward and to the left. He turns his head towards the bailiff so that his face is seen in three-quarters profile. His right arm is slightly bent and down by his side and he holds the handle of a shovel with this hand. The shovel stands upright next to his right leg, which is bent slightly forward; the shovel's head rests on the ground next to his right foot. The farmer raises his bent left arm vertically overhead, pointing upward with his raised left index finger. He has short curly hair and wears shoes, stockings, breeches, and a shirt, or perhaps tights. A string or ribbon ties the front of his shirt closed. He may also wear a belt. The farmer's snug dwelling appears in the background, partially extending beyond the right edge of the design. The small cottage has a window, a door, a thatched roof, and smoke rising from the chimney. A path curves away from its door over the gentle, grass-covered hill on which it sits. Two large trees stand atop this hill, their trunks side-by-side below the text panel. Branches appear above the text panel, and above the branches appear the leafy canopies of the trees, which are difficult to distinguish from one another. A smaller leafy tree with one visible branch grows to the left of the cottage. A craggy mountain, or mountains, rise in the distance between the large trees and the cottage. Wash in the background suggests the sky, perhaps with clouds.

component.illusobjdesc: The bailiff appears in the lower left corner of the design, walking forward and to the left, but turning to look at the farmer at the right. His left leg is forward and his right is extended backwards, with his right foot on tiptoe. He twists at the waist so that his torso faces forward, and turns his head further to the right to look behind him with a cross expression. Both arms are down by his side and bent forward. He holds a legal document in his left hand; its official seal hangs from the edge of the paper. Indecipherable text appears on the document. He wears a robe with fur trim over an ascot or similar necktie. He has short hair beneath his hat. He wears shoes on his feet. His shadow falls on the ground below and to the left of his feet.

The sturdy farmer stands at the right side of the design, facing forward and to the left. He turns his head towards the bailiff so that his face is seen in three-quarters profile. His right arm is slightly bent and down by his side and he holds the handle of a shovel with this hand. The shovel stands upright next to his right leg, which is bent slightly forward; the shovel's head rests on the ground next to his right foot. The farmer raises his bent left arm vertically overhead, pointing upward with his raised left index finger. He has short curly hair and wears shoes, stockings, breeches, and a shirt, or perhaps tights. A string or ribbon ties the front of his shirt closed. He may also wear a belt. He casts a shadow on the ground beneath him.

The farmer's snug dwelling appears in the background, partially extending beyond the right edge of the design. The small cottage has a window, a door, a thatched roof, and smoke rising from the chimney. A path curves away from its door over the gentle hill on which it sits.

The two men stand on a gentle hill that slopes up to the right towards the cottage in the distance. It is covered with grass. Two large trees stand atop this hill, their trunks side-by-side below the text panel. Branches appear above the text panel, and above the branches appear the leafy canopies of the trees, which are difficult to distinguish from one another. A smaller leafy tree with one visible branch grows to the left of the cottage.
A craggy mountain, or mountains, rise in the distance between the large trees and the cottage.
Wash in the background suggests the sky, perhaps with clouds.

desc.objtitle: Elegy Written in a Country Church-Yard: Page 8, Object 112 (Butlin 335.112)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 10 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The "unletter'd Muse" (see the letterpress text) stands or walks on a dirt path near the left side of the design, facing right towards several tombstones. She stands with her weight on her right foot; her left leg is extended backwards slightly and her left foot is on tiptoe. This leg may also be slightly bent. Her torso twists away from the viewer, so that she is also partly seen from behind. Her slightly bent left arm is down and drawn back, and she holds a small lyre in her left hand, just visible to the left of her body. She bends her head down to look at the tombstone nearest her, and holds her slightly bent right arm out at about 45 degrees before her. With her right index finger she points to, and perhaps touches and traces, the first letter of the inscription engraved on the stone (see the Textual Transcription). Her extended finger casts a small shadow on the tombstone. Her long, curly hair is drawn back into a bun or similar coiffure from which long locks escape and hang down her back. She wears a long gown with a wide collar visible over her right shoulder. Another tombstone, with no visible text, tilts to the right at a sharp angle. It casts a shadow on the rightmost structure, a stone monument or tomb that extends beyond the right edge of the design. The muse stands on a dirt path that runs from the bottom of the design up over the near horizon. Grass grows on either side of the path, as well as around and between the gravestones. Wash above the horizon, around the muse, and around the text box suggests the sky, perhaps with clouds.

component.illusobjdesc: The "unletter'd Muse" (see the letterpress text) stands or walks on a dirt path near the left side of the design, facing right towards several tombstones. She stands with her weight on her right foot; her left leg is extended backwards slightly and her left foot is on tiptoe. This leg may also be slightly bent. Her torso twists away from the viewer, so that she is also partly seen from behind. Her slightly bent left arm is down and drawn back, and she holds a small lyre in her left hand, just visible to the left of her body. She bends her head down to look at the tombstone nearest her, and holds her slightly bent right arm out at about 45 degrees before her. With her right index finger she points to, and perhaps touches or traces, the first letter of the inscription engraved on the stone (see the Textual Transcription). Her extended finger casts a small shadow on the tombstone. Her long, curly hair is drawn back into a bun or similar coiffure from which long locks escape and hang down her back. She wears a long gown with a wide collar visible over her right shoulder.

Three grave markers appear at the bottom of the design. The leftmost marker, a tombstone, bears an inscribed text (see the Textual Transcription). The tombstone next to left, with no visible text, tilts to the right at a sharp angle. It casts a shadow on the rightmost marker, a stone monument or tomb that extends beyond the right edge of the design. The setting is clearly a graveyard.
The muse stands on a dirt path that runs from the bottom of the design up over the near horizon.
Grass grows on either side of the path, as well as around and between the gravestones.
Wash above the horizon, around the muse, and around the text box suggests the sky, perhaps with clouds.

lg.l: DUST THOU ARTLines 2-5 are written, rather crudely, on one of the two tombstones pictured below the text panel. The figure holding a lyre in her left hand points to line 2 with the extended index finger of her right hand.
HERELIETHThe two words are written over two partly-erased words. The first partly-erased word is probably "HERE"; the second word may be "LIES."

WmBl keThe second word is very probably meant to be "Blake," although the third letter is not indicated and the final letter is only suggested by a small mark. Lines around most letters suggest different positions for them, or even a different inscription, the second word ending in the letter "S."

Aged10The last two letters of the first word are conjectural. A cluster of dots after "10" suggests more numerals. The number may be "100" with the final numeral barely indicated. The oddly shaped light lines left of the number may be a "y" (for "year"?) or simply a decorative element.

desc.objtitle: Elegy Written in a Country Church-Yard: Page 9, Object 113 (Butlin 335.113)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 10 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This design shows the poet Thomas Gray in the graveyard of the church. Gray stands at the left side of the design, facing right but turning his head slightly forward. His right leg is bent backwards and his right foot is on tiptoe. His bent right arm is down by his side, and he holds a book in this hand. His finger holds his place between its open pages. He wears shoes and a long robe or gown with a wide collar, and he has short curly hair. His eyes are lowered slightly. The older man, who represents "some hoary-headed swain" (see the letterpress text), stands at the right side of the design and faces left, towards Gray. He leans on a cane or walking stick, which he holds in his left hand; his left arm is straight down by his side. His slightly bent right arm is raised at 45 degrees in front of him, and he points towards a humble grave between the men with his right index finger. His head and eyes are slightly lowered, and his mouth is slightly open; he tells stories to the poet Gray about the man in the grave nearby. He has long white hair beneath a wide-brimmed hat, and wears a long, wide-collared coat that reaches to his ankles. His shoes and stockings are visible beneath the hem of the coat. The nearest (and lowest) grave visible between Gray and the old man is a grassy mound crisscrossed with briars. Above it appears a grander stone tomb monument. A mountain or large hill rises from lower left to upper right corner of the design, in the background. Several rocky ledges suggest cliffs in the upper right corner especially. A stream may run along the ledge second from top. The graveyard and part of the mountain beyond is covered with grass. A tree grows from the highest visible point of the mountain, its trunk curving to the left. Branches that split off from the trunk bear clumps of leaves. Grass covers the ground below it. Nearer, just beyond the graves, a tree grows past the right side of the text box, its trunk splitting into thin bare branches near the upper right corner of the box and its leafy canopy spreading just above the box. A second, smaller tree grows just to the left, its leaves partly hidden behind the text box. Indeterminate leafy vegetation fills the middle distance at the right side of the design. Wash around the trees and the figure of the poet suggests the sky streaked with thin clouds, and perhaps at sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: The poet Thomas Gray is in the graveyard of the church. He stands at the left side of the design, facing right but turning his head slightly forward. He is listening to the stories of an older man nearby. His right leg is bent backwards and his right foot is on tiptoe. His bent right arm is down by his side, and he holds a book in this hand. His finger holds his place between its open pages. He wears shoes and a long robe or gown with a wide collar, and he has short curly hair. His eyes are lowered slightly.

The older man, who represents "some hoary-headed swain" (see the letterpress text), stands at the right side of the design and faces left, towards Gray. He leans on a cane or walking stick, which he holds in his left hand; his left arm is straight down by his side. His slightly bent right arm is raised at 45 degrees in front of him, and he points towards a humble grave between the men with his right index finger. His head and eyes are slightly lowered, and his mouth is slightly open; he is telling the poet Gray about the man buried in the grave nearby. He has long white hair beneath a wide-brimmed hat, and wears a long, wide-collared coat that reaches to his ankles. His shoes and stockings are visible beneath the hem of the coat. An ascot and perhaps a shirt show between the lapels of his coat; the cuff of his shirt is visible beneath the left cuff of his coat.

The nearest (and lower) grave visible between Gray and the old man is a grassy mound crisscrossed with vines. Slight indications of thorns appear on the vines on the left. Above it appears a grander stone tomb monument.

A mountain or large hill rises from lower left to upper right corner of the design, in the background. Several rocky ledges suggest cliffs in the upper right corner especially. A stream may run along the ledge second from the top.

The graveyard and part of the mountain beyond is covered with grass. A tree grows from the highest visible point of the mountain, its trunk curving to the left. Branches that split off from the trunk bear clumps of leaves. Grass covers the ground below it. Nearer, just beyond the graves, a tree grows past the right side of the text box, its trunk splitting into thin bare branches near the upper right corner of the box and its leafy canopy spreading just above the box. A second, smaller tree grows just to the left, its leaves partly hidden behind the text box. Indeterminate leafy vegetation fills the middle distance at the right side of the design.
Wash around the trees and the figure of the poet suggests the sky streaked with thin clouds, and perhaps at sunrise or sunset. The setting is of course a graveyard.

desc.objtitle: Elegy Written in a Country Church-Yard: Page 10, Object 114 (Butlin 335.114)

objnote.p: Blake has inscribed in pencil a cross to the left of line 11 of the letterpress text to indicate the line or passage illustrated.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Three village women sit in the foreground under the branches of a large tree. The woman on the left faces forward and slightly left. She turns her head slightly to the right as if to speak to her neighbor. Her right arm is extended and raised at 135 degrees, and she points with her right index finger. Her bent left arm lies down across her lap. With this arm she supports a nude infant who seems to suckle at her left breast. This child, who may be male or female, twists its torso to face away and raises both bent arms past its head. It reclines into the crook of its mothers arm, its lower body facing up with its left leg bent back and drawn up, and its slightly bent right leg extended along the mother's open hand. The woman is dressed in a long gown and wears a scarf over her long, loose curls. The neckline of her gown is drawn down to allow her infant to nurse, partially exposing her left breast. An older child, perhaps a boy, stands at her right knee. This boy faces right and slightly forward. His right arm is by his side but bent up. He has short curly hair and seems to wear a gown. The woman in the middle sits facing right, though she tilts her head and turns it slightly to the left. A young child stands on her lap. This child, a girl, faces right and raises her slightly bent right arm in front of her at 135 degrees. The girl holds a ball in this hand and seems to offer it to the rightmost woman. The child wears a long gown and has long hair. Her mother holds both bent arms in front of her, clasping her daughter loosely around the waist and legs with both hands. The mother wears a long gown and has long, curly hair that seems to be drawn back to the nape of her neck. The rightmost woman is only partially visible at the edge of the design. She faces forward but turns her head to look left. Her right arm is by her side and bent up across her chest, palm raised and facing right. Like her neighbors, she wears a long gown and has long curly hair. A fourth child stands at the knees of the rightmost woman and the woman in the middle. This girl faces left and slightly away, so that she is seen partly from behind. Her left arm is down but bent so that her lower left arm is hidden. Her hair is long, and she wears a long gown. The women and children sit underneath a tall tree. Its trunk grows up past the right side of the design. A large limb splits off to the left near the top right corner of the design and arches over the text panel, bearing leaves at its tips. Other, leafier limbs fill the spaces above and to the right of this arching limb. The ground on which the women sit is covered with grass. A hedge or line of bushes or smaller trees crosses the design in the middle distance from the left edge to the tree trunk. The ground behind rises as it nears the horizon, and slopes gently upward from left to right. A grassy plateau appears in the distance, just below and to the left of the text panel. At least four leafy trees appear in the mid-distance, near the edge of the design. Two mountain peaks rise on the horizon. A path or road appears at the base of the plateau in the middle distance. A solemn funeral procession moves up the path to the right, the figures dressed in dark clothing. Four pallbearers support a large coffin, draped with cloth, at the edge of the procession. Behind them, three couples walk in pairs, the women in long gowns. Then an adult follows with two children, one on either side. Finally, an adult brings up the end of the small parade. The spire of a church, presumably the destination of the funeral procession, is visible between the right side of the text panel and the tree trunk. A smaller building, or group of buildings, is situated on the top of the plateau. Blue wash on either side of the tree trunk suggests the sky. The upper right side of the trunk is in shadow; shadows also fill the spaces between the seated women.

The spire of a church, presumably the destination of the funeral procession, is visible between the right side of the text panel and the tree trunk.

desc.objtitle: Elegy Written in a Country Church-Yard; Page 11: The Epitaph, Object 115 (Butlin 335.115)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A large stone tomb monument stands on the ground below the text panel. The ground beneath the tomb is covered with grass. The trunks of at least two trees rise beyond the tombstone, at the left of the text panel. Each trunk splits into multiple branches, which bear leaves above and to the left of the panel. A "Shepherd" (see Blake's text, Object 106) stands on the tomb at the right side of the design. He faces left and bows his head slightly. His left arm is by his side, but bent up at the elbow to cross his chest; his left hand is not visible. His staff rests on the ground, its crook in the crook of the shepherd's arm. He wears a hat over his short, slightly curly hair, and a long gown or robe that parts to reveal his bare left foot. Wash surrounding the shepherd and text panel suggests the sky, perhaps with clouds.

component.illusobjdesc: A large stone tomb monument stands on the ground below the text panel.

The ground beneath the tomb is covered with grass. The trunks of at least two trees rise beyond the tombstone, at the left of the text panel. Each trunk splits into multiple branches, which bear leaves above and to the left of the panel.

A "Shepherd" (see Blake's text, Object 106) stands on the tomb at the right side of the design. He faces left and bows his head slightly. His left arm is by his side, but bent up at the elbow to cross his chest; his left hand is not visible. His staff rests on the ground, its crook in the crook of the shepherd's arm. He wear a hat over his short, slightly curly hair, and a long gown or robe that parts to reveal his bare left foot.
Wash surrounding the shepherd and text panel suggests the sky, perhaps with clouds. The setting is of course a graveyard.

desc.objtitle: Elegy Written in a Country Church-Yard; Page 12: Blank Page Bearing Blake's Poem to Mrs. Flaxman, Object 116 (Butlin 335.116)

illustration.illusobjdesc: This design depicts two spirits (see Blake's text, Object 106). The higher one appears to guide the lower as they ascend through the sky. One of the spirits flies or hovers to the left of the text panel, facing forward and slightly to the right. His legs extend together slightly to the right; he also bends and twists his upper body slightly to the right and lowers his head. Overall his body forms a gentle rightward curve. His left leg is bent forward slightly. One or both feet may be in tiptoe position. He extends his right arm vertically overhead and points with the index finger of his raised right hand. He reaches his left arm down at an angle a bit below 45 degrees with his palm facing out towards the spirit below. He has short curly hair, and wears a transparent gown that drapes his figure gracefully and trails between his feet. He seems to be looking down at the spirit beneath the text panel. The spirit below the text panel flies or hovers with body roughly horizontal, though curved up slightly at the waist. He faces forward but turns his head to look up to the left, so that his face is seen in three-quarters profile. His head is bent back and his eyes are raised to look at the spirit above. Both arms are at his side, but bent forward at the elbow; both hands are raised with vertical palms facing out. His right leg is extended but his left seems to be bent, or is otherwise hidden behind his right. His right foot is in tiptoe position. He has short curly hair and wears a diaphanous, semi-transparent gown. The spirit on the left may be an angel; the spirit below may be a personification of the soul of a dead person. Wash throughout the rest of the design, surrounding the two figures, suggests the sky with clouds.

component.illusobjdesc: One of the spirits flies or hovers to the left of the text panel, facing forward and slightly to the right. His legs extend together slightly to the right; he also bends and twists his upper body slightly to the right and lowers his head. Overall his body forms a gentle rightward curve. His left leg is bent forward slightly. One or both feet may be in tiptoe position. He extends his right arm vertically overhead and points with the index finger of his raised right hand. He reaches his left arm down at an angle a bit below 45 degrees with his palm facing out towards the spirit below. He has short curly hair, and wears a transparent gown that drapes his figure gracefully and trails between his feet. He seems to be looking down at the spirit beneath the text panel. This upper spirit may be an angel guiding the soul of a dead person to heaven (see Blake's text, Object 106).

The spirit below the text panel flies or hovers with body roughly horizontal, though curved up slightly at the waist. He faces forward but turns his head to look up to the left, so that his face is seen in three-quarters profile. His head is bent back and his eyes are raised to look at the spirit above. Both arms are at his side, but bent forward at the elbow; both hands are raised with vertical palms facing out. His right leg is extended but his left seems to be bent, or is otherwise hidden behind his right. His right foot is in tiptoe position. He has short curly hair and wears a diaphanous, semi-transparent gown. This lower spirit may be a personification of the soul of a dead person being guided to heaven (see Blake's text, Object 106).
Wash throughout the rest of the design, surrounding the two figures, suggests the sky with clouds.

lg.l: To M.rs. Ann Flaxman
A little Flower grew in a lonely Vale
Its form was lovely but its colours pale
One standing in the Porches of the Sun
When his Meridian Glories were begun
Leapd from the steps of fire & on the grass
Alighted where this little flower was
With hands divine he movd the gentle Sod
And took the Flower up in its native Clod
Then planting it upon a Mountains brow
'Tis your own fault if you dont flourish now
